HEADLINE: 6.9% Rise in Home Starts Despite Rate Increases

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The most interest-sensitive part of the American economy -- the housing market -- seems almost impervious to this year's sharp rise in the cost of mortgages.
Confounding forecasters, builders stepped up groundbreaking on new homes by 6.9 percent in November to an annual pace of 1.54 million, the Commerce Department reported today. This was the biggest advance since March and the most rapid rate for residential construction in nearly a year. 
 "The housing sector is just not showing signs of slowing," said David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. "I think you've got some raised eyebrows at the Federal Reserve."
Despite today's figures, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates at its policy meeting on Tuesday, waiting instead to act until the next scheduled meeting, a two-day session starting Jan. 31, economists said. The Fed, the nation's central bank, has been trying since February to slow the pace of economic growth and keep inflation from accelerating by raising short-term interest rates six times. Most economists expect further rate increases.
The bond market took today's news in stride, apparently interpreting the strong housing starts figures as having been significantly swollen by exceptionally mild weather last month. And analysts noted that the report showed a decline in permits issued for future construction, which suggested a possible slowdown ahead. Bond prices rose today, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, on the 30-year Treasury bond falling to 7.85 percent.
The gains were highly concentrated in the Northeast and Midwest, where prolonged good weather has the biggest impact.
Still, analysts were impressed by housing's strong performance in the face of a jump in conventional mortgage rates to above 9 percent, more than two percentage points higher than at the beginning of the year. Starts for the second and third quarters were both higher than in the preceding quarters, and the first two months of the fourth quarter showed yet another advance.
But while the total number of units seems little affected, analysts say higher interest rates have caused a change in their composition. People who can no longer afford to buy homes are generating fresh demand for apartments and other multi-unit dwellings, on which construction soared 19.9 percent last month. Mr. Lereah estimates that this year's rate rises have priced about 240,000 first-time buyers out of the market.
Another factor, said Edward Guay, chief economist for Cigna Investment Management in Hartford, was a scramble to finish developments on which work had been suspended and then resumed last year when interest rates dropped sharply. The idea is to complete these projects, which involve heavy preliminary investment, in time for the spring buying season.
Starts of single-family homes climbed 3.7 percent, to a pace of 1,196,000 in November, today's report also showed. This was 4.2 percent less than in November 1993.
"Single-family starts remain in a flat trend," said Edward E. Yardeni, an economist with C. J. Lawrence/ Deutsche Bank Securities in New York, adding that the latest survey of builders' estimates of the number of potential home buyers points to weakness in coming months. About 51 percent of members of the National Association of Home Builders reported "low to very low" customer traffic this month, compared with about 21 percent in April. Members reporting "high to very high" traffic plunged to 9.4 percent, the lowest reading in four years.
Some analysts found another harbinger of a slowdown in November's 1 percent decline in permits issued for future construction, which eased to an annual pace of 1,384,000 -- up about 6 percent in the Northeast, down that amount in the West and unchanged in the Midwest and South.
For starts, the Northeast posted the biggest gain, 26.8 percent, though its pace of 161,000 units is less than half that of any other region. The Midwest had a 25 percent November spurt while the South was ahead 1.9 percent and the West was 6.4 percent lower.
Last month's advance, which was the biggest since a 14.4 percent jump in March, followed a 4.6 percent October decline that had been the first setback in four months. Starts for both September and October were revised modestly higher today.

HEADLINE: $76 Million to Settle Treasury Note Charges

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Two prominent private investment firms agreed yesterday to pay $76 million to settle charges that they had cornered the market in an issue of two-year Treasury notes in 1991, making millions for their investors in the process.
Steinhardt Management Inc. agreed to pay $40 million and the Caxton Corporation, $36 million, to settle antitrust and securities-law violations in an agreement with the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Neither firm admitted wrongdoing, but both agreed to hire independent consultants to monitor their compliance with the rules governing the trade of Treasury securities. In addition, for the next 10 years they must provide the S.E.C. with information about their positions in Treasury securities on demand. 
 "This case stands for the proposition that parties cannot engage in fraud and manipulation in the market for U.S. Treasury securities," William McLucas, director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, said in Washington yesterday.
According to the terms of the settlement, Steinhardt Management will pay $19 million in fines to the Government and $21 million to a fund that will compensate investors who lost money as a result of the alleged manipulation. Caxton will pay $22 million in fines and $14 million to the compensation fund.
The $35 million in compensation represents the excess profits the two firms made as a result of their manipulation, the Government said.
"Our strategy in the spring of 1991 was to concentrate our investments in two-year Treasury notes because we anticipated that the Fed would lower short-term interest rates," said Michael Steinhardt, the principal in the firm bearing his name, in a statement. "That strategy was reflected in a concentrated holding of two-year notes, including the April two-year notes, and was immensely successful for our investors."
But the Government charged that Steinhardt and Caxton, which is run by Bruce Kovner, a close associate of Mr. Steinhardt, together acquired as much as 158 percent of the April 1991 auction of $12 billion worth of two-year notes. The two firms were able to amass more than 100 percent of the issue by buying notes from short-sellers, investors who borrow securities and sell them, with the intention of replacing them at a cheaper price later.
The Government said that act created a so-called short squeeze, which forced the investors who had sold borrowed notes to pay higher prices to cover their positions.
A second such short-squeeze occurred the following month, leading to charges against Salomon Inc. that ultimately led to the resignation of John H. Gutfreund, the company's chairman, and several other top executives.
In 1992, Salomon agreed to pay $290 million in fines and compensation as part of a settlement with the Justice Department and the S.E.C. related to the May 1991 auction. Earlier this year, Salomon, Caxton and Steinhardt agreed to pay $100 million to settle a class-action lawsuit filed by holders of the April and May notes.
Yesterday's settlement removes a cloud that had been hanging over both Caxton and Steinhardt for years. Mr. Steinhardt in particular had been dogged by the pending action, which added additional financial uncertainty in a year when his funds have performed miserably.
One of Wall Street's most successful investors, Mr. Steinhardt has posted an average annual return of 27.2 percent since he first started his company 27 years ago. But after interest rates began rising earlier this year, the $4.5 million that Mr. Steinhardt had under management shrank to just over $3 billion.
The large losses and his continuing legal problems led Mr. Steinhardt to consider retiring earlier this year, according to a letter sent to investors last month. But in the letter, he said that he had decided to continue to manage the firm's funds in 1995.
Mr. Steinhardt wrote that he had considered waiving the firm's 20 percent cut of the profits from the funds until he earned back what his investors had lost this year. But he said that he decided not to because he was bearing the legal and settlement costs related to the Treasury scandal.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading of Dollar Is Light Before Interest Rate Review

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most leading currencies yesterday, with many traders unwilling to buy or sell the currency ahead of a key meeting of the Federal Reserve next week.
"There is not a whole lot of incentive to do anything," said Amy Smith, an analyst with the consulting firm of IDEA. 
 In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar fell to an eight-month low.
While few expect the Fed to raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets on Tuesday, dealers said yesterday that the market was keeping a close watch nonetheless
"There is always a chance that the Federal Reserve could surprise," said Anne Pankowski, vice president at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. "The last time they had a meeting they surprised the market with the magnitude of their rate hike. So, there is the chance that the Fed may surprise again."
When the Federal Reserve raised rates by three-quarters of a percentage point after its Nov. 15 meeting, the move touched off a monthlong rally in the dollar. Higher rates help support the value of the dollar because they attract investors by raising the rate of return on investments denominated in the currency.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.5737 German marks from 1.5710 marks on Thursday. The dollar slipped to 100.25 Japanese yen, from 100.37 yen on Thursday.
In other currency trading, the Bank of Canada intervened in the foreign-exchange market and bought Canadian dollars for United States dollars. The Canadian dollar had weakened after the Canadian Bond Rating Service downgraded Quebec's debt rating.
"It fueled some speculation that one of the major American rating agencies may now downgrade Quebec's debt, too," said Curtis Perkins, foreign exchange trader at Chemical Bank.
Dealers said that foreign investors might become wary about purchasing Quebec's fixed-income securities and thus put further pressure on the currency.
In New York, the Canadian dollar fell to 71.85 United States cents, from 72.07 United States cents on Thursday, its lowest level since April 4.
The dollar rose to 1.3322 Swiss francs, from 1.3270 francs on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.5603 from $1.5620.

HEADLINE: Teaching Children Respect for Wildlife

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While most Americans are concerned about budget cuts and a failing economy, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is throwing hundreds of thousands of dollars into a National Shooting Sports Foundation program to turn unsuspecting children into sport hunters, according to Bob Herbert ("Reading, Writing, Reloading," column, Dec. 14). 
 Children have a natural affinity toward animals, yet the gun lobby -- along with state and Federal wildlife agencies -- wants to brainwash youngsters into believing that animals are nothing more than moving targets. The number of hunters decreases each year, and killing animals for recreation will eventually die out if hunting organizations and apologists do not interfere with social evolution.
We should teach children respect and compassion for wildlife, not teach them that violence is an acceptable and laudable form of entertainment. The very last thing responsible parents want to see is a gun in their child's hands, whether it be on a city street or in a state park.
 
CLEVELAND AMORY
President
The Fund for Animals
New York, Dec. 16, 1994

HEADLINE: Bad Examples Abroad

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Fleeing Bosnia, Blocked by America" (Op-Ed, Dec. 9), Julie Mertus writes: "The Embassy's counselor for refugee affairs, Caryl Courtney, told me that the immigration officer hoped to make the trip this fiscal year, but added that 'there may not be enough money in the budget -- the per diem adds up.' " 
 I'll bet it does. United States Government personnel travel on expense budgets completely out of line with living standards in the countries they visit. While I was doing administrative work for the Agency for International Development in Budapest a year ago, I learned that the per diem for officials visiting Budapest was close to $200.
That amount is two-thirds of an average Hungarian's monthly salary (closer to half of the salaries of Hungarians employed by the agency), and is more than half the monthly rent that I paid for a furnished, one-bedroom downtown apartment.
In Budapest, the outrageous standards at which diplomats were living was merely embarrassing. Hearing that a diplomat's comfort is more important than the lives of 32 refugees, however, is offensive -- and presents a nasty picture of American priorities.
 
RACHEL ELSON
San Francisco, Dec. 13, 1994

HEADLINE: Trying a Jump-Start at Hoffritz

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
After months on the brink of collapse, Hoffritz, an old name in specialty retailing, has been given a reprieve.
It remains to be seen if the company that was forced into bankruptcy proceedings last August really has much of a future, but a group of investors injected up to $500,000 into the company last week, providing Hoffritz's few remaining stores with some much-needed merchandise and maybe a full-fledged second chance. 
 "This is a new business that is walking, not running," said Joel J. Silver, who along with his brother, Leonard, bought Hoffritz in 1975. "We have been given the opportunity to restart an idea that began back in the 1930's."
That Mr. Silver has been given another chance may have more to do with the Hoffritz name than anything else, a name that dates to 1932 and has long been associated with high-quality pocket and kitchen knives. It has survived despite what suppliers and competitors say were flawed expansion plans and overly generous salaries and bonuses that the Silvers paid themselves.
"In the minds of many New Yorkers, Hoffritz was the first place people thought of when they wanted to buy a pocket knife," said James Kennedy, co-chairman and chief executive of the Forschner Group of Shelton, Conn., which supplied Hoffritz with Swiss Army knives from the early 1940's until early last year.
"The Silvers took a business risk when they expanded so rapidly, and it didn't work out."
Last August, after months of unpaid bills and an ill-fated attempt to raise money through a public stock offering, Hoffritz was forced into bankruptcy court proceedings by three of its biggest suppliers. Separate discussions were held later with a group of suppliers and a competitor about taking over the business. Both efforts failed.
Starved of inventory, the Silvers had no choice but to rapidly dismantle what only three years earlier had been a sprawling retail enterprise, with 110 stores in 33 states and annual sales of nearly $50 million.
Early this month, only five stores, all in the New York metropolitan area, remained open. In Manhattan, the stores at 43d Street and Madison Avenue, and on 57th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, were shuttered. In Grand Central Terminal and the World Trade Center, sites of the two remaining stores in the city, what was left in inventory was being sold at half-price.
But now, new money has changed that.
Last Monday, the leases of the remaining Hoffritz stores were assigned to a new company, International Cutlery Ltd. Joel Silver will oversee the business. Leonard Silver, a longtime retailing executive, is retiring.
New knives, manicure sets and scissors flowed back into the stores this week. For the time being, the "50 percent off" signs are gone.
At the Grand Central store, display windows, dark for months, not only have a festive spray of Christmas tinsel and some goods, but also a sign of revival saying, "We are restocking with new merchandise for your holiday needs."
Even though Hoffritz is now a snip of its former self, with much lower costs, many suppliers have been returning only if they get paid up front.
Precise International, an importer in Orangeburg, N.Y., that shares the Swiss Army knife franchise in the United States with the Forschner Group, said it had resumed shipments to Hoffritz on a pay-as-you-go basis even though the Silvers still owed the company more than $300,000.
"This is an old-line company that has had a lot of difficulty," said Tom Higgins, president of Precise. "But it seems as though there is some possibility for them to maintain it, and we made a business decision to ship to them on a prepaid basis. The names of Hoffritz and Swiss Army knives are synonymous, so if we had decided not to ship to them, they would die."
Hoffritz's troubles worsened after a plan to raise more than $7 million through an initial public offering of stock was cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission, but was rejected by both Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange.
"If the public offering had worked, they probably would have been successful," said Lou Kindleberger, a vice president at Frost Cutlery, a supplier in Chattanooga, Tenn., that was one of the companies that pushed Hoffritz into bankruptcy.
Mr. Kindleberger might have been right, but the story told in the company's offering prospectus was not one that would probably attract many investors.
After they bought Hoffritz from Federals Inc. through a leveraged buyout in 1975, the Silvers set about expanding the business, and by 1990 had 81 stores across the country, up from 22 when they bought it.
But business began to sour in the late 1980's, the Silvers said. The stock market crash in 1987, and the subsequent deterioration in New York's economy, hurt business in their home market. "We started losing money in 1989 and 1990, and could have gone into Chapter 11," Joel Silver said in an interview. "We made a concerted effort not to do that."
Instead, they pursued a strategy that in hindsight was even more disastrous: they expanded further.
In the fall of 1990, the Silvers bought the assets of Cutlery World of America Inc., a bankrupt retailer that had 95 stores, mostly in California and Florida shopping malls.
Initially, the Silvers intended to close 20 stores, and were confident that they could turn the others around.
Closing the stores was easy. But disposing of more than $5 million in Cutlery World's inventory was not. In fact, it took three years.
All the while, revenues declined and losses mounted. By last April, Hoffritz had accumulated a $12.3 million loss, according to the documents from the stock offering.
As losses mounted, so did delinquent payments. Although stores were being closed to cut costs, debts owed to suppliers had risen to nearly $2 million by last June. Landlords were owed $858,900 in back rent.
The Silvers, however, continued to pay themselves well. In 1992, when the company lost $2.6 million on sales of $18.4 million, Joel Silver, a lawyer who was an official in the New York City Housing Development Administration from 1970 to 1972, received $387,000 in salary and bonus, and $60,000 in legal fees from the company. His brother was paid more than $413,000 in salary and bonus.
Both men took substantial pay cuts in 1993; each received a base salary of $200,000 and no bonus. But by then, critics say, the damage was done.
"I think too much money has been taken out of that company for it to survive," said David Hall, co-owner of United Cutlery of Chattanooga, another of the suppliers that forced Hoffritz into bankruptcy. "The company was in dire need, but the executives were taking too much in terms of their salaries and the like."
Joel Silver said the criticism was unjustified.
"I beg to differ with them as to what we could have taken," he said. "We took significantly less than we agreed with our lenders to take. And we could have taken far more in the 1970's and 1980's, when times were good."
To keep themselves afloat, in 1992 and 1993 the Silvers arranged a series of private debt and equity placements, and sold the Hoffritz name and trademarks.
With the new infusion of capital and inventory, Mr. Silver says he is confident the remaining stores will be profitable "from day one." Others are not so sure.
"I don't see how it's viable," Mr. Higgins of Precise said. "But we wish him luck, and hope they can do something."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 20, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about the financial problems of Hoffritz, a specialty retailer of knives, referred incorrectly to the company's plan for an initial public offering of stock. The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken no action on it; it has not been approved.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
O.K., Call It War

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
I USED TO HATE hearing about the "war" against drugs, and as executive editor tried to discourage that metaphor in The Times. But the politicians won the battle of the cliche even as they were losing the war. The "war" term appeared in this newspaper only 16 times in all of 1981, but 66 times in 1987 and 511 times in 1989, after President Bush promised at his inaugural, "Take my word for it, this scourge will stop." Well, it didn't, and we're down to about 100 mentions in each of the Clinton years, a mere twice a week. And now I'm sorry, for it's time the media began to cover the war on drugs as a war -- the way they covered the last war that America lost.
The better newspapers are portraying the drug quagmire the way they once portrayed the quagmire in Vietnam. Dispatches from the front find cops risking life and limb to drag in users and dealers, but just as many stalk the streets the next night. The brass that's bragging about progress and calling for still more troops, weapons, prisons and money must be smoking something. 
 If the newspapers, magazines and TV networks would agree that there's a war on, maybe they would report a monthly "bag count" -- the number of kilo-size packs of cocaine or heroin seized by Federal, state and local raiders in urban hideaways, remote marinas and canine stomachs. They could point out that the bag count, much like the Vietnam body count, is a meaningless index of progress in the war; no matter how impressive the seizures, the flow of bags in the underground drug channels continues relentlessly.
The press has been too generous with pictures of prosecutors and politicians posing with the mounds of heroin and cocaine they've stumbled across somewhere. If more of the media would open drug-war bureaus in the inner cities, their bravest reporters would find that there's no shortage anytime, no increase at all in the street price of drugs, just constant pressure by a guerrilla army of street pushers supporting their own drug habit by enlarging the circle of customers. The reporters would document the cost and futility of the pursuit, the cynicism and corruption of the pursuers and the serene confidence of a wealthy enemy.
GRADUALLY, MAYBE through C-Span "teach-ins" run by such radicals as former Secretary of State George Shultz, Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore and William F. Buckley Jr., the commercial networks might learn that the war on drugs -- meaning the prohibition of drugs -- is not only being lost but is also unwinnable. The radicals have adopted the antiwar slogan of "legalization," but the TV anchors don't have to embrace that still-undefined remedy. They need only climb to the rooftops of Washington Heights in New York and cruise down along the Potomac Delta while reciting the terrifying findings of their research staffs: the direct, recognizable cost of this war is probably running in excess of $100 billion a year. There's not even a good estimate of the cost of the related crimes committed by drug peddlers and users, and of the measures taken to prevent such crimes, to compensate the victims and to punish some of the perpetrators. Hundreds of millions of dollars are being stashed in offshore sanctuaries and hundreds of millions more are available to import the stuff and to pave the way with bribes and untaxed wages. *
Of the 20 million American drug users, maybe 5 million are "seriously" addicted. A year's supply of heroin for all of them can be made from opium poppies grown on only 20 square miles of land -- not quite the area of Manhattan. A year's supply of coke can be stashed in 13 truck trailers. So "eradicating" the supply abroad is impossible; "interdicting" drugs at the border is a joke.
About 40,000 Americans die each year of the direct and indirect effects of drugs; a large proportion of New York City's 2,000 annual homicides are attributable to drug trafficking. And drug offenders, whether or not they are violent criminals, clog the courts and prisons.
When finally one of the TV anchors senses that the country is ready to hear unvarnished truth, like Walter Cronkite's passionate declaration in 1968 that it was time to get out of Vietnam, she won't have to bother with statistics. Against a backdrop of gripping graphics, she could simply list the war's consequences:
 
* Urban blight, fear and destruction.
* Neighborhood turf wars and shootouts.
* Family ruin, school failure and wreckage.
* Lost productivity in the economy.
* Crack babies, kids dealing drugs, addicts felled by AIDS.
* Cops corrupted. Courts and prisons overwhelmed.
* Murder and mayhem clear to the top in Mexico, Colom
 
* Most of the statistics in this column are taken from "The Making of a Drug-Free America" by Mathea Falco and "A Wiser Course: Ending Drug Prohibition, a Report of the Special Committee on Drugs and the Law of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York."
bia and other countries that cannot resist supplying the rich American market. And in America, contempt for government -- and despair.
IF THE PROHIBITION OF drugs is a lost cause then "legalization" -- in some form -- is inevitable. But the word "legalization" has been demonized, like "negotiation" before Henry Kissinger sat down with the Vietcong in Paris. A year ago, Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders was pilloried -- and disowned by her President -- for recommending "some studies" of how drugs might be legalized and regulated. Most Americans still think legalization would constitute "surrender" to immorality. Some call it "genocide" because they imagine ghetto children lining up at the corner drugstore for their daily fix.
Not until we in the media do a better job of reporting the horrendous costs of this unwinnable war will the public consider alternative policies. By definition, legalizing drugs would put the big dealers and their gun-toting distributors out of business. It would also keep most users from having to steal to support the habit. That alone would liberate a great deal of money and energy for reclaiming wrecked lives and neighborhoods.
Like the Surgeon General, I don't pretend to know how a legal drug trade might be managed. Maybe drugs should be sold inexpensively to adults through Government outlets, like the ABC liquor stores that many states opened after Prohibition. Maybe drugs should be given away at neighborhood dispensaries that also offer treatment to cure addiction. Maybe dozens of experiments are in order.
By all means, let's call it "war." Then deal with defeat.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 18, 1994

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2959 words

HEADLINE: PASSING THE SCOOP;
BEN & JERRY

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus is a contributing writer to this magazine.

 BODY:
BEN AND JERRY ARE HAPPY AS clams, even though for much of the past year or so they have been getting a lot of dubious press. Many of the news stories pounced on the announcement in June that Ben Cohen was stepping down as chief executive of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., which takes in $150 million a year selling such diet-busters as Coconut Almond Fudge Chip and Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough ice cream. In fact, Cohen and his partner, Jerry Greenfield, were looking for a chief executive officer to "help the company realize its next stage of growth and financial strength." Was this, reporters wanted to know, a prelude to Ben and Jerry's leaving the company they founded in 1978?
Other stories took the company to task for including artificial ingredients in some of its "all-natural" flavors; for a high injury rate among employees; for making many stockholders anxious with a sharp fall in share prices and other stockholders unhappy by dropping its official policy of having the highest-salaried jobs at the company paying no more than seven times the lowest-paid ones. 
 "When we began," Cohen explains, "there were all those stories about 'Look what good they've done.' That stopped being news. So the new story is 'Look what bad they've done.' "
As leaders of a socially responsible business movement -- a loose coalition of companies that includes the Body Shop, Patagonia and Esprit -- Cohen and Greenfield have funneled part of their profits into organizations concerned about children's rights, the homeless and the environment. In many ways, Ben and Jerry, ex-hippies, invented a business that institutionalizes the ideas and values of the 1960's.
Born on Long Island within days of each other in March 1951, they have been best friends since junior high school. Jerry is the quiet, thoughtful one. Ben has more bombast. Jerry is married and has a 7-year-old son. Ben is divorced, with a 4-year-old daughter. Both love to eat. The interview at company headquarters in Waterbury, Vt., begins when Ben goes to a huge freezer near his office, produces three containers of what he calls "product" and three spoons. "This is an old 60's ritual," he says, laughing. "Pass the pint."

Q: O.K., guys, why have you spent the past six months looking for a new C.E.O.? Are you giving up your baby?
JERRY: We're not giving up the baby. But this is necessary. We have 600 employees. We manufacture ice cream on two shifts and on three different sites, and the level of complexity is such that it requires organizational, operational and management expertise that goes beyond what Ben and I can offer. In terms of creating an evolving vision for the company, instilling values, pushing the boundaries of what our company can do, Ben and I have an incredible amount to offer. In terms of day-to-day management, we are lost.

Q: Mel Brooks once said, "It's good to be the king." Will it be hard to not be king?
JERRY: I haven't been king for a long time. I've been more chief of staff. We're not leaving the company, though when Ben announced in June that he was stepping aside as C.E.O., the press played it as if we were leaving. It never entered our minds.
BEN: The job I'm looking to take on is being chairman of the board, which is the title I've always had. I'm looking to find out what a chairman of the board does.
JERRY: We want to institutionalize what we're doing so that if Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield get run over by a truck tomorrow, this company would still do the things on which it is based. In the new setup, I'll be vice chairman of the board. Ben and I expect to continue to work on new flavors, new products, long-term strategy, keeping in touch with customer desires and, for me personally, I'm interested in keeping closer relationships with our staff.

Q: In searching for your new C.E.O., you took ads inviting people to write essays on why they should be named C.E.O. of Ben & Jerry's. First prize in the contest is the job. Were you serious?
BEN: Definitely. The person we are looking for must have a strong commitment to progressive social values and experience running a company our size. There probably are only a handful of people that meet that description. So we wanted to make an open search. We had a professional headhunter looking, but we also found some candidates through the contest. In all, we've interviewed about 20 people for the job. We should announce our choice sometime after the new year.

Q: What kind of entries came to you through the contest?
JERRY: Incredible ones. Most were humorous. We had several resumes that came in written on icings of cakes.
BEN: Really good-tasting cakes.
JERRY: Excellent cakes. We got over 20,000 responses. I suspect a lot of people were aiming for second prize: a lifetime supply of ice cream.

Q: Your contest was a public relations hit. But there have been reports that your franchises feel neglected, that your employees have a high on-the-job injury rate.
BEN: Our accident rate is a lot higher than we want it to be. We want a much safer operation, and we're devoting a lot of effort to doing that. We stopped producing our brownie ice-cream sandwiches because our workers were getting repetitive stress injuries. In terms of our franchises, our company has put a lot of effort into helping them do a good job. But a franchise is like a parent-child relationship. The franchiser is the parent and the child doesn't like it that much. As the child moves into adolescence, the child thinks that the parent doesn't know anything. We will always have problems.

Q: Your company used to have a salary system where the highest-paid employee made no more than five times the lowest-paid one. It's been in the press that you've increased your own salaries.
JERRY: We went from a salary ratio of 5 to 1 to 7 to 1. The top salary moved from $100,000 a year to $150,000 year. Ben and I are not at the top salary within the company. The president of the company, Chuck Lacy, is. Ben and I earn $132,500. In order to get this new C.E.O., we are not going to restrict ourselves. I expect that we will be paying compensation at the low end of market rates for a C.E.O.

Q: How are you two guys different from each other?
BEN: As a manager, I'm fairly autocratic. I'm hard to please, not very communicative. People perceive me as intimidating. I tend to be more conceptual and Jerry tends to be more practical. I tend to be more independent and Jerry is better with people. I am not able to do routine things. Jerry is.
JERRY: Right. Ben is the creative one, the risk-taker. Ben has often told me that he would rather fail at something new than succeed at something that has already been done before. That's a shocking concept to me. Also, as a team, we have a good sense of the absurd. The most immediate absurdity is that our business was started by two non-business people and it has reached such an exalted status in the ice-cream world.

Q: As kids growing up in the wilds of Merrick, L.I., in the 1950's, what did you dream about becoming?
BEN: After a fireman, my dream was to be a modern-day Judah Maccabee. He seemed like a really good guy. He helped his people and he gave the world Hanukkah.
JERRY: I guess I wanted to become a doctor. It's what Jewish kids from Long Island who were good in science did. Ben and I were very uncool. We were fat nerds. I was in the math club. Ben played the cello.

Q: When you first met in a seventh-grade Merrick junior-high-school gym class, what drew you to each other?
JERRY: The fact we were both fat, unathletic and outside the social mainstream. The first time I saw Ben, the gym teacher was yelling at him. We had to run a mile in seven minutes or we had to do it all over again. So Ben was saying, "Gee, Coach, if I can't do it in under seven minutes the first time, how am I going to do it on the second try?" Ben likes arguing with authority figures. It was a revelation to me that anybody would do that. And it is still a revelation when Ben does certain things. In 1988, we received this Small Business Administration award from President Ronald Reagan. There was this White House dinner and we got to say a few words and Ben got up and made this speech about how we should take the money from the defense budget to meet basic human needs. It was shocking to me that he would have the gumption to attack government policies in front of those people.

Q: How did your ice-cream business start?
BEN: Around 1975 or so, I had decided to homestead -- buy a piece of land, grow food, do pottery. Pottery was to be the cash crop. In those days, people talked regularly about alternative life styles and looking for ways not to become part of the system. Problem was, I would take my ceramics to fairs and markets, set them up, sit with them all day and I'd bring every one of them home again.
JERRY: It was a bad time for us both. I had been rejected by 40 medical schools. We were clearly not succeeding in our chosen fields. So we started considering different ways to support ourselves. We wanted to live in a rural college town, do something where we could be together and that was fun. Since we love to eat, we immediately thought of food. Ice cream made sense, though we considered bagels, shish kebab, fondue. Ben & Jerry's scoop shop opened in Burlington, Vt., in 1978. Sixteen years later, Ben and I are as surprised as anyone that we're running a $150-million-a-year business, with 600 employees and 100-plus franchisees.

Q: Is it true the early success of your product stemmed from the fact that Ben, the official ice-cream taster, has a smelling problem?
BEN: I've never had a very good sense of smell, and if you don't have that, you don't have a good sense of taste. When we began, the game was for Jerry to make a flavor I could taste with my eyes closed. To do that, he had to make ice creams that were intensely flavored. Also: because of this disability, I have an excellent sense of mouth feel. Creaminess and crunchiness are very important to people who can't taste.
JERRY: This led to our putting bigger than standard chunks of fruit and candy into our ice creams. It turned out that people really liked these highly flavored, extra-chunky ice creams. We were offering them something unique.

Q: Is ice cream better than sex?
BEN:It depends on what you're in the mood for. If you really need some Cherry Garcia, then having some Cherry Garcia is going to do it for you more than sex will.
JERRY: We've just entered the British market, where Haagen-Dazs has an incredibly sexy ad campaign. Someone there wrote of us: "If Haagen-Dazs is the ice cream you have after sex, then Ben & Jerry's is the ice cream you have instead of sex."

Q: What is your assessment of your competitor?
JERRY: Within the super-premium ice-cream category, the two major players are Haagen-Dazs and us. Haagen-Dazs tries hard to project an elegant high-class European image, even though the product is made in New Jersey.
BEN: I think Haagen-Dazs is an excellent ice cream. It's smooth, rich, creamy. But smooth ice cream is not that difficult to produce. Making the crunchy sort is much harder.

Q: Have you had any flavor failures?
BEN: Fred and Ginger. That's ginger ice cream with chocolate chunk bow ties. Now I happen to think that Fred and Ginger is a great flavor. There are great flavors that are ahead of their time and don't sell that well.

Q: Did you ever met a flavor you didn't like?
JERRY: Bubble gum ice cream. Gumdrop ice cream.
BEN: Once, while in Florida, I had something called Smurf ice cream -- it was blue with white dots. This was for research. In our business, research can be difficult and hazardous.

Q: Of your own flavors, which do you consider the best?
BEN: For some odd reason, I can't get Cherry Garcia off my mind.

Q: It's sort of a frozen Black Forest cake, right?
BEN: Except that its base is vanilla. Don't think we haven't tried frozen chocolate. It didn't work because the chocolate overpowered the cherries. There are things that are good in cake and terrible in ice cream. My first concept of Cherry Garcia was to chocolate coat the cherries and throw them in. It was really difficult for me to get a supplier who would make chocolate-coated cherries. Once we finally did, we tried them in the ice cream and they were lousy. We tried different chocolate coatings, thickness, cherries and it was still lousy. So we separated the chocolate from the cherries, because it was cracking off in the machinery. Next, I wanted whole cherries, but they wouldn't go through the machinery. Finally, we agreed on a combination of whole and half cherries.

Q: How does Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead feel about being a flavor?
BEN: He's honored. It's a good flavor. Plus he gets his royalty. We've since gotten flavor suggestions that pay tribute to other 60's cultural heroes: the Almond Brothers, Mint Jagger.

Q: Speaking of the 60's, does your product have some of the qualities of recreational drugs?
BEN: In that it's really good and people like to eat it a lot and sometimes people can't help themselves, yes.

Q: Let's be honest about your yogurt. It's not nonfattening.
JERRY: It is very low-fat.

Q: What's the calorie count?
JERRY: I don't count calories. I count fat grams. If you look at Chocolate Fudge Brownie frozen yogurt or Cherry Garcia frozen yogurt, they are very low-fat.
BEN: Listen, it is a dessert. People need to eat stuff that makes them feel good and most everything, aside from rice and celery, is fattening. The bottom line is that our low-fat yogurt has 2 percent fat in it.

Q: Ben & Jerry's is considered a socially responsible business. Define that.
BEN: It's a business that cares about people, that seeks to use its power to improve the quality of life within society. It seeks profits and tries to integrate spiritual and social concerns into day-to-day activities. Typical businesses tend to do everything in terms of narrow self-interest. They want to maximize profitability and quality. We add a third factor: impact on the community, on the consumer, on our employees. We use suppliers like Greyston Bakers, which provides jobs for the previously unemployable. We buy our coffee from a rural cooperative in Mexico, helping to raise the standard of living there. We sell some of our ice cream through partner shops like Common Ground, which trains the previously unemployed. We give 7 1/2 percent of our pretax profits to our foundation, which, as far as we know, is the highest percentage of any publicly held company.

Q: A conservative economist like Milton Friedman might say that what you're doing is bad for business.
BEN: Milton Friedman's position is that the only justifiable action for business is to maximize profits. He thinks if the owners of the business desire to use their profits for social good, fine. Jerry and I believe that corporations are chartered by the society and that they are charged with operating for the public good. Corporations have tremendous power. If you're just going to give out these little bits of money to stockholders, then the power is going to be dissipated. I think Friedman negates all the other aspects of business that are not financial in nature. Like lobbying. Like contributing to elections. Putting politicians in power. They are doing that to maximize their profits at the expense of the welfare of the society.
JERRY: We think making a better world increases profits. If you have a world where there are a lot of riots and disparities, that's not a world where you can sell a lot of ice cream. If you have a world where people are nurtured and their basic human needs are met, you can sell more.

Q: Some would say you two display a touching innocence.
BEN: When we talk about our image, we think of childlike sophistication. "Let's have fun. Let's not be jaded. Let's try to run a business according to values that we learned as children."
JERRY: Here, if somebody says, "Let's look for our new C.E.O. by having a national essay contest where we offer the job as first prize," people say, "Cool, let's do it."

Q: You have ex-Black Panther Bobby Seale on your new advertising campaign. Does he sell ice cream?
BEN: Is he the guy on the poster who says, "Vanilla"? He says it very well.

Q: What were you trying to do with that campaign?
JERRY: Support activists, pay homage to them. We needed to tell consumers that Ben & Jerry's was now making ice cream without chunks in it. And the only way we could do that was through mainstream advertising, which is unusual for us. So, how could we use mainstream advertising to support our social values? The original concept behind the ad was to show these activist mouths next to a scoop of ice cream and ask people to guess whose mouths they were. But when we did tests, a lot of people couldn't guess the mouths of Daniel Berrigan, Pete Seeger and Dolores Huerta. Spike Lee, who directed and appeared in the commercial, said, "Look, if you're going to use these activists, you want to use them full face so that you help them gain recognition for their causes and what they are about."

Q: In many ways, your company has become one of the major custodians of the ideals and values of the 1960's. Do you find that ironic?
BEN: It humbles us. Who would have guessed that fat little old nerdy Ben and Jerry would be the keepers of the 1960's flame? Perhaps it's fitting for an ice-cream company to be the keepers of 60's values. Ice cream is fun. It's happy. The 60's were a wonderful time and the values of the 60's were serious and happy: peace, love, fairness, equality.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ben, at left, and Jerry have been juggling identities: activists and businessmen. (PHOTOGRAPH BY KAREN KUEHN/MATRIX, FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 18, 1994

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 3; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 3913 words

HEADLINE: Striving for That One Singular Sensation

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
"HELLO. THIS IS JAMIE. I can't answer the phone right now, but please leave a message and I'll call you as soon as I can! Thanks a lot! Bye."
The voice on the answering machine is resonant, that of someone ready for anything. It is the voice of a Broadway gypsy, a triple-threat performer who has learned to live in roller-coaster bursts of optimism and despair in a world that is becoming an anachronism. 
 Gypsies today must be more expert than ever at dancing, singing and acting. They must remain poised and self-confident despite continual rejection. And more than ever, they must be prepared not to work on Broadway, where they once trekked their way from musical to musical. Sometimes the casts were so big, there were separate choruses of singers and dancers. But today smallness is the watchword. While there were nearly 9.000 gypsy members in Actors Equity in New York City in 1994, only two major musicals opened on Broadway. One was "Show Boat"; the other was "Sunset Boulevard," and that was cast in Los Angeles.
All gypsies come from somewhere other than New York, or so it is supposed, hopping a bus from some dusty little place with a suitcase and a dream. Mr. MacKenzie grew up in Petoskey, a town in northern Michigan, but he came east to attend Phillips Exeter Academy and Dartmouth College, where he majored in government. He fell into theater at Dartmouth, learning as he participated. He came to Manhattan in 1990, at the age of 31, and he came with no conservatory or musical-theater training.
Today, he said, "hundreds and hundreds" of university theater graduates are coming to New York to try their luck. And the talent pool has been further enlarged after the Actors Equity union was forced to open auditions to a new category of members after a suit in 1988.
"Differences aside," Mr. MacKenzie said, "we're all sort of in a common fraternity: getting up early, standing in line and waiting, talking about casting directors and directors."
The last show in which Jamie MacKenzie performed closed in May. There have been nibbles and near-misses since then, but nothing else. In some ways Mr. MacKenzie is not a very typical gypsy; for one thing, he came to theater relatively late. But in other ways the tale of his travails is, in microcosm, the tale of all Broadway gypsies, struggling to maneuver in the shrunken Broadway of today.
Mr. MacKenzie did not seem especially interested in performing as a child, recalls his mother, Barbara MacKenzie. He sang in a church choir and participated in a few "little plays." But from a very early age he had all the aplomb of an entertainer. "He was very verbal," she said. "He talked to adults all the time. The neighbors loved to have him come over -- they called him The National Observer. He was kind of a studied 2-year-old."
Even at Dartmouth, Mr. MacKenzie did not seriously consider becoming a performer. With nearly everyone in his family a lawyer (his mother is a judge), he was expected to go to law school. "But in my senior year of college, I felt I wasn't doing it for myself."
In the end he accumulated enough credits for a degree in drama, "but I didn't want to frighten my parents," he said teasingly. He came home after graduation, in 1982, working at odd jobs, then studying acting in England. Boston drew him back a year later.
In Boston, where he learned word processing, a skill that has kept him solvent in lean times, something inside snapped. He had studied voice during college with a charismatic teacher named Atea Ring and developed a powerful second tenor. Now, he realized, he had to commit himself to acting lessons if he was to pursue a career in the theater. And so in 1985, with his parents' blessing and financial help, he enrolled in the intensive Shakespeare and Company Acting Workshop conducted at Wellesley College. It was, he said, an invaluable "boot camp for actors."
A college friend, Lori Glaser, attended the workshop, too, and remembers Mr. MacKenzie as "an amazing friend. At college we'd go swing-dancing at this little hotel with all these old couples. We'd take day trips to Boston, driving down to see a matinee, eating early, then getting on the road in time to make a 7 o'clock rehearsal."
Often they danced and sang together to Bing Crosby and Rosemary Clooney in Mr. MacKenzie's room at his fraternity house, the singing nearly obliterating the sounds of carousing frat brothers. "There was always something a little not mainstream about Jamie, which was what I loved about him," said Ms. Glaser, who is now a singer and actress in New York. "I hadn't thought of him as a risk taker. But I knew he would do well. He always had a phenomenal voice and was talented in so many ways."
Successful auditions for Boston theater and club acts followed Mr. MacKenzie's workshop experience. By 1988 he was earning a living by his performing alone; by 1990 he was a popular fixture on the scene. "I was spending 250 nights a year on stage," he said. It was time to try New York.
"I always swore I wouldn't come to New York without a show," he said. "But one day I woke up and said to myself: 'I'm almost 30. I've got to do it now.' "
 
 
The Early Days
 It was Michael Rafter, a college friend who is now a Broadway conductor, who helped encourage Mr. MacKenzie to move to New York in 1990, letting him sleep on his couch in his Upper West Side apartment until he found a place in New Jersey. It was a time of intense loneliness and disappointment. Mr. MacKenzie had started auditioning, one in a crowd now, a performer with a big, sweet voice, well-honed acting skills but an untrained body (5 feet, 11 3/4 inches of it) that betrayed his fear of auditions. There were many dismissive thank-you's.
"I had to sort of relearn everything: how to audition, what material to use," Mr. MacKenzie said. "In Boston I could get by on my voice. There was no real competition; a pool of about 30 people turned up for every audition. I wasn't prepared for here, where you're up against 300 guys at every chorus call."
Mr. Rafter came to his rescue by inviting him to an informal audition workshop for Broadway gypsies that he held every Monday. At first the experience was almost as unnerving as auditioning itself; this audience was gypsies who had performed in shows like "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Les Miserables." But the discomfort paid off. By February 1991 he had a dozen audition pieces prepared.
The process could still be painful and in at least one case devastating: Mr. MacKenzie lost his voice during an audition, after seven weeks of starring in "The Music Man" without a microphone in a regional theater. At the end, the casting director called out, "Everybody, please stay except the following people: Jamie MacKenzie." "Well, this is the worst-case scenario," he tried to reassure the person staring back at him from the elevator mirror as he left.
That year he landed a few small jobs in summer stock and on a cruise ship.
 
 
The Dance Class
 In February 1992 Mr. MacKenzie found a dance class, on the Lower East Side, "without attitude," as he put it. He realized that he needed to brush up on his dancing.
The teacher, Jerri Garner, a quick-moving woman with a Texas style, specializes in hard dancing and gentle encouragement in small tap and jazz classes in which even late starters like Mr. MacKenzie can learn to think on their feet. In one exercise the class is given a rhythm, each student calls out a step, and the sequence of steps is performed as a dance routine.
"You learn a broad vocabulary of basic steps so that 95 percent of the steps in audition combinations look familiar, and you can focus on the things you don't know," said Mr. MacKenzie. "Jerri has given me the ability to get through a dance audition with commitment."
 
 
Closing In On the Goal
 Mr. MacKenzie's preparation to become a triple-threat performer seemed to be paying off. By the summer of 1992 he was getting callbacks for things like the Robert Goulet "Camelot," the national tour of "Evita" and "Annie Warbucks." He knew he was getting closer. But the callbacks yielded only two jobs, both in summer theaters. At home on a visit, he called family members together. Should he give up and go to law school?
"I worry about the rejections," his mother said. "That's got to be terribly hard. But I think he handles it pretty well."
She did not hesitate to encourage him to stick it out in New York. "I know there are other things he could do," she said. "But he is so good, I want him to try as long as he wants to, so he'll know he tried." His family would support him through a year of auditioning.
 
The Big Break
 In December Mr. MacKenzie was one of about 1,500 performers seen over six days of open chorus calls for "My Fair Lady," which was due to open on Broadway about a year later. He chose "The Song Is You" and added a final E flat to show off his vocal range.
"We didn't need that last note, Jamie," the auditioners told him. But around Christmas he got a callback for Dec. 30.
"I was convinced I blew it," Mr. MacKenzie said of the second audition. There had been a long wait to enter the studio. "I was ticked off. When they called me, I threw down my 'Barchester Towers' and went in. I felt later I was going through the motions."
Five days went by without a word. The fifth night, frustrated after learning that he looked too young for a role for which he had auditioned and that he had felt good about, he stormed home, turned on the television and drank a lot of "bad Michigan wine."
But the next day there was a phone message for him from Charlotte Wilcox, the general manager of "My Fair Lady." She was offering him a job.
"Would you like to hear the details before you say yes?" she asked. "No," Mr. MacKenzie replied. Didn't he want the dates? No. How about the itinerary? No.
"There were two or three things she thought I was worried about," he recalled. "I wasn't. I said: 'It's all right, I'll take it.' "
Mr. MacKenzie was cast as an antic young Cockney in the quartet backing up Eliza Doolittle in the song "Wouldn't It Be Loverly." Rehearsals began in February. The show, starring Richard Chamberlain as Professor Higgins, went on tour on March 26, playing in 23 cities over nine months before opening on Broadway on Dec. 9 at the Virginia Theater.
"It was really a gift," Mr. MacKenzie said, remembering his earlier despair. "I don't know how much longer I could have held out."
"My Fair Lady" opened in New York to mixed but generally respectable reviews. But it was clear the musical was in trouble after Mr. Chamberlain left the show four months later, on April 3, and a closing notice went up three weeks later.
Over the summer, until some chorus members began to get jobs and others drifted away, they got together for baby and wedding showers and Broadway Show League baseball games and bowling. Many still keep in touch. More recently, in November, some attended the sixth annual gypsy-of-the-year competition, in which Broadway and Off Broadway choruses compete before their colleagues.
Mr. MacKenzie got an even more tangible bonus from the experience. By saving of his salary on tour, he was able to put a down payment on a studio apartment on the Upper West Side. It is decorated with photographs and prints, a piano from home and a few pieces of understated antique furniture from his grandmother. He wakes up every morning, he said, blessing "My Fair Lady."
 
 
Starting Over, Every Day
 Like any other gypsy, Mr. MacKenzie had to start all over again after "My Fair Lady" closed. Yes, a certain glow remained, and he returned to auditions with extra confidence. Nonetheless, it was as if he had never gotten that break.
Mr. Rafter, his audition coach, estimates that 95 percent of Equity members earn less than $20,000 a year from acting. Gypsies who make it into a Broadway show make a minimum, according to the union, of $975 a week. Mr. MacKenzie estimates that the year he performed in "My Fair Lady" he earned $60,000, counting per diem tour payments. Since the show closed, in May, he said wryly, he has earned "about $1,000."
He has lived off an income-tax refund and money from the sale of his car. These sums have kept him going financially, along with unemployment benefits of $300 a week. By early last month, Mr. MacKenzie was contemplating a return to temporary work, though even that can be difficult. "Temping is much more competitive now," he said.
His chief expenses are the training he needs to stay in shape: four dance classes a week, workouts at the gym and coaching with Mr. Rafter -- all of which adds up to $85 a week. He can't afford regular voice training, which averages $75 a session.
 
 
The Coaching Session
 In the summer of 1993, after "My Fair Lady" had closed, Mr. MacKenzie decided to respond to a cattle call, or big open chorus rehearsal, for the national tour of "Blood Brothers." Having an agent streamlines the audition process somewhat: shows that are casting notify agents, who may send out head shots of 10 clients; two or three are likely to be called for more select "agent-submission" auditions. Mr. MacKenzie did not yet have an agent; he planned to audition for "Blood Brothers."
As he often does, he scheduled an audition-coaching session with Mr. Rafter beforehand. As Mr. MacKenzie's coach, Mr. Rafter is probably one of his most important influences.
Mr. MacKenzie pulled sheet music from his knapsack. A song was chosen, and his huge, rich voice seemed to push up against the walls around him. There was a moment's silence after he finished. "Wow!" his teacher said softly. Then he played 16 bars of Noel Coward's nostalgic "Come the Wild, Wild Weather."
"The trouble with that is the bridge," Mr. MacKenzie said.
"It's a song that can be sung at auditions or funerals," Mr. Rafter responded dryly.
"Yeah, but it never goes above a C."
A good voice is obviously important, Mr. Rafter said later, but so is an honest treatment of the material. Concentrate on telling a story with the song, Mr. Rafter advised.
Mr. MacKenzie was afraid of sounding maudlin, he told Mr. Rafter, who then talked the two of them through a word-by-word analysis of the song.
"Higher stakes, O.K.?" Mr. MacKenzie sighed resignedly. He sang his way to the end again.
"It's not moving forward," Mr. Rafter said gently. "It's just bumping from section to section."
He then fixed on Mr. MacKenzie's hiking boots. "Are you going to wear those at the audition?" Mr. MacKenzie shook his head. "You should always wear the shoes you'll wear at the audition." Then he addressed Mr. MacKenzie's slightly stooped shoulders and diffident stance.
One moment the singer was a tiger, assertive, even cocky. The next moment he was a vulnerable child. Can both be one and the same person? Welcome, Mr. Rafter said, to the heart of the actor.
 
 
The Audition
 Actors line up as early as 5:30 A.M. at the headquarters of Actors Equity, on West 46th Street near Broadway, to sign up for auditions. Things are a little more relaxed for chorus calls, though no one auditions without an assigned time and an appointment card.
The room is decorated with Broadway show posters, job notices and a sign that warns "No smoking, eating, drinking, vocalizing." Auditioners file quickly in a single line past a woman everyone knows as Marilyn, a veteran actor who checks their union membership cards. Hal Blankenship, a tall, genial man and union audition monitor who has overseen two generations of job-seeking gypsies, records their appointments. Several soundproof studios line a corridor behind the waiting room.
It is in Studio D that the "Blood Brothers" tryouts will take place. On that day the door opens, and a man walks out. "Sixteen bars of a pop-rock ballad or dramatic," he orders. The auditioners begin to disappear into the studio.
Inside, two men in khakis and T-shirts sit behind a table, the accompanist to their right. "Hello, how are you?" they ask as each auditioner presents his photo, resume and music. The room is small and pink, with a mirror, a barre, a few chairs and a large clock. Somehow, it seems vast and empty.
Each person gets his moment, is thanked and disappears. It is Mr. MacKenzie's turn. Entering with a confident bounce, he greets everyone and chats a little. Then it is time.
His voice fills the room with warm, rich sound and all the subtle nuances his coach could have wished for. "Very nice," Mr. MacKenzie is told. Next.
Mr. MacKenzie feels good about his efforts. But then his mood is good anyway. He had a call from Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, to audition for a singing commercial. He hurries downtown by subway to the luxurious offices of the huge international advertising agency.
"I was a little down at the coaching session yesterday," Mr. MacKenzie admits en route. "But I went to see 'Perestroika' last night, and I sort of used the positive, affirmed sense I got from watching that to get me upbeat."
Indeed, one antidote to the down times is attending theater, whenever he can afford it. "I'm constantly fighting to keep things real and fresh. The real process is to keep yourself from being bitter," he said. He mentions an exceptionally blase actor who turns up at most auditions, though he never seems to get jobs. "I want to say to him, 'Get away from me.' "
Mr. MacKenzie waits calmly in the reception room at Saatchi & Saatchi, his throat muscles moving almost imperceptibly as if vocalizing silently to himself. Eventually a casting director leads him into a small high-tech recording studio. He is to sing an upbeat, old pop standard with new lyrics, giving it an Andy Williams-Perry Como spin. He practices twice. Now it's time.
"Take one," a ghostly voice from the sound booth calls out. "State your name, please."
The voice describes the character to be portrayed: "Let's do a bit of a sendup, a singing-at-a-wedding kind of idea."
Mr. MacKenzie complies.
Pick up the pace for take two, he is told, and give it a little "lounge lizard."
Mr. MacKenzie juts out his pelvis a bit, greasily extending his vowels as he sings. The auditioners seem pleased, and Mr. MacKenzie leaves on a wave of warmth. Things are looking good.
But neither audition pans out. There's not even a callback for "Blood Brothers."
"Last week was really hard," Mr. MacKenzie said of the experience. "What keeps me from getting too bitter or too beaten is that I laugh. You have to laugh. You have to turn it into an anecdote, or it eats you up."
A few experiences make the bad times easier to bear. Mr. MacKenzie auditioned for "Kiss Me, Kate" and felt optimistic about his chances. But the producers were unable to get the rights to the show. In the brief limbo before news filtered that the show was dead, he drifted into the familiar gypsy blues. "I didn't know if they had liked me," he said. But the choreographer, Susan Stroman, had written a personal note to all the callbacks, adding to Mr. MacKenzie's letter a warm note of praise for his audition.
"She was so nice," he said. "That really raised the level, treating us like people."
 
 
What They Did For Love
 Older Broadway gypsies have endured the highs and lows of the life many times over, of course. But the theater world has changed since they began, said two veteran performers of the chorus of "My Fair Lady." "Show business suddenly became 'the entertainment industry,' " said Ron Schwinn, 54, who played Pearly King in the show. "I think that's when the 'business' took over."
Mr. Schwinn has worked fairly steadily, but it is getting harder.
"From 1960 to when I closed in '42d Street,' in 1985, my average span of idleness between jobs was six weeks," he said. "In those days you could go from show to show to show. There was a stock season, too, with three to four auditions a day, five days a week. There is no resident stock any more. It was a wonderful way for a young person to learn to work. You'd rehearse and perform and rehearse again."
There are other changes. Performers now spend as much time auditioning for agents as for shows, Mr. Schwinn noted. And this is the era of the absentee director and choreographer, he added, who often delegate their work with choruses to lesser mortals. The gypsy terminology, too, has changed.
"I learned a whole new language in 'My Fair Lady,' " said Patti Karr, a gypsy who has been in the business for 44 years. "You now have your 'station' in the dressing room. Excuse me? Those of us from the old school had to be nailed to our beds to miss a show. And now when you get your period you take a 'personal day.' It would never have entered my mind.
"I think the big difference today is that people want to have another life. This was our life. Some guy asked me once if I was going to give this up when I got married. What? Excuse me?"
While Ms. Karr talks of retiring, Mr. Schwinn plows happily on. "Every now and then I walk into an audition," he said, "and someone looks up and says, 'Oh, my God, are you still alive?' "
When he was called in to work on "My Fair Lady" on tour, Tommy Tune voiced similar surprise. "I said, 'Yeah, Tommy, I'm still here. It's what I do."
 
 
The Future
 Mr. MacKenzie gave himself five years in New York to find out if he could succeed in the theater. He has a year to go. "I've done enough now so that I don't feel as if I'll walk away after a year," he said. "I've started a life here. I don't know what form it's going to take: cabaret, theater or something else. That's one of the cool things about 'My Fair Lady.' It made it all make sense."
October was a good month for auditions, with 12 in the first three weeks, but November offered almost nothing. Things picked up early this month, but the holidays will be a dead time.
Mr. MacKenzie would like to be working. "You get to the point where you're so hungry to work, you take almost anything," he said.
He has done two training films, one in which he portrayed Vinnie the Vegetable Man for a supermarket, another in which he played a worker worried about the effect of a drunk-driving arrest on his job.
Mr. MacKenzie is at a critical age for gypsies. "It's so brutal. Some get tougher. Some give it up. There was a girl in 'Ain't Broadway Grand.' She'd been working for years, and that was her first show on Broadway. It opened and closed. She couldn't keep going; she went back to Ohio to start a new life. She was a talented, beautiful, incredible dancer. But over the long haul it just got too hard."
Mr. MacKenzie rehearses regularly with Wayne Barker, his accompanist for a nightclub act, and has now put together four acts that include bits like George Gershwin sung in French and parodies of Harry Connick Jr. and Garth Brooks. "I've kept my club act," he said. "I can do that anywhere."
Why keep going?
"I love the process," Mr. MacKenzie said. "I started because I love to sing. But I love the nuts and bolts of acting and creating life out of words on a stage. Theater pays you back in the satisfaction of doing something well, working on a great piece. It pays you back when the audience responds.
"This is your calling," he added. "And if you want it, no one else is going to do it. Nobody will come along and say, 'Oh, a new star.' I realize that I love this. I always just wanted to be a working actor. That's always been the most important thing -- the work."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE COLLECTED STORIES OF LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Nineteen stories, the oldest from the 1940's, by a writer unfashionably and passionately concerned with the beliefs and behavior of the WASP civilization that until very recently produced America's ruling class.
 
D.H. LAWRENCE: The Story of a Marriage, by Brenda Maddox. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Lawrence's violent life with the formidable Frieda Weekley, who bedded him 20 minutes after she met him, makes for absorbing if unappetizing reading.
 
THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A Complete History, by Martin Gilbert. (Holt, $35.) Mr. Gilbert's enormous breadth of view seeks to render this dreadful conflict as soldiers lived it on many fronts, often relying on the poetry and prose of the many gifted writers who saw action.
 
GENTLEMAN SPY: The Life of Allen Dulles, by Peter Grose. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $30.) A biography, full of new information, of the irresistibly charming (and manipulative) man who headed -- and embodied -- the Central Intelligence Agency from 1953 to 1961.
 
IN PHARAOH'S ARMY: Memories of the Lost War, by Tobias Wolff. (Knopf, $23.) The follow-up volume to Mr. Wolff's memoir "This Boy's Life" is a series of small, elegant, personal sketches of his year in Vietnam.
 
THE LAST SHOT: City Streets, Basketball Dreams, by Darcy Frey. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Mr. Frey examines the myth of deliverance through basketball on the courts of Coney Island, where black youths compete to be exploited by coaches, colleges and, in the rarest cases, by professional sports.
 
LOST PURITAN: A Life of Robert Lowell, by Paul Mariani. (Norton, $27.50.) This approach to the "real" character of a protean confessional poet uses letters and diaries to reveal a writer whose fascination with preachers, statesmen and generals hints at restlessness with his own art.
 
THE MASTER OF PETERSBURG, by J.M. Coetzee. (Viking, $21.95.) The hero of Mr. Coetzee's grimmest novel yet is Dostoyevsky himself, trapped in generational and political clashes, trying to scrape meaning from the death of a son.
 
MONSTERS OF THE SEA, by Richard Ellis. (Knopf, $30.) A delightful and learned adventure in cryptozoology (the study of hidden life forms, including the leviathan, the sea serpent, the kraken, the blob and the globster).
 
TOULOUSE-LAUTREC: A Life, by Julia Frey. (Viking, $34.95.) A valuable life of the only great painter of France's golden age who was an aristocrat, incorporating much family correspondence recently made available.
 
WHERE THE SUCKERS MOON: An Advertising Story, by Randall Rothenberg. (Knopf, $25.) A lively rendition, by a former advertising columnist for The Times, of real life at an agency that tried to sell cars by ridiculing ads for cars.
