SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2964 words

HEADLINE: 2 SoHo Blocks: A Landmarks Notebook

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
FOR Spalding Gray, it's the cobblestones.
"When I come back from traveling and take a cab home," said the actor, writer and longtime resident of SoHo, "the cobblestones on the street give me the sense of returning to a place that's old, that has character, that has history, that has a name. That's so important to me."
He is not alone. It is more than two decades since the Landmarks Preservation Commission, on Aug. 14, 1973, designated 26 blocks of SoHo -- from Crosby Street to West Broadway and from Canal to Houston Street -- as a historic district. The designation has preserved the neighborhood's notable 19th-century cast-iron architecture. It even led to the reintroduction of such amenities as the Belgian block cobblestone so beloved by Mr. Gray, the rectangular granite stones, so redolent of roadbeds past, with which parts of Mercer and Greene Streets were repaved several years ago. 
 A look at the effects of designation on two blocks of Wooster Street, from Grand to Spring Street, shows that residents, landlords, store owners and representatives of community organizations give both the designation -- and the landmarks agency, whose approval is required for any changes to building exteriors in the district -- largely positive reviews.
There are complaints that renovations according to landmarks guidelines sometimes take too long and cost too much, that bureaucracy can create delays and that the increased price tag sometimes keeps owners from upgrading deteriorating facades. There is concern about owners who violate landmarks guidelines and about the difficulty the city has in enforcing the regulations. And there is a desire to plant trees in the neighborhood, an idea that the commission has questioned.
There is also mention, positive and negative, of the important role landmarking has played in SoHo's booming economic development, the neighborhood's transformation to a busy tourist and shopping area, a change that has caused chagrin among many residents, including Mr. Gray.
But there is also praise for the commission's often nonbureaucratic tendencies, its ability to make relatively fast decisions. The new owners of 42 and 46 Wooster Street, two long-vacant adjacent buildings just south of Broome Street, have nothing but accolades for the commission's cooperation in their plans to rescue from demolition and restore two currently shabby-looking examples of the glories of cast iron.
And in general, there is agreement that without the historic district, things would have been very different, and not nearly as good, south of Houston.
"A LOT of people say they don't like landmarking," said Sean Sweeney, chairman of the SoHo Alliance, a neighborhood organization, and a member of the landmarks committee of Community Board No. 2. "They complain that the whole rigamarole and the bureaucracy is a pain in the neck. But I think landmarking is a good thing. It increases property values. And it definitely improves the neighborhood. If it weren't for the historic district we'd be getting a lot of tacky buildings here. Broadway for instance, with all its retail stores, might look more like a suburban mall."
Margot Gayle, the founder of Friends of Cast-Iron Architecture and a crucial figure in the lobbying that helped established the district, put it this way: "Without landmarking, a lot of SoHo wouldn't be there at all."
"There was great pressure at the time," she recalled, "to tear much of it down and build a big public housing project like the one in Co-op City."
SoHo has not always been a choice destination. In the early part of the 19th century, the section of Manhattan north of Canal Street and south of Houston Street was given the name Hell's Hundred Acres, for the many fires that began in its warren of warehouses and small factories.
After a brief period in the 1850's that featured an elegant shopping district along Broadway, the area became a center of light industry, known for its furriers and doll, rag and box makers, all housed in Palladian or Italianate warehouses and factories built between 1860 and 1900 and featuring cast iron as a prime building material.
Over the years, though, little note was taken of the design of the closely spaced buildings. In 1959, the City Club of New York issued a report calling that part of town a slum and declaring that its architecture was of no significance.
But Ms. Gayle and other preservationists felt differently, and their views prevailed. Fourteen years after the City Club report, in designating as a historic district much of the neighborhood that had come to be known as SoHo (for South of Houston Industrial Area), the landmarks commission extolled its architecture, saying it contained "the largest concentration of full and partial cast-iron facades anywhere in the world."
In the intervening years, as manufacturers left the city, groups of artists, attracted by the neighborhood's low rents and its large, underutilized loft spaces, had begun moving into SoHo (at first illegally, because the area was not zoned for residential use). They were turning the once-desolate section -- which comprises about 40 blocks, including the 26 of the district -- into the lively and trendy center for art and artists of many kinds -- visual, performance, cinematic, musical -- that it remains today.
EARLIER this year, in the southern part of the historic district, the landmarks commission had a problem. It involved 46 Wooster Street, a six-story Romanesque cast-iron structure built in 1895 and designed by the architect F. S. Baldwin. The building had been vacant for more than 15 years, and the top two floors had collapsed after a construction crew replaced some beams.
The Department of Buildings issued an unsafe-building notice against the property, and the owner at the time, Simon Elias, whose renovation plans had been derailed by the real-estate recession and who was concerned about any further collapse, sought to have the building torn down.
A compromise, though, was reached with the commission, which agreed to allow Mr. Elias to remove just the top three floors. Then new developers came along interested in 46 and its next-door neighbor, 42 Wooster Street, an 1883 cast-iron building designed by Jarvis Morgan Slade that had been vacant for more than 12 years.
"We decided to ask him to hold up on demolition," Tony Leichter, co-developer with Dr. Axel Stawski (whose buildings include 565 and 579 Fifth Avenue) and Charles Blaichman. "We decided to go informally to the commission and see if they would be interested in our attempting to save the top three floors of the building and if they would work with us on the use changes we required to make it financially feasible. They seemed to indicate they would work with us."
Mr. Leichter and his partners worked with Brian E. Hogg, the deputy director of preservation, and with Jennifer J. Raab, the new commission chairwoman. Engineers studied the building's foundation and decided that it could be stabilized. In September, the commission approved a design for facade restoration.
The developers' plan involves 10,000 square feet of retail space and 50,000 square feet of residential space, for about 18 loft units. As part of the agreement the landmarks commission itself is applying to the City Planning Commission for a modification-of-use permit for joint living-work quarters and for retail space under Section 74-711 of the Zoning Resolution. The section gives landmarks very wide discretion to apply to the Planning Commission for modifications of use and bulk.
"I'M really excited about this project," Ms. Raab said. "This application gave us a chance to make preservation come to life by bringing a building back to life, by providing artists' residences and workplaces. Section 74-711 is very useful, because it allows us to say to another city agency that we believe there's a strong preservation purpose here and we support the applicant."
Lawrence B. Bogdanow, the architect for the project and a longtime SoHo resident, said the renovation would maintain the separate architectural identities of the two buildings, with each having its own access and egress.
"We will be restoring the original facades, cornices and architectural details of both buildings, with set-back penthouses added to both," Mr. Bogdanow said. "We will repair the masonry, mortar and terra cotta and replace virtually all the windows. In addition, at 46 we plan to add an atrium that will descend five floors down from the roof, with a terrace at the fifth floor and an outdoor walkway around the atrium on the sixth. We will also have basically new storefronts, basing them on precedents in the neighborhood and what remains of the old storefronts."
Mr. Leichter said that he hoped the applications would be before the Planning Commission in January and that final approval would be received by summer. He added that he had nothing but praise for the landmark's commission's role in the process.
"I can't emphasize enough what a surprise it was to me as a developer to find a city agency that was so receptive and cooperative," he said. "My initial reaction was always that the fewer governmental agencies one has to deal with the better. But our experience was totally favorable."
There are more Wooster Street success stories. No. 84, an L-shaped seven-story building dating from 1895 that is also 134 Spring Street, was also the recipient of help from the commission under Section 74-711 as part of a renovation plan.
"A couple of years ago, a very large and elaborate metal cornice was in very bad condition," said Shael Shapiro, a SoHo architect who designed the restoration. "At one point we had to cover it to protect it from falling on the street."
The owner wanted to repair and restore it, Mr. Shapiro said, but the commission wanted the restoration to expensively reproduce the original sheet-metal form. The owner, he said, suggested a deal. There are certain restrictions on the use of ground-floor retail space in SoHo; one rule requires a special permit for retail usage in ground-floor space of more than 3,500 square feet in the section roughly west of Mercer Street and north of Broome Street. No. 84 has 7,500 square feet.
"So the owners basically agreed to restore the cornices in the original manner," Mr. Shapiro said, "and the landmarks commission agreed to apply on behalf of the owner under 74-711 to the Planning Commission to modify the zoning, so they could get more rent to make up for the cost of restoration."
Susan Penzner, the building's managing agent, said the project, which included other repairs and repainting of window trim to comply with landmarks regulations, cost about $750,000. "It was very costly," Ms. Penzner said, "but our building is quite beautiful on the outside now and we feel it was worth it."
No. 35 Wooster, south of Broome, is occupied these days by the Drawing Center, a prominent gallery with a beautifully restored facade. The five-story building, known as Lyall House, was originally a department store and is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. But in the early 1980's, it was the home of a rag baler and a futon retailer.
Then a developer, Affirmative Asset Group, took over and, with certification from the Federal Interior Department that allowed buyers to qualify for an investment tax credit for rehabilitation of a historic property, turned it into loft condominiums.
Not everyone, of course, cares about preservation. There are building owners in SoHo, and in other historic districts throughout the city, who ignore landmarks guidelines and make changes without consultation or approval. The commission has found that with its limited staff, enforcement is a problem. It can issue violation notices, but it is difficult to force people to remove the changes.
Ms. Raab, who was appointed in July, said she was hoping to change enforcement procedures. "I think we should be doing more effective enforcement and should consider moving to a system of fines for more egregious violations," she said. "But I think it only fair to first do a much better job of public information, education and accountability, making sure architects working in historic districts understand that our rules are the law."
THE agency's power comes into play if an owner wants to make other changes that require Buildings Department approval and a new certificate of occupancy. The owner will soon find that he cannot get the certificate unless the landmarks commission first signs off on the project, and the commission will not do so until the violations are corrected.
That is essentially what happened at 70 Wooster Street, between Broome and Spring Streets, when the owner sought to obtain a certificate of occupancy for the residential loft tenants in the building. The landmarks commission discovered violations issued in 1983 and 1985, apparently because a former retail tenant had made illegal alterations in the building's facade.
John Pasquale, the building's owner, said that until he filed his plans with the Buildings Department, he had had no knowledge of the violations. "Landmarks said we could do nothing until they were satisfied," Mr. Pasquale said.
Mr. Pasquale said he felt that "landmarks really dragged their feet" and that it took the commission more than year "to get it together." The delay, he said, caused him to miss deadlines, "and I can't get a mortgage to do the improvements; I have to take the money out of pocket, because the bank won't give a mortgage without a certificate
of occupancy." Ms. Raab said she could not comment on the process in Mr. Pasquale's case because it predated her arrival. But she added that she was "very committed to moving projects through the process expeditiously, in a way that does not discourage developers from investing in New York."
Now at 70 Wooster Street, the landmarks guidelines are being met. And Mr. Shapiro, who is also the architect for its nearly complete partial restoration -- which includes the storefront, the first two floors and a new cornice on the second floor -- said he felt that the landmarks requirements will, when work is completed, "make a significant impact on what was an eyesore on that block and turn it into quite a nice storefront."
"It's a good example of landmarking improving things," he said. "It's a case in which because there had been a violation, and because new work was proposed, the commission was able to say, 'You've got to remove that violation.' "
And even Mr. Pasquale agreed that despite his difficulties, "as a whole landmarking has to improve the area."
Bill Downey, an artist and a resident of 80 Wooster, a seven-story former warehouse that was by all accounts the first artists' cooperative conversion in SoHo, said he understood why some people objected. "It's another layer of bureaucracy," Mr. Downey said, "although compared to other city agencies they're actually relatively efficient and certainly more courteous. But it becomes another hurdle if you're doing anything as simple as painting a building, because unless you paint it the same color you have to get their approval."
"They're not the world's most practical people," he added. "It appears they never take into consideration how much things cost. Once when we had a little minor painting done on the front of the building landmarks wanted to have somebody approve the color of the grout."
BUT Ms. Raab said that money was on the commission's mind: "Our staff can often make suggestions to an applicant of ways to be appropriate and to do something economically."
Some SoHo residents feel that the commission's insistence on adherence to tradition can inhibit experimentation and creativity.
"It can have a chilling effect on architecture," said Jim Clayburgh, a designer and member of Wooster Group, a theatrical troupe that works out of the Performing Garage at 33 Wooster Street (where Spalding Gray began creating the monologues for which he is best known). Mr. Clayburgh said that because of landmarking, his group had not "even attempted to realize some of the things we wanted, particularly installing a marquee with an air-conditioning system above it, because we knew it wouldn't be approved."
Ms. Raab said, though, that there was room in landmarking for an architect's vision. She cited as examples Mr. Bogdanow's plan for 42 and 46 Wooster Street and the Smith-Miller and Hawkinson Architects' 141 Wooster Street, north of Prince Street, "a simple, elegant, creative and contemporary interpretation of the cast-iron esthetic of the area."
Despite the criticisms, landmarking basically gets good reviews, especially for what it has prevented.
"You only have to look at West Broadway," said Mr. Bogdanow, the architect for 42 Wooster. "The cast-iron district ends on the east side of West Broadway. The west side of the street is not landmarked, and two new buildings stand out like sore thumbs because they have nothing to do with the rest of the district."
Mr. Downey of 80 Wooster said many longtime residents miss the old days of SoHo, "when it was actually quiet down here at the end of a workday, when it was living in the country and there was a real sense of community.
But, said Ms. Gayle, the preservationist who championed the original designation: "You can't have it both ways. You can't have great economic success and a magnet for tourism from people around the world and make it a cozy and quiet place."
And a magnet it remains. "Something about SoHo draws people to the place," said Mr. Leichter, the co-developer of 42 and 46 Wooster. There's a feeling of cohesiveness, a feeling of excitement." And a feeling of history, of cast iron in all the right places.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: New Downtown Study;
An Updating For Brooklyn

 BODY:
The Regional Plan Association, which 11 years ago created a blueprint that spurred a surge of development in downtown Brooklyn, has been called upon again to create an outline for the area's growth.
H. Claude Shostal, president of the R.P.A., said that that much has changed in downtown Brooklyn since the association's last plan was released in 1983. 
 "The MetroTech Center has had a major impact," he said. "And there is a huge amount of high-tech infrastructure that wasn't there.
Mr. Shostal also noted that the demographics of the downtown Brooklyn have changed over the last decade.
"Iit is a much more diverse population than it used to be," he said.
The R.P.A.'s new plan will include recommendations for improving urban design and transportation as well as stimulating retail activity and institutional cooperation.
Mr. Shostal said that plans generally cover 10 to 25 years, and the new plan will cost $130,000. It will be funded with a combination of public and private funds, including $35,000 from the Borough President and $50,000 from the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
"As business people, we understand the importance of long-range planning," said Robert Bailey, president of the Downtown Brooklyn Development Association and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, which, along with the Borough President's office, requested the study.
The 65-year-old R.P.A. is a non-profit research organization that helps develop programs to improve the quality of life in the tri-state area.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Setting A Price Limit

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
WHEN shoppers go out to buy a car or a microwave oven or a TV set they don't automatically go for the top of the line, even if they can afford to do so.
But when it comes to buying a home, brokers rarely ask how much you want to spend. Rather, they assume you will spend the most you can afford, based upon income and assets. They may even pull out charts that show how you can stretch that limit if you're willing to consider, say, a variable-rate mortgage. 
 By doing so they are playing on a sensitive nerve in American culture that suggests it is inconceivable for someone to actually set their sights lower than their purse permits.
For a home is more than simply shelter. It makes a statement about the owner's financial means and status in life. And few people want to look less successful than they really are.
Conspiring to keep this ideal alive is the fact that virtually everyone connected with the transaction -- from the salesperson to the title company -- is compensated on a formula based upon purchase price. So it's not in their financial interest to even raise the notion of settling for less.
In fact, certain brokers are known to ignore a self-imposed ceiling, taking a prospective buyer to see costlier homes in the hope they can tempt them upwards. They insist this is because the buyers are often disappointed by what they get at the price they initially decided to pay.
"If you can afford $550,000 and you say you will only spend $400,000 you usually end up paying around $475,000," said Barbara Mulrooney, manager of the office of Coldwell Banker Schlott Realtors in the Tara Hotel in Stamford, Conn.
But it doesn't have to be that way. David Donnelly, chief financial officer for the Mount Vernon Hospital in Westchester County, decided recently to spend no more than $265,000 for a colonial in Ringwood, N.J., when he could have gone as high as $325,000. Despite attempts to show him more expensive homes, he said, he stuck firmly to his self-created maximum by selecting the broker who really did take him at his word.
The limiting factor in his case was the specter of imminent college costs for three daughters that included two 14-year-old twins. "I wanted to save the difference for school," he said. By capping his monthly housing overhead at $2,200 rather than $3,000 -- the maximum he had been told he could afford -- he figured he could save at least $800 a month without too much difficulty.
When Jeff Binder and Stephanie Maxwell purchased a four-bedroom Tudor in Montclair, N.J., in September in a move from a much smaller condominium, they held to their limit by constantly reminding themselves of all the furniture they would need and how, if they paid any more, they would lose the chance to make even minor alterations. "And there's always something you want to change," said Mr. Binder.
Expressions like "house poor" and "living to pay the mortgage" didn't enter popular usage for nothing. They're manifestations of a frustration -- often discovered too late in the day -- concerning all the other costs that tend to pile up: decorating, heating, cooling, cleaning, landscaping, repairs and taxes -- all of which rise as the house or the lot grow larger and more expensive.
No wonder financial advisers are beginning to advise clients that less is often more in terms of overall fiscal health, especially at a time when values are not leaping upwards, property taxes are rising and jobs are being lost.
Marcia Levy, manager of the Montclair office of Burgdorff Realty, is already seeing more of these buyers. She maintains its also a symptom of a pervasive anxiety, articulated in the November elections, that life is not getting any easier for most people.
"They're afraid to max out," she said, noting that some also talk of friends who stretched to the limit at the height of the 80's market only to slip into foreclosure during the economic turndown of the early 90's.
Evelyn Atanas, president of Atanas Realty of Williston Park, L.I., has found similar resistance recently among buyers moving from Suffolk County where property taxes lately have been "going through the sky," she said.
Others refusing to get caught up in the buy-the-most fantasy, she said, are young couples eager to base their budget on just one income. They say they prefer to be in a position where one parent can stay home while the children are small. The recent upward spurt in interest rates has created an added level of conservatism, she said.
Buyers wishing to settle for less should weigh a variety of different methods they can use to scale back. They include looking in a less costly neighborhood, buying a home that needs work or might be suitable for later expansion and making a larger-than-necessary down payment to keep the monthly mortgage costs low.
Making the larger down payment is the option of choice among conservative buyers at the high end said Vicky Papson, a senior mortgage consultant with Emigrant Mortgage Bank of Darien, Conn. She has found the idea particularly appealing to those of her Wall Street buyers facing the possibility of lower incomes and layoffs.
But it can also include anyone taking a large chunk of cash out of a former home, even though it's normally in a homeowner's best interest from a tax standpoint to put down no more than 20 percent on the next purchase.
Christopher Plaut, a lawyer, and Nancy Winkelstein, a psychiatric social worker, decided they would rather trade size than location. "The two most important things for us were neighborhood and commute," said Mr. Plaut.
So instead of giving up Larchmont, N.Y., for a less costly area, they stayed in the community but confined their search to three-bedroom homes with asking prices around $275,000 instead of four-bedroom homes at $380,000. "We really didn't need that much space right away," said Mr. Plaut.
This way, they reasoned, they could also continue to save for retirement, enjoy expensive vacations and put money aside for their children's education or simply as a nest egg. "It makes us more relaxed," continued Mr. Plaut. "And if I ever want to switch careers and take a job with lower pay I can. That's a very nice feeling."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Tenant Complaints Activate Heavy State Machinery

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
WHEN tenants file a complaint with New York State government over services or conditions in their rent-regulated apartment or building, they probably do not say to themselves, "This is a complaint-driven system."
That is the expression state officials use to describe the task of handling complaints within the Office of Rent Administration of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal. It is a thankless task, though government may not be displeased with that, since it positions itself as an intermediary force in what many New Yorkers seem to believe is an inherent antagonism between tenants and landlords. 
 But after 10 years of experience with state administration of the New York City rent-regulated housing stock it seems safe to conclude that the price of fairness, if such it is, is administrative gridlock. It takes very little to initiate a case -- filing a complaint costs nothing -- but it can take years to conclude it.
Small owners can be overwhelmed by the process and many tenants are frustrated by slow results. Because of rent-reduction orders, an untold amount of rent money is permanently lost by owners, even when housing deficiencies are corrected.
With George E. Pataki, a Republican, replacing Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, as Governor in January and a new leadership due to take over at the state's housing agency, the management of rent regulation is likely to get a fresh look. Republicans are less likely than Democrats to embrace the rigorous regulatory system now in effect. But that doesn't mean they will find reform a simple task.
The handling of tenant complaints over services and conditions is merely one aspect of the system -- separate, for example, from the system that handles overcharge complaints. It is run by the Service Compliance Owner-Restoration Enforcement Bureau, or Score, formerly known as the Tenants Services Complaint Bureau. The operation demonstrates the scale and stunning complexity of regulatory practice.
"While we've made progress, after 10 years we're still not on top of the caseload on tenant complaints," said Lula M. Anderson, the deputy housing commissioner in charge of the Office of Rent Administration, who previously had the job of running the Score section.
The state regulates 1.12 million rental housing units, all but about 50,000 of them in New York City. The cost is about $35 million a year, $11.5 million of it paid by owners and the rest by taxpayers. The Office of Rent Administration has a staff of 640.
Before state takeover in 1984, New York City had about 350 employees handling the rent-controlled (or pre-World War II) housing stock, and the quasi-public Conciliation and Appeals Board had 120 employees dealing with the rent-stabilized stock (postwar rentals, or prewar apartments with a tenancy turnover since 1971).
Last year the state office handled nearly 290,000 requests for assistance, with 223,000 coming over the telephone and 66,700 from appearances at a district rent office.
Tenant service complaints to the Score Bureau are made on forms available at district rent offices. They can lead to significant rent reductions. In a rent-stabilized apartment, even seemingly minor housing infractions lead by law to the loss of an entire rent-guideline increase once the infraction is confirmed by a state inspection. If the infraction is in a public space, the guideline increase can be lost for the entire building.
OWNERS may of course apply for a rent restoration. They usually contend that the alleged deficiency had been corrected prior to the inspector's arrival. The inspection comes three months to a year after the owner receives notice of a tenant's complaint, the agency says. Owners are not informed when the inspection will occur and are not allowed to attend it.
If deficiencies lead to an order of rent reduction and the owner chooses to challenge it, the owner may file a "petition for administrative review" and usually does. Tenants may also file for a review.
The dispute can go on for five years or more. The number of pending petitions for administrative review in the Office of Rent Administration at the end of last year stood at 20,800. There were 5,700 pending in the Score Bureau alone. The Overcharge Bureau had 5,800 pending cases.
Other petitions for administrative review concern actions by bureaus regulating owner applications for rent increases after building improvements are made, and rent levels in New York City rent-controlled apartments or controlled or stabilized apartments outside the city.
The normal wait for a decision in a petition for administrative review on a Score case is three years. Unwilling to wait that long, owners often go to court, demanding to have their petition "deemed denied" so they can challenge the rent-reduction order in court. The rent agency has no figures on what percentage of rent-reduction orders wind up in court.
Aside from the appeals caseload, there is a big complaint caseload awaiting action. In Score, 19,500 cases were pending at the end of last year. The largest category -- 8,800 cases -- concerned conditions within the apartment, such as leaky faucets and broken windows.
There are 15 inspectors to view these conditions. The inspection follows a notice to the owner, who gets 20 days to respond. It takes inspectors three to nine months to get to an apartment, the agency says. In 1993 there were 7,300 new complaints about apartment conditions and 1,600 about buildingwide conditions.
Half the complaints are dismissed after inspection, either because the condition has been corrected or didn't exist, or because the inspector could not get into the apartment after two visits. The otrher half get rent-reduction orders.
The average processing time for a tenant's complaint (from date of filing to the date an order is issued) is 13 months. The average time it takes for an owner to get an Order of Rent Restoration after the rent has been cut but the service has been found to be restored is 20 months.
Owners say that lost rent is often never recovered. The collection of lost rent can take effect only upon a re-inspection that confirms a restoration of services. But the process takes so long, owners say, that many tenants will have moved before retroactive increases can be collected. The restoration order in fact often precipitates a departure, they say.
Moreover, the re-inspection often comes so long after the owner's application that the same condition -- peeled paint or damaged flooring or a dirty hallway -- may have recurred to nullify a rent restoration.
In one recent situation, a stabilized apartment on Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn lost its 1994 guideline increase on the following grounds: "Vermin control, apartment; toilet bowl; living-room floor-baseboards; buzzer." Whether the conditions are flagrant or not is not clear from the notice. It is also irrelevant to rent loss.
In another case, a buildingwide reduction was ordered at a 36-unit building on 191st Street in Flushing because of "water leaks skylight; floor covering stairs; vermin control public area."
In rent-controlled apartments, the rent reductions are for specific amounts for specific service deficiencies. On Morris Avenue in the Bronx, one tenant's rent was lowered $6 a month for a defective intercom; $5 for a stair-rail condition; $3 for "paint-plaster bulkhead," and $6 for "paint-plaster hall."
The rent agency has tried to nip service disputes in the bud with a voluntary mediation service. A pilot program began March 1. When there is goodwill on both sides, mediation has been workable. But often there is hostility and a mistrust of motivation.
A case in point involves an apartment in an eight-unit co-op at 161 President Street in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. The tenant in one of four sponsor-owned rental apartments in the building filed for a rent reduction in 1987 over allegedly inadequate painting. The sponsor then painted, and obtained an affidavit from the painter that the tenant had denied access to portions of the apartment.
The apartment was re-inspected 17 months later. The painting was found inadequate. Rent restoration was denied. Now the sponsor has gone to court. The tenant continues to pay only $500 a month instead of would otherwise be a rent of nearly $800. The sponsor says the tenant has filed a new complaint on deficient painting.
According to Harriet Thompson-Shand, a lawyer in Brooklyn who formerly worked for the rent agency and now represents small owners in real-estate matters, it is not possible for many non-English-speaking owner-managers to handle the procedures of rent administration. "Often they buy buildings that are riddled with rent-regulation problems and find they have to have perfect records going back 10 years or they'll lose part of the rent roll," she said.
IN Queens, Dorette Gallan, a broker who handles paperwork for some 200 small owners of six-family houses, mainly in Astoria, makes the same point. "Many of them are self-taught plumbers and painters who want to do the improvement work themselves, but they often can't get rent increases for it because they can't show paper to prove the work was done," she said.
But in a report called "Rent Regulation After 50 Years," the Division of Housing and Community Renewal last September identified the privately owned rental housing stock as part of the inventory of housing that government has a responsibility to maintain as "decent, affordable" rental housing, while assuring owners an "adequate return on investment" and safeguarding tenants from "burdensome rent increases."
These goals are far-reaching and perhaps contradictory. The usual way in which government assures affordable housing for renters of modest income is to subsidize the difference between the economic cost of providing the housing and the tenants' ability to pay.
The state does just that in several affordable-housing programs. But the regulatory system for privately owned buildings operates mainly as a counterweight to landlord power, needed, in theory, because a housing shortage gives them too much leverage. Many owners would be surprised to learn that it is also supposed to function as a way to sustain the quality of the housing product.
Already 33 percent of the privately owned rental apartments in New York City are unregulated. Their tenants are not without protection on habitability issues. New York City must enforce the multiple-dwelling code, and Housing Court enforces the Warranty of Habitability law.
The probability is that the quality of the 54 percent of rental units that remain regulated would be enhanced in the long run if they were deregulated at the time of a tenancy turnover. In the meantime, state regulation has come to mean a heavyhanded system of regulation in the name of tenant protection.

HEADLINE: Juggling the Needs of Taxpayers and the Poor

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
KNOWN as Rose City, Norwich was a flourishing industrial center at the turn of the century. But when Beverly Goulet, who was born and raised in Norwich, returned to her home town in 1985 after a 20-year absence, she was shocked to find empty storefronts and factory buildings and lines of people outside the welfare office. She watched as members of her family lost their jobs.
"I was taken aback when I returned to a community where the urban centers had been thriving," Ms. Goulet said. "The factories went South, and we never replaced those manufacturing jobs. It should be no surprise that we're in this situation now. We haven't invested in human capital in this country for a great many years. Now people are looking for quick fixes." 
 Ms. Goulet, now director of social services for the City of Norwich, is one of many local and state officials struggling to come up with a plan to cut the cost of welfare and at the same time enable a growing number of poor and jobless people in Connecticut to become self-sufficient.
Debate continues over a plan to turn municipal welfare over to the state to ease the financial and administrative burdens on cities and towns. Pilot projects aimed at getting people off state welfare and back to work have been started in New Haven and Manchester. The worry is that there may not be enough jobs to absorb those ready for employment. And the City of Bridgeport, adopting a state law passed two years ago, is cutting welfare benefits after nine months for able-bodied people. Legal aid groups have challenged the law.
After the November elections that swept Republicans into control in Congress, both parties are promising to cut benefits and put welfare recipients to work. President Clinton's plan would require people who receive Aid to Families With Dependent Children for more than two years to join a work program or accept a government-subsidized job. States would be allowed to place a cap on family welfare benefits.
But Ms. Goulet said she disagrees with that approach. "How do we get people in leadership positions to see the bigger picture?" she said. "This is about poverty. It's about unemployment. A check is not the answer. For every seven people on welfare in Connecticut, there is only one job available. Those same people have to compete with the newly unemployed who are better trained. People still don't want to face the facts."
Bridgeport reduced its welfare rolls under a 1992 state law that allows the cutoff of benefits for able-bodied people (they can re-apply after 90 days) and limits a community's obligation to shelter homeless people. Since the law was passed two years ago, 72 communities have imposed the nine-month limit on welfare benefits, said Carolanne Curry, a project director with the City of Bridgeport Welfare Department. Connecticut Legal Services Inc., a nonprofit organization that provides legal assistance to low-income people, challenged the law in court, as did the New Haven Legal Assistance Association after the city closed a homeless shelter. The state Supreme Court is expected to issue decisions on the two cases within the next few months.
Advocates for the poor argue that the Connecticut Constitution requires state and local government to provide basic care for the poor. Lawyers for the state maintain that the constitution does not guarantee welfare benefits despite the fact that Connecticut laws involving care for the indigent date back to the 1600's.
The Connecticut Alliance for Basic Human Needs, a nonpartisan group campaigning for welfare reform, argues that the assumption that people stay on welfare for years and thus a time limit is needed is wrong. Studies show that nearly three-quarters of new A.F.D.C. clients leave the rolls within two years. Furthermore, the waiting list for Connecticut's education and job training program numbers about 20,000, and people complain that they must wait up to two years for education or training.
Also mistaken is the assumption that people are poor because they lack a work ethic, the alliance states. The real reason they are poor is that they lack jobs with good wages. An estimated 40 percent of A.F.D.C. participants have some work history, but the jobs they held do not pay a living wage, offer benefits or provide long-term security. As a result, many people alternate work with welfare as the economy expands and contracts.
Nine studies in other states of the effects of eliminating or reducing General Assistance, which deals primarily with single adults, found that clients fared significantly worse after the cuts, said Irene Glasser, a professor in the department of sociology and anthropology at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic.
Although the cuts were aimed at welfare recipients ready for employment, Ms. Glasser said, the labor market did not absorb most of those people. Instead, they were forced to rely on shelters and soup kitchens for survival, and the clients' overall health and ability deteriorated.
There were 12,400 people on General Assistance in Connecticut in 1988-89. By 1991-92, as unemployment rose, the number had risen to about 32,600.
The Connecticut Association of Local Administrators of General Assistance supports the idea of spreading the cost of local welfare more equally, since the poorest cities and towns with the highest case loads pay the greatest amount. But it opposes the General Assembly's moves during the last two years to shift General Assistance from the municipalities to the state.
Local welfare directors, who understand their communities and residents, do not trust the state to deal properly with clients. "We care about the communities in which we work," the association said in a report asking that the issue be given another look. "We fear that the present course will leave them in a worse position than they are at present."
The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, an organization of town and city officials, favors either turning General Assistance over to the state or reimbursing all local costs. "Instead, takeover has been put off, and reimbursements have been cut," the manager of legislative services for the group, Gian-Carlo Casa, said.
In 1992, the General Assembly provided that the state assume the administration of General Assistance beginning July 1, 1994. But in 1993, it delayed the plan for two years. And Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s tentative 1995-96 budget proposed a further delay until 1998 and elimination of employable people from city welfare rolls by next year.
Meanwhile, under a program, called A Fair Chance, which attempts to remove some of the obstacles that prevent people from becoming independent, welfare recipients who work are allowed to keep more of their income and education, job training and opportunities for child care are being expanded.
Pathways, the first of the program's two pilot projects, places a two-year limit on benefits for randomly selected A.F.D.C. recipients in New Haven and Manchester. During the first two years, according to the plan, welfare recipients get help seeking jobs, and those who are not prepared receive education and training. At the end of two years, they are required to take a job or participate in work-related activities. Pathways also establishes a child support assurance system, which guarantees parents a monthly payment under certain guidelines.
The second pilot project, Family Strength, provides, among other things, an increase in the limit on A.F.D.C. clients' assets from $1,000 to $3,000, excluding the value of one non-luxury car. In addition, families may qualify for A.F.D.C. even if both parents are in the home.
"We were concerned that the message we sent out was that it wasn't good to have both parents in the home," said Nancy Wiggett, manager of the family support team for the state's Department of Social Services. "We'd much rather send a message that if the parents want to be together but are having financial trouble, we will help them."
While Family Strength is offered statewide, it will be tested only in New Haven and Manchester. Pathways, also being tested only in the two cities, can be expanded to other sites if it is successful. The social services department will run the seven-year projects.
"It's not just changing programs. It means changing a culture for both our staff and clients," Ms. Wiggett said. "Under the old program, the culture was to make sure people had the right amount of money, and then they were left on their own. Now there is more emphasis on encouraging people to go to work, even if they can't right now. The message of combining work with welfare for a while is a new one to clients and the staff."
Paul Russillo, program supervisor in the Manchester office of the social services department, said "If clients get the necessary training, they can at least go out and compete in the job market and find something. Maybe the best some people will get is a job that pays minimum wage or a little higher. Others may never be totally independent."
In that case, Mr. Russillo said, "We'll give them only a partial check. So, there's still some savings."
Sixty percent of the 750 welfare clients cut from Bridgeport's rolls last April, or about 450 people, are back on welfare for various reasons. The city takes a group of people off the rolls every month. New applicants for welfare are told that their benefits will be stopped after nine months. "But we tell them we'll work with them to get them into permanent employment. In nine months, we expect to do that," Ms. Curry added.
The city formed a partnership in 1992 with businesses and training schools in greater Bridgeport that offers job training for welfare clients. Those who complete the courses successfully are offered employment. More than 800 of the city's 2,200 able clients have been placed in permanent jobs in road construction, automobile repair and rehabilitation of blighted properties, Ms. Curry said. "There is work in the trades," she added. "We put clients into 16 or 17 apprentice programs."
The city provides clients with transportation to work for about 60 days, and social workers and employment counselors instruct them in personal hygiene and workplace behavior. "Individual attention is important," Ms. Curry said, "so that we can spot alcohol, day care or other family problems. Working with a small number enables us to see what the problems are."
As Ms. Curry describes the current mood, in which welfare money is considered money owed: "There is a drive to have some sort of accountability for the money loaned, and there is resentment for the money loaned. We try to let our welfare population know these changes are coming down."

HEADLINE: Off Welfare, and Into Self-Employment

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
SUSAN MAYBIN, who is divorced, held three or four jobs at once to support herself and her five children. Then she burned out. "I worked seven days a week," said Ms. Maybin, who lives in Norwich. "I realized my children were lacking a mother. I became overwhelmed and had to stop working."
Still, she held on to her dream of someday starting a nonprofit agency, a sort of extended family that would provide people who care for others with parenting classes, support groups, help with money management and child care and job information. "You have to have a stable domestic front if you want to pursue a career and get off welfare," Ms. Maybin said. 
 After years of experience as a counselor for rape victims, pregnant teen-agers and people with schizophrenia, Ms. Maybin felt she had the tools to start her own business.
A phone call led her to the Entrepreneurial Center in Norwich, a branch of the center at Hartford College for Women, which prepares low-income people and welfare recipients for starting their own businesses. Skills sometimes taken for granted, like managing on a small income, being flexible and making the best use of limited resources, are the ones that make a good business owner, according to the center.
Founded in 1985 and funded by the state's Department of Economic Development, the center has a 50 percent success rate for graduates starting their own businesses, said the assistant director, Marge Blizard, who owns a housecleaning service. The center's 12-week course covers marketing and advertising, bookkeeping, taxes, legal issues, insurance, negotiating and sales techniques, balancing personal and business roles and establishing credit.
Members of the group who met recently in Norwich said the course is changing their lives. Deborah Sage, who lives in Colchester with her mother and two children, receives state welfare benefits. She also earns $180 a month working one day a week. After the state deducts her earnings from her cash and food stamp allotments, her earnings amount to $2 a month, she said. "It wasn't worth going to work," she said. Ms. Sage plans to start a business that provides personal services like bookkeeping, shopping and deliveries.
Gene Champagne of Ledyard was a carpenter before he was injured on the job and went on unemployment. Also a singer and song writer, Mr. Champagne is trying to find a place in southeastern Connecticut's tourism and entertainment business. "I want to become an owner, not a loaner," he said, referring to the idea that those getting public assistance owe it back in some sense.
George Hnatowicz of Bozrah was devastated after he was laid off from his welding and is living on I.O.U.'s, he said. "I figured I would have that job until I retired. It was an ending but also a beginning for me." Mr. Hnatowicz plans to run a grease removal service for restaurants.
Owning a business is not for everyone, Ms. Blizard said. A first step is a four-session self-assessment workshop to help would-be entrepreneurs decide whether they are suited to the role. "These people are motivated and self-directed," she said. And the community helps. A bank in the Norwich area has agreed to give one participant, Brendia Merchant, an unsecured loan to open a consignment clothing store. The Eastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce sets up meetings with members of the business community.
So far, 420 people have completed training at the Entrepreneurial Center, and there are plans to open a branch in Bridgeport in January, the director of the program, Donna Wertenbach, said. She is concerned, however, that under welfare reform programs self-employment may not be considered an acceptable alternative, that welfare recipients are expected to enter a work program after two years of benefits. "We're almost going back to square one to establish this as legitimate," Ms. Wertenbach said.
To members of the Norwich class, however, the point is simple: Each new business creates employment for others.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

WINTER HABITAT
 The waters off Norwalk have been chosen by some harbor seals as a nice place to spend the winter. Ever watchful for ways to keep the public in touch with the sea, the Maritime Center on North Water Street last year ran Creature Cruises to view the seals, and it will do so again every Sunday from Jan. 8 to March 26, weather permitting.
Sailing times aboard the research vessel Oceanic will vary with the tides, and since only one cruise will be offered each Sunday, reservations should be made early. 
 The seals, including some gray seals down from Maine and Canada, have increased in number to the point that last year about 40 of them were observed sunning themselves on the rocks and shoals at low tide.
Staff educators from the Maritime Center will provide commentary on the seals and on many winter birds to be seen along the way. Binoculars and warm clothes are strongly recommended. The fee is $15. One may call 852-0700, extension 206, for reservations or more information.
 
CHRISTMAS TREES
 Almost 100 members of Connecticut's Christmas Tree Growers Association are open for business, squiring customers around their tree farms, helping them cut a tree or cutting it for them. Every county in the state has a dozen or more tree farms listed in an Agriculture Department brochure, and a call to 566-3571 or 566-4845 will put customers in touch with the nearest one.
The state's Agriculture Department says the best way to buy a tree is fresh at the farm. Trees grown in Canada and Western states were cut at least a month earlier and shipped. There is the distinct possibility that they will shed needles long before the end of the holidays.
Among the oldest and largest of the cut-your-own farms is the 400-acre Jones Family Farm on Israel Hill Road in Shelton, where the tradition began 60 years ago. The first trees that were sold there in the 1930's were grown for a 4-H project that Philip Jones Jr. started in the backwoods of the family's dairy farm. The property was originally settled about 140 years ago by Philip James Jones, and the sixth generation, Jamie Jones, is now a horticulture major at Cornell University.
The farm, which is open daily until Christmas from 9 to 5:30, allows customers to cut their own trees. Large trees, hauled by a tree-tram and wrapped by the staff, cost around $40 with tax. Saws are available to borrow. Smaller trees, fresh cut and ready to take away, start at around $19, and there are living trees for sale as well, to plant in one's own backyard. Santa is in the barn from 1 to 5 each day, surrounded by a wide selection of wreaths and garlands and all the usual trappings of the holiday, and tree buyers get a pewter ornament to take home. Call 929-6235 for more information.
 
WREATHS AND FLOWERS
 Custom-made Christmas wreaths and holiday floral arrangements are available at Cricket Hill Garden in Thomaston. Kasha and David Furman, the owners, built their reputation on an exceptional array of Chinese tree peonies that bloom in the spring, but for the past few years they have added Christmas arrangements, turning the business into a sort of May-December affair.
Using real sugared fruit, lemons and oranges studded with cloves, roses, dendrobium orchids, holly, ivy, berries, as well as just about any material anyone wants, the establishment will dream up unusual wreaths, garlands, table centerpieces and arrangements for mantle pieces.
Some arrangements are on display and may be purchased, but "we like to have people come in and discuss their preferences," said Kasha Furman. "Sometimes they want to match the dining room wallpaper, or they are committed to a particular flower. It's hard to do over the phone." Prices range from $35 to $75, and a custom order takes about three days to complete. Delivery is possible at extra charge. More information: 283-1042 or 283-4707.
 
BUILDING BLOCKS
 An archway of giant blocks leading to a children's village of castles, bridges, towers, cabins and cottages will be on view in the main gallery at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center today from 1 to 5, Monday through Thursday from 9 to 5, and Friday from 9 to noon. Call 322-1646 for Christmas-week hours.
Covering a period from the mid-1800's to the present, the exhibition was put together from every kind of building block and interlocking construction set dear to the hearts of children of all ages.
A rare set of Crandall's Interlocking Blocks from 1867, Hill's Alphabet Blocks from 1858, and Richter's Anchor Blocks from 1900 are some of the golden oldies, while Bilt-E-Z and Legos form some of the 20th-century structures. In addition, an area has been set aside for children to create their own buildings.
The antique components are on loan from the Stamford Historical Society and several individual collectors, the contemporary blocks were provided by toy stores, and a child psychologist, Dr. Patricia Grimes, served as a consultant.
The museum is on Scofieldtown Road at the junction of High Ridge Road. Admission is $4, $3 for children 5 to 13 and older people, free for children under 5.
 
WORKING HISTORY
 A new limited edition print by Andrew N. Wyeth, titled "Millgirl at No. Four," was unveiled recently at the Windham Textile and History Museum in Willimantic, and will be for sale until the end of the year. One thousand prints, some of which have already been sold, are priced at $45 each.
The museum itself offers an unusual view of the history of the textile industry in Connecticut and the people who worked in the local mills throughout the Industrial Revolution and into this century. It is open to visitors at 157 Union-Main Street from Thursday through Sunday year round, noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $3, $2 for older people and students. More information: 456-2178.
 
GAY NETWORKING
 The Connecticut Business Guild, formed in April of this year as a statewide networking association for gay and lesbian business people will hold a holiday buffet dinner on Monday at 6:30 at Cafe 1150, 1150 Chapel Street in New Haven. Reservations cost $12 and may be made by calling 278-6666, extension 104.
The guild has 60 members, including lawyers, accountants, financial planners, travel agents, restaurateurs, retailers and people in the media. It has created a business-to-business directory as a first step in its commitment to promoting economic growth for its members.
Presentations for executives, professionals and business owners are planned throughout the year at meetings to be held in various parts of the state. Dues are $50 a year. The same phone number may be called for more information about the organization. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Social Studies Panel Hopeful Despite Delay

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
WHAT should students know after 12 years of social studies and how should they learn it? Members of a state-appointed committee, who spent nearly three years drafting a framework for a new social-studies curriculum, say they expect to save the core of a plan that failed to win the approval last month of the State Education Commissioner, Dr. Thomas Sobol.
Daniel Berman, chairman of the social studies department at Fox Lane High School in Bedford and the only county representative on the 18-member committee, said he felt "much better" about the framework's future since he and others met in Albany recently with Dr. Sobol and an assistant commissioner, Edward T. Lalor. 
 "It's not an issue of diversity," Mr. Berman said, referring to the multicultural aspects of the 120-page plan, which has not been made public. "The major need is to make sure the document is clearly understood by the public as well as by professionals in the field."
Contrary to published reports, Dr. Sobol will neither dissolve the Social Studies Committee nor discard the framework, said Christopher Carpenter, a spokesman for the Education Department. "In a nutshell, things will be added to it," Mr. Carpenter said, observing that the department had "studiously avoided any speculation" about specific changes. "Three social-studies-curriculum writers will work on it, and then it will go back to the committee," Mr. Carpenter said, adding that he expected the revisions to be completed by spring. The framework will be made public when it is presented to the State Board of Regents, which must approve all curriculum changes.
While many courses of study are being redesigned on a national level and by states, New York has had particular trouble with social studies. Two earlier efforts to revise the curriculum -- "The Curriculum of Inclusion" in 1989 and "One Nation, Many Peoples" in 1991 -- were rejected. "There has been enormous controversy in the past over this thing," Mr. Carpenter said. "People tend to tear away at this like a dog with a bone."
In writing its document, "The Social Studies Curriculum Framework," Mr. Berman said the committee grappled with eight "overarching goals" in the areas of American and world history, economics, political science, sociology, anthropology, geography, philosophy and psychology. He said the most controversial of the goals dealt with the ways Americans are "unified yet diverse" and how the multiple perspectives of blacks, women and other groups can be understood. "Do you teach the canon of the textbooks, or introduce real political perspective?" Mr. Berman said.
Mr. Berman said the committee's discussions reflected the national debate over the role that diverse viewpoints should play in education. "I think we found an excellent balance," he said of the committee's plan. "I think its not a radical document." In keeping with the state's Compact for Learning, a blueprint for educational reform, the committee was asked to devise a structure that would allow schools flexibility in carrying out the curriculum. Mr. Carpenter said that such an effort, in which frameworks rather than specific curriculums are adopted for different subjects, had never been undertaken before.
A separate debate about the framework concerns the elimination of economics and government as distinct half-year courses in 12th grade. In an effort to interconnect subject areas, Mr. Berman said the committee had recommended integrating those subjects into other social-studies courses, a move that Dr. Peter F. Bell, executive director of the State Council on Economic Education, said "would put back the cause of economic education about 10 years." He attributed the suggestion in part to the absence of anyone from the field of economics on the committee.
After the Board of Regents made economics mandatory in high school in 1986, the state council began a continuing series of workshops for social studies teachers, many of whom had only the slightest acquaintance with the subject. Partly state financed in the past, the council, based in Purchase, now operates with private funds to infuse economics into school programs as early as elementary school.
Dr. Bell, an associate professor who has taught economics at Purchase College for 22 years, said that only when schools were required to teach economics did they hire teachers with a background in the subject.
Steven A. Goldberg, president of the New York State Council for the Social Studies, said dropping economics as a mandate might wrongly suggest that the subject "is no longer important" for students. "It's clearly a controversial issue," said Mr. Goldberg. "But social studies always seems to be in the forefront of controversy."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Law Teacher Tutors The Owners on Perils That Might Lie Ahead

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When Richard Ravitch was chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York in the early 1980's, an outside counsel to the M.T.A. was Lewis Kaden. When Ravitch more recently was trying to induce major league club owners to agree to a revenue-sharing plan, he sought legal opinion on what voting requirement would be appropriate for the adoption of a plan. The lawyer he asked was Lewis Kaden.
Ravitch, who has resigned as the owners' chief labor executive, effective at the end of the year when his contract expires, was not at the owners' meeting in Chicago last Thursday, but Lewis Kaden was. 
 Kaden was there at the invitation of the Mets and the Toronto Blue Jays, two of the few opponents among the owners of the plan to declare an impasse in negotiations with the players and implement a salary cap. A well-known New York lawyer, Kaden also teaches labor and antitrust courses as an adjunct professor at Columbia Law School, a combination that made him peculiarly qualified to speak to the owners on matters most relevant to them.
Kaden addressed the owners on the perils they may face before the National Labor Relations Board as a result of their strategy in the fruitless negotiations.
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, declined to discuss Kaden's appearance, but another person who attended the meeting said, "He gave a good assessment of the risks."
Other people who were in the room offered a more comprehensive report of what the lawyer told the owners, all speaking on the condition they not be identified because, one said, "We had the riot act read to us about keeping quiet."
Kaden, they related, talked specifically about the complaint issued by the N.L.R.B. against the owners for their failure to make a $7.8 million pension payment Aug. 1 and generally about impasse and implementation.
If the board substantiates the pension complaint, Kaden was quoted as telling the owners, it could ultimately undermine their contention that they negotiated in good faith and truly had reached impasse. Proving that an impasse existed, he said, is as difficult as proving there wasn't an impasse, but he said the owners created uncertainty by not making the pension payment.
Warning of the potential risks of impasse/implementation, Kaden explained the potential antitrust ramifications if a court, in a lawsuit filed by the players, should hold that the antitrust exemption does not cover the owners' labor activity.
The players, Kaden said, have to overcome many obstacles to make their charges stick, but if they succeed, the owners would face such serious consequences -- he suggested the possibility of damages reaching hundreds of millions of dollars -- that they should evaluate the risks against the potential of the mediation route.
One of the risks they face, Kaden reminded the owners, is "joint and several liability," meaning if a monetary judgment were so great that some clubs couldn't pay their shares, the unpaid shares would accrue to those clubs that could pay.
One person who related Kaden's remarks said he appeared to be troubled by the direction the owners are headed. But 25 owners apparently preferred the advice of their lawyers. They voted for impasse and implementation. Only the Mets, Blue Jays and Baltimore Orioles voted no.
 
Replacements, Pro and Con
 The use of replacement players was another topic of discussion at the owners' meeting.
Peter Angelos said the Orioles would not use replacement players. He punctuated his comments by talking about the importance to Baltimore and to baseball of Cal Ripken's consecutive-game streak that would come to an end if the clubs played regular-season games.
Paul Beeston said the Blue Jays are prohibited by Ontario provincial law from using replacement workers, but he added, "We wouldn't use them if the law didn't prohibit it."
Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies spoke after Angelos, pounded the table and said the clubs have to use replacements if the striking players don't play. It's the only step available to the clubs, he said.
 
Salary Cap 101
 Dan Duquette of the Boston Red Sox most likely echoed the thoughts of all of the general managers who had just undergone a briefing on the new economic system, a k a the salary cap, the owners still plan to impose on the players.
Asked what he learned in the briefing, Duquette said, "I learned I need to learn more."
For some of the general managers, sitting in the ballroom at the O'Hare Hilton last Thursday must have reminded them of the days when they sat in a large lecture hall in college listening to a boring lecture in a boring course, maybe even economics, they had to take.
They didn't want to be there, they didn't want to learn the subject and they never were going to need whatever it was they were learning.
In this instance, though, the general managers can only hope they never will need what they learned in Salary Cap 101.
"Here's what you have to know if you have to know it," Joe McIlvaine of the Mets said, describing the seminar conducted by management lawyers. "It's very confusing."
 
Yankees' Risky Trade
 Before fearlessly trading for Jack McDowell, the Yankees considered him along with three other pitchers, Kevin Appier of Kansas City and two free agents, Kevin Brown, formerly of Texas, and Bill Swift, most recently of San Francisco. They opted for McDowell even though his are the most uncertain circumstances.
McDowell could become a restricted free agent if the owners implement their Nov. 17 proposal, which includes free agency with right of first refusal for players who have been in the major leagues between four and six years. Or he could become an unrestricted free agent if an arbitrator rules that players should receive service credit for the 52 days of the strike.
What kind of free agent will McDowell be? "A high-priced one," a players' lawyer said.
 
Lucchino Back in the Game
 John Moores, a Texas software millionaire, is buying the Padres a couple of years too late to salvage a prospective pennant contender for San Diego. The 15-man ownership group, headed by Tom Werner, decided to decimate the team rather than fulfill its commitment to the city.
When the sale, which major league owners approved last week, is completed in a couple of weeks, the Werner group will remain as minority partners with about 10 percent of the club. Larry Lucchino, former president of the Orioles and a teammate of Bill Bradley at Princeton, will also own about 10 percent and is expected to be the club's president and chief executive officer.
Major league baseball can't be in critical condition if Lucchino is so eager to get back in. He also led a group that probably could have bought the Pirates in his hometown of Pittsburgh, but the city's prolonged process for finding a buyer prompted him to abandon that effort and go with Moores.
"We recognize these are uncertain times to be jumping into this process, but we're willing to take a risk and make a commitment," Lucchino said. "You have to believe in the city and the potential of the market, and you have to believe in the resilience of the game."
 
According to His Needs?
 From the looks of the owners' tax proposal that last week was on and off the table in 48 hours and could return this week in a variation, Fred Wilpon of the Mets must have written it. How else explain the windfall the Mets would receive in the first year of the transition phase, a payment of $1,996,000 instead of a contribution to the revenue-sharing pool of $3,365,000 under the players' proposal. That's a net plus to the Mets of $5,361,000.
Bud Selig, on the other hand, would lose $3,021,000 under the owners' plan compared with the one the players presented. How could the acting commissioner have allowed that document to reach the table?
It certainly raised serious questions about the owners' oft-stated desire to raise money for low-revenue clubs from contributions from high-revenue clubs.
The Mets rank sixth in projected 1994 revenue (based on a full season) and certainly don't need economic assistance, but the owners' plan would reward clubs with high revenues and low payrolls (the Mets rank No. 21 there). Help the low-revenue clubs? The San Diego Padres, 27th in revenue, would receive $10.2 million under the players' plan, only $5.5 million under the owners' proposal.
A person on the players' side said the clubs' negotiators have said several times at the bargaining table that this dispute is not about big markets-small markets, then amended their statements to say that's part of it but not entirely.
In another difference in the plans, the clubs would give money to the recipient clubs on a gradual basis -- 40 percent the first year, 60 percent the second, 80 percent the third and finally reaching 100 percent the fourth. The players would generate 100 percent of the money from the start.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Baseball Fan: Heal Thyself

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
We came back after the Fix of 1919 and we came back after the Abandonment of 1957 and we'll come back after the Strikeout of 1994, sadder Budweiser, wearing our rally caps, salary caps, dunce caps, backward, of course. We need to be tested every four decades or so to prove that fan is short for fantasist.
"We're the problem," said Roger Sims, an acknowledged fan. "We have this unrealistic view of who they are, and what our relationship is. The owners are truly from another planet, these gray old men who smell of cologne, but what did we ever do about the reserve clause or the antitrust exemption? And the players haven't been one of us in years, but we still demand some connection between our lives and theirs, just because we need them so much. 
 "Which is the point. We are junkies. We will forgive and forget as soon as the next season starts. And so what? Baseball don't mean nothing. That's what's so good about it."
Sims, who played baseball briefly at Howard University 35 years ago and who was loving last season because the Yankees were winning, lost interest when the conversation got to Bud Selig and Darryl Strawberry, who will probably be the handiest effigies for those looking to hang Poor Sportsmen of the Year from columns and wrap-ups. Why can owners collude and players be in a position to take money under the table and all we can do is wax nostalgic?
"Two stories," said Sims, who was watching a night rain bat on his condo windows in Everett, Wash. "In 1948, my grandfather took me to my first baseball game, in Wrigley Field. Loved that place. I held his hand as we walked in, and he said, 'If anyone asks you your favorite Cub, say Phil Cavarretta.'
"I waited the whole game but no one came up to us. I mean, who interrogates an old black man and a fat 10-year-old at a ball game? But holding my granddad's hand and baseball and Phil Cavarretta are mixed up in my mind forever. That's why I'm a fan. How could it have anything to do with right now. I mean, Gregg Jefferies. How many millions?
"And some years after that, when I was living in New York, I was waiting outside Yankee Stadium, too cool to rush for autographs, just watching other kids run after the players, and here comes Hector Lopez, and he's friendly and he signs for everybody and he talks while he's doing it and then he goes off to the subway. I remember the little half moons of sweat under his armpits. To the subway. So his fielding wasn't always perfect. You better not call him Whatta Pair of Hands Lopez in front of me unless you're smiling."
Having established his credentials, Sims turned a little mean. "We keep talking about the greedy owners and the greedy players, but what about the third corner of that triangle, the greedy fan? Emotionally greedy for a romance that never existed. We helped create all this. They know we'll be here when it's over. So how will anything ever change?"
Nevertheless, there are theories of change: a young generation of fan will be lost to multimedia, for example, less of a blow to club-owning corporations already in that field than to players; the bursting economic bubble will send players' salaries sliding back toward their fans', and fans will return but emotionally distance themselves from the game to prevent further disappointments.
Maybe fans will take a closer look. The reflexive bashing of owners is based on the Figaro complex, the common man reaffirming his fate as servant by railing at the master for not being perfect. Did we really expect owners to be smarter, more virtuous than players because they're richer? On the other hand, owners ARE the future of the game because they amass the capital, create the arena and meet the payroll, which is at least as important as throwing and catching. In the history of the game, Bud Selig is more important than Paul Molitor, and has done far more to keep it going.
That players are not necessarily smarter and more virtuous than fans may even be excusable, certainly understandable. Fans masquerading as parents, teachers, lovers and friends have been letting these adolescents off the hook all their lives so long as they performed. And as soon as they get into trouble, we wonder how they could be so ungrateful. Some compassion, please.
How much of Strawberry's current problems for allegedly taking card show fees without declaring it grew out of the addict's need for unaccountable cash?
"C'mon," Sims said. "That's just another hero-with-feet-of-clay story. You guys love that. Build 'em up and knock 'em down. Look, the world didn't end without baseball, which is good. It means we can keep on being fans. As much as we love and need it, baseball don't mean nothing. It's based on unrealistic expectations. Enough for now. I'm just gonna wait for the new season." It was getting late, even on the West Coast, and his voice sounded dreamy.
"When I get to the hereafter," he said, and it was hard to tell if he meant heaven or spring training, "I've got two questions to ask granddad: Is he proud of the way I turned out? Why Phil Cavarretta?"
