SECTION: Section 1; Page 73; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1328 words

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
Cabdriver's School Benefits to Public Hardly Need Explaining

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The tour bus lurched down Columbus Avenue and stopped near Lincoln Center. Mor-Sourang Mbaye and his companions stared silently ahead, unimpressed. Later, when they passed the World Trade Center, not a single neck craned skyward.
But when the bus approached a no-taxi zone, Mr. Mbaye and the other passengers murmured appreciatively. And when it hit gridlock on Third Avenue, they leapt to their feet for a better view. 
 "Just look at that," Mr. Mbaye said as cars piled into an intersection. "People like that are going to make our lives very difficult."
For Mr. Mbaye, a Senegalese immigrant struggling to learn the warlike art of cab driving, the bus tour was about strategy, not sightseeing. It was part of a private class that teaches prospective taxi drivers -- nearly all of them immigrants -- how to navigate the five boroughs and get along with passengers.
The class was begun in 1984, in response to customers' complaints about how hard it was to find drivers who could speak English or find their way around New York.
The city requires the class for all new drivers, who have to pass an English-proficiency test and pay their own tuition. Thousands do so eagerly, hungry for the chance to gain a marketable skill and a foothold in the economy.
Although it is dangerous and tiring, the taxi business has always drawn immigrants -- Irish and Italians a generation ago, Bangladeshis and Indians today. Newly arrived New Yorkers often turn to taxi driving because it promises steady work and above-average pay, said Leonard H. Katz, coordinator of the Federation Employment Guidance Service's New York City Taxi Driver Institute, which sponsors the class.
The service, which receives financing from UJA-Federation of New York, a charity supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, provides an array of training programs for immigrants, teaching things like business management and appliance repair. But as the percentage of foreign-born cabbies continues to rise -- it was 90 percent in 1991, up from 75 percent in 1984 -- the program whose results are the most visible to New Yorkers is taxi school.
"Immigrants drive taxis because they can't make this kind of money in the other jobs available for them," Mr. Katz said, adding that cabbies can make up to $12 an hour. "If they're not driving cabs, chances are they're working very long hours in a very menial job," he said.
Ali Sibtain, who immigrated from Pakistan in 1990, earned $4 an hour in a toy store before he quit this month. His boss paid him off the books, and if business was slow, he would send Mr. Sibtain home early.
"Driving a taxi means you are the boss; you can work 24 hours a day," said Mr. Sibtain, 38. "I wish I could go to school and prepare for a better job, but I have two children and rent to pay. Right now this is the best choice."
That is why Mr. Sibtain, a former customs official, sat in a taxi institute classroom on the eve of the bus tour, poring over a map to determine the quickest route from the Bronx to Staten Island. When the instructor, Andrew Vollo, asked a question, Mr. Sibtain and his classmates answered in a singsong melange of accents:
"What do you do if you get stuck in traffic?"
"Alternate route!"
"What if you get really stuck?"
"Sit back and enjoy it!"
The taxi school, mandatory for new drivers, consists of a 40-hour course that covers regulations, geography, courtesy and crime prevention. Students pay their own tuition, which ranges from $70 to $275 based on language proficiency. Those who speak poor English take an 80-hour course with emphasis on driver-passenger conversation, learning essential terms like "scofflaw" and "anti-lock brakes."
If they pass the course, immigrants can look forward to 12-hour days, unpaid vacations and constant worries about mechanical breakdowns, robberies and even murder. (A record 43 livery drivers and cabbies were killed in New York last year.)
Durand Dormelus, a Haitian immigrant who has driven a cab in New York for six years, said he was happy if he cleared $80 in a 12-hour day. Mr. Dormelus, 38, of Irvington, N.J., said the job was dangerous and hard on his health. "It's a killer," he said. "A few months ago I had a problem with my back, and it hurt so bad I had to stop work for a while." But he says he considers himself fortunate: he has steady work, and has never been robbed.
"This is the perfect American job," said Mohammed Iqbal, 32, a Pakistani immigrant who worked in a convenience store before enrolling in the taxi school. "We work hard, we can make as much money as we want." Mr. Iqbal said his previous job was the only one he could find in his first two years here. Like others in the class, he said he planned to drive a taxi for several years and save enough money to attend college or start a business.
In the 1980's, when fewer people immigrated to New York and the economy was booming, entry-level jobs were easier to find. But now, an estimated 111,500 immigrants are coming to the city each year, and a long recession has forced many to work in the underground economy or seek public assistance. Job-training opportunities are rare, but invaluable, said Ilene Margolin, associate executive vice president of the employment guidance service.
"A lot of immigrants are highly educated, very bright, but they have no language skills," Ms. Margolin said. "Our programs help them hit the ground running, to shorten the time it takes for them to learn English and get placed in jobs."
In addition to the taxi institute, the guidance service operates a business school with the New York Association for New Americans. And in Brooklyn, a trade school trains immigrants, many of them refugees, in building maintenance and appliance repair.
Oksana Lvova, a Ukrainian immigrant who is studying bookkeeping at the business school, said she hoped secretarial training would eventually lead to a high-paying job. "In America, it is impossible to find a job without work experience," said Ms. Lvova, who was an engineer in Kiev before she came to New York this year. "I hope that this will be the first step. Being a secretary is better than sweeping the streets."
Even when low-wage jobs are available, Ms. Margolin said, educated and skilled immigrants are sometimes reluctant to take them. "They don't realize that their first job is not necessarily their last job," she said. "They have to go through many levels, layers and careers to reach their eventual goals."
But even the most patient immigrants grow frustrated. Shib Das, a taxi institute student, came from Bangladesh with an electrical engineering degree. Since he arrived in New York two years ago, he has worked at a fast-food restaurant for the minimum wage.
"It makes me cry to see others with no education, no English, working next to me for the same wages," he said. "For the last two years I have not taken one day off, and still I cannot afford school."
Mr. Das said driving a cab would help him reach his goal of returning to school. But thousands of others will not have the same opportunity. The demand for job-training programs far exceeds the supply, and government cutbacks make the prospect of new programs unlikely. Mr. Mbaye, the Senegalese immigrant, said he did not understand why the city did not offer more services to help immigrants find work.
"If I am not mistaken, the Mayor, Mr. Giuliani, has parents who came from Italy," he said. "If the system did not provide some chances for them, he would not be the Mayor today."
Before Mr. Mbaye went to taxi school, he worked in restaurant kitchens, clothing stores and, most recently, selling watches on the street. He said he was willing to drive seven days a week to realize his dream of becoming an actor. But after several years of menial jobs and poverty-level income, he is cynical.
"You come here with wishes to make money, to make a good life," he said. "But you have to kill yourself to make it happen."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
A Chance to Help Your Neighbors

 BODY:
Expecting a decrease in financing over the next few years, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, is recruiting volunteers to deliver social services to the poor.
Thomas A. DeStefano, executive director of the agency, said it is relying more heavily on a network of 1,600 volunteers, saving money that would otherwise be spent on salaries or contracted services. He pointed to the example of a retired couple who cook meals in a center for the elderly in their Brooklyn neighborhood. 
 "There are some things the local communities just cannot provide, so we step in with our volunteers," Mr. DeStefano said. "They are working in their own communities, where they are already invested and really want to make a difference."
Catholic Charities may fall about $100,000 short of its $5 million budget because longtime donors are not able to give as much this year. "Up until this year we have been holding our own," Mr. DeStefano said. "But times are harder and people are really feeling threatened by the economy."
A loss of $150,000 from the city Department of Youth Services means 15 staff positions will be eliminated, affecting services for children. Project Bridge, in Bushwick, Brooklyn, will lose four after-school programs for 240 children aged 6 to 12. A skills-building program in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, called Pass II Play will be eliminated.
Catholic Charities was founded in 1899 when several smaller agencies in Brooklyn and Queens pooled their resources. It now offers dozens of services, including job training for teen-agers, prison ministry and day-care centers. Six mental health clinics provide individual and group counseling for people of all ages. A program delivers hot meals to more than 5,000 homebound elderly people. A refugee resettlement program provides emergency help, counseling and job training to new immigrants. And a Human Mobile Outreach Team provides help to mentally ill homeless people in Brooklyn and Queens.
Mr. DeStefano said the organization's four Family Action Centers, which receive no government funding, desperately need private donations. The centers, which provide crisis intervention, emergency assistance and long-term counseling, serve more than 35,000 families a year. Their services include parenting workshops, support groups for grandmothers and child safety workshops. But only 10 to 15 people staff each center, with a total budget of $2 million.
"People come to these centers with every kind of issue you can imagine, and our staff monitors each case," Mr. DeStefano said. "But with limited resources, there's no way they can cover the whole barrage of issues that arrive on their doorsteps."

HEADLINE: Mr. Assistance Davis

BYLINE: By Kenneth S. Davis; Kenneth S. Davis's most recent book is "F.D.R. Into the Storm 1937-1940: A History."

 BODY:

SLY AND ABLE
A Political Biography of James F. Byrnes.
By David Robertson.
Illustrated. 639 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. 
THE rather unflattering title -- "Sly and Able" -- that David Robertson has given this valuable work suggests a main difficulty presented him by his subject. James F. Byrnes (1882-1972), who 50 years ago was widely deemed the second most powerful man in American political life, was a small man physically and, save for his ambition, not large in other ways. Though he was at different times in his career a United States Senator, a Supreme Court Justice and a Secretary of State (in 1946 Time magazine selected him as its Man of the Year), he had no grand vision, no great compassion, no capacity for inspirational leadership. In personal relationships he manifested a good deal of "Irish charm." He could and did make himself liked by those who might advance him. But he was an intensely private, rather cold personality, shrewd, quick, manipulative, hard-working, the very opposite of colorful or dramatic, with a sharp eye for the main chance and a talent for seizing it.
Byrnes's ambition, which was immense, was for power per se; he seems never to have asked himself why he craved it or what ultimate ends he would pursue with it once he had it. He was a remarkably adroit politician, with a flair for resolving conflicts through more or less creative compromises. But when he achieved a position that demanded high statesmanship of him in a historical crisis, he remained exclusively a domestic political animal who measured possibilities and made decisions exclusively in terms of their perceived effect on coming elections.
Faced with the problem of writing an interesting book about so essentially uninteresting a man, Mr. Robertson, a poet and former newspaper editor, has solved it triumphantly by emphasizing context. Prodigious research has enabled him to produce a richly detailed narrative, and the details are almost as much about the people, the forces and the issues amid which Byrnes made his way as they are about Byrnes himself. There are full-length portraits of the men who most helped his career, notably the South Carolina populist leader and demagogue Pitchfork Ben Tillman and the financier Bernard Baruch. There are illuminating accounts of every project, every historical development in which Byrnes had even a minor part. As a result, "Sly and Able" is history as well as biography, rising to a climax in its account of the years 1945-46, when Byrnes's attitudes and decisions at the very apex of American political power helped determine some of the main features of the America we live in today.
Born an Irish Catholic in Charleston, S.C., in 1882, but converted to Episcopalianism after his marriage in 1906, Byrnes began his national political career in 1910 when he was elected a Democratic Congressman. He served seven House terms as a typical Southern politician of his time, if far more able than most. He was conservative in his socioeconomic views and a white supremacist as a matter of course, less eager than some to use race as a campaign issue yet capable, in 1919, of delivering on the House floor a virulently racist diatribe incited by the demands of black war veterans for citizenship rights in the South.
After losing a bid for the Senate in 1924, he won a seat six years later with the financial help of Baruch. Once there he actively opposed anti-poll-tax and anti-lynching bills, helping to lead a notorious filibuster against the latter in 1938. However, his tactical skill in political warfare, influence with fellow conservatives and party loyalty enabled him to serve President Franklin D. Roosevelt well on important occasions, especially after the 1938 midterm elections drastically reduced Congressional liberalism.
But it was with the establishment in 1942 of the Office of Economic Stabilization as one of the President's war emergency agencies that Byrnes entered his period of greatest fame and power. He had been appointed a Supreme Court Justice in 1941 -- a lifetime post of great honor for which, however, he was ill fitted and in which he was unhappy. He longed to return to active politics, especially after Pearl Harbor, and jumped at the chance to do so when Roosevelt, in October 1942, offered him the directorship of the new agency. He moved into an office in the White House's East Wing, whence he exercised authority over activities, as Executive Order 9250 put it, "relating to the control of civilian purchasing power, prices, rents, wages, salaries, profits, subsidies and all related matters." He proved a highly effective wartime inflation fighter, if in ways that helped business and hurt organized labor (wages were pretty well frozen at mid-1942 levels; there was no such freezing of business profits). When Roosevelt at last established, in May 1943, a long-needed superagency, the Office of War Mobilization, with blanket authority over virtually the whole of the civilian side of the war effort, Byrnes was the natural choice to head it.
As "economic czar" or "assistant President" he administered a planned economy that was far from socialistic. Every key economic post in the
Federal Government was occupied by a big-business man, thanks to Roosevelt's reliance on wealthy "dollar-a-year" men; these individuals set a basic planning pattern that was profitable to their corporations (they successfully fought off all efforts adequately to tax what were called excess profits); and they were generally enthusiastic about Byrnes's operations, especially during the winter of 1944-45, when, with the winding down of the war effort, his agency became by executive order the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion.
Byrnes was by then embittered by the disappointment of his hopes for the 1944 Vice Presidential nomination -- Roosevelt having led him to believe he was the White House's choice, then picking Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri instead. If there was poetic justice here (Roosevelt's decision was partly determined by opposition to Byrnes from black people and organized labor), it only increased Byrnes's bitterness. This in turn increased his willingness to side with big business and the armed services during the vehement arguments over reconversion that raged in 1944 and 1945.
The reconversion Byrnes opted for assured the continued concentration in large corporations of economic strength that had been drained away from small businesses by wartime Government procurement policies. It also weakened organized labor. Hence, to the extent that Byrnes, as economic czar, made a permanent contribution to American institutional life, it was by helping establish that "military-industrial complex" President Dwight D. Eisenhower later uncharacteristically deplored.
When Roosevelt died in April 1945, Byrnes was a private citizen in Spartanburg, S.C., having just resigned from government. But within a week or so President Truman appointed him to a committee to advise on the use of the atomic bomb (Byrnes had been one of the very few in Washington who knew of the Manhattan Project, and had been included in the American delegation to Yalta). In July he became Truman's Secretary of State.
During this crucial period when the cold war began, his chief foreign policy contributions, Mr. Robertson indicates, were to make sure that the atomic bomb was dropped, without warning, on Japan, and to see that it remained exclusively an American possession. To these ends, he resisted the efforts of many atomic physicists for a demonstration rather than a murderous employment of the awesome weapon they had created, and for international atomic controls to prevent an otherwise inevitable arms race with the Soviet Union.
Simultaneously, he refused to consider, until after Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Japanese peace feelers that were first put out in April 1945 -- offers to surrender on the condition that Japan be permitted to retain its Emperor and his prerogatives. Failure to use the bomb, after $2 billion of the taxpayers' money had been spent on it, would outrage the electorate and destroy the Administration, Byrnes argued, and failure to demand unconditional surrender from Japan would have the same effect. Truman agreed. Yet five days after the Nagasaki bombing, Japan was permitted to surrender on terms that retained the Emperor.
THE remainder of Byrnes's Cabinet service was considerably less controversial. He capably managed the Iranian crisis of the winter of 1945-46 and bravely resisted, on behalf of his department, the onset of McCarthyism. But under the new pressures he revealed character traits (arrogance, vanity, conceit) hitherto concealed or perhaps undeveloped, antagonizing both the men closest to Truman and Truman himself. His resignation in January 1947 was welcomed by the President, who promptly appointed George C. Marshall his successor.
Returning to South Carolina, Byrnes was elected Governor in 1950 and as such, after the Supreme Court's 1954 Brown v. Board of Education decision, became a leader of the South's massive resistance to racial integration. Leaving office in 1955, he soon left the Democratic Party also, since the party's civil rights policies had become anathema to him. As one of his last activities in the public arena, he helped Richard Nixon devise the "Southern strategy" of the 1960's, whereby Republicans were able to pry much of the white South away from the Democrats. Byrnes died in relative obscurity on April 9, 1972, less than a month before his 90th birthday. Today he is almost entirely forgotten. "Sly and Able" should help revive the memory of a man whose career -- as Congressman, Senator, Governor, Supreme Court Justice, Secretary of State and "assistant President" -- continues to affect us all.
 
 
 
F.D.R.'S FIXER
 Despite his later success in other branches of government and the comparative financial insecurity of his years as a senator, Byrnes at the close of his life declared this period of his public service to have been the happiest -- the period of political inheritance in the U.S. Senate beginning with Franklin Roosevelt's 100-day special session of the 73d Congress. . . .
Unemployment, bank failures and depressed prices for manufactured goods and farm commodities were, as Byrnes knew, now the responsibilities of the Democratic Administration. Consequently, Byrnes was of one mind with the President on the necessity for action. During the four months between March and June 1933, during the first session of the 73d Congress, President Roosevelt and his advisers released what could be described as a God's plenty of proposed legislation; and in the U.S. Senate, Jimmy Byrnes was the embodiment of that Presidential energy. Byrnes assisted in drafting major New Deal legislation of the Hundred Days, including the Emergency Banking Act . . . allowing Government purchase of preferred bank stock; the Farm Credit Act and the Home Owners' Loan Act, providing Federal financing of mortgages to distressed farmers or urban homeowners; and the Economy Act of 1933, which in the name of promoting greater efficiency gave Roosevelt unprecedented powers to reorganize the Federal bureaucracy by executive order. Additionally, Byrnes during the special session acted as the Administration's whip on the passage through the upper chamber of the bills creating the Civilian Conservation Corps (C.C.C.), the Agricultural Adjustment Act (A.A.A.) and the Federal Emergency Relief Administration. During this sustained activity, Byrnes was often described as the mercurial figure in a pin-striped suit working behind the scenes for the Administration. . . .
Jimmy Byrnes knew the angles. He became known in the Senate as the Administration's "fixer," who could take control of a piece of legislation stalled by opposing viewpoints, improve the bill's chances for passage through compromise and then quickly get the bill passed and off the legislative calendar. Cassandra Connor, personal secretary to Byrnes, later recalled how frequently Franklin Roosevelt telephoned the Senator's office during the Hundred Days and subsequent legislative sessions. "I don't want to talk to him," the President sometimes told Miss Connor. "I just want to know what he's up to." From "Sly and Able."

HEADLINE: The Joy of Boredom

BYLINE: By Adam Phillips; Adam Phillips's most recent books are "On Kissing, Tickling and Being Bored" and "On Flirtation."

 BODY:

BOREDOM
The Literary History of a State of Mind.
By Patricia Meyer Spacks.
290 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $24.95. 
BOREDOM is one of the ways we break our habit of believing in the future. When there's nothing we want, nothing to look forward to, the story stops. Boredom, as Patricia Meyer Spacks says, "defies narration." A boring detective novel, for example, is a contradiction in terms: when we are bored, nothing happens next (there's no next next). A capacity to be interested in things -- in virtually anything -- is so fundamental to our sense of well-being that we are unlikely to imagine that a preoccupation with boredom could even have a history. One of the many engaging things that "Boredom," Ms. Spacks's immensely informed (and sometimes overinformed) book, shows us is that boredom began in the 18th century, that it was then "a new concept, if not necessarily a new event." So one of the intriguing subplots of this book is how such an "event" -- and a mood is always something of an event -- turns into a concept.
Nowadays, everything seems to have begun in the 18th century. But Ms. Spacks's enthusiasm about boredom, so to speak, is infectious and convincing. In chapters whose subtitles may sound drearily academic -- "Eighteenth-Century Women, Boredom, and Narrative," "Nineteenth-Century Women and Their Fictions," "Postmodern Enlargements of Boredom," etc. -- she manages to tell a spry and often illuminating literary history of boredom.
Ms. Spacks's lucid approach brings with it some revealing insights. "The invention of boredom as concept and of the novel as genre," she writes, "coincided in time and implicated one another." And by the same token, insofar as women were more likely to be the readers -- and eventually the writers -- of novels, boredom was, as it were, a woman's activity. Because boredom is circumstantial, Ms. Spacks points out, "it is not so clear that women . . . have the same evasive resources" as men. If the ambiguity of "evasive resources" is unintended, Ms. Spacks nevertheless makes a telling point that men and women confront boredom in different ways. But if boredom is all about resources, both psychic and economic, it is also always potentially a transgression or a route to transgression, a threat to good manners. As Ms. Spacks implies in her account of 18th-century fictional heroines, it is of some moral significance that being interesting and interested is often incompatible with being good. "Only by violating decorum might a young woman avoid tedium."
Avoiding tedium, of course, has to be both the project and the subject of this book. As a title, "Boredom" is something of a provocation. We can't help wondering how Ms. Spacks, who is the author of "Gossip" and "Desire and Truth: Functions of Plot in Eighteenth-Century English Novels," is going to go about keeping our attention (there are, including the extensive bibliography and the index, 290 pages of "Boredom"). As it happens, it would be difficult not to be interested in this book, despite the occasional academic drawbacks (throwing in too many plot summaries and too assiduously proving her points), partly because Ms. Spacks is so alert about the problem at hand.
"As action and as product," she writes in the first sentence of the first chapter, "writing resists boredom, constituting itself by that resistance." How writing goes about doing that and how boredom became something to be resisted are the subjects of this timely book. Timely because, as Ms. Spacks knows, boredom has become the forbidden thing -- the state of mind we must avoid at all costs, and yet the one to which we find ourselves being drawn, as to a riddle without a sphinx. ("There is nothing so troublesome," the poet Thomas Gray wrote, "as that one has nothing to trouble one.")
Faced with the enigma of boredom and its pervasiveness as a modern preoccupation, Ms. Spacks offers "four hypotheses to explain the new importance of boredom" that began to emerge in the 18th century. First, there was the development of the notion of leisure. Being bored takes time and costs money, so boredom becomes one of the things you can do (or feel) when you are not working, and very soon, of course, boredom becomes something felt even at work. Second, as Christianity's importance declined, boredom began filling the space left by God. Initially, boredom was a kind of sin that betrayed a lack of faith, the important assumption being that faith was necessary to sustain interest and occupation, that killing God was killing curiosity because He was the object of interest. Third, there was what Ms. Spacks calls "the intensification of concern with individual rights," including the right to happiness and the spurious need to be endlessly pleasured by commodities. Today, as confidence in sexuality wanes, the best available, if temporary, cures for boredom are drugs, glamour and shopping. And finally, the fourth change, which in a sense unifies the other three, was an evolving focus on "inner experience," on the growing sense that people have complex worlds -- of feelings, wishes, thoughts, desires, prejudices -- that are located somewhere inside them. As we become more psychically discriminating, or more seduced by psychobabble, we become more sensitive to our emptinesses, and more obsessed by what we lack.
At one point, Ms. Spacks quotes Samuel Johnson: "So few of the hours of life are filled up with objects adequate to the mind of man . . . that we are forced to have recourse every moment to the past and future for supplemental satisfactions." When we are bored, of course, nothing is adequate. But it's not clear in these long moments of boredom whether the world has let us down -- just isn't alluring enough -- or whether, for some obscure reason, we are not up to it. Ms. Spacks's remarkable book shows us in detail how boredom "menaced ethical energy," and what the minds of women, in particular, have to tell us about this.
 
 
 
IT'S NOT HER PROBLEM
 For one who has written a book on boredom, Patricia Meyer Spacks has frighteningly little personal knowledge of it. Speaking by telephone from her home in Virginia, she said "I am very rarely bored." And when she tried to dredge her memory for an experience of boredom, she remembered her daughter's boredom instead of her own. "When my daughter was little," Ms. Spacks said, "the only thing that made me angry enough to yell at her was when she said she was bored. It seemed ridiculous for a child to be bored. I couldn't stand my daughter being bored."
Clearly Ms. Spacks's new book, "Boredom," wasn't hatched in hours of heartfelt tedium. Rather, it was inspired by a friend's observation that "it was a sin to say to anyone else that he or she was boring." Ms. Spacks, the Edgar F. Shannon Professor of English at the University of Virginia, said she went home after that conversation and did "what English teachers do." She looked up "boredom." She found a word without roots, a word invented in the middle of the 18th century. And she spent the next five years studying how boredom grew, yawn by yawn.
When she told people she was writing a book on boredom, "their immediate response was 'I'm never bored.' " In their unsolicited denials, Ms. Spacks detected a touch of moral defensiveness. "People will deny their own boredom," she said, "but they'll often attribute it to others: they'll say adolescents are always bored, workers in a factory are always bored." Why? "Many people say their mothers said that if you're bored, you're boring; you have no inner resources." Ms. Spacks seems preternaturally unworried about that. She has already begun her next book -- on self-love. SARAH BOXER

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 18, 1994

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: He Who Smuggles Must Learn to Party

BYLINE: By Harlow Robinson; Harlow Robinson's most recent book is "The Last Impresario: The Life, Times and Legacy of Sol Hurok." He teaches Russian literature at the State University of New York, Albany, and has been traveling to Russia regularly since 1970.

 BODY:

THE RANSOM OF RUSSIAN ART
By John McPhee.
Illustrated. 181 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
$20. 
IN his previous 22 books, the indefatigably inquisitive journalist and essayist John McPhee has addressed topics as various as canoes, the game of Monopoly and Scottish distilleries. His 23d, a skinny volume padded with illustrations, ponders something rather different: the fate of Russian visual artists just before and after the collapse of Communism. Heavily traveled of late by a wide variety of critics and groupies, this is no longer the virgin territory it was only a few years ago. Now that the cold war is over, Russia has become cool, especially on the artistic front.
But Mr. McPhee approaches this trendy story from a new angle in "The Ransom of Russian Art." He focuses (with many chatty digressions) on a quirky and elusive personality, Norton Dodge. An economics professor at the University of Maryland who began collecting Soviet "nonconformist" art 30 years ago, Mr. Dodge eventually amassed 9,000 works by 600 artists at his farm in southern Maryland. His collection is now the largest of its kind in the world. Several years ago, he donated his art to the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University, where the works are currently being catalogued. The Zimmerli will open the collection to the public in October 1995.
Mr. Dodge's feat was not accomplished without considerable expenditure of cash, energy and flying time. Over the years, this man, whom one of the Russian artists calls "the Lorenzo de' Medici of Russian art" spent more than $3 million of his own money, operating under secretive and quasi-legal conditions that posed considerable risk both to himself and to the artists whom he befriended and patronized on his many trips to the former Soviet Union.
In those years of Brezhnevian stagnation, which are already beginning to seem a distant and dangerously unreal memory, citizens in the Soviet Union were strongly discouraged even from having casual contact with foreigners -- let alone inviting them to their studios and selling them art. Accepting foreign currency was a crime with very serious consequences. So was the unofficial export of artworks, particularly these abstract, highly spiritual pieces that pointedly ignored (and often mocked) the pompous "accessible" vocabulary of Soviet Socialist Realism. "We were scared to death," one of the artists who dealt with Mr. Dodge told Mr. McPhee. "All of us" -- including Mr. Dodge.
It was after a chance meeting with Mr. Dodge on a train between Washington and Trenton that Mr. McPhee became intrigued with his story. Mr. McPhee then began a piece for The New Yorker on Mr. Dodge that was subsequently adapted into "The Ransom of Russian Art." This genesis helps to explain its breezy, somewhat superficial style, more suitable for an essay than a book.
Nor does it help that Mr. Dodge's many years of covering his tracks and eluding both the K.G.B. and the C.I.A. have clearly made him extremely resistant to the kind of direct questions Mr. McPhee kept trying to ask. Despite the author's conscientious probing and pushing, Mr. Dodge and his motivations slip away time and again from Mr. McPhee's grasp, rather like the cartoon road runner always just beyond the coyote's grasp.
Even now, Mr. Dodge is understandably reluctant to say exactly which foreign diplomats helped him smuggle art out of the Soviet Union. Like all of us who spent considerable time in the former U.S.S.R., Mr. Dodge has internalized a certain reticence and secrecy about what went on there. After years of conditioning, it's hard to discard the feeling that such information might later be used against ourselves and others.
The character who emerges most vividly from this volume is not Mr. Dodge, in fact, but one of the artists whom he befriended and enriched in the 1970's. Yevgeny Rukhin, of what was then called Leningrad, was a Rasputin-like figure of legendary proportions and prodigious appetites on the Russian avant-garde scene. "He was nearly two meters tall," Mr. McPhee writes. "Under his head of dark hair -- its rolling curls spreading out in great radius -- his beard, brown and red, broadly fell halfway down his chest. When he walked on a street anywhere, people turned around."
Mr. McPhee's description is secondhand, since Rukhin perished in 1976, at the age of 32. He suffocated in a suspicious fire in his studio, set (many of his friends believe) by K.G.B. operatives who had discovered him and a friend making love to a woman "sandwich-style." Terrible accidents ran in Rukhin's family; his father, a popular geologist at Leningrad State University, was killed by the K.G.B. in 1959, run over by a truck.
In order to win the confidence and trust of the artists whose work he began collecting, Mr. Dodge also had to learn to stay up most of the night and tolerate often-wild parties with artists. The parties at Rukhin's home were particularly celebrated. (One of the best, according to Rukhin's widow, Galina Popova, took place in August 1971, with the participation of the touring Russian Chorus from Yale University. As it happens, I was on that tour and at that party. My awareness of its future historical significance was deeply clouded, however, by the general, rapid and massive consumption of vodka.)
Unfortunately, Mr. McPhee never alights on any one artist or idea for very long. There is a jumpy, almost unfinished quality to the writing here, as though the author could not quite find the key either to Mr. Dodge or to the nonconformist art scene. The question of why Mr. Dodge did all this remains unanswered. One is all too aware that Mr. McPhee is observing from a comfortable armchair distance, and without the firsthand emotional and cultural knowledge of Russia that would make the tale come alive.
Like many accomplished writers who have attempted to penetrate the Oriental mystery of the Russian psyche and its irresistible appeal for certain Westerners, Mr. McPhee is undone by his cheerful American optimism and his desire to explain things rationally. He should have listened more closely when he was cautioned by the poet Konstantin Kuzminsky, formerly of Leningrad and now residing in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, that "Americans are afraid of everything which causes too much emotion and tragedy. That is the problem between East and West."
That is also the problem with "The Ransom of Russian Art."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 18, 1994

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1719 words

HEADLINE: Then Came the Fall of Rome (Splat!)

BYLINE: By Jonathan Spence; Jonathan Spence teaches modern Chinese history at Yale University. He is writing a history of the 19th-century Taiping Rebellion.

 BODY:

THE CARTOON HISTORY OF THE UNIVERSE
Volumes 1-7:
From the Big Bang to Alexander the Great.
By Larry Gonick.
Illustrated. 358 pp. New York:
Main Street Books/
Doubleday. Paper, $14.95.
 
CD-ROM. Volumes 1-7 on 2 disks.
(Macintosh or Windows) Reston, Va.:
Putnam New Media. $40.
 
THE CARTOON HISTORY OF THE UNIVERSE II
Volumes 8-13:
From the Springtime of China
to the Fall of Rome.
By Larry Gonick.
Illustrated. 305 pp. New York:
Main Street Books/Doubleday. Paper, $15.95. 
HERE is a scenario for the holiday season of 1994. Two children are playing at home with the presents brought by their favorite uncle. One child -- let's call her Wendy -- has just been given a CD-ROM set. Idly clicking the mouse on her parents' multimedia computer, she watches and listens to the little figures jostling by in a torrent of words. Suddenly the image of a woman catches her attention. She has the beak and protruding eyes of a duck or goose, her hair is wild and tangled, she holds an enormous bloodstained knife, and as Wendy clicks the mouse a voice declaims, as the same words appear on the screen:
"Each dying breath flung from his breast swift, bubbling jets of gore, and the dark sprinklings of the rain of blood fell upon me. . . . Not sweeter is the rain of heaven to cornland, when the green sheath teems with grain."
Wendy has never heard words like those before! Clicking back one panel, she finds the duck-billed woman is called Clytemnestra, and the man she has just killed is called Agamemnon. Wendy remembers that her new CD-ROM program began with a picture of a professor's time machine, and that in the picture was a file marked "Index." Clicking her little mouse again, she looks under Clytemnestra, clicks back to the screen, and finds the mystery partly explained, partly deepened. Clytemnestra is not a duck or goose. She is part swan! Her mother, Leda, mated with a swan, and then had her and her sister, Helen. That's why they call her "Goosy." She learns that Clytemnestra kills Agamemnon because he killed their daughter Iphigenia in a sacrifice. A little note on the screen says someone called Aeschylus wrote this account of Agamemnon. Wendy decides it is such a good story that she must read more by this person Aeschylus.
Wendy's little brother, Peter, is lying on the floor beside her. He has been sulking because his uncle gave him only a book, not a CD-ROM disk. But the book turns out to be fun to leaf through, just like a comic, with pictures of lots of people being killed and lots of sexy women. The words are difficult and full of curious names, and many of the people seem to be Chinese. Peter's attention is caught by a calm and thoughtful portrait of a Chinese man, with an oddly ornate hat and long but wispy beard. The explanation says this is Ssuma Chien, author of "one of the greatest histories ever written." Yet in the panel just above, this Ssuma Chien man is being dragged away, crying "Gleep," while an angry looking man is shouting "OFF WITH HIS --." The words in the intervening panel are really long and complicated. "Mommy," shouts Peter, "who is Ssuma Chien? And what's 'castrated'?"
Is this the end of the civilized world as we know it? Or the birth of a new and dazzling technology with the capacity to transform us all and open up a new age? It's probably a bit of both, for what we are contending with here is the world according to Larry Gonick. Wendy has been playing Mr. Gonick's new two-disk CD-ROM set, "The Cartoon History of the Universe," volumes 1-7, which spans the period "From the Big Bang to Alexander the Great," and Peter has been reading Mr. Gonick's latest book, "The Cartoon History of the Universe II," volumes 8-13, which goes "From the Springtime of China to the Fall of Rome." In combination, they suggest a preview of where we may be heading.
The question that Mr. Gonick forces one to think about is both a simple and a complex one: Why should nonhistorians bother to learn about history at all? Most professional historians draw from a pool of more or less stock answers: because history gives us a context for our lives, because it humanizes us, because it illuminates the rise and fall of races and communities and thus helps us understand our own, because it shows the interconnections of economic production with social relations, because it highlights the very different fates of men and woman, because it shows the wellsprings of human greatness and compassion, because it shows the baseness of which human beings are capable, because it defines the various relations we have constructed between our individual lives and the unknowable forces that seem to control our destinies. To this list Mr. Gonick adds another. We bother about history because it is interesting and because it is fun.
Four years ago, Mr. Gonick began to present history in his own eclectic and eccentric way with the first seven volumes of "The Cartoon History of the Universe." Now he has expanded his terrain considerably, with the appearance of volumes 8-13 as well as a CD-ROM version of volumes 1-7. Mr. Gonick impels us to ask a basic question: If this is the wave of the future, then what on earth is going to happen to the past?
Mr. Gonick himself, by his own description, was a student of mathematics at Harvard University for nine years who "dropped out" in 1972 and thereafter lived for a time in India, programmed computers, worked in pharmacology labs, swam laps, read books in the local libraries and spent all his other time drawing cartoons. Like a true outsider, he mocks academic pretensions and jargon in his books; yet, as a former insider, he has respect for intelligent theories and will present them, even if in shortened form, when he feels it to be appropriate. He follows his sources with precision in a clear attempt at accuracy, and carefully lays out the bibliographies at the end of each book, embellishing them with lots of funny drawings and with a cheerful acknowledgment of the titles he has misplaced and the books he couldn't finish. The result, as one might expect, is a curious hybrid, at once flippant and scholarly, witty and politically correct, zany and traditionalist.
Mr. Gonick's approach to the past is personal, free-wheeling and immensely ambitious: in these books he tackles the origins of the solar system, the beginnings of animal and human life, the ancient civilizations of the Near East and China, the origins of the Hindu gods and the roots of Buddhism, the Trojan War and Greek mythology, the Old Testament and the birth of Christianity, the rise and fall of the Roman Empire. The text, even in the cartoon format, is surprisingly dense, larded with names and dates, so dense indeed that despite the drawings one occasionally gets the same sense of glut one gets from certain history textbooks, where all is presented and nothing is explained. This is especially true with the grisly presentations of the wars that have so ravaged the people of this planet: "splam" and "oof" and "thwok" and "paf" and "gleep" form odd accompaniments to the passages from the "Iliad" and Herodotus, the Vedas and Ssuma Chien, "Exodus" and Tacitus.
WHY then mix the lot together, the grunts of comic-book warfare and the greatest chronicles of the past? Do the grunts make the past more fun, more real? And why try to be accurate at all?
The combination of density and accuracy in the print versions of the "Cartoon History of the Universe" leads one to hope that the CD-ROM version of the first seven volumes might have some useful applications. Academic presses have already begun to use CD-ROM technology to integrate archeology, art, sound and movement into historical studies, and this is surely a field that is bound to grow, initially as a supplement to traditional learning rather than as total substitute -- though later, who can tell?
Disappointingly, the CD-ROM set of Mr. Gonick's "Cartoon History of the Universe" makes no use of the intellectual possibilities implicit in the form. It is basically a filmed copy of the original text, unimaginatively colored, with the simplest level of animation to the figures in a given panel. The text is voiced-over for each panel, so one need not read at all, though the mouse must be clicked occasionally to obtain the dialogue; there is an unimpressive musical score to accompany the text; and the professor's voice is oddly ineffective, high-pitched and wheedling, a voice clearly meant to mock the teaching of history as we have known it.
The main addition to the original text, the feature that was supposed to make this an "interactive joy ride through history," as the CD-ROM's box promises, are three "games" that take one (if one so chooses) to the Pyramid of Cheops, the maze of the Minotaur and the Acropolis. But even though these "game concepts" were designed by Matt Costello, who is famous among young connoisseurs of CD-ROM technology for his game "The 7th Guest," they do not seem to reach the level of difficulty, imagination or fun of even moderately advanced video games. And once the games have been played there is no incentive to move into the text and endure the weariness of acquiring information.
For those who do not want to try the games, the CD-ROM set offers nothing that is not in the printed text except an index. (And incidentally, the games and the integration of the text with the index are not
really usable on what is the "minimum configuration" of a 386-series microprocessor. The crank-up time is so slow that most people would simply abandon the alleged adventures altogether. A 486-series microprocessor is the absolute minimum.)
The shortcomings of this particular CD-ROM set in no way diminish the challenge it represents to conventional historians. If large segments of the population are drifting toward virtual illiteracy as they acquire new types of skills through handling computer technology, and if we want to keep alive the idea that history has meaning, then cartoon books and CD-ROM sets like Mr. Gonick's might end up becoming lifelines, rather than mere diversions. And thus "splat," "pow," "ouch" and "whoof," along with whatever has by then replaced the mouse, will end up as our descendants' last points of entry back into the inner mysteries of their pasts.

HEADLINE: One Aviator Was Killed in North Korea Helicopter Downing

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The White House announced today that the pilot of an Army helicopter that was shot down or forced down in North Korea was killed in the incident, while the second pilot was alive and apparently unharmed.
"This tragic loss of life was unnecessary," President Clinton said in a statement today, taking a tougher tone toward the Korea than American officials did when they first learned of the incident late Friday. 
 President Clinton said his primary concerns were the return of the body of Chief Warrant Officer David Hilemon of Clarksville, Tenn., and the release of the other pilot, Chief Warrant Officer Bobby Hall of Brooksville, Fla.
Eager to resolve the incident to prevent a major rupture in relations, American diplomats negotiated today for the quick release of Warrant Officer Hall and of Warrant Officer Hilemon's remains, but they said North Korea had not indicated that it would comply with the request.
American military delegates met today with North Korean officials in the border village of Panmunjom while American diplomats met in New York with North Korean representatives to the United Nations. In addition, Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who was on a visit to North Korea, sought to resolve the crisis in several meetings in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.
North Korea has insisted that the unarmed two-seat OH-58 Kiowa helicopter was on a hostile surveillance mission three to five miles inside North Korean territory, but Pentagon officials maintain that the two pilots strayed innocently across the demilitarized zone during a routine training mission. The helicopter went down in the area of Kungang.
Pentagon officials said today that they remain unsure whether the helicopter was shot down, forced down or perhaps had mechanical difficulties, although many officials said they assumed the helicopter was downed by hostile fire.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that he was eager to learn how the Army scout helicopter had strayed so far over the 155-mile long, 2.5-mile wide demilitarized zone. The Kiowa helicopter is a reconnaissance aircraft frequently used for scouting and training.
"The Defense Department has launched a full investigation of the circumstances that led to this tragic loss on a routine training flight," Mr. Perry said in a statement. "Results will be reported as this investigation reaches its conclusion."
The White House statement said that Warrant Officer Hilemon "was killed in the downing of the helicopter" and that Warrant Officer Hall "is alive and reportedly uninjured."
Several American officials said they were frustrated with North Korea's handling of the incident, saying it has been slow to release information. They also questioned why North Korea's official news agency at first said the two pilots were being held for questioning.
Administration officials said that some North Korean diplomats had informed them and Mr. Richardson early on that Warrant Officer Hilemon had died when the helicopter went down. But they said other North Koreans, especially some officials in the army, were sending different signals. One American official said the lack of a clear message could indicate that the country's new leader, Kim Jong Il, was not firmly in control.
In its initial comments, the Clinton Administration was eager to get the pilots released quickly to ease tensions in the hope that Washington and Pyongyang could concentrate on the delicate task of putting the month-old agreement to restrict North Korea's nuclear program into effect. But with the news of Warrant Officer Hilemon's death, Administration officials took a tougher line.
Mr. Clinton said he has asked Representative Richardson to extend his stay in North Korea to help resolve the crisis. Mr. Richardson arrived in North Korea early Saturday for a two-day visit to examine the human rights situation there and discuss the nuclear accord.
In the agreement, the North agreed to scrap its current policy on nuclear weapons. In return, the United States pledged to lead an international effort to build $4 billion in new, less-threatening reactors for North Korea.
American officials said the biggest move Pyongyang could make to reduce tensions would be to let Mr. Richardson bring Warrant Officer Hall and Warrant Officer Hilemon's remains with him back to the United States on Monday, the day he was scheduled to leave North Korea.
"The first and most important thing is a full accounting of what happened, and the release of the body and of the other pilot," said a senior Administration official. "If that doesn't happen, it would be hard not only for Congress, but the Administration to proceed with other discussions, like exchanging liaison offices."
American officials said they told North Korea that the wisest course would be to follow what South Korea did last January after capturing two North Korean soldiers who drifted into South Korean waters. They were released to the North four days after being captured.
One message American diplomats say they have conveyed to North Korea is that if it moved quickly to turn over Warrant Officer Hilemon's remains and release Warrant Officer Hall, the nuclear agreement will not be threatened.
Stu Nagurka, a spokesman for Representative Richardson, said he has warned Pyongyang that "failure to aggressively investigate this case and failure to return the missing servicemen would have a serious impact on U.S.-North Korean relations."
According to the Pentagon, Warrant Officer Hilemon was 29 years old and is survived by his wife, Berit. He joined the Army in February 1988 and became a pilot in August 1989. He was assigned to Fort Campbell, Ky., from June 1990 to March 1994 and earned a medal for combat service for flying a helicopter in the Persian Gulf war. On Nov. 4, he arrived in South Korea, where he and Warrant Officer Hall were stationed at Camp Page at Chunchon with Company A, 4th Battalion, 501st Aviation Regiment of the Army.
Before the White House announced Warrant Officer Hilemon's death, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, issued a warning to the North Koreans on the CBS news program "Face the Nation."
"They're not exactly in an enviable position in the world, are they?" he said. "Their dictator's dead. Their economy's dead. And they've got two American pilots, and they'd better get them back fast."

HEADLINE: Bradford Morse Is Dead at 73; Held High-Ranking U.N. Posts

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
Bradford Morse, a former Republican Congressman from Massachusetts who rose to become a top-ranking United Nations official, died yesterday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 73.
The cause was heart failure, his family said. 
 A lawyer who was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1960, Mr. Morse served six terms before resigning to join the United Nations. In his 13-year career there, Mr. Morse supervised a diverse series of relief efforts that ranged from job-training for two million Colombians to a program that built hundreds of miles of secondary roads in five African nations.
As head of the United Nations Development Program, which helps finance and administer development projects in more than 150 nations, Mr. Morse became an advocate for aid to poor countries and for victims of famine in Africa. In the mid-1980's, when droughts ravaged Ethiopia and the Sudan, Mr. Morse organized a large-scale relief effort with help from a Canadian official, Maurice F. Strong, executive coordinator of the United Nations Office for Emergency Operations in Africa.
Bradford Morse, a native of Lowell, Mass., returned from Army service in World War II to graduate from Boston University and Boston University Law School. In 1953, he was appointed as special counsel to the Senate Armed Services Committee; in 1958, he was named Deputy Administrator of Veterans Affairs by President Eisenhower.
Mr. Morse resigned from the Veterans Administration in 1960, the same year he was elected to Congress. According to friends and associates, Mr. Morse was one of the first Republicans in Congress to express concern over the sharp division among Americans over the country's role in Vietnam, and helped develop the strategy advanced by President Johnson to coax the North Vietnamese into negotiations in 1968.
In 1972, Mr. Morse was appointed Under Secretary General for Political and General Assembly Affairs. Four years later he was asked to take over as administrator of the United Nations Development Program, which was then facing bankruptcy. He secured record pledges, and was credited with turning the program around financially.
After retiring from the United Nations in 1986, Mr. Morse became president of the Salzburg Seminar, a nonprofit organization based in Cambridge, Mass., that brings together politicians, academics and business leaders from the West, developing countries, and countries in the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Morse is survived by his wife, the former Josephine Anne Neale, and three children: Stephanie Hillary Jennifer Morse, of Naples, Fla.; Susanna Francesca Morse of Cincinnati, and Anthony Bradford Morse of Washington.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New York 1 News Becomes Global Role Model

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

 BODY:
New York 1 News, the 24-hour local cable channel that has been in existence since September 1992, has not yet turned a profit. Neither has any similar enterprise in the United States.
But a small and encouraging new source of revenue has materialized for the channel, which is owned by Time Warner Inc. and is available to 1.3 million cable subscribers in the five boroughs of New York City. 
 Representatives of foreign media companies, intrigued by the channel's highly automated, tightly focused, relatively low-cost news operations, are flocking to the New York 1 studios at 42d Street and 10th Avenue. They are observing, learning, and occasionally copying the methods -- and paying for the privilege.
New York 1 may not be a financial success yet, but the number of cable channels is multiplying overseas, as government broadcasting monopolies are eased and entrepreneurs search for useful role models.
Other regional news channels, particularly Chicagoland Television, which is owned by the Tribune Company, offer consulting services. But most of the dozen or so others, available in cities like Washington and in the San Francisco area, are too distracted by their own battles for survival to offer more than brief tours and words of encouragement.
The management of New York 1 thinks differently. "We've been flooded with requests to come visit us," said Paul Sagan, a founder of New York 1 and senior vice president of Time Warner's cable programming division. "If we didn't charge, we'd spend our entire lives working as tour guides, for nothing."
The minimum charge for an introductory tour is $3,000 a day, but longer-term consulting projects have reached $100,000.
"I'd say for us, right now, consulting is a six-figure business over all," Mr. Sagan said in a recent interview. "We've made a big investment in developing proprietary knowledge, and now that we've got it, we appreciate its value."
As he spoke, seated in his office in the converted bus terminal that is the headquarters for New York 1, many of the channel's 30 or so "video journalists" -- camera-carrying reporters who report, videotape and edit their own stories -- were at large in the five boroughs.
In the newsroom, a small crew of producers, technicians and on-air announcers were feeding the channel with recorded news stories covering, among other things, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget battles with the city council, the day in New York City's history, the continuing struggles of New York's football teams and borough-by-borough weather reports.
The channel also has interview programs, including a public affairs program co-produced by The New York Times five nights a week.
Several thousand miles away in London, a remarkably similar all-news operation called Channel One -- owned by Associated Newspapers, the publisher of The Daily Mail and The Evening Standard -- was getting ready to go on the air. New York 1 was a prime consultant in its creation.
In Miami, a 24-hour Spanish language news service called Telenoticias, jointly owned by the Telemundo Spanish-language television network and Reuters, was preparing to begin sending its signal to cable and broadcast outlets in North and South America, using the New York 1 model for its studio operations. Other American broadcasters have shown interest in New York 1's operations, but not enough to contract for consulting services.
Paul Ramsay, chairman of Prime TV, an Australian company that owns 14 television stations in Victoria and New South Wales, recently sat in a second-floor conference room at New York 1. Mr. Ramsay, an amiable Australian who also controls a chain of psychiatric hospitals in the United States, said he was looking to start his own news channel, perhaps in Asia.
Mr. Ramsay was being given a morninglong tour of the operation by Steve Paulus, head of programming at New York 1, and Laurie Ward, the channel's director of finance and administration.
"Unlike other local news operations, we don't have to go live unless there's news happening at the moment," Mr. Paulus said.
Ms. Ward added: "We use technology differently. We use people differently. Instead of sending three our four people out on a story, we send out one. When that person comes back inside he works as a writer and an editor."
After a brief discussion of the station's finances -- including the projection that New York 1 was "right on schedule" to match its $10 million annual budget with advertising revenue -- Mr. Ramsay was shown the way that prerecorded news and feature stories formed a one-hour programming "wheel."
He was escorted downstairs and shown the software that tied together the assignment, editing, scheduling and programming processes -- allowing a video journalist, for instance, to create on-screen captions and send a scripted introduction directly to a news anchor's prompter.
Mr. Ramsay was also shown the hyperkinetic one-woman assignment desk, an editing bay, the sparsely-manned control booth, the anchor station and a nearby "producer pod," a small second studio equipped with robotic cameras and a "reporter package," consisting of a 20-pound Sony Hi-8 video camera, a microphone and cable and a tripod.
A highlight was a visit to the Sony LMS-1000, a "video jukebox" the size of a walk-in closet, whose robotic arm snatches videocassettes of commercials as well as news features from storage racks and feeds them at preprogrammed times into a tape player for transmission.
"Very interesting," Mr. Ramsay said. Several days later, several of his employees visited New York 1.
"You've got to hand it to them for enterprise," a video media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, Tom Wolzien, said of New York 1's consulting efforts. Any additional revenue is helpful, he added, in an industry whose march to profitability has been "excruciatingly slow."
Since 1986, when the Cablevision System Corporation began News 12 Long Island, the first regional news channel, broadcasting companies have struggled to make low-cost all-news operations profitable. Some of those channels employ numerous repeats of live newscasts rather than taped programming wheels. The obstacles to profitability have included cable regulations, the economic recession and an inability to attract a mix of national and local advertising.
Foreign operators appear to be unfazed. "The whole plan starts to work around 2002," said Julian Aston, the director general of Channel One in London. With most of Britain only now being wired for cable, only 200,000 Britons will receive the news channel initially.
Since Associated Newspapers decided that "the New York 1 model could be applied absolutely to our situation," he said, Channel One should look familiar to New York expatriates.
There is one exception: While in New York, Mr. Aston and his associates admired New York 1's subway reporter, who courses through the transit system, camera at the ready, rating the various subway lines for cleanliness and comfort.
"We went to the London Underground and asked them for permission to do something similar," Mr. Aston said. "They told us, 'You wouldn't be like that New York 1, would you? Always criticizing the Underground service?' Then they turned us down."

The channel's programming head, Steve Paulus, standing at left, gave a tour of the studios to Paul Ramsay, chairman of Prime TV of Australia. (Julio A. Ibarra Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: As Deng Fades, China's Leaders Tighten Grip on Power

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 18

 BODY:
With a new wave of repression and nationalistic bluster on issues like trade and national defense, China's Communist Party leaders are asserting their authority in ways that Western diplomats attribute to the further decline of Deng Xiaoping's health.
As Mr. Deng's health has deteriorated through the fall, the Chinese leadership has handed down long prison sentences to dissidents, increased overall security in Beijing and threatened trade retaliation against the United States if Washington cracks down on the rampant pirating of compact disks in China. 
 China's Trade Minister, Wu Yi, said last week that a trade war would erupt if Washington decided on sanctions over copyright piracy in China.
"The day when the United States produces its list for retaliation will be the day when China produces its own," Ms. Wu told the official People's Daily.
What's more, negotiations over China's bid to enter the World Trade Organization by the Dec. 31 deadline have been marked by escalating political rancor.
At the same time, while military cooperation between the United States and China has been improving, a cat-and-mouse encounter between an American aircraft carrier and a Chinese nuclear submarine in late October has rankled Chinese officials and resulted in sharp recriminations.
Pentagon and State Department officials have confirmed the incident, which was first reported by The Los Angeles Times, saying the carrier battle group of the Kitty Hawk detected one of China's five Han-class nuclear attack submarines in the Yellow Sea. The carrier's antisubmarine escorts dropped sonar buoys to track the submarine, which headed for its base at Qingdao on the Shandong peninsula, and China scrambled air force jets that flew within sight of the American battlegroup as it tracked the submarine.
A Chinese Foreign Ministry official said last week that China was seeking "clarifications" over the incident. Yet at a dinner with a United States military attache in Beijing, a Chinese official later asserted that another such incident could lead to a military clash.
American analysts attribute the tough talk to political uncertainty in Beijing.
"No one dares be anything but a strong nationalist in these circumstances," said Michel Oksenberg, a White House aide on China in the Carter Administration and now president of the East-West Center in Hawaii.
"I think in each major dimension of relations with China, one can expect to see recalcitrance as Chinese leaders and the various contestants for power position themselves to make sure they don't lose their nationalist bona fides."
Chen Yizi, a onetime top Communist Party official now living in the United States, said: "I believe that the situation in China right now is in a very delicate state. No matter what, Deng's health isn't going to get any better. The second reason for the fragility of the situation is that there is a series of sensitive problems facing Chinese society, for instance: inflation, corruption and the legacy of the June 4, 1989, incident," the military crackdown on student-led prodemocracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square. "If something goes even slightly wrong with the handling of these questions, the consequences will be severe."
Mr. Deng's declining health, a Western diplomat added, "has been a factor for the last year, but more so in the last few months -- everything is just waiting."
Western officials say that the 90-year-old paramount leader is extremely frail and that his doctors are using life support systems to sustain him. Mr. Deng reportedly suffers from advanced Parkinson's disease and other ailments. Mr. Chen said his sources had told him that Mr. Deng has suffered from progressive kidney failure since October 1992 and undergoes frequent dialysis treatments.
The Chinese Government and members of Mr. Deng's family continue to maintain that he is in good health, but Western officials indicate that he has markedly weakened. One indicator of his health is that Mr. Deng and his family remain in Beijing, and have not gone to his winter residence in Shanghai.
On Friday, the harsh sentences -- including one for 20 years -- were handed down to nine prodemocracy dissidents who had been held in jail for 30 months. The punishment followed the sentencing of Gao Yu last month to six years in prison. Ms. Gao, a prominent journalist who was invited to Columbia University as a visiting scholar this year, had written articles about the political maneuvering of China's leaders for Hong Kong-based magazines.
Hu Shigen, a 39-year-old lecturer at the Beijing Languages Institute, received the heaviest sentence, 20 years, for "spreading counter-revolutionary propaganda."
The New York-based Human Rights in China organization said Mr. Hu and the other defendants had drafted four articles on human and workers' rights. They mimeographed them and began distributing them by mail and by hand before the 1992 anniversary of the1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Robin Munro, the Hong Kong director of Human Rights Watch called the sentences "appallingly severe." He said the dissidents' activities "were all entirely peaceful."
The other dissidents sentenced on Friday received terms ranging from 3 to 12 years. Five others were convicted and released, and one was placed "under surveillance" for two more years.
China's top leaders, who certainly approved of the length and the timing of these sentences, appear to be warning dissidents that the slightest challenge to the Communist Party in this sensitive season will be severely punished.
China's most vocal campaigner for democracy and free speech, Wei Jingsheng, remains a captive of the State Security Ministry, which refuses to charge him or release him. Mr. Wei was initially released in September 1993, after serving more than 14 years in prison, but was rearrested in April.
Chen Ziming, one of two dissidents released from 13-year prison terms last spring, remains a captive in a tiny apartment where as many as 56 policemen have kept him under guard and surveillance. Mr. Chen and Wang Juntao, sentenced in 1991 to 13-year prison terms, were accused of being behind the Tiananmen Square uprising. They were released on medical parole, and Mr. Wang went to the United States for treatment.
Although Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown announced in August that he had won China's commitment to renew its dialogue with Washington on human rights, three months later the dialogue has produced no results.
The State Department's top human rights official, John Shattuck, has announced that China agreed to resume talks with the International Committee of the Red Cross to allow access to thousands of political prisoners. But China has yet to resume negotiations with the Red Cross. And no date for a meeting in 1995 has been set.
Last week, because of Washington's warming toward Taiwan, China withdrew an invitation to United States Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, who stopped in Taipei before a scheduled visit to Beijing.
On the issue of copyright piracy, Dec. 30 is the deadline for the results of Washington's investigation, and they could lead to higher tariffs or import restrictions on $800 million worth of Chinese goods, the estimated value of annual American losses that result from Chinese copyright infringement.
Lee Sands, a negotiator for the United States trade representative, walked out of talks in Beijing last week, saying China had put nothing substantive on the table. After 18 months of discussions, Mr. Sands said, there are still 29 factories in China churning out pirated compact disks.
Earlier this month, a Chinese Trade Ministry questioned Washington's motives by suggesting that pressure on Beijing to drop trade barriers arises from the fact that China "is led by Communists" and that it may someday threaten American dominance in the world economy.
