HEADLINE: G.O.P. Vows to Make Cuts In Spending Before Taxes

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Trying again to outflank President Clinton, the four Republican members of Congress in charge of budget and tax policy said unequivocally today that they intended to cut Federal spending before they cut taxes next year.
House Republicans said that to enforce fiscal discipline they would begin slashing spending next month and would use the savings to pay for tax cuts to be passed later in the year. 
 "We're going to cut spending first," said Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, who is in line to become chairman of the House Budget Committee. "We will take the savings by cutting spending first, and we're going to put them in the bank." Then when Congress cuts taxes, he said, "we'll draw down the bank; we will draw down the savings account."
Mr. Kasich appeared on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" with Representative Bill Archer of Texas, who is in line to become chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon, the incoming chairman of the Finance Committee, and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, who is in line to be chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
Their coordinated comments -- reflecting a strategy formulated at a meeting with Haley Barbour, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, on Friday -- revealed a shift in emphasis from the course laid out in the House Republicans' election manifesto, the "Contract With America." That document made very few specific commitments on the timing or details of budget cuts.
Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic affairs, said tonight that the Republicans had still not specified how they would slow the growth of Federal spending. He challenged the Republicans to give "a line-by-line, program-by-program account of how they'll balance the budget and pay for all their tax cuts."
Mr. Sperling said the Republicans were using "gimmicks" like the balanced budget amendment and caps on various types of spending to conceal the potentially unpopular details of the cutbacks they will make.
The positions staked out today were the latest moves in a long-running chess game over tax and fiscal policy.
In the 1992 Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to cut taxes for the middle class. But after taking office, he deferred action on that pledge, saying it was more important to reduce the Federal budget deficit. In the year that ended Sept. 30, the deficit declined to $203.4 billion, the lowest level since 1989.
In this year's Congressional elections, Republicans promised tax cuts for the middle class as part of their "Contract With America." Mr. Clinton responded to that promise last week, proposing his own package of tax breaks for the middle class, including a tax deduction for college tuition costs. With their vow to cut spending before cutting taxes, the Republicans today tried to outdo Mr. Clinton in fiscal responsibility.
President Clinton plans to hold a news conference on Monday to explain how he would pay for the tax cuts he proposed last week.
In general, the House Republicans said today that they were not backing away from the tax cuts promised in the Contract with America. Representative Dick Armey, the Texas Republican in line to become House majority leader, said the House Republicans intended to pass all their tax cuts by April 15.
But Mr. Archer added a qualification, saying it might be necessary to scale back the corporate tax cuts proposed in the "Contract With America." "We may have to trim that in such a way" that the official estimates of revenue losses are acceptable, he said.
Mr. Packwood, who has served in the Senate for nearly 26 years, was more cautious. "I'm not even going to consider what tax cuts we're going to do until I see spending cuts that will match them," he said today.
"I am not going to support any tax cuts that are going to widen the deficit, period," Mr. Packwood added. "I just don't want to see us once again send out tax cuts with a lick and a promise and a hope that the spending cuts are coming later. We somehow never quite seem to get to them."
In his address to the nation on Thursday, Mr. Clinton said he did not want to make "any new cuts in Social Security or Medicare." Republicans today agreed that Social Security was off the table, but Mr. Kasich and Mr. Archer said they had given no such immunity to Medicare. Mr. Archer said Congress should consider cutbacks to slow the growth in Part B of Medicare, which pays doctors' bills for elderly people and is financed with large amounts of general revenue.
The White House asserted today that the tax cuts proposed by Mr. Clinton were much fairer and more fiscally responsible than those proposed by House Republicans. From 1995 to 2000, it said, the Clinton tax cuts would cost $60 billion, whereas the Republican tax plan would cost $197 billion. Mr. Sperling said that 54 percent of the benefits of the Republican tax proposals would go to families with incomes exceeding $100,000 a year, while 13 percent of the benefits of the Clinton plan would go to such families.
Mr. Packwood, Mr. Domenici and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said that the Senate, in keeping with its constitutional role, would follow a slower, more deliberate pace in handling the legislation on which House Republicans plan to vote in the first 100 days of the new Congress.
The Republicans' Contract with America proposes a Constitutional amendment to require balancing the Federal budget by 2002 or soon thereafter. And Republicans often talk about fiscal conservatism. But under President Ronald Reagan, the deficit nearly doubled, from $79 billion in 1981 to $155 billion in 1988. Under President George Bush, the deficit soared to $290 billion in 1992.
Mr. Armey outlined the House Republicans' plans today on the ABC News program "This Week with David Brinkley." "What we have decided to do, in January, we will build an American tax-relief savings account," he said. "Through rescissions, through lowering the spending caps and through other budget reforms, we will actually bank the money.
"We will bank the money in January with the spending cuts. Then as we pass the tax proposal, all of which we intend to pass before April 15, we will spend out of that savings account to pay it down."
In this way, he said, Americans "will be reassured that the spending cuts come first."

HEADLINE: Capitol's New Jobless Greet the Future

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Boxes were packed, the desk was bare, and the Rayburn House Office Building was no longer home to Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas.
Along with Congressional aides, press officers, staff assistants, secretaries and elevator operators, Mr. Glickman was joining the ranks of the 3,600 Capitol Hill workers left unemployed by the demise of the Democratic majority. Even worse, so was his wife, Rhoda, who for the last 13 years has headed one of the 28 Congressional caucuses whose financing the new Republican-controlled Congress plans to eliminate. 
 One recent day, the Glickmans sat among packing crates in his cream-colored office, eating shoestring potatoes from a can and reminiscing about the election, their 18 years in Washington and what they would miss. And although they said they had no immediate money worries, they wondered about their future.
"I was a little more prepared than some folks because I had worked for the White House Committee on the Family during the Carter Administration, and when he lost I had six months of depression," said Mrs. Glickman. " But this is Washington. This is part of the life." Until the election, Mrs. Glickman had headed the Congressional Arts Caucus.
Joking about the Capitol's notorious reputation for abandoning those out of power, Mr. Glickman said, "The only one working in the family now is our son, and he won't take our calls."
But in truth, Mrs. Glickman said, she and her husband had been spared that humiliation. "We were overwhelmed by the number of people who called," she said. "Everyone says that once you lose, the phone calls stop. But they haven't."
Before last month's election, when the balance of power shifted further than most people had expected, Mr. Glickman -- who was well liked back home in Wichita -- had expected to be re-elected to a 10th term in Kansas's Fourth Congressional District. On a coffee table cluttered with items to be shipped or discarded sat a letter from a constituent saying that it was not Mr. Glickman, but the anti-Democratic, anti-Washington tide that had swept him away.
"The race was not on the radar screen," said Mr. Glickman, who lost to Todd Tiahrt, a Republican who ran a grass-roots campaign fueled by evangelical and Catholic conservatives. "I thought I had very little chance of losing until a couple of weeks before the election."
Mr. Glickman is losing more than just the office, the perquisites, the ability to deliver services to constituents and the salary. As the departing chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, he is also losing his access to the most sensitive of secrets -- the inside information on Russia and North Korea, the Central Intelligence Agency's most highly classified papers.
Mr. Glickman also said he felt that his last two years had been his most productive for his district. For example, he won passage of a bill that limited manufacturers' liability for older planes, freeing companies from the threat of many costly lawsuits. In Wichita, an airplane plant reopened, with the promise of 2,000 new jobs.
But in the end, that did not make enough of a difference. "I honestly believe that in people's minds, I had become identified with Congress, even though I hadn't fallen victim to the royalty," he said. "I liken it to a bear market; sometimes the good stocks got hit every bit as much as the bad stocks. In this case, I think I was a good stock."
Since Nov. 8, the Glickmans have spent evenings dining with other displaced Democrats, commiserating and replaying various campaign scenarios.
"You spend a lot of time talking about the race," said Mrs. Glickman. Completing his wife's thought, Mr. Glickman added: "Thinking to yourself, if so-and-so had been my campaign manager, would this have happened? And interviewing for jobs."
For now, the Glickmans have not decided whether to leave Washington. She said she was interested in finding a job that affected social policy. Although Mr. Glickman mentioned several options, he is reportedly being courted by law firms here who see his pro-business stance as a plus.
In addition, Mr. Glickman is among those being considered to replace Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. Still, Mr. Glickman said he would miss being a Congressman.
"I'll miss being recognized and being fawned over," he joked. "Now the only unrequited love I'll have is from my beagle."
Despite Mr. Glickman's touch of humor, a wistful note crept into his voice as he fingered his tie tack shaped like a sunflower, the state flower of Kansas.
"I came in with the class of '76, with Al Gore and Panetta and Gephardt," he said. "The class that's running the country. These are my contemporaries. Everybody gives their eyeteeth for this job.
"And this office," Mr. Glickman said. "I'll miss this office. And the mail. I just love opening the mail. I'd come in on the weekend just to open the mail."

As they discussed their future, they were surrounded by boxes from Mr. Glickman's office. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mexican Banking's New Scorecard

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Moving boxes were stacked by the reception desk and no one knew the number of the telephone in the conference room, but the new J. P. Morgan financial group in Mexico City opened for business anyway this month as one of the first new American banks in Mexico since 1932.
The arrival of Morgan, along with a pack of other foreign competitors, has opened a new era of global competition in Mexico's financial sector. The new institutions could push Mexico's 36 banks, which were privatized or created in the last few years, to become more aggressive and efficient. The Government sold the country's large national banks to private investors starting in 1991 after a disastrous period of Government ownership. 
 "The presence of foreign competition is one of the great challenges we face," the new president of the Mexican Bankers Association, Jose Madariaga, said at the annual bankers' convention. "We must recognize that as one of the forces of the process of opening and something that will form part of our strategy of the future."
The foreign banks were allowed in by the North American Free Trade Agreement, which not only lowers tariffs but also removes regulations covering trade and commerce among the United States, Canada and Mexico. On Oct. 17, Mexico opened its financial markets to outsiders like Morgan by approving the presence of 18 foreign banks, 16 brokerage houses, 12 insurance companies, 1 leasing company and 5 financial groups.
Some American financial institutions have moved into more than one sector. The Morgan financial group, for example, consists of a bank and a brokerage house.
"We bring to the table not only our checkbook to start lending to the top corporations in pesos, but better techniques and better banking practices," said Eduardo Cepeda, 37, the managing director of Morgan in Mexico. Mexican banks, he said, "will have to basically speed up and catch up."
Until the trade accord, Citibank, which has done business here for 65 years, was the only foreign banking institution operating openly in Mexico. It remained after tough Government restrictions prompted other foreign banks to leave. Citibank now intends to expand its branches, market its credit cards and offer brokerage services.
Just how much competition the new banks represent worries Mexican bankers. During the first half of 1994, many Mexican banks reported declining profits and expanding portfolios of bad loans. The banking industry was shaken last September when Government regulators seized control of two national banks and accused the president of the group that runs them, Carlos Cabal Peniche, of lending himself $700 million.
Mr. Cepeda said he expected some head-to-head competition in specialized fields like underwriting and corporate lending. But he said it was unlikely that the new foreign banks would open branches and go into the retail market, or that an interest-rate war would break out as the banks scrambled for market share.
"Ultimately, the man on the street will also benefit," Mr. Cepeda said. "Some of the domestic banks will say, forget about competing with J. P. Morgan in, say, trading derivatives, if they can make money by providing a very good service and doing a good margin on the retail side."
Some financial analysts see the market differently. "We cannot ignore the fact that the spirit of Mexico's financial opening was to increase competition," said Rafael Bello, a banking analyst with Morgan Stanley, which has approval to establish a brokerage office in Mexico.
Competition in corporate lending may force some Mexican banks to shift their focus to less profitable and more risky consumer banking. They will be pressured to improve service and perhaps offer more competitive interest rates. Some Mexican banks without sufficient resources could try to ally with stronger institutions.
Morgan, which has initial capitalization in Mexico of $114 million, looks unlikely to go after passbook savers. Its threshold for most transactions is $50 million.
Morgan has done business with the Mexican Government and Mexico's 100 largest companies for a century without being here. In 1980, it opened a representative office in Mexico, through which it could make loans and sell bonds for Mexican clients, but only outside Mexico. Last May, the company arranged $700 million of a $1.1 billion internationally syndicated loan for the Government oil company, Pemex. Morgan, which has subsidiaries in 17 countries, can now handle peso-denominated instruments and trade stock for clients in Mexico as well as in New York and the rest of the world.
Under the terms of North American accord, foreign banks in Mexico are treated the same as national banks, but with these restrictions: At first, the foreign banks as a group are limited to 8 percent of the total banking capital in Mexico, and no single bank can account for more than 1.5 percent. By 1999, that overall limit will be raised to 15 percent. The cap will be lifted in 2000, although the Government reserves the right to reimpose a cap if foreign participation in Mexico exceeds 25 percent of the total banking capital.
No Canadian banks sought a Mexican license, preferring to rely on their representative offices here, but French, German and Spanish banks applied and are poised to enter. Financial analysts here said the approvals given Fuji Bank and the Bank of Tokyo are especially significant for the Mexican economy, because these institutions tend to do business with Japanese manufacturing companies, which could arrive after the banks.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New President of Conde Nast Predicts Clear Sailing Ahead

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Reflecting the new upbeat mood spreading through the magazine industry, Steven T. Florio, who became president of Conde Nast Publications Inc. in April, said that in 1994 the company experienced its largest financial improvement in years.
"And as we go into 1995, it is my belief that every single magazine will be up in ad pages for the first quarter," Mr. Florio said in an interview last week. "We are just closing the March issues, and we will have a better idea by the first week in January. But right now it looks as if we will be up 20 percent in advertising pages for all the magazines." 
 It has been five years since this kind of talk has been heard in the magazine industry. After seeing an overall increase in advertising pages for the 185 magazines measured by the Publishers Information Bureau for 10 of the first 11 months of 1994, many publishers are sharing Mr. Florio's belief that the advertising recession that has dogged the magazine industry since 1989 is finally over.
"Advertising has really turned around," said Martin S. Walker, chairman of Walker Communications, a magazine consultant. "But remember the first quarter of 1994 was a disaster, so the 20 percent increase is coming off a very low base."
The real question, or course, is not whether advertising is up, but whether overall revenue and -- more to the point -- profits are up.
Conde Nast is a privately held company that plays its cards close to the vest and does not disclose financial information. But earlier this month, at a lunch in a private room at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan, S.I. Newhouse, the chairman of Conde Nast, told about 50 executives that the improved performance in 1994 reflected profits as well as revenue, according to people who attended the lunch.
Mr. Florio declined to identify the magazines that were losing money. But an executive at the company said all the magazines were profitable except Mademoiselle, Bon Appetit and Details, which were described as "close, but not over the top."
The other big Conde Nast magazines include Allure, Architectural Digest, Bride's, Glamour, Gourmet, GQ, Vanity Fair, Self and Conde Nast Traveler. In addition, Conde Nast's parent, Advance Publications, owns The New Yorker.
In terms of advertising pages, six Conde Nast magazines showed losses through November: Architectural Digest, down 3 percent from the first 11 months of 1993; GQ, down 8 percent; Vanity Fair, down 16 percent; Mademoiselle, down 25 percent; Bon Appetit, down 36 percent, and Glamour, down 8 percent.
Still, Mr. Florio is clearly on a roll, anticipating a turnaround based on January and February ad pages, which have already been scheduled.
As soon as the announcement was made in January that he would leave his job as president and chief executive of The New Yorker to become president of Conde Nast in June, Mr. Florio moved into the company's headquarters at 350 Madison Avenue and began to make his presence known, even though his predecessor, Bernard H. Leser, still held the title.
By April, Mr. Florio had made so many new appointments that the pretense that he was only president-elect was dropped and he officially assumed his new position.
He has appointed 18 top executives, which include new publishers for Bon Appetit, Details, Conde Nast Traveler, GQ, Glamour, Self and Vanity Fair. He said his teams were now in place. "What's done is done," he said.
Conde Nast is considering several ideas for new magazines and will probably announce a start-up around the middle of next year to begin publication in 1996. "It would be a natural extension of what we do best," Mr. Florio said, but he declined to elaborate.
James Truman, editorial director of Conde Nast, said an entertainment magazine was not under consideration, contrary to a published report. "There are several ideas knocking back and forth and we are going to see which one germinates," he said.
Mr. Florio also expects to announce early next year a new interactive publishing project involving food and travel. The company is still deciding on the way in which it will participate in the new media, but Mr. Florio made it clear that the emphasis would be on editorial content. "That's what drives the company," he said.
Mr. Florio has been a strong presence since taking charge, an exuberant man whose enthusiasm has re-energized the company. He is known as a good manager with a keen instinct for appointing the right person to the right job.
"He taught me how to manage a big staff, how to be fair, how to be exacting and how to create an environment that focuses on creativity while giving people latitude to make their own decisions," said Lynn W. Heiler, publisher of Bon Appetit.
Mr. Florio hired Ms. Heiler to work for him at GQ and then brought her with him to The New Yorker as publisher. Mr. Florio came to the New Yorker from GQ, where he had risen through the advertising ranks to become publisher.
"It is a tremendous help that he came out of sales," Ms. Heiler said. "He is still a salesman and can relate to the situation."
Perhaps the most successful coup engineered by Mr. Florio so far was convincing General Motors to start advertising again in Conde Nast publications, after the auto maker had pulled its advertising eight years ago because Conde Nast would not give it special discounts. People close to the company estimate that the return of G.M. will mean about 500 pages of advertising in 1995, valued at $20 million in revenues.
"Steve's genius is that he got the G.M. deal done," the editor in chief of Self, Alexandra Penney, said. "It was there to do but nobody could do it but Steve."
What distinguishes Mr. Florio from the presidents at many other magazine companies is that he is clearly interested in editorial content. He is said to enjoy a good working relationship with Mr. Truman.
Mr. Florio and Mr. Truman are constantly wandering into each other's offices in what Mr. Truman described as "a casual but close partnership."
So casual is the partnership, in fact, that one day when Mr. Truman, a boxing enthusiast who spars with a teacher once a week, mentioned that he had a pair of boxing gloves in his office, Mr. Florio, who can never refuse a challenge, suggested a quick round. They each put on one glove and began dancing around the office. "He stole the advantage," Mr. Truman said. "We're both right-handed and he took the right glove."
The two men, whose relationship is under constant scrutiny by the company, provided a spectacle that, had it been witnessed, would probably have sent the Conde Nast rumor mill into double overtime.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
On a White-Water Advertising Ride

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
WHERE THE SUCKERS MOON
An Advertising Story
By Randall Rothenberg
478 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
"When business is good it pays to advertise; when business is bad you've got to advertise," an old adage holds. By the late 1980's business had finally gone bad for Subaru of America, which sold 183,242 of its practical if unsexy Japanese-made sedans and wagons in 1986 but saw sales drop to 108,547 in 1990. 
 So when the sales company was taken over in 1991 by Fuji Heavy Industries, the manufacturer of the cars, and the decision was made to retool Subaru's image by hiring a new advertising agency, Randall Rothenberg, then a media reporter for The New York Times, saw an irresistible opportunity. Knowing how much it meant to an agency to land a lucrative car account, he got Subaru's permission to cover the selection process from the inside and report on it, first in an article for The New York Times Magazine and now in this book, "Where the Suckers Moon: An Advertising Story."
As one can sense from its title, which comes from a line by the writer A. J. Liebling, "Fortune swims, not with the main stream of letters, but in the shallows, where the suckers moon," the book does not tell a story of resounding success. After screening hundreds of agencies, Subaru of America finally settled on Wieden & Kennedy, a hot young outfit in Portland, Ore., put on the map by its contribution to Nike's high-flying advertising.
As Mr. Rothenberg tells it, Wieden & Kennedy created a series of ads for Subaru that were based on the tag line "What to drive" but were richer in trendiness than in detailing the virtues of the product. Understandably, this didn't play well with the dealers, who saw the message as implicitly designed to drive the customer away. Defects in the quality of the ads, the balky Bush economy and Fuji's refusal to lower production quotas combined to do the rest of the damage. Wieden & Kennedy ended up being dismissed.
Mr. Rothenberg follows the entire process like a gray-flannel fly on the wall, reconstructing those few scenes at which he was not present. At every opportunity, he whizzes back into relevant history, for instance to trace the migration of the ad business to and from Madison Avenue or to describe the watershed of so-called creative advertising that was represented by the famous Volkswagen ads ("Think Small") created by Doyle Dane Bernbach.
The author's skeptical outlook can be entertaining and instructive, particularly where he digs up stories like the one in which George Lois, "the Marat of the Creative Revolution," signed up a Japanese baseball star as a pitchman for Subaru -- "You taught us baseball; we're teaching you how to make cars" -- only to discover that the player was actually Korean.
Or where he traces the rise of West Coast advertising and explains the development of "a post-modern sensibility in the advertising industry." As he puts it, advertising could be "metacommentary," or "art that explicated, through irony, camp, iconic reference or self-reference, the commercial itself and the consumer culture of which it was part."
The drawback of "Suckers" is that Mr. Rothenberg goes on at too great length with a story that doesn't quite bear the weight of his commentary. A greater handicap still is that moral disdain for the culture of advertising is such an ancient exercise that this reader for one tended to discount Mr. Rothenberg's subtle ridicule and to look for the virtues of effective salesmanship, a necessary evil in a free-market economy, despite all of John Kenneth Galbraith's complaints.
But what you get in "Suckers" is a surfeit of people who themselves have contempt for the advertising game; whose attitude is summed up by one art director's television commercial that began with the statement "Karl Marx once described advertising as maggots feeding on the rotting corpse of capitalism," and concluded with the response "Let's do lunch."
In fact, as Mr. Rothenberg presents his story, this attitude lies at the heart of why Wieden & Kennedy's Subaru campaign failed: it was written by people who not only disliked advertising in general but also despised cars in particular. As Jerry Cronin, the creative director on Subaru of America's advertising account sums up his own attitude: "I want people to know what cars can do. They won't make you feel better or more successful. . . . I want to separate people from their cars, get rid of the emotional bind. People are far too attached to their cars. I want them to see that cars are a hunk of metal. Automotive advertising is the biggest lie of all time. You want to live better, look better -- buy a grill, go to the gym!"
So despite the distastefulness of so many of its characters, Babbitts and anti-Babbitts alike, "Where the Suckers Moon" remains a revealing job of reporting. Mr. Rothenberg concludes his narrative by describing a party given to watch the 1993 Super Bowl on television for people more interested in advertisements than in football. His immediate point is that in their awareness of the advertisements, Subaru's finished dead last. But the deeper message of the anecdote is that there are people who care about what advertisements tell them. And the way to their hearts and minds is not through condescension.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Randall Rothenberg (Susan Roy/Alfred A. Knopf)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Leading From Behind

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In the final part of his speech to the nation last Thursday hardly mentioned in press reports -- President Clinton spoke with eloquence about the need for civility and community in our politics.
"Citizens have to listen as well as talk," the President said. "We need less hot rhetoric and more open conversation, less malice and more charity. . . . we have got to be a community again." 
 True. But a democracy also needs leadership -- leadership that speaks to citizens in terms of reality, not popularity. On that score Mr. Clinton's speech was a disaster, for the country and for him.
"It was a moment when he had to show command and conviction," Doris Kearns Goodwin said. "That was the way to restore respect for him and the office. Instead he changed his policy and followed the Republicans."
Ms. Goodwin's new book, "No Ordinary Time," is the story of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt during World War II. As an example of Presidential leadership, she cited Roosevelt's calling for lend-lease aid to embattled Britain when polls showed little support for aid -- and persuading the country that it was right.
"That is what leadership is all about," Ms. Goodwin said the other day: "Staking your ground ahead of where opinion is and convincing people, not simply following the popular opinion of the moment."
Virtually all economists, right across the political spectrum, think tax cuts now are a terrible idea. Among other things, they take the focus away from the need to bring down the budget deficit.
The Federal Reserve Board, seeing a relaxation of budget discipline, is likely to raise interest rates even higher than it already has. That would take the steam out of a growing economy, leaving more Americans unemployed and more with falling pre-tax incomes. What good will largely symbolic tax cuts do then?
During his first two years in office, President Clinton emphasized deficit reduction and achieved remarkable results. The annual deficit has been cut from $290 billion to $160 billion: the first downward movement in many years.
In calling for $60 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, Mr. Clinton said he would pay for that with reductions in Federal spending. But he was slow to say how; and his own budget director, Alice Rivlin, was strongly opposed to the idea of lowering taxes.
The public does want leaner government. But if the President has good ideas on how to reduce spending, he could and should carry them out regardless of tax cuts -- and use the saved money for valuable programs and for deficit reduction.
Of course anyone would enjoy lower taxes. When people were polled after the President's speech, 75 percent said they liked his proposals. But in the same poll, 64 percent said they thought reducing the deficit was more important than reducing taxes. Americans are not so stupid.
The reason Mr. Clinton switched policy gears and went back to this long-abandoned campaign call for a middle-class tax cut was obvious to everyone who heard the speech. Newt Gingrich's winning "Contract With America" promised lower taxes. The President was mimicking Newtonian politics.
How could a man as smart as Bill Clinton believe that copy-cat tactics would enhance his standing? Would make Americans look to him for leadership?
A speech that actually led the country -- and made Mr. Clinton look like a leader -- would not have been hard to write.
"The tax cuts you hear about," he might have said, "would buy the average American family a pizza a week. And we would pay a high price for that as a country: the risk of inflation and higher interest rates that would make most people worse off."
In short, he might have appealed to the sense of community that he extolled last Thursday. Instead, we are likely now to have a bidding war on lower taxes, with one irresponsible proposal topping another. And Bill Clinton will be like Gilbert and Sullivan's Duke of Plaza Toro: "He led his regiment from behind / He found it less exciting."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Despite Request for Freeze, Cuomo Is Filling State Jobs

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Despite a request for a hiring freeze by Governor-elect George E. Pataki, the Cuomo administration has hired hundreds of people in the five weeks following the Nov. 8 election.
Most of the new state workers were hired to fill relatively low-level positions, the kinds of jobs that state officials say are necessary to insure that roads are cleared of snow, sheets are changed at psychiatric centers and bathrooms are cleaned at state buildings. But others have filled jobs considered less essential to the public's health and safety. 
 The new employees include a grant processor at the Department of Economic Development; a conservation educator at the Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation; clerks at the Department of Motor Vehicles, and an assistant business officer at Rockland Psychiatric Center.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican who will take office on Jan. 1 after defeating Mr. Cuomo last month, said in an interview that he found the hiring "very disturbing."
"I just don't know whether it's a deliberate political decision or it's simply a business-as-usual approach, but either way I don't think it's right," he said. "We have requested a hiring freeze from the Governor. Obviously, it hasn't happened, and that's disappointing."
Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff, Andrew J. Zambelli, said that Mr. Cuomo had never promised to freeze hiring. "We said we weren't going to do a freeze per se but that we would reduce costs and would remind people of that as they moved forward," Mr. Zambelli said. "The vast majority of these new positions are in institutions, where the issues of staffing ratios and Federal requirements are constantly being monitored."
Mr. Pataki has been concerned about the Cuomo administration's post-election hiring practices since late November, when news reports revealed that a Department of Motor Vehicles official had sent a memorandum to subordinates announcing that his goal was "to fill every item before an anticipated job and promotion freeze."
Mr. Pataki says the standard for hiring during the transition should be whether the position is absolutely essential and whether it needs to be filled now. He added that the post-election hiring would complicate the task of closing a large projected gap in the budget for the fiscal year that begins on April 1.
"It's important to us to keep those positions vacant if they're not essential, because we don't want to have to be in a position where they get a job and then they're laid off," he said.The gap in next year's budget has been estimated at $4 billion, even without the estimated $1 billion first-year cost of Mr. Pataki's plan to cut income tax rates.
The Governor-elect believes the gap could grow even larger in the next few months. A report released by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall shows that the state's personal income tax receipts in November fell $99.3 million below projections made in October, contributing to a $96.5 million shortfall in this year's general fund budget.
After learning of the size of next year's projected budget gap, Mr. Pataki wrote Mr. Cuomo on Nov. 21 requesting "a freeze on hiring new state employees, promotion of current employees, reclassification or other personnel action in all but essential areas until after Jan. 1."
The Governor responded in a letter that his staff would "work to limit the filling of vacant positions in the state general-fund work force."
Two days later, Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Rudy F. Runko, informed his staff that state agencies should not do any hiring that would increase the size of the state's general-fund payroll unless workers were needed to protect the health and safety of employees or clients, said Claudia S. Hutton, Mr. Runko's spokeswoman.
But those determinations were left up to the agencies, and many apparently have continued to hire employees without following Mr. Runko's standard.
The Office of Mental Health, for instance, hired 116 workers after Nov. 23, the day that Mr. Runko issued his edict. Many of them provide direct care to patients in psychiatric centers. But others -- like a laborer hired on Nov. 28 for the agency's headquarters in Albany and the assistant business officer at Rockland Psychiatric Institute, who was hired on Dec. 2 -- do not.
Similar cases were found at many of the three dozen state agencies surveyed by The New York Times. At the Department of Environmental Conservation, an environmental engineer, an engineering geologist and a forestry technician were hired on Nov. 28.
The Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation hired 11 people on Dec. 1, ranging from park workers to a mechanic to an assistant purchasing agent to the conservation educator. The conservation educator "teaches people what kind of trees they're seeing, not to mess up trails, what kind of leaves, that kind of thing," said Steve Osborne, a spokesman for the agency.
In all, close to 1,000 people have been hired by the state since Election Day.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 29, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 19 about hiring by New York State during the transition between the Cuomo and Pataki administrations referred incorrectly in some copies to the agency being monitored by Michael Clemente, a Pataki transition aide. It is the Department of Civil Service, not the Department of Motor Vehicles.

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: Watching Out for 'Panic Shoppers'

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

 BODY:
Marian Goodman is waiting for the men to arrive.
 "The men'll be here," said the 40-year-old assistant store manager at Bloomingdale's flagship in midtown Manhattan, accelerating past a snow-white Clinique counter toward trays of ties layered like freshly caught fish. "You see the panic shopper. You can see the look on their faces." 
 Men," she declared, "are panic shoppers."
 After 18 years in department stores, Ms. Goodman's instincts, about shoppers, hot items and men's buying habits, are honed like a good boning knife. And this is the time of year when those instincts are tested.
 In this last week before Christmas, Ms. Goodman and thousands of buyers and executives at department stores, toy stores, apparel shops and jewelry boutiques across the country are on trial. "Many typical stores generate 50 percent of their sales and 70 percent of their profits during the period from Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Walter F. Loeb, a retailing consultant in New York.
 No hard data are yet available about how this Christmas shopping season is faring but Wall Street analysts are estimating that sales will be up 6 to 8 percent, and profits somewhat less, over last year.
 Across America, from the biggest retailers to the neighborhood toy shop, the sounds most eagerly awaited are not Santa's "Ho Ho Ho," or Bing Crosby's liquid "White Christmas," but the beep, ratchet and ring of cash registers and the rustle of shopping bags filling.
 And though those bags are filling, come January many retailers may rue their bottom lines. Some shoppers are buying with abandon, but others seem cautious as they browse.
 "I'm getting people things they would not spend money on for themselves," explained a harried Debra Fulscher, the director of client services and administration in the Chicago office of Trimedia Inc., an advertising and marketing firm, who was shopping in downtown Chicago last week.
 After driving in from her home in Barrington, Ill., Ms. Fulscher visited Tiffany's -- and bought a $425 gold cross for her boyfriend. "I wanted to make it something special instead of just going to a regular jeweler," she said. Besides gifts for her own family, she bought some presents -- mostly clothing and toiletries -- for a 4-year-old girl on Chicago's South Side, whose family was "adopted" by a church group that provides gifts to the needy.
 Also cruising Chicago's stores was Brenda Large of Ironton, Ohio, who was shopping between sessions at a conference she was attending. Ms. Large said she expected to spend about $3,000 on Christmas gifts. "The economy continues to be pretty good in our area," she said. "It hasn't had much of a negative effect on us."
 There were the usual presents of clothing for some of her adult children, but this year she also plunked down money for some pricier gifts -- a television for a daughter who attends Ohio State University and an exercise bicycle for another daughter and her husband.
 Yet, even with such enthusiastic shoppers, blips of concern are popping up across the retailing map. Pre-Christmas sales are already in full swing at many stores, paring profits dramatically even as sales volume surges.
 "Many retailers are looking at the lower end of their expectations," Mr. Loeb said.
 Vicki Malafronte, her ears wedged with rhinestone earrings, bustled around one of her perfume counters at Nordstrom's in San Francisco, and fretted: "It's frustrating. The crowds aren't showing up yet, even though the weekends have been okay. It's just not cranking up like it was last year."
Many senior executives, when questioned about sales, begin by exuding holiday and commercial cheer in equal bounty, but, when pressed, they acknowledge some worries.
 "Last year we had the best Christmas in our history, and this year we expect to do better," said John H. Costello, a senior vice president for marketing at Sears, Roebuck & Company in Chicago.
 At the 2,000 Sears stores across the country, Mr. Costello said customers were "focused on both wants and wishes," adding, "They are buying practical gifts they need, as well as little luxuries that make Christmas a little more special."
 In the Sears store in Hicksville, L.I., "the bags are nice and full, but certain categories are doing better than others," said Thomas Clarke, the general manager there. Hardware, a Sears staple, "has been coming through very, very nicely," he said. "In men's wear, ramie cotton sweaters with lots of vibrant colors mixed in together, wrinkle-free pants by Docker and Haggar, are all doing very well. And outerwear is finally starting to kick in. You know, when it starts to get to 30 degrees, you can't go out without a coat on, so that's definitely picking up."
 What is not doing so well, he said, is women's wear. "Women's is not really cranked up because the men are not shopping yet," he said. "But jewelry is a really big boomer. Very large increases over last year. The average ticket is well over $100, from $100 to $200."
 Other retailers are singing the apparel blues, too. "I think generally speaking apparel sales throughout the industry have not been up to expectations," said Henry J. Russman, a spokesman for the 1,250-store J.C. Penney chain, which offers lower-priced men's and women's wear.
 And Donald Hess, chief executive of Parisian Inc., a Birmingham, Ala., clothing retailer with stores from Detroit to Sarasota, Fla., said, The year continues to be a pretty tough year for apparel."
 Yet some companies, like Talbots Inc., which specializes in classic women's wear, are less concerned. Clark J. Hinkley, the executive vice president and chief executive of the 392-store company, said, "It's not as big a dependency for us, Christmas. We run a more balanced business throughout the year."
 The hottest items, he said, involve velvet: sportswear, dresses, trim on dresses. "It's just a great trend we're seeing," he said. "Vests are next; that's a new trend for us. And the third major thing is jumpers, fine gauge sweaters and pants. We've seen a major swing from skirts."
At Carson Pirie Scott & Company, which is based in Milwaukee and operates 32 department and furniture stores in the Midwest, snow and a biting wind have warmed Ed Carroll's heart. "Cold weather goods, which were backing up on us and other retailers the last few weeks, well, when the snow hit, the sales skyrocketed," said Mr. Carroll, the executive vice president for marketing. Hats, gloves, coats, boots and sweaters have all posted double-digit increases in sales over last year, he said.
 In Atlanta, Marsha Brinkley, co-owner of Hermit Island, a small shop selling eclectic goods from Central and South America and Asia, said things were looking good.
 "Business is definitely up over last year," Ms. Brinkley said. "The retailers all over the mall are talking about it. Our business is much stronger."
 Ms. Brinkley said that in addition to increased volume, shoppers seem willing to spend more. "Last year, our best-selling item was $6.95," she said. "This year we have things priced at $50 and $60 that are walking out the door as fast as we can get them on the shelves."
 In San Francisco, shoppers are deluging stores, large and small. At Williams-Sonoma Inc., a high-end cookware store -- La Cornue French stoves run from $11,000 to $17,000, though none yet have sold yet this Christmas -- the hottest items are terra cotta garlic bakers, made in Taiwan, selling for $7 and $16.
 "Sales are still up comfortably over last year," said Howard Lester, the company's chief executive, who was, nonetheless, chary with hard numbers. "We've got nothing to worry about."
 Yet there were some signs of moderation.
 "We're doing something this year that we see more and more of," Linda Bertolli of Berkeley said of her family's plans. "We pick names and get a present for that one individual." But she cheats on that system, she said, by buying something for her mother and her mother-in-law, and small presents for a gaggle of nieces and nephews.
 Aside from winter clothes for her husband, Ms. Bertolli said she had found "a terrific gift" for her brother -- a miniature Etch-a-Sketch that can fit on a key ring.
 "I'm definitely spending less this year, and for a couple of reasons," she said. "We made a conscious decision to spend less and to give more to charity. This year we'll donate to Fresh Start Farms, a group that tries to put homeless parents to work developing rooftop urban gardens."
 Ms. Bertolli also said her company, which buys and trades mailing lists for left-of-center nonprofit organizations, had not had a great year.
 At Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, in a windowless office tucked behind racks of Barbie dolls and infants' wear, David L. Fisher, a senior vice president, was plotting the last days of the Christmas season.
 "November was spectacular for 59th Street," he exuded. "The first reason is we consciously put a lot of effort into being in stock and in depth in key items -- basic sweaters, cashmere sweaters, candy and novelty foods. The second reason, frankly, is the weakness of the dollar. Bloomingdale's is on the hit parade for foreign tourists."
 Yet, like many other retailers, Mr. Fisher acknowledged, "December has not been as strong for the first two weeks as November was."
 One problem for retailers, he said, is that people keep delaying their Christmas shopping. "It's just getting later and later," he said. "A box of Godiva chocolates will wind up being something you buy at the last minute."
 Down on the floor, maneuvering though clots of shoppers, Ms. Goodman stooped to pick up a scrap of paper, glanced at her ever-chirping beeper and shooshed a shopper toward kitchenware.
 "This is my 19th Christmas," she said, between words of encouragement to people folding sweaters, tying ribbons and trying to spritz perfume on customers. "This week I was here 'til midnight on Tuesday. At this time of year, I need to be flexible."
 As she zoomed past racks of children's clothing on eight, she swung by Santa Claus, who was twiddling his thumbs, the vicinity clear of wandering children. Ms. Goodman popped onto his lap.
 "And what do you want for Christmas, my dear," he asked through a bush of clip-on white beard.
 "Happiness, for my kids to graduate," she said, "and to make my sales plan."

HEADLINE: Orange County's Emergency Expert

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 14

 BODY:
Thomas W. Hayes, the former California state treasurer hired to help salvage Orange County's loss-plagued investment fund, is no stranger to fiscal emergencies.
Gov. Pete Wilson, upon taking office in 1991 just as California plunged into a recession that shattered the state's economy, turned to Mr. Hayes as the principal architect of his $55 billion state budget, which required both painful spending cuts and tax increases. Earlier, Mr. Hayes defied state tradition by putting the underwriting of its bonds up for public bid. Along the way, he developed a reputation as a better financial expert than as a politician. 
 "He's willing to take on big challenges and get down in the foxhole," said Larry Thomas, a campaign adviser to Governor Wilson, who recommended Mr. Hayes to the county's Board of Supervisors.
In an interview, Mr. Hayes said his strategy in Orange County is to liquidate the remaining $5 billion or so in assets as soon as possible but "without a fire sale," replacing them with more conservative securities that mature in no more than 180 days. Orange County has now began disposing of some of the more plain vanilla bonds in its portfolio.
Hired for 90 days, Mr. Hayes has also developed a work-out plan that, if necessary, calls for arm-twisting some Government-sponsored agencies that issued bonds especially sensitive to interest rates to buy them back at an advantageous price. He is also trying to spread the county's fund losses over several years, a process that involves rescheduling interest payments owed on debt.
Since being chosen on Dec. 8, Mr. Hayes has seen his workdays stretch, sometimes to 22 hours. His phone rings at least 100 times a day. Among the calls are those from some of the 187 investors in the county's pool, which has a loss of $2.02 billion, or 27 percent. A lot of the calls go unanswered.
"You have to keep your focus on the main goal," he said. "Unfortunately, that's going to irritate a lot of people because they aren't going to get through to you."
Being pulled back into the public arena, with all its demands, is one reason, among others, that Mr. Hayes's wife, Mary, did not want him to take the job. The family, which includes two daughters, live in the exclusive Sacramento suburb of Rancho Murieta, where Mr. Hayes has been working as a private investment adviser and trader.
Gray-haired and mild-mannered, Mr. Hayes, who is 49, acknowledges: "Quite frankly I'm not comfortable with politics." He prefers to be "invisible" and professes no further political ambitions. Indeed, he was not registered with any political party until he was appointed state treasurer by then-Gov. George Duekmejian. He then registered as a Republican.
Until taking on the around-the-clock job in Orange County, Mr. Hayes devoted his spare time to his two hobbies, golf and cooking, and gave financial advice to emerging nations. After the Ferdinand Marcos regime toppled in the Philippines, for example, he made 10 trips to Manila. Meanwhile, 100 Filipino officials came to California under his sponsorship for study and internships.
Appointed treasurer in 1989, Mr. Hayes replaced Jesse Unruh, a longstanding California legislator and public official who died in office and was best known for saying that money is the "mother's milk of politics."
In his two years managing the state's $20 billion investment portfolio, Mr. Hayes decided to put the job of underwriting state bonds up to bid, a highly lucrative task previously at the discretion of the treasurer.
"It was not well received on Wall Street," said Donna Lucas, Mr. Hayes's former campaign manager. Still, she added, some firms that had been shut out of state business were pleased the playing field had been leveled.
In some ways, his even-handed policy came back to haunt Mr. Hayes in his first run at elected office in 1990, when he campaigned to stay in the treasurer's post. He was defeated by his opponent, Kathleen Brown. While both candidates accepted contributions from investment houses and Wall Street firms that did business with the state, Ms. Brown was much more successful, raising $7 million to his $1 million.
Mr. Hayes has long favored competitive bidding. After succeeding his fired boss to become auditor general, Mr. Hayes expanded the bidding process to many more state projects. And in a decade as the state's top auditor, Mr. Hayes issued 600 audits -- many of which were critical of his elected bosses.
"He was completely nonpartisan," said Alfred E. Alquist, a Democrat from San Jose, and chairman of the state Senate budget committee.
Last year, Mr. Hayes quit his job in the Wilson Administration to specialize in international investing at Metropolitan West Securities of Los Angeles, where he was recently chosen as president. The firm trades securities and gives technical advice to institutional investors, including California's two big pension funds for state employees and teachers.
Mr. Hayes says he can't wait to return.

HEADLINE: Bridge City Journal;
In Taking On a Corporate Goliath, A Small Town Saves Its Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRIDGE CITY, Tex., Dec. 15

 BODY:
Maybe it was the 2,064 signatures on the petitions in this East Texas community of 8,000 people. "Don't do it! Will shop Kmart if you do," one person added. "Don't want a Super store, want this one," wrote another. "I have to have you here!" said a third.
Or maybe it was the impassioned letter from Libby Mitchell and Cheryl Meeks, two housewives who led the protest against the planned closing of the Bridge City Wal-Mart. "Wal-Mart was built on small towns like ours," they said. "Now all over America, corporate Wal-Mart is chipping away at their own foundations, store by store." 
 Or maybe it was the face-to-face meeting between the housewives and executives from the Arkansas-based retailing giant who flew down here on the company jet to see just why people were so angry about the closing, which was intended to make way for a new "Wal-Mart Supercenter" four times larger and a few towns up the highway.
Mrs. Mitchell, a mother of two toddlers, showed up at the meeting clutching a copy of "Made in America," the autobiography of the company's late founder. She had made liberal use of a yellow highlighter to show the founder's canon, right there on page 218, of "thinking small" and his dread of what he termed the "big disease."
" 'Gentlemen,' " the 24-year-old Mrs. Mitchell recalled herself telling the executives, " 'If Sam Walton was here today, I believe Sam would have kept this store open.' "
Whatever it was, the store will stay open.
For the first time on record in a 32-year history, Wal-Mart officials say they have rescinded a planned closing, or a "consolidation" as Wal-Mart prefers to call it. The announcement this week set off a celebration here and prompted a banner headline in the Penny Record, a weekly newspaper: "Wal-Mart Saved!"
The supercenter will still open next month and feature everything from general merchandise and groceries, to a hair salon, a minibank, a dry cleaner and a McDonald's.
There are towns in the United States that have feared and fought the arrival of Wal-Mart, but Bridge City, sitting amid a vast collection of chemical plants near the Louisiana border, was definitely not one.
"Me and my wife, we just love this place," said Mark Howard, a taxi driver. "It has everything you need, clothing to automotive." Mayor Don Peters proudly describes the 14-year-old store as "our local country club."
Indeed, while parts of the Northeast have been hostile to Wal-Mart, in Texas the chain is part of the cultural landscape. There are 234 stores in the state, more than in any other.
But in an odd way, the battle to save the Bridge City Wal-Mart in the face of the new Wal-Mart Supercenter in nearby West Orange is an echo of the battle that many other communities have waged against Wal-Mart in the first place.
People here said the 200,000-square-foot supercenter, the size of nearly four football fields, would be too big, too impersonal. One petitioner wrote: "Superstore too big for senior citizens to walk around."
And people fervently argued that even if the profits did go to Arkansas, the local Wal-Mart supported the local economy, providing a quarter of the town's sales tax receipts, around $150,000 annually, money that would be lost if customers were diverted to the supercenter.
On the other hand, at least in Bridge City, Wal-Mart no longer has to worry so much about competing with local mom-and-pop operations, many of which closed in the face of competition from the store here, though without any evident ire of most townspeople.
Now, Wal-Mart may simply be vying with itself.
"The fact of the matter is, a supercenter is just that," said Don Shinkle, the vice president for corporate affairs of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. "It has nothing but state-of-the-art shopping conveniences for the customers. And the supercenter no doubt is going to provide a lot of competition to that smaller Bridge City store."
While the store here is profitable now, Mr. Shinkle said, the company had believed that it might no longer be so once the supercenter, seven miles away, opened. Nonetheless, he added, "The decision was made by Bill Fields -- let's give Bridge City a chance."
Bill Fields is the president and chief executive officer of Wal-Mart Stores, a division of the Wal-Mart company, and the man who flew down to hear what Mrs. Mitchell and Mrs. Meeks had to say.
To Mrs. Mitchell, an expressive woman with a huge mane of blonde hair whose husband, Barney, works in a local chemical plant, Bill Fields is "a great guy."
Mrs. Mitchell said, "At first, to tell you the truth, our opinion started to get negative on Wal-Mart."
"We couldn't get to these people," she continued. "It was like a big corporate giant with a mask, pretending to be as American as apple pie and listening to their customers when they're really just the opposite and don't care what we think. But as soon as we got to the top, they were everything we hoped they would be. They were so friendly and down to earth."
Mrs. Mitchell and Mrs. Meeks, who waged their campaign around the constant demands of their children, sent cookies by Federal Express to Wal-Mart's corporate offices after the decision to stay was announced. "It was like 30 bucks or something, but we didn't care," she said.
It is possible, of course, that in keeping the Bridge City store open, the company was simply acting to head off a public-relations disaster. The protest had attracted the local press, and some of the petitions seemed to border on desperation:
*"You'll kill Bridge City."
*"When you leave us, you leave us with nothing."
*"Crippled and elderly people can't go to another town!"
*"Care about people, not about money, just this once."
*"Where will we get film developed?"
But Wal-Mart insists that the incident is a classic example of how assiduously it is willing to pay attention to its patrons.

Referring to the company's founder, Mrs. Mitchell told its top executives, "If Sam Walton was here today, I believe Sam would have kept this store open." HEADLINE: Harvard Chief Is to Return Next Semester

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 19

 BODY:
The president of Harvard University, Neil L. Rudenstine, is recovering from what officials here describe as "severe fatigue and exhaustion" that led him to take a leave of absence last month. He is expected to return to work next semester, the university said today.
Harvard's announcement on Nov. 28 that its 59-year-old president was too tired to perform his duties surprised the academic world and led to speculation about what caused him to leave, and to discussions about the difficulties of managing a modern university. 
 Today, in a brief statement, Harvard officials said they expected him to resume his full duties by the end of February, but they continued to be vague about Mr. Rudenstine's condition.
"He has been resting at home and sleeping well," said Dr. Daniel C. Tosteson, the dean of Harvard Medical School. "Diagnostic tests have provided no evidence for bacterial, viral, cardiovascular disease or cancer. His doctors believe that his condition was related to overwork and insufficient sleep."
Although Dr. Tosteson is serving as Mr. Rudenstine's official medical spokesman, he was not available for interviews today. Other Harvard officials declined to comment on Mr. Rudenstine's health, refusing to identify his doctors or to say whether he was treated at a Harvard-affiliated hospital.
James H. Rowe, vice president for community, government and public affairs, said that Mr. Rudenstine has been resting at home, reading biographies of Andrew Jackson and James Madison and a history of D-Day. Mr. Rudenstine went to his annual staff holiday party on Dec. 9. "He joked about how well things were going without him," Mr. Rowe said.
Charles P. Slichter, the senior fellow of the Harvard Corporation, the seven-member board that governs the university, issued a statement about Mr. Rudenstine that said, "We expect that he will begin to resume some of his activities early in the second semester, with a return to full-time duties by the end of February."
The Harvard president's first three years in office have been marked by two major projects: instilling more cooperation among Harvard's nine historically independent faculties, and supervising a $2.1 billion fund-raising drive.
The goals are connected. Rich parts of the university, such as the Harvard Business School, have long been able to raise more money from their wealthy alumni than, say, the School of Public Health. Mr. Rudenstine tried to make the current fund-raising campaign a coordinated effort among all the schools.
One of his first major actions after he became president in 1991 was to appoint Jerry R. Green, an economics professor, to become Harvard's second provost, a post that had not been filled in four decades. But last April, Professor Green resigned his post and returned to teaching. The resignation, coming just weeks before the fund-raising drive began, reflected dissension within Harvard's administration.
As of early December, the university had raised $782 million. Professor Green was succeeded by Albert Carnesale, dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government. Dean Carnesale is serving as the acting president in Mr. Rudenstine's absence.

HEADLINE: Mayor and Medicaid: Old Puzzle, New Approach

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration's call for sharp reductions in health and welfare benefits for the poor represents a new approach to an old problem: how to get New York City out from under the burden of Medicaid.
With the cost of Medicaid steadily rising over the years, New York City mayors, Rudolph W. Giuliani included, have long battled for the state to pay the city's share of these health care costs for the poor. But now Mr. Giuliani has opened a second front and is seeking state approval simply to slash city spending on the Federal program by nearly a third. 
 The shift in strategy, intended to appeal to the new Republican administration in Albany, was signaled last week when Mr. Giuliani's budget director wrote to all city commissioners that the Mayor's second fiscal plan for the city would rely more on cutting health and welfare benefits for the poor than on scaling back government bureaucracy to close a $2 billion gap.
The memorandum by the budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, showed that the Mayor's single largest target was Medicaid, with the Department of Social Services instructed to draft proposals for cutting city spending on the program by $900 million.
Why mayor after mayor has been concerned with Medicaid costs has to do with New York City's peculiar relationship with New York State.
In most parts of the country, Federal and state governments split the costs of Medicaid. But in New York -- in a formula that was born of upstate reluctance to pay for New York City's poor -- the state and its localities share Medicaid costs that are not met by the Federal Government.
The result has been that Medicaid, at a cost of $2.6 billion a year to the city, is now the second largest item in its budget behind education, and more costly than the Police Department.
The growth in Medicaid expenses has far outstripped inflation or the overall growth of city spending. "It has been growing on average at about 12 percent a year for the last four or five years," Mr. Lackman said. "It is the single biggest budget buster."
For more than a decade, New York's mayors sought relief from this burden. Gov. Hugh L. Carey, a Democrat, was the first to propose that the state assume the full local share of Medicaid, as most states do. But neither Mr. Carey nor Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a fellow Democrat, who embraced the idea after him, was able to push a complete Medicaid assumption through a Republican Senate loath to see the state take on such a fiscal burden.
George E. Pataki, who will be the state's first Republican Governor in 20 years, parting company with his Democratic predecessors, says the state's fiscal condition is too dire even to consider a state Medicaid pickup in the coming year. But he has expressed interest in freeing cities from state mandates to provide services and programs. He has also asked Elizabeth P. McCaughey, the incoming Lieutenant Governor, to find ways to cut Medicaid costs.
While Mr. Giuliani says he has not abandoned the quest for the state to assume all local Medicaid costs, he is betting that Mr. Pataki will allow him to make vast reductions in the program, reductions that a Democratic governor would have blocked.
How the administration would actually reduce Medicaid expenditures is unclear. Mr. Giuliani could follow the lead of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, whose administration recently announced a 20 percent reduction in Medicaid payments to hospitals.
He could propose that the city stop paying for anything besides the basic services required by the Federal Government, no longer picking up the bill for prescription drugs, elective abortions, eyeglasses and prostheses.
He could require many more of the city's 1.8 million Medicaid recipients to use managed care, or require the middle-class elderly who turn assets over to children so they can qualify for Medicaid payments for nursing homes to contribute to their own care.
The Mayor could propose that the city sharply cut the number of single adults allowed on Home Relief, a state welfare program that automatically qualifies its recipients for Medicaid. Mr. Lackman has already called for scaling back public assistance programs by $300 million, which would mean a reduction in the number of individuals who receive Home Relief.
In fact, some analysts said Mr. Giuliani would have to use every cost-cutting option imaginable to achieve his goal of nearly $1 billion in Medicaid savings. "That's a 33 percent cut," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund. "To do that you would probably have to be implementing all of the strategies simultaneously."
Success for such changes of policy are far from assured, with virtually all of them needing approval from Albany either through legislation or a change in regulations, and some also needing Washington's sign-off.
While Mr. Pataki might embrace plans to scale back health services for the poor, it is far from clear that the Democratic-controlled State Assembly would. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said that without details he could not comment.
Hospitals also maintain a strong lobbying presence in Albany.
And even with state government support, Mr. Giuliani would still have to push plans through an already restive Democratic-controlled City Council.
Opposition is already building. Penelope W. Pi-Sunyer, executive director of the City Project, a coalition of advocacy and labor groups, wrote in an angry open letter to the Mayor that Mr. Lackman had outlined the proposals for cutting health and welfare for the poor on the same day that Mr. Giuliani had unveiled a package of tax breaks for landlords in lower Manhattan.
Yet by planning to make more than half the savings needed to close next year's budget gap through cuts in Medicaid and other public assistance, Mr. Giuliani was challenging those who might oppose him yet share a commitment to New York City's fiscal health. How else would they find such savings in the new city budget?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
 Main Street has been awash in derivatives as brokers making sales pitches for the risky, complex investments besieged municipal officials for the last few years. [Page A1.]
The next chairman of the House Commerce Committee, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, has made it clear he intends to push for much lighter regulation of business. [D1.]
Wall Street's rescue desks can find opportunity even in Orange County's investment-fund disaster. The desks buy loss-plagued bonds like those held by the California county at a deep discount and repackage them for a profitable sale. [D8.]
The Orange County treasurer's and auditor's offices were searched as part of an investigation of the bankruptcy. [D8.]
The E.P.A. will allow 12 Eastern states to impose California's strict tailpipe emission standards on cars. [A16.]
 
Companies
 ITT agreed to acquire Caesars World for $1.7 billion. A combination of the Caesars name and ITT's Sheraton hotels is expected make ITT a force in the gaming industry. [D1.] The deal dashed expectations that ITT would shop for a television network. [D6.]
More retailers are relying on Federal Express, especially in the busiest time before Christmas. Fedex has successfully wooed some big customers from United Parcel Service. [D1.] Fedex has been able to win retail clients by better controlling its costs, and hence its fees. [D2.]
Philip Morris will sell a food-service business in an effort to focus on its brand-name foods. The sale of Kraft Foodservice to Clayton, Dubilier & Rice is estimated at $700 million. [D1.]
BMW will supply Rolls-Royce with its engineering expertise and with components for future Rolls-Royce and Bentley models. The deal represents a victory for BMW over Mercedes-Benz. [D1.]
Mattel plans to eliminate 1,000 jobs, or 4.5 percent of its work force. The company also announced a 5-for-4 stock split. [D5.]
Xerox sold Constitution Re, a reinsurance company, to Exor America for $400 million. [D5.]
Shares of Cyrix tumbled after the company said earnings would be lower than expected. Stocks of other chip makers fell. [D5.]
LTV, Sumitomo and British Steel will join in a venture to build a $450 million mini-mill in the United States. [D5.]
Ben & Jerry's expects to post a loss for the quarter, its first since going public in 1984. Its stock fell sharply. [D5.]
The chairman at Saatchi & Saatchi's New York agency said he would relinquish his post if Maurice Saatchi, who was ousted as chairman of the parent company, wanted it. [D22.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Toyota's Tercel infomercial draws a significant response from its youthful, hungry audience.

BYLINE: By James Bennet 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE Toyota Motor Corporation believes it may have hit on the right technique to get through to young people today: a combination of daytime television, computer software and free food.
Groping for a fresh way to promote the 1995 model of its small car, the Tercel, Toyota decided to try its first infomercial, testing a 28-minute advertisement in New York and Los Angeles during November. Toyota was hoping for a way to make the Tercel stick out from among its numerous competitors, which include Honda's Civic, Chrysler's Neon and General Motors' Saturn. The results were so encouraging that last week Toyota began broadcasting the advertisement in 15 markets around the country. 
 The infomercial features brief comments from unidentified young Tercel buyers and customers in dealerships describing what they're looking for, and from youthful Toyota product specialists describing features of the car. It also includes interviews out on the street with young people, some of whom, Toyota said, were actors.
A highly caffeinated hostess, Molly Scott, periodically bounced into the picture to urge callers to telephone a toll-free number for more information, and to sum up the ad's message.
"You know what is so amazing about what we're seeing?" she asked at one point. "We're seeing that you can finally have the best of all worlds."
The infomercial proved to be a superb vehicle for reaching the target audience, 18- to 35-year-olds, said Irving A. Miller, corporate advertising manager for Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A. "They're a tough demographic to reach, and they also tend to watch television, when they do, at off hours," he said.
Other auto makers have experimented with infomercials, but none has invested heavily in the format yet. As a result, the Tercel ad has the virtue of standing out from the crowd of 30-second spots showing cars racing through deserts. Mr. Miller said infomercials might be better suited to small cars for young people than to Toyota's more upscale products, like the new Avalon sedan.
Toyota broadcast the advertisement on network affiliates on weekends, in the early morning hours or the middle of the afternoon, when ad time is cheaper. The infomercial, called "I want a car," was produced by Hudson Street Partners, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi's Kobs & Draft Worldwide direct marketing agency.
While the effects of normal television advertisements are hard to measure, Toyota started tracking the infomercial's results immediately. About 7,000 people in the two markets called to order more information during the three-week tests, a result that Mr. Miller said delighted Toyota. A few months from now, Toyota plans to compare vehicle registration data with the addresses provided by callers to see how much of the curiosity resulted in sales.
The Los Angeles test drew more responses than the one in New York, because in Los Angeles Toyota also offered a free "night on the town" to anyone who requested the brochure and then visited a dealer to test-drive a Tercel.
The evening out, the infomercial explains, consists of two movie tickets and dinner for two at "one of America's favorite restaurants" -- a Chili's Grill and Bar, in Los Angeles. Ads with the offer garnered twice the response of those without, so Toyota incorporated it into its general campaign. "They went for the burger every time," Mr. Miller said.
Perhaps a more surprising result came from the New York test, where Toyota offered to send information either in a brochure or on a computer disk. Sixty percent of the people who called requested the disk.
The advertisement is broken down into seven segments, each for a specific aspect of the car: its styling, performance, interior, and so on. The ad does not dwell on price, but it does mention that the car starts at less than $10,000, and sells "nicely equipped at around $13,000."
Interspersed with the product information are snippets from twentysomethings commenting on what they look for in a car.
"I want my car to say that I'm 25," said one man, wearing a tie and what appears to be a leather jacket.
Since none of the young people are identified, their observations do not always seem credible and occasionally they seem off the wall. One young man said he was concerned about fuel economy because "the cost of fuel has just skyrocketed."
In another, more poignant moment, a young woman, who Toyota said was not an actress, explained why she becomes tearful when describing driving away from the lot in her Tercel, her first new car. "I've worked really hard to get to the point in my life where I could do something like this, she said, "so I feel pretty fortunate."
