HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3 Steelmakers in $450 Million Mini-Mill Pact

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
In an indication of how the two sectors of the basic steel industry are converging, three integrated steel companies announced plans yesterday to build a $450 million mini-mill in the Southeastern United States.
The new mill will be half-owned by the LTV Corporation of Cleveland, with the remaining half split evenly by Sumitomo Metal Industries and British Steel P.L.C. Although joint undertakings involving Japanese and American steel companies have become common, this is the first time American, Japanese and European steelmakers have invested together in a new production plant. 
 Integrated steel companies are those that make steel from iron ore, coal, limestone and other minerals. They argue that this approach produces the highest quality steel.
But the better economics of mini-mills, companies that melt steel scrap in electric furnaces and recast it into new products, has changed the nature of the industry. Whole ranges of products, like bars for reinforcing concrete and light structural beams, have been captured by the mini-mills because they could price them lower than the integrated mills.
One of the key advantages enjoyed by the mini-mills as they have developed over the last 25 years has been nonunion plants operated with a high degree of flexibility by workers whose pay is tied to production. The integrated companies were organized in the 1930's by the United Steelworkers union, and many remain saddled with detailed, restrictive contracts with the union.
David H. Hoag, the chairman of LTV, said the company hoped to duplicate the mini-mill system at the new factory, which will be operated by a new entity, the Trico Steel Company. "All three companies involved are committed to a high performance organization," he said.
All three companies will supply executive talent, but most of the blue-collar work force will be hired locally. The plant is expected to employ about 300 people when in full operations.
LTV and Sumitomo jointly operate two electrogalvanizing plants in the United States and Sumitomo holds about 10 percent of LTV's stock. British Steel owns a plate mill in Tuscaloosa, Ala., but does not have plants for thin rolled products.
Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of next year, with operations scheduled to begin in late 1996. The companies said they were looking at several sites in the Southeast, but they did not disclosed the specific locations.
Operators of mini-mills have been fiercely opposed to unions and have been able to discourage labor organizers by offering pay incentives equivalent to the income of union workers. In addition, many mini-mills are in states where laws make organizing difficult.
The new plant will be equipped with the latest technology for producing liquid steel, thin casting and hot rolling that may enable it to eliminate processing steps needed in older plants, reducing costs. In addition to scrap steel, the plant will be designed to use the new types of ore-based scrap substitutes being developed by the industry.
The mill will have an annual production capacity of 2.2 million tons of flat rolled steel. Though the current boom in steel production has provoked a flurry of new mill announcements, Mr. Hoag noted that the United States imported 14 million tons of steel in the categories to be produced by Trico this year.
"In the past, bars from mini-mills put a dent into bar imports, so I think we have reason to be optimistic," Mr. Hoag said.

HEADLINE: BMW to Help Rolls-Royce Develop a New Model Line

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd., perhaps the quintessential British company, said today that it would turn to BMW of Germany for help in building a new generation of luxury cars.
After months of negotiations, BMW beat out Mercedes-Benz to supply engineering expertise and key components, including engines, for future Rolls-Royce and Bentley models. 
 Rolls-Royce said it would also collaborate with BMW in developing a proposed new Bentley sports coupe,tentatively known as the Java, that could go on sale at the end of the decade.
The deal was the most far-reaching that Rolls-Royce had made with an outside supplier and the biggest with any non-British supplier.
The parent company of Rolls-Royce, Vickers P.L.C., and Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. provided few details of the arrangement, but said it would not involve an equity investment by the German company in Rolls-Royce or Vickers.
Vickers has toyed in the past with selling Rolls-Royce, and held talks about a sale or joint venture with BMW several years ago. More recently, Vickers has said that it intends to keep Rolls-Royce, but that it will need a partner to share the costs of developing new models.
Sir Colin Chandler, chief executive of Vickers, said the BMW deal was "extremely significant" in planning the medium- to long-term strategy for Rolls-Royce.
"Having said that we would find a partner for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars for longer-term collaboration, we are delighted that we have reached agreement with such a prestigious company," he said in a statement.
After losses totaling $150 million in 1991 and 1992, Rolls-Royce recorded a small profit last year and is expected to earn money this year as well. Vickers does not provide details of the car company's financial results.
Rolls-Royce sold 1,360 cars worldwide last year, and through Sept. 30 had sold 1,051 this year, at prices starting at about $140,000. Its peak sales year was 1990, when it sold 3,333 cars.
The turnaround at Rolls-Royce was driven by the economic recoveries in the United States and Britain and a rigorous cost-cutting program at the production plant in Crewe, England.
The deal with BMW centers on engines. Rolls-Royce wants new V8 and V12 engines for models that would go into production around the turn of the century, but cannot afford the high cost of developing them on its own, especially given the rigorous emissions and fuel-economy standards that auto makers face in key markets like the United States.
BMW would supply its engines to Rolls-Royce, but would permit the British company to modify them to meet its needs. For example, Rolls-Royce requires a turbocharged V8 engine, and BMW's V8 is not turbocharged.
Vickers executives said that as Rolls-Royce developed plans for its new models and as Rolls-Royce and BMW engineers learned more about each other's needs and capabilities, the relationship between the companies might be expanded.
BMW already supplies air bags to Rolls-Royce, and through BMW's Rover subsidiary, the British car maker it acquired earlier this year, it also supplies body panels.

HEADLINE: School Board Rebuffs Giuliani On Terms of Cortines's Contract

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
The New York City Board of Education yesterday brushed aside Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's demand that Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, if he stays on, be limited to a one-year term and meet specific performance goals.
The board president, Carol A. Gresser, said the Mayor, who had backed down from his opposition to a contract renewal for Mr. Cortines, was in no position to dictate conditions. She said she would urge the board, which has sole legal authority to hire and fire chancellors, to offer a two-year contract, at least. And although Mr. Giuliani outlined "worthy suggestions" for budget and administrative reforms, she said, the board and Mr. Cortines had developed similar initiatives on their own. 
 Mr. Cortines, 63, declined to comment on the contract dispute yesterday morning and spent the day in Washington pursuing a $15 million grant from the National Science Foundation. The Chancellor, who has served for 15 months, has not said whether he will accept a contract extension, but his aides said that they expect a decision before Friday.
In endorsing an extension of Mr. Cortines's tenure, the Mayor abandoned an effort to pressure Mr. Cortines into leaving the chancellorship when his contract expires in June. But the Mayor kept up his criticism yesterday, and expressed continuing irritation with the board's support for Mr. Cortines.
"If we can't do a better job with $8 billion than the board or the Chancellor are doing, then they have to turn the movement of that money over to someone else," he said. "The Chancellor is largely held unaccountable, and what the board apparently wants to do is to continue that."
Mrs. Gresser's statements of independence, which were echoed or stated even more energetically by four other representatives on the seven-member board, underlined their sense of confidence that they and Mr. Cortines had prevailed in their latest confrontation with the Mayor, at least for now. Mrs. Gresser and other board members also said they hoped more respectful mutual relations might result from their bruising confrontation.
"We need a working relationship with City Hall," she said. "That's something that I'd like to build, not just on City Hall's terms and not just on the board's terms, but on terms agreeable to both. City Hall is the seat of this city's government and we are the city's school district. We need each other desperately."
Mr. Giuliani's turnabout prompted other reactions yesterday ranging from suspicion to bewilderment. "This was a clever change in tactics in City Hall's vigorous spin-control war," said John Beckman, the spokesman for the Board of Education. "But there was no real change in substance. City Hall is not offering a compromise, they're making a demand dressed up as a compromise."
One board member said he was confused. "The Mayor spent the last week beating the hell out of everybody, us included," the member said. "You get beat up, you're part of the problem, and then suddenly his story is: 'I'd like to make a peace offering -- but I'm not going to talk to you about it.' "
Mrs. Gresser said she heard about Mr. Giuliani's call for a compromise late Sunday from a reporter. Neither the Mayor nor any of his aides ever spoke to her directly during the recent dispute, she said. The last time that she talked face to face with Mr. Giuliani, she said, was at a party on Dec. 4.
Mrs. Gresser and her four board colleagues appeared in a joint news conference with the city's five borough presidents, all of whom urged an extension of Mr. Cortines's contract. Their appearance was scheduled last week.
Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, criticized the Mayor's call for limiting Mr. Cortines's extension.
"It is my own belief that a one-year contract is insufficient, and that, next year, we will once again witness the same jockeying and political posturing that is simply not good for our city or its schoolchildren," he said.
The general tenor of the Borough Presidents' remarks was to praise the Chancellor and to support the board's independence. But Howard Golden of Brooklyn and Claire Shulman of Queens both called on the board to take seriously Mr. Giuliani's ideas and to seek a closer working relationship with him.
"I'm here to support Chancellor Cortines," Ms. Shulman said. "But I also believe the Mayor is a good mayor. I think we ought to give the Mayor the benefit of the doubt in his attempts to get a handle on the board's budget."
Mr. Giuliani, acknowledging that his two representatives on the board, Ninfa Segarra and Irene Impellizzeri, were likely to be outvoted when the contract comes to a vote, scheduled for tomorrow, said the contract should be tied to the condition that Mr. Cortines show measurable progress in four areas of management and budgeting.
City Hall has a stake in the budget process because it supplies about 40 percent of the board's $8.4 billion annual budget, but the Board of Education has the power to allocate the funds. But in two recent rounds of budget cuts, made to meet a city budget deficit this year, the Mayor has demanded specific personnel reductions, which the board is close to meeting.
Mr. Giuliani said any new contract ought to require Mr. Cortines to establish a school-based budgeting system in which each of the city's 1,100 schools would be required to draw up their own budgets, to develop a less confusing budget system, to make further reductions in the number of administrators working at the board and to overhaul the special education system, which serves 130,000 of the city's one million schoolchildren.
Mr. Giuliani said that his representatives would seek to insert language into the Chancellor's contract reflecting those four points, but Mrs. Gresser said neither Ms. Segarra nor Dr. Impellizzeri had made any such request.
The board has been carrying out a formal review of Mr. Cortines's work and future agenda. Mrs. Gresser and other members argued that the four points on which Mr. Giuliani wanted the contract to be made conditional were all initiatives that the board had already, on its own, discussed with the Chancellor. Last week, for instance, Mr. Cortines appointed a commission to develop specific proposals for reforming the special education system, she said.
And the Chancellor has also outlined specific plans for making school budgets easier for taxpayers to understand and to reduce further the number of administrators at board headquarters. To date, Mr. Cortines has eliminated 1,400 of the board's 6,300 headquarters employees, and he has pledged to eliminate another 800 employees by June, Mr. Beckman said.
Board members did not specifically respond to Mr. Giuliani's call for the establishment of school-based budgeting, an innovation that would, for accounting purposes, allocate all of the board's $8.4 billion budget, including money spent on board administration, debt service and other centralized functions, to the city's 1,100 schools. That would allow parents and taxpayers to have a clearer view of how their education tax dollars are spent.


GRAPHIC: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's four conditions for renewing the contract of Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines reflect an agenda that both men generally share. These are the Mayor's conditions and a report on the Chancellor's progress in each area:
 
A BUDGET FOR EVERY SCHOOL
 
Mayor's Condition: Last summer, Edward N. Costikyan, whom the Mayor appointed to explore ways of improving school governance, recommended that the Board of Education's budget be drafted and allocated to show how much of the Board's $8 billion budget is being spent on each of the system's 1,100 schools. Mr. Giuliani wants the Chancellor to move "aggressively" to do this and estimates it would take a year.
 
Chancellor's Progress: Mr. Cortines has committed himself to imposing a "transparent budget" within two years, one so clear that the average taxpayer will be able to tell where every dollar was spent.
 
SPECIAL EDUCATION
 
Mayor's Condition: Educating the city's 130,000 students diagnosed as having some disability is expensive -- the 13 percent of the system's students account for 25 percent of spending. But Mr. Giuliani has called for a reduction of the disparity between spending on special education students and those in regular classes.
Chart: "POINT BY POINT: What the Mayor Wants"
Herman Badillo, whom the Mayor named to monitor school spending, says the Chancellor can impose some economies. Mr. Costikyan says it is mostly City Hall's burden to seek more leeway from the Federal judge who approved a consent decree that specifies what services the schools must provide.
 
Chancellor's Progress: Last May, Mr. Cortines postponed a promised reorganization that would have, among other things, transferred control of nearly 3,000 special education employees from the central board to school principals. In October, he said he would appoint a panel to review the system; last week, he named two committees to set academic standards and to restructure delivery of special education services.
 
COST OF THE BUREAUCRACY
 
Mayor's Condition: The Mayor wants the Chancellor to clearly identify administrative costs. Nobody disagrees with the goal, only with what constitutes an administrator. In October, an audit commissioned by Mr. Badillo found that central and district operations consumed 9.95-cents of every school budget dollar. That estimate was revised last month to 3.75 cents.
 
Chancellor's Progress: Nobody disagrees with the goal, only with what constitutes an administrator.
 
CUT MIDDLE MANAGEMENT
 
Mayor's Condition: Mr. Giuliani demanded that 2,500 "bureaucrats" be pared from the Board of Education payroll. Mr. Cortines "has done some," Mr. Badillo acknowledges, "but until we get a total breakdown we don't know how much."
 
Chancellor's Progress: Mr. Cortines has cut 1,400 employees at the central headquarters and 700 more will be cut, nearly the target Mr. Giuliani had originally set.

HEADLINE: Wall St.'s Rescue Squads Also Turn A Tidy Profit

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The investment-fund disaster in Orange County, Calif., is shining a spotlight on a little-noticed corner of brokerage firms' trading floors: the investment rescue desk.
It is there that financial instruments that have gone sour can be repackaged as something sweet enough for a bank, mutual fund or other investor to want to buy. 
 Because they have these rescue operations, Wall Street firms are clamoring to buy the Orange County portfolio, which is still laced with risky securities whose value will continue to plummet as interest rates rise. But if the firms can buy the debt at a nice discount, they can restructure it and sell it at a tidy profit.
Every major brokerage firm and many large banks have a handful of traders who specialize in such financial rescue. The larger firms involved include Morgan Stanley, Goldman, Sachs, Bankers Trust, Merrill Lynch and J. P. Morgan.
While the maneuvers involved in such a rescue operation may sound complex, they actually have become fairly routine. The rescuers are usually junior traders.
Brokers say the business of swapping assets, which is what the rescue desks do, is up slightly this year even as most other bond business has fallen off sharply. Many of the deals this year have involved buying up volatile bonds, similar to those owned by Orange County, that have fallen sharply as interest rates rise.
Orange County said last week that it would sell the remaining $5.4 billion of assets in its portfolio and Salomon Brothers, the county's adviser, began auctioning it off last week. The losses on the portfolio have already topped $2 billion and forced the county into bankruptcy.
Both Orange County's problem and Wall Street's solution relate to the controversial and rapidly growing market for derivatives, a wide range of financial transactions that are custom-designed for an investor.
Orange County's problems involved, among other things, investments in notes on which the interest rate payment the county earned increased as market interest rates fell, and vice versa. That made the notes twice as profitable as regular bonds if short-term interest rates declined. But they were doubly vulnerable if they rose, because both the price of the notes and the interest they paid would fall. The county bought most of the notes from Government-sponsored agencies, such as the Federal National Mortgage Association.
To neutralize such notes and limit their risk, the rescue desk uses what are known as interest-rate swaps. Swaps, the most common form of derivative, were invented 15 years ago to let companies that borrowed money at fixed interest rates switch to a floating interest rate, or vice versa.
The rescue desk can combine Orange County notes with a swap to form a more attractive, less volatile investment.
Investors buying the two-part package will get a note with the strong credit of a Government agency at a yield that is slightly higher than they would otherwise receive for such an investment. The price of the note will still fall as interest rates rise, but the swap offsets this by paying a higher interest rate under those circumstances.
Depending on the terms used, the Orange County note in combination with the swap could now perform as if it were a Treasury note, with a fixed interest rate paid to the new owner and the price of the note moving in the direction opposite that of market interest rates. Or it could be a note with a fixed principal and an interest payment that moves up and down with market rates.
None of the investors will get rich from these deals, which will earn perhaps one- or two-tenths of a percentage point more interest than normal notes.
But for the brokers, these are especially lucrative trades. Brokers make their normal markup selling bonds for slightly more than they paid for them and they make a second profit selling the swap. And that is why the salvage specialists on the rescue desk are always on the lookout for any kind of cheap bond or note that they can buy, transform and sell for a profit.
"We get two trades for the price of one," said a trading executive at a large bank that is eager to buy some of the ill-fated Orange County paper.

HEADLINE: Peasants Block Roads in Troubled South Mexican State

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TUXTLA GUTIERREZ, Mexico, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Peasants who said they were part of a mobilization ordered by the rebel Zapatista National Liberation Army blocked several highways in the southern state of Chiapas today and took over the town hall in at least one community outside the zone that the rebels have held for almost a year.
But no shots were reported, and Government officials insisted that the actions were a civil protest by peasants and Indians and not the resumption of the insurrection that began in Chiapas on Jan. 1. 
 It is not clear whether the peasants are members of the Zapatista army or sympathizers of the mostly Indian movement in Mexico's poorest state.
Rebel leaders who had been warning for the last two weeks that resumption of war was "imminent" said at a news conference that their forces now were present in 38 communities in Chiapas, but here, too, it is not clear whether they meant troops or supporters.
Many of the 38 communities are poor Indian settlements that have pledged their allegiance to a "government in rebellion" formed by the official loser in August's gubernatorial election.
The masked rebel leader called Subcommander Marcos told reporters this morning that he had ordered a troop mobilization as the first "military action" since the uprising began nearly a year ago. At the same time, he offered to honor a Government truce if the official Governor of Chiapas resigned.
The rebel leader rejected a recent plan by President Ernesto Zedillo to form a multiparty commission to negotiate a peace settlement, demanding instead that an existing panel headed by Bishop Samuel Ruiz of the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Cristobal de las Casas handle the negotiations.
In the last week, President Zedillo has sought to take the initiative away from the rebels in Chiapas by proposing a new peace commission including members of the opposition and by divulging details of offers he had sent to the rebels before taking office on Dec. 1.
The moves were intended to take advantage of growing public sentiment against the Zapatistas for their insistence on threatening to use violence to resolve longstanding problems of poverty and injustice suffered by Indians in Chiapas.
This afternoon, Governor Eduardo Robledo Rincon announced the formation of an economic development program for the state, in a move that also was intended to increase pressure on the rebels to negotiate in peace, advisers to Mr. Zedillo said.
But the rebel leaders repeated their demands for Mr. Robledo's resignation. Since he took office on Dec. 8, Chiapas has been stuck between the war threatened by the rebels and the peace promised by the Government.
Before dawn this morning, a group of peasants peacefully took over the town hall of Simojovel de Allende, about 30 miles northwest of San Cristobal de las Casas and outside the zone of conflict.
Witnesses reported that 50 to 150 peasants, some armed with shotguns and sticks, occupied the town hall without firing a shot.
Adelfo Gutierrez Velasco, a local official from Huitiupan, a small community near Simojovel, said armed men also showed up about a half-mile from his town this morning and said they were part of the Zapatista movement. The armed men handed out Zapatista literature and stopped buses, telling residents "to listen to the instructions about this movement."
Heriberto Velasco Castaneda, a state government spokesman, said the local police in Simojovel had offered no resistance. He said that there were no other reports of armed peasants today, and that tree trunks used to block several highways had been removed by early afternoon.
This morning's action resembles the initial offensive of the Zapatistas in the first few hours of Jan. 1, when they took over government buildings in four towns in Chiapas.
The rebels retained control of the towns for about two days before the Mexican Army mobilized to retake them. Officials estimate that 145 people were killed in the fighting, but human rights groups and the Catholic Church say the toll was much higher.
A cease-fire agreed to on Jan. 12 has so far been honored by both sides. Negotiations between the Government and the rebels in February resulted in a proposed settlement that was rejected by the rebels in June.

HEADLINE: Will Jesse Jackson Beat Queen in British Ratings? Stay Tuned

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, December 19

 BODY:
One of Britain's most familiar holiday rituals -- the annual Christmas Day television broadcast by Queen Elizabeth II -- will run up against some unexpected and, in some quarters, unwanted foreign competition next Sunday: a pre-recorded, nationwide lecture by the Rev. Jesse Jackson on the sorry state of British race relations.
At the same time the Queen is scheduled to appear delivering her Christmas Day homily, at 3 P.M. on Channel One and Channel Three, the American civil rights campaigner will be making his own 15-minute appearance on Channel Four, one of Britain's four nationwide broadcast television networks. 
 Billed by the station as an "alternative Queen's speech," Mr. Jackson is appearing at the invitation of station officials, who are promoting his appearance as part of a weeklong schedule of holiday programming devoted to minority affairs and entertainment, built around the theme of celebrating a "Black Christmas."
In The Times of London this morning, Mr. Jackson was quoted as saying he did not mean to undermine the Queen's annual Christmas message, nor did he intend her any disrespect, by agreeing to present his own holiday address.
But some British politicians are already steaming over the timing of the broadcast, and accounts in British newspapers in the last two days quoting excerpts from Mr. Jackson's remarks, including an appeal to blacks and other disadvantaged groups in Britain to engage in what was described as mass political action to bring about change.
"The lives of too many of our young people are going to waste," Mr. Jackson is quoted as saying. "The oppressed must engage in sane, sober, sensitive and disciplined resistance to their oppression."
Among other things, Mr. Jackson blames economic insecurity in Britain for breeding fear, which he says has contributed, in turn, to growing intolerance and racial violence, including several racially motivated killings.
Michael Howard, the Home Secretary, was quoted as dismissing Mr. Jackson's remarks, in an account in The Sunday Times. "We have nothing to learn from Mr. Jesse Jackson on these issues," he said. Sir Ivan Lawrence, a Conservative member of Parliament and chairman of the Home Affairs Select Committee, was even sharper.
"It will be a broadcast surpassing impertinence by someone who doesn't have the faintest idea what he's talking about," Sir Ivan was quoted, in The Times. "He should look to his own country, where racial attacks occur far more frequently than they do in this country."
Earlier this year, Sir Ivan's committee issued a report on race relations in Britain, concluding that "racial attacks and harassment, and the spread of literature which preaches racial hatred, are increasing, and must be stopped."
A week later, Britain's Commission for Racial Equality issued another report saying that the number of racial incidents officially reported to the police have doubled in the last five years to 9,000, with a 20 percent increase last year alone.
Like the Queen's annual message, Mr. Jackson's remarks are also pre-recorded. A spokesman for Channel Four said he taped his remarks in Washington within the last two weeks.
This is the second year that Channel Four has promoted its own alternative to the Queen's speech. Last year, as part of a "Camp Christmas" theme, they broadcast an appearance by Quentin Crisp, an outspoken British homosexual.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Natural Gas Takes a Tumble On Mild Weather Forecasts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Natural gas futures prices tumbled yesterday as mild winter weather forecasts deflated expectations for a seasonal surge in heating-fuel demand.
Heating oil prices also sagged, dragging crude oil lower. Elsewhere, orange juice and wheat futures rose sharply, while corn and soybeans declined. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.21 point, to 231.85. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, natural gas for January delivery plunged 10.8 cents, or 6 percent, to $1.577 for 1,000 cubic feet, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Oct. 20.
Last week, the National Weather Service predicted above-normal temperatures this winter in the densely populated Midwest and Northeast, the key regions for heating-fuel demand. The weather in both regions has been unseasonably mild this autumn.
A forecast released after the close of trading yesterday for above-normal to much-above-normal temperatures in most of the United States through Dec. 29 reinforced expectations for light demand.
United States natural gas in storage was at 90 percent of capacity Dec. 7, about 10 percent above last year's level, the American Gas Association reported last week.
"The market's falling like a rock in a pond," said Tom Curtis, director of energy research for Pegasus Econometric Group in New York. "You have basically very high levels of supply and very little demand."
In other energy trading, the January crude oil contract, which expired yesterday, rose 15 cents, to $16.91 a barrel. January wholesale home heating oil fell 0.60 cent, to 47.86 cents a gallon, and January wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 0.13 cent, to 51.42 cents a gallon.
Orange juice prices surged on the news that Brazilian processers had raised their prices to customers in the United States to $1.40 from $1.30. January deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice rose 4.85 cents, to $1.195 a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange
Wheat prices reached a five-week high on the Chicago Board of Trade on persistent rumors of Chinese buying interest.
Early in the session, March wheat touched $4 a bushel for the first time since Nov. 11 as talk circulated that China was interested in buying as much as one million metric tons of United States wheat. Profit taking cut the gain before the close. March wheat ended 3.5 cents higher at $3.9625 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits 8-Month High Against Lira in Italian Crisis

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit an eight-month high against the Italian lira yesterday as confidence eroded that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's Government would survive.
The dollar was otherwise little changed against other leading currencies in light trading. Dealers sat on the sidelines ahead of a meeting today of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. 
 Investors have dumped the lira in favor of the German mark and the dollar in recent weeks as Mr. Berlusconi's coalition Government slowly unravels. Mr. Berlusconi faces a confidence vote in Parliament tomorrow, an effort led by an important member of his coalition.
"If Berlusconi is pushed out, the political picture becomes very unclear and that's not good for the country's currency," said Tom O'Malley, foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1,645.50 lire from 1,638 on Friday. The last time the dollar traded that high against the lira was in mid-April.
The lira also fell to a record low against the German mark, trading at 1,048.01 lire to the mark before settling at 1041.09.
In other currency trading, most market participants were waiting to see what would happen to interest rates.
Most participants expect the Fed to postpone another increase in short-term interest until its next meeting in late January, yet participants were not betting on the Fed action.
"People are just prepared to wait and see what the Fed will do, but no one wanted to bet any money on it," said Chris Iggo, foreign exchange specialist at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Higher interest rates create demand for the currency because higher rates make dollar-denominated assets more attractive.
With many participants out this week for the Christmas holiday and no economic news yesterday to influence trading, activity was light and the dollar exchanged hands in tight ranges against the yen and most European currencies.
In New York , the dollar slipped to 1.5730 marks, from 1.5737 on Friday.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: A Freshman Light at Colgate;
Just Another Basketball Star, Foyle Reads Faulkner for Pleasure and Writes Poems

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMILTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Adonal Foyle had not heard of Michael Jordan when Jay and Joan Mandle approached him one summer afternoon and offered him a future he had never dreamed of. He did not know about the National Basketball Association. He did not know Magic Johnson from Larry Bird from Julius Erving.
He was 16 years old, and he had first set eyes on a basketball less than 12 months before that eventful meeting, which took place on the island of Dominica in the Caribbean. At the time, Foyle was a raw basketball talent, a 6-foot-9-inch, 240-pound kid with breathtaking athleticism and an underdeveloped sense of the game. 
 "They told me that if I came to the United States, I could get an education by playing basketball," Foyle said. "I was stunned. I wanted to know what I had done so spectacular to deserve this."
The Mandles, professors at Colgate University, gave him that chance by offering to become his legal guardians. They did not intend to groom Foyle to be the savior of the basketball program at tiny Colgate, a school that has had just four winning seasons in the past two decades. They thought he would accept a scholarship to a major program, play in the big leagues, and aim for the N.B.A. But Foyle surprised them.
Recruited heavily by Duke and Syracuse, Foyle chose to recruit Colgate, a school that he felt suited his academic interests. A poet and budding actor who earned honors grades in high school and who reads William Faulkner for pleasure, Foyle decided he wanted to play at a school where the pressure to win did not supersede everything else in his life.
"People were saying that Duke was the school for me and Syracuse was the school for me, and I was shocked," said Foyle, who attends Colgate on a need-based scholarship. "It's confusing to me, this idea that the decision has to be based on what's best for my basketball life. I still want to play in the N.B.A., but isn't this supposed to be about education and what's best for me as a whole?"
Foyle has revitalized the Colgate basketball program and captured the fancy of both the campus and the town. When freshmen were asked to fill out their housing request forms, more than 70 percent of the male enrollees requested Foyle as their roommate. He is a hero to the children in town, and served as the show-and-tell item for "big and small" day at a local kindergarten.
To showcase Foyle's talents, the Red Raiders scheduled early-season games against difficult teams, like Syracuse, Stanford and Maryland, and were invited to participate in the ECAC Holiday Festival, which will be played at Madison Square Garden next week.
Now 6-10 and 260 pounds, Foyle has developed into an an all-round player with a quickness and agility rare for a player his size. After the first seven games of his freshman season, he is averaging 14 points, 13 rebounds and 5 blocks as the Red Raiders (1-6) have struggled to find ways to get Foyle the ball.
It is an awkward situation for a player who has already been compared to a young Karl Malone. But he still does not question his college choice or that he is playing out of the limelight.
"You have to understand Adonal," said Jack Bruen, the Colgate coach, who broke out a bottle of champagne when Foyle committed to his program, which does not award athletic scholarships. "Kids who grow up in American basketball, they understand what TV is all about, what commercialism is all about. That's not important to Adonal. It's just not a factor."
There is no basketball culture on the island of Canouan, one of the smallest of the islands that make up the Grenadines. Foyle was raised there by his grandmother, Faith, and his great aunt, Isla. Just as the other 700 or so inhabitants, they had no electricity and, consequently, no television. Children were raised on track and soccer and a game called "net ball" that consisted of a tall pole with a loose net that swung freely from a string.
Having exhausted a limited educational system by age 15, Foyle moved to neighboring Union Island (population 2,000) to live with his mother. He had been there a few days when he was approached by another teen-ager who barely came up to Foyle's waist.
"You, hey you," he said, jabbing Foyle, who already stood 6-9, in the stomach. "You have to play basketball. You're tall."
Foyle had almost no idea what he was talking about.
"He taught me how to rebound and block shots and then pass the ball up to him -- that's all," said Foyle, laughing at the memory. "He kept scoring, and I noticed that everybody seemed to get excited about scoring, not rebounding or blocking shots. And I figured, 'Hey, I'm not chopped liver, I want to score, too.' So the next time I rebounded the ball, I ran down the court and tried to dunk. Everybody just stood there staring at me like I was nuts."
Foyle had forgotten to dribble. Actually, he hadn't realized that he was supposed to dribble. It was not something he had been taught.
"Humiliating," Foyle said. "I never wanted to play again."
He learned to play at night, to minimize his embarrassment. And, within a year, he was invited to play in a tournament in Dominica with an island club team. It was there that he was spotted by the Mandles.
"He was not a terrific basketball player -- when we look at the tape now, he looks skinny and he wasn't the best player, not by far," said Jay Mandle, who is an economics professor. "It was his athleticism that caught our attention."
Foyle first moved to Philadelphia, where he took his first ride in an elevator, attended an Eagle game -- "I had never seen that many people," said Foyle -- and became the centerpiece of the basketball program at Cardinal O'Hara High School. After one year, he chose to move to tiny Hamilton, N.Y., and live with the Mandles, who helped prepare him for applying to college and encouraged his academic interests.
Last Friday night, the Mandles were in the stands when Colgate opened the home season with the team's first victory, against Harvard. Foyle calls them mom and dad now, and they acted like proud parents. Joan, Colgate's director of women's studies, videotaped the game from her seat. At 2,863, the crowd at Cotterell Court was the largest home crowd in 20 years. The fans cheered for everyone, but especially for Foyle, who cannot walk across campus without students yelling his name.
"He has a charisma about him," Bruen said. "Already you can see he is going to be a star. I don't think anyone has any doubt about that."

HEADLINE: SOCCER REPORT

BYLINE: By ALEX YANNIS 

 BODY:
United States
It appears very strongly that Bora Milutinovic, who piloted the Americans through the second round of the World Cup last summer, will be the coach of the United States for the 1998 World Cup as well. 
 Reliable sources in the United States Soccer Federation have said that Milutinovic has made a verbal agreement with Alan Rothenberg, the federation president, and an official announcement will be made in the near future.
Timo Liekoski, Milutinovic's top assistant for the last two years, was given an additional task yesterday by Hank Steinbrecher, the executive director and secretary general of the U.S.S.F.
Besides his duties as the coach of the United States Olympic team, Liekoski was named director of coaching and player development for the U.S.S.F. He replaces Bob Gansler, who coached the Americans in the 1990 World Cup in Italy.
 
European Championship
 Although Germany came up with a 2-1 victory over Albania at home in one of three games for the European Championship played on Sunday, the Germans' performance was far below the standard of a world class team.
"That's like a defeat for us Germans," midfielder Matthias Sammer told The Associated Press after the game, which was staged at Kaiserslautern.
Coach Berti Voghts, who has piloted Germany since Franz Beckenbauer resigned after the World Cup triumph in 1990, said: "I didn't like it at all. For some reason, the players tightened up."
Lothar Mattaeus and Juergen Klinsmann, two of the team's harshest critics, scored the goals that helped the Germans tie for the lead in Group 7 with Bulgaria, the team that eliminated Germany in the quarterfinals of the World Cup last summer at Giants Stadium.
In Group 6, Portugal opened a three-point lead in the standing after scoring eight goals, including three in a three-minute span, in an 8-0 thrashing of Liechtenstein in Lisbon.
A goal from the penalty spot by defender Stratos Apostolakis gave Greece a 1-0 triumph over Scotland in Athens. The victory was the fourth in a row for the Greeks, who are making some progress after finishing last in the World Cup last summer.
 
Italy
 All games in the Italian League were delayed for 45 minutes on Sunday by a players' protest. The union staged the demonstrations in an effort to gain $5.6 million from league owners for unemployed players and coaches.
When the games were over, Parma was back in first place after a 2-1 triumph at Bari, and a 1-1 tie between Juventus and Genoa in Turin dropped Juventus to second place. Juventus got a goal from Fabrizio Ravanelli in the 74th minute and was a minute away from victory when Fabio Galante scored on a header for Genoa.
Massimo Crippa scored the winner for Parma with 13 minutes left after Gianfranco Zola had put Parma ahead and Sandro Tovalieri tied it for Bari.
Gabriel Batistuta's league-leading 14th goal at Florence salvaged a 1-1 tie with Fogia for third-place Fiorentina.
Lazio of Rome posted a 2-0 victory over Inter at Milan on goals by Roberto Cravero and Diego Fuser, while Roma played a scoreless deadlock with three-time defending champion AC Milan at Rome's Olympic stadium.
Milan is in ninth place and has apparently made a mistake letting Ruud Gullitt get away. Gullitt had two more goals for Sampdoria in a 5-0 triumph over Cagliari at Genoa.
 
The Netherlands
 Dick Advocaat, who coached the Dutch to the quarterfinals in the World Cup last summer, will leave the national team on Jan. 1 to take the job as coach of PSV Eindhoven.
The Dutch federation (KNVB) said that Advocaat's job on the national team would be taken by Guus Hiddink, who has signed a contract through the European Championship finals, which will be staged in England in 1996.
The 47-year-old Advocaat, who played for the Chicago Sting in the long-defunct North American Soccer League, has shouldered the task of reviving the glory days that Eindhoven enjoyed as the European champion a decade ago. ALEX YANNIS

HEADLINE: Harsh Wind From Beijing

 BODY:
It is extraordinary and more than a little alarming. The world's most populous country, a nuclear power with a booming, internationalized economy, is frozen into hard-line immobility on a wide range of policies because its nonagenarian supreme leader lies dying and those beneath him fear jeopardizing their own political futures by appearing too flexible.
Some of the effects of this succession crisis are now being felt throughout the world. But the primary and most brutal effects are felt in China itself. Crucial reforms of state industry have been postponed repeatedly. Arbitrary challenges and revisions have left foreign investors questioning the reliability of their contracts. Most recently, human rights and democracy activists have been subjected to a new round of repression that is ferocious even by China's harsh standards. 
 Last week, nine defendants drew cruelly excessive sentences for distributing four articles on human and workers' rights. One man was condemned to an incredible 20 years' imprisonment, seven years more than was imposed on the alleged masterminds of the Tiananmen Square movement.
These sentences form part of a pattern that includes the re-arrest last spring of China's most famous democrat, Wei Jingsheng; the six-year sentence imposed last month on an internationally respected journalist, Gao Yu, and the menacing harassment of a former student leader, Wang Dan.
The roots of this crackdown are domestic, but its severity reflects Beijing's perception that it can now ignore international human rights pressure. The trial that brought last week's sentences had twice before been postponed: in 1993 when China was seeking the 2000 Olympics, and last spring when President Clinton was weighing extension of China's low-tariff access to the U.S. market. Turning down that Olympic bid and extending trade access without human rights conditions reduced the outside world's leverage.
Despite President Clinton's conciliatory policies, the U.S. too has felt the new chill from Beijing. Washington's favorable tariff decision brought no honeymoon but a fresh burst of Chinese threats. Beijing warned it would retaliate if the U.S. persisted in holding China to reasonable standards for joining the new World Trade Organization, and in demanding that it crack down on copyright piracy.
Meanwhile, as the U.S. hastens to re-establish military cooperation, Beijing has escalated its rhetoric over a minor naval surveillance incident earlier this year.
Given this present touchiness, Washington needs to avoid gratuitous provocation. But it cannot avoid asserting legitimate U.S. interests from trade to security to human rights.
Republicans who have criticized the Clinton Administration's overly accommodating China policies will soon hold key committee chairs. The Administration, which is considering sending either Vice President Gore or Hillary Rodham Clinton to Beijing next year, would be wise to consult first with Republicans and seek bipartisan agreement on how to stand up to today's Chinese bullying without wrecking a valuable long-term relationship.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Missing at The White House

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Russell Baker is on vacation.

 BODY:
The three men, New Yorkers of the center-right, had voted for Bill Clinton.
"Do you think he can be salvaged?" one of them asked. 
 "What for?" another said. "To do what?" There was a silence then, a long invisible shrug.
That was after Bill Clinton surrendered. The Republicans trounced him on Election Day but the surrender came nine days later, when he had had plenty of time to think about what to say. Essentially what he said after all that cogitation was that the Comeback Kid was again the Turnaround Kid.
The President of a country where children shoot children, where drugs are on the rise again, where workers have not had a real raise in 20 years, where skilled mechanics can find themselves flipping hamburgers part time, decided that the best thing he could do for his country was to pick up political crumbs from the Republican table by handing out a few tax cuts.
Some of the better brains around him thought it was exactly the wrong thing to do; never mind. Never mind that he had promised to devote himself to fighting the deficit that loads Americans down with billions in interest payments. Never mind that tax reduction could lead to inflation, which would take from the American pocket a lot more than tax reduction would put in.
Mr. Clinton knew what he was doing was economically risky and ran against the heart of his preaching. The proof is that although he had mentioned a "middle-class" tax cut during the 1991 campaign, he did not move until he decided it might appease all those angry voters.
Don't politicians appease all the time? Maybe -- but when Presidents take the turnaround trail they gamble with the public's trust. And this President does not seem to understand that he has already squandered any public assumption of his constancy; no free turnarounds left.
Constancy is not simply consistency. Nobody expects a President to follow a narrow path every day, never looking down to dodge a hole.
But constancy -- you know it when you get it. Steadfastness, faithfulness to purpose and promise, no ducking, no turnarounds, no who-me? no playing around with word and intent.
President Clinton began the journey from constancy soon after inauguration. Do you understand exactly what his legal policy toward homosexuals in the armed forces is, or is not? On Bosnia, he is unpredictable from day to day; in wartime, Presidential unpredictability can cost lives. Now, almost offhand, he lets us know that he may do what he swore he would never ever do -- send combat troops into Bosnia.
He did well on Haiti in the end -- after he had backed and forthed miserably on Haitian refugees. But Cubans now are locked in tropical detention camps for being naive enough to think that it was still heroism, not a crime, to flee dictatorship.
Human rights as an instrument of foreign policy -- candidate Clinton said that would be fundamental to his Presidency. Into the can with that, right there with his promise to pressure Beijing for human decencies for Chinese and Tibetans. So long, suckers, hello Deng baby.
But still -- there's shock when a President whirls around, to get Chinese contracts, or a scrap from the new Republican platform. But I would hate for us to become so cynical about a President that we would not feel pain when he was not true to his promises and premises.
Mr. Clinton gathers his team on TV to present tax cuts as a sudden part of "rethinking" government. If he ever says he is dropping out of the race, millions of Americans who voted for him would be relieved and start candidate-shopping at once, no tears. But I doubt he would or should do that. Politics can turn around fast; see Thomas Dewey Bush.
I vote candidate, not party -- Republican or Democrat, President to State Assemblyman. On the Presidency, I dearly would love to vote for somebody twice in a row.
But I know if tax cuts ever become my major political motivation, there is a long list of interesting Republicans who will give me more than the Turnaround Kid, and I might as well vote for the real stuff.
I just looked up something tickling my mind and found that a poet did give fair warning about 350 years ago -- love me not for comely grace, nor for a constant heart. Maybe that goes for Presidents too, but it is very sad to think so.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Hold Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of government securities were little changed yesterday, holding to very narrow trading ranges ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy making committee.
The 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to a price of 964/32 for a yield 7.84 percent, down from 7.85 percent on Friday. In the shorter-maturity bill market, rates were up a few basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Traders said that President Clinton's news conference yesterday concerning plans to cut $24 billion in spending from the Federal budget to help pay for the middle-class tax cut had little impact on the bond market.
Many dealers and traders do not expect the Fed to raise its short-term interest rate target today, which would be the central bank's seventh increase this year. The Fed last raised interest rates at its Nov. 15 meeting, when it increased the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent. It also raised the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges on loans to member banks, to 4.75 percent from 4 percent.
Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said he thinks that many investors have become less worried about inflation. And this fact, he said, "should give the Fed an avenue to avoid raising rates at this meeting and passing it off until the meeting in January.
"While the inflation numbers were a little higher this month," he added, "they weren't that much higher than the previous months."
But while Mr. Chan thinks the Fed will not act today, the rise in short-term interest rates recently shows that investors and traders still expect the Fed to raise interest rates in the beginning of next year.
The spread between the yield on the six-month Treasury bill and the yield on the 30-year bond narrowed to 154 basis points yesterday, down from 284 basis points a month ago. The yield on the six-month bill moved to 6.66 percent yesterday from 5.73 percent, while the yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 7.84 percent from 8.62 percent, a decline that Mr. Chan says shows growing confidence in the Fed's ability to contain inflation.
Today the Treasury is selling $17.25 billion of new two-year notes and tomorrow, $11 billion of five-year notes. Yesterday in when-issued trading the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.62 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 7.76 percent.
Also little changed were the prices of municipal securities amid growing concern by dealers and traders that selling by bond funds may increase following a resumption of investor redemptions. Money managers say investors have been withdrawing money from bond funds in the wake of the bankruptcy filing by Orange County, Calif.
With most bonds unchanged, Bloomberg Business News reported that the 5 percent California revenue anticipation notes due in 1995 were among the actively quoted securities, unchanged at a price to yield 4.85 percent.
Traders said they do not expect too much of a decline in prices because few issues are scheduled to be sold before the Christmas holiday.
At the regular weekly auction of new bills yesterday, the average rate on a new three-month issues was down 17 basis points, to 5.59 percent, while a six-month maturity was down two basis points, to 6.30 percent. Both were down to their lowest level in nearly a month.
The following are the results of yesterday's three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions:

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In October

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The American economy pulled in a record amount of imported goods in October as the nation's trade deficit with Japan soared to a new peak of $6.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
Over all, the gap between what this country buys abroad and what it sells abroad widened to $10.14 billion for the month, an increase from the September total that was revised sharply downward. Initially the department had estimated a September deficit of $10.13 billion. 
 Despite some figures moving into record territory, analysts and currency markets took the report largely in stride, with the dollar steady even against the Japanese yen, before it drifted down a bit after the Federal Reserve adjourned a policy meeting without announcing another rise in short-term interest rates.
"When we grow rapidly, we bring in a large amount of imports," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. She called the $1.3 billion rise in the deficit with Japan largely a "bilateral manifestation" of the broad trend in which the strong United States economy is buying more foreign goods that its trading partners that have recovered more recently from recession.
Nor did most private analysts express much concern about the latest figures, which also included a narrowing of the trade deficits for July and August as well as for September.
They pointed to, among other things, the so-called J-curve effects of the dollar's 1994 weakness that should help shrink the deficit in 1995.
When the dollar, for example, depreciates against the yen, it makes Japanese goods more expensive for Americans and American goods more affordable for Japanese, thus setting in motion a tendency to reduce the trade imbalance by increasing American exports and lowering imports. But until this adjustment occurs, toward the bottom of the "J", the figures reflect high volumes of imports at high prices.
"Improvement will be throughout 1995," said Harald B. Malmgren, a trade consultant in Washington. "The squeeze going on in corporate Japan is really severe," he said, because the high yen makes exporting difficult.
But some dissented, including Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group that has often complained of limited American access to foreign markets. "The macro-economic explanations are getting a little thin," he said. And now that Japan has been building cars in this country for a decade -- and is now also manufacturing parts here -- record bilateral trade deficits suggest "some structural problem," Mr. Prestowitz said.
The Clinton Administration is seeking to resume talks that could lead to more sales in Japan of American automotive products.
The October deficit with Japan, surpassing the previous record of $6.4 billion in October 1986, brought the 10-month total to $53.9 billion, compared with $48.4 billion for the comparable period in 1993, the report today showed.
October is a big month for importing holiday merchandise, and the figures pertaining to individual countries are not adjusted for seasonal variation.
Last week Japan reported that its merchandise surplus with the United States surged in November to $5.17 billion from $4.78 billion in October and from $4.29 billion in November 1993.
In the aggregate, the report today also showed, imports of goods and services climbed $400 million, to a record $69.8 billion, the sixth consecutive advance.
Exports eased by a similar $400 million, to $59.7 billion, the second consecutive decline, mainly reflecting a sizable decline in deliveries of civilian aircraft and parts.
The nation's oil bill eased during October, apparently reflecting an unusually mild autumn. Imports of crude oil totaled $3.3 billion, down $600 million, as volume shrank by 39 million barrels from September, while prices were 20 cents a barrel less.
While the American deficit with Japan was widening, the deficit with Western Europe narrowed slightly during the month and the gap with China, a fast-growing trade presence, was about unchanged, at $3.5 billion, the Government found. For the first 10 months of the year, however, the deficit with Europe soared to $10.4 billion, from $800 million in the comparable period in 1993.
The deficit with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, rose $300 million, to $1.6 billion, while the balance with Mexico swung to a deficit of $89 million from a surplus of $37 million.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Insurers Were Hit Hard in 1994, Report Says

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Claims from the Los Angeles earthquake in January, followed by declines in stock and bond prices, made 1994 a poor year for property and liability insurance companies.
According to a report released yesterday by the Insurance Information Institute and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, after-tax profits for property and liability insurers will fall to an estimated $7.2 billion this year from $19.3 billion in 1993. The profitability of insurers, which has been lower than the average for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index every year since 1986, remained low in 1994, with insurers earning a meager 3.9 percent return on capital, down from 10.6 percent in 1993. 
 Insurers' profits in 1995 are expected to improve modestly to more than $11 billion and a 7.5 percent return on equity, Peter Wade, an associate director at S.& P., said.
Keen competition among companies will prevent sharp increases in premiums, he said, noting that earnings improvements will be tied closely to cost-cutting within individual companies and the level of catastrophe losses.
Unfortunately for property insurers, catastrophe losses have been rising, as population growth and building construction in vulnerable areas have increased risks at the same time as the weather seems to have turned harsher.
Five of the six largest insurance catastrophes in the United States have occurred in the last five years, led by the $17 billion of losses from Hurricane Andrew in 1992 and the $9 billion of losses from the Los Angeles earthquake in January.
The Los Angeles earthquake accounted for most of the $13 billion of catastrophe losses in 1994, making it the second-worst year ever. The worst year was 1992, when catastrophe losses totaled $23 billion.
Because the property and liability insurance industry has long paid more in claims and expenses than it collects in premiums, it relies on earnings from investments to produce profits. In 1994, profits from capital gains in securities trades dropped to only $1.9 billion from $9.8 billion in 1993.
At the same time, the maturing of old bonds with high interest rates and the reinvestment into new lower-yielding securities caused a slight decline in investment earnings, primarily interest.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
For the third time in two months, shooting erupted near the White House today. This time a Park Police officer critically wounded a homeless man holding a hunting knife.
President Clinton, who was working in the Oval Office when the shooting occurred at 9 A.M., was not in danger, officials said, and witnesses said he was not the target of threats by the homeless man. 
 Witnesses said the man, identified as Marcelino Corniel, was angry because homeless people who had been sleeping in Lafayette Park, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House, were being rousted early in the mornings by the Park Police.
The incident was the second shooting this week near the White House and the fourth violent incident there since September.
Mr. Corniel was in very critical condition tonight at George Washington Hospital after a second operation was performed at 9:30 P.M., said Merle Goldberg, a spokeswoman for the hospital. Earlier, he underwent six hours of surgery for extensive liver damage, she said.
Today some witnesses questioned whether Mr. Corniel had been the victim of a jittery security detail.
A videotape of the incident taken by a photographer for a satellite-news cooperative, Conus Television, showed Mr. Corniel being shot as he stood still holding the knife, in his left hand, pointed to the ground. The officer who fired the shots had just run to the scene, joining three other officers who, with guns drawn, had been facing down Mr. Corniel from 10 feet away.
The standoff developed after Mr. Corniel, waving his knife, had chased at least one officer across Pennsylvania Avenue. With dozens of tourists looking on, the three officers shouted at Mr. Corniel to drop the weapon. He refused, and he glanced over his left shoulder. As he turned to face the officers again, the fourth officer, whom the Park Police refused to identify, fired two shots. Mr. Corniel fell to the ground, wounded in the chest and leg.
Ms. Goldberg, the hospital spokeswoman, said one bullet had penetrated Mr. Corniel's right hand and chest and struck him in the back. The second bullet struck his right leg.
A spokeswoman at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Susan Lloyd, said prosecutors were considering charging Mr. Corniel with assaulting a Federal officer. Other officials said such a charge would be in connection with his chasing the officer across Pennsylvania Avenue.
A spokesman for the Park Police said the officer who shot Mr. Corniel had been put on administrative detail pending a review of the shooting.
Law-enforcement officials said prosecutors were also studying whether the officer was justified in using potentially deadly force.
Federal law-enforcement procedures allow officers to use guns only when their lives or the lives of others are threatened or if they face a threat of serious bodily harm.
Police officials asserted that the force was not excessive. "If somebody is brandishing a knife, it's justified to shoot him," said Maj. Robert Hines, a spokesman. "The officer feared for his safety. So he shot the man. This was a seasoned officer. I don't think he was too quick to fire."
Major Hines said the National Park Police, who guard the White House along with the Secret Service, had recently stepped up security.
But some witnesses wondered whether the shooting was a reflection of an overly security force that had been on edge since a small plane piloted by a drunken and unemployed man crashed under the President's bedroom window in September.
"There were more than enough police officers there to subdue him without shooting him," said Wade Varner, an antinuclear protester from Portland, Ore., who watched the shooting today from across Pennsylvania Avenue. Mr. Varner told reporters that Mr. Corniel had complained about how before tourists arrived each morning the Park Police woke up homeless people in the park by banging their clubs on signs erected by protesters.
Mr. Varner and other witnesses said Mr. Corniel, standing in the park this morning, began shouting profanities at an officer.
"He had been sitting quietly drinking coffee under a jacket when he stood up, grunted, threw off his jacket and ran in front of my stand," said Concepcion Picciotto, who said she had been holding a vigil in the park for 11 years. Mr. Corniel then chased an officer across the avenue to the sidewalk in front of the North Portico of the White House, she said.
"They could have subdued him with gas or something," she said. "He didn't have a gun."
The Associated Press reported today that relatives who filed a missing persons report on Marcelino Corniel on Aug. 26, 1994, notified the authorities that he was the man shot in front of the White House. The news agency also reported that the police in Culver City, Calif., said a man named Marcelino Comiel, also known as Marcelino Corniel, pleaded guilty to armed robbery in 1986 and was convicted in 1985 of assault with a deadly weapon. His date of birth was listed in police records as Aug. 17, 1961, the same date that the F.B.I. gave for the man shot today.
Tension between the police and the homeless has long been present in Lafayette Park. Ten years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that the Government might ban overnight sleeping in the park without infringing on constitutional rights.
Mr. Corniel, described as a 33-year-old artist, started living in the park early in the summer, people who live there said. The homeless people said Mr. Corniel had burn scars on his hands and face and walked with a limp.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After the police shot Marcelino Corniel, a knife was next to him on the sidewalk in front of the White House. (Conus Television via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Mexico Devalues the Peso, Dealing a Blow to Stocks

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The Mexican Government devalued the peso yesterday, presenting Americans who have been pouring millions of dollars into Mexico through stocks, bonds and mutual funds with a nasty surprise that essentially cut the value of their investments by about 15 percent.
Under the new exchange-rate policy announced early yesterday, the peso will be allowed to fall to 4.0 to the dollar before Mexico's central bank will intervene -- not far from its close yesterday of 3.9750. The previous intervention limit was slightly more than 3.46 pesos to the dollar. 
 For all the immediate pain, however, fund managers and investment advisers -- who have helped spur the boom in Mexican investing -- contended that the move would be positive in the long run. Indeed, it may provide opportunities for buyers now, they said.
"Let's put it in perspective," said John Boich, a portfolio manager with Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco. "Yesterday the peso was worth 29 cents; today it's worth 25 cents. The positive effects of the devaluation in terms of economic competitiveness overpower the short-term negative."
Though the Mexican stock market rallied a bit after the devaluation, shares of Mexican companies favored by Americans dropped sharply, as did mutual funds that are heavily weighted in Latin America. American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, which is probably owned by more Americans than any other Mexican stock, dropped in heavy trading more than 5 percent, or $2.50, to $46 a share. The Mexico Fund, a closed-end pool that trades on the New York Stock Exchange, dropped $1.75, to $25.875
The dozen stock funds that specialize in Latin American shares fell about 5 percent yesterday, leaving them down an average 5.2 percent this year, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund-tracking service in Chicago. Among the largest such funds, Merrill Lynch Latin America fell 4.7 percent, while Fidelity Latin America dropped 6.5 percent.
Funds that buy the debt of emerging markets were also hit, falling 1.6 percent yesterday, putting their losses for this year at almost 12 percent. The kind of debt that many of these funds hold, known as Brady bonds, fell to the lowest level in three years.
The losses come at a time when Americans have increasingly been venturing overseas in search of better returns than those available in the United States. Much of that money has flowed into Mexico, which has attracted the bulk of investment in Latin America.
Last year, Latin American funds zoomed more than 50 percent while those made up of United States stocks rose roughly 13 percent. As a result, the amount of money in Latin American equity funds multiplied -- quadrupling in the year ending on Sept. 30, 1994, to $4.4 billion, from $950 million a year earlier, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
"We think there are a lot of exciting opportunities down there -- you just need to think in a three- to-five-year time horizon," said Mark W. Headley, director of international investments at Litman/Gregory & Company in Orinda, Calif.
"Next year could be a banner year, so-so or downright dismal," he added. "But three years out, it will be one of the most attractive places to invest."
Mr. Boich of Montgomery Asset Management said he would probably start buying short-term Mexican Treasury notes, or cetes, which he expects to yield about 15 percent. He said he was confident that the Mexican Government would not devalue the peso again any time soon.
The devaluation of the peso came amid resumed tension in a southern state, Chiapas, and continuing pressure on the nation's financial system. Yesterday, the peasant rebels and their sympathizers in Chiapas again expanded the area of conflict, taking over town halls and blocking major highways, then vanishing.
Finance Minister Jaime Serra Puche said the devaluation was needed to take pressure off the peso. "What we are doing is simply expanding the band to insure that the central bank has the sufficient flexibility to deal with the disturbances that have come forward in the Chiapas conflict," he said.
Speculation about a devaluation has been rampant since the election victory of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon on Aug. 21. The decision is a major reversal for him. Before taking office on Dec. 1, Mr. Zedillo argued that the exchange-rate fluctuation band did not require any changes despite political uncertainties and a growing trade deficit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stock traders in Mexico City bidding prices up after the devaluation. (Associated Press) (pg. D17)

HEADLINE: New York Is Picked to Get Federal Development Zone

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton will designate part of upper Manhattan and the South Bronx -- including the area around Yankee Stadium -- as one of the first Federal Empowerment Zones, Congressional officials said today.
The officials said the Federal aid and tax breaks that would be provided through the zone would help the city in its efforts to keep the Yankees baseball team and provide a huge windfall for the team's owner, George Steinbrenner. 
 New York is one of six cities and three rural areas that will be awarded empowerment zones this week, officials said, bringing to fruition an idea in urban development that was first conceived during the Reagan Administration, when they were called enterprise zones.
Congressional staffers and others familiar with the program said the other urban zones would be in Atlanta, Baltimore, Chicago and Detroit, in addition to one that will include parts of Philadelphia and Camden, N.J. Administration officials, who plan to announce the grants on Wednesday along with other urban-aid grants, would not confirm that list today.
It was not clear where the three rural empowerment zones would be.
Under empowerment-zone legislation, cities with the zones will receive up to $100 million in block grants over two years for community development projects inside the zones. Rural empowerment zones will receive up to $40 million in block grants.
In addition, businesses in the zones will receive some tax incentives, chief among them a tax credit of up to 20 percent of the first $15,000 earned by any worker who lives in the zone.
"We're very happy," Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said in an interview on the New York One television channel. "It's going to bring $100 million into the economy."
Officials were not able to say today how much the Yankees could benefit. But they said it would be more attractive for the team to hire people who live within the zone, since doing so would make it eligible for a break in its corporate taxes.
In a telephone interview, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, whose district will contain much of the zone, said: "We hope to be the flagship of the empowerment-zone fleet."
New York's zone will encompass much of West, Central and East Harlem, as well as Washington Heights and a predominantly industrial area in the Bronx that includes Yankee Stadium. It represents a victory for Mr. Rangel who, along with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a Democrat from Chicago, managed to keep the idea of enterprise zones alive during the late 1980's and first years of this decade.
The zone's final configuration also represents a different kind of victory for Mr. Rangel, who turned back the attempt of the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, to have a larger slice of the Bronx included in the zone.
Mr. Ferrer sought to amend New York's application so that the zone would also cover Melrose and Mott Haven, two sections of the Bronx that are among the poorest regions in New York City. The Borough President argued that if the zone was going to give a tax break to the Yankees, one of the richest franchises in major league baseball, the zone ought to benefit these poverty-stricken neighborhoods as well.
But despite appeals to Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Representative Jose E. Serrano, a Democrat from the South Bronx, Mr. Ferrer was unable to have the zone map altered.
Mr. Rangel fought any change, since Federal law limited the zone's size to 200,000 people. Any increase in the number of people in the Bronx would therefore have meant a reduction in the number of people in Mr. Rangel's district who could be included in the zone.
Mr. Ferrer declined to comment on the award today, but Clint Roswell, his spokesman, said the Borough President was "deliriously happy."
The selection of the zones is the latest chapter in a saga that began during the Reagan Administration when a group of conservatives, including Jack Kemp, the Buffalo-area Republican Representative who later became HUD Secretary, and Stuart M. Butler, head of domestic policy at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research institute, argued for their adoption as a means to spur economic development in blighted inner city areas.
For years, the concept languished in Congress. Many Democrats viewed it with suspicion, asserting that it was a way for the Reagan and Bush administrations to justify cutbacks in programs to aid cities. Republicans, whose constituencies tend not to be based in cities, did not rally behind the program.
The idea was revived during the Bush Administration chiefly through the efforts of Mr. Rangel and Mr. Rostenkowski, the powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who was defeated in his re-election bid in November.
When the empowerment-zone legislation was passed in 1993, Congress authorized the program to run for 10 years. But it has appropriated financing for only two years, leaving questions about the program's long-term viability in a climate of reduced Government spending.
After it took office, the Clinton Administration requested that cities and rural areas submit elaborate applications to compete for the zones. In the applications, cities and rural areas had to list what kinds of projects would be financed through the block grants and list how local residents would share in the planning and implementation of the zones.
Some students of the enterprise-zone concept say the detailed and complex application process spurred cities to undertake planning and community relations initiatives that will be beneficial even if they did not win an empowerment zone.
But such requirements have disappointed conservatives like Mr. Butler who say that Democrats have hijacked the original idea of enterprise zones and turned it into another micro-managed development program.
"This is more of a Model Cities throwback," said Mr. Butler, referring to a old Great Society program for the cities. "They will send Washington their plans, and Washington will see how well they do things that Washington wants them to do."
