HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Unchanged But Soars vs. Devalued Peso

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rate unchanged. But the dollar soared against a devalued Mexican peso.
The Fed ended a policy meeting yesterday without announcing any change in interest rates. The decision was widely expected, dealers said, and therefore had little effect on the dollar. 
 Most analysts expect the central bank to nudge short-term rates higher when it meets again on Jan. 31, an expectation that should keep the dollar on a solid footing. The dollar tends to benefit from a widening in the gap between American and foreign short-term interest rates.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5698 German marks from 1.5730 marks on Monday. It edged up to 100.15 Japanese yen from 100.12 yen.
But the dollar rose sharply against the Mexican peso after the Mexican Government devalued its currency.
The decision was intended to calm markets that have been battered by investor fears over a rebellion in Chiapas state and other political and market uncertainties. The devaluation, which lowered the peso's value by about 15 percent, went against the advice of many financial analysts in Mexico and on Wall Street.
Currency traders quickly followed the devaluation's path. In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 3.9750 pesos, from 3.4657 on Monday.
The devaluation, Mexico's first in seven years, came early in the day, after the peso hit the bottom of its trading band against the dollar -- a level where the central bank must either step in to defend it or let it slide. Under the devaluation, the upper limit of the exchange band within which the peso trades against the dollar would rise by 53 centavos. There are 100 centavos to a peso.
Official United States reaction to the move was more favorable than the market's. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said Mexico's exchange-rate action would "support the healthy development of the Mexican economy."
In currency dealing elsewhere, the dollar rose to 1,647.50 Italian lire, up from 1,645.50 lire on Monday. Political troubles for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's Government have battered the lira's value.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Former Kidder Chief Named To Two Posts at Travelers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Michael A. Carpenter, who left in June as chief executive of Kidder, Peabody & Company and before that was a deal-maker for GE Capital, was named to senior positions at the Travelers Group yesterday.
In one of his new jobs, Mr. Carpenter, 48, will be responsible for the life and annuity businesses of Travelers Insurance, reporting to Robert I. Lipp, chief executive of all the Travelers Insurance businesses. 
 Mr. Carpenter was also named an executive vice president at the Travelers Group, where he will report to Sanford I. Weill, chairman, on business development and strategic planning.
The Travelers Group, based in Manhattan,is the parent company for Travelers Insurance; the Smith Barney securities firm; the Commercial Credit Corporation, a consumer loan company, and Primerica Financial Services, a network of agents, many of them part time, who sell term insurance.
Mr. Carpenter said he was not sure how his time would be divided between the two jobs. Although he has no experience operating an insurance company, he said he was familiar with the industry as a result of deals he arranged while at GE Capital, including the acquisition of the Employers Reinsurance Corporation of Overland Park, Kan., and a leveraged buyout of the John Alden Financial Corporation of Miami.
James Dimon, president of the Travelers Group, and Mr. Carpenter both said they expected the Travelers life insurance business to grow, but added that there had been no determination to begin buying other companies.
"There will be opportunities as the industry consolidates," Mr. Carpenter said, but he added that there were also opportunities to expand the existing network of sales agents and to sell insurance investments, such as annuities, through the Smith Barney network of securities brokers.
The appointment of Mr. Carpenter comes one day after the announcement that Robert W. Crispin had resigned as vice chairman of the Travelers Insurance Companies to become executive vice president at the UNUM Corporation, a leading disability insurance company based in Portland, Me. The life and annuity businesses had previously reported to Mr. Crispin, who was one of the most senior executives of Travelers Insurance to remain with the company since it was acquired in 1993 by Mr. Weill's firm, then known as Primerica.
At Kidder, Mr. Carpenter never succeeded in revitalizing the firm to meet the profit standards of other GE Capital subsidiaries. He resigned the Kidder job as rising interest rates caused big losses for the bond business at the same time the company discovered a bogus bond trading scheme that caused it to report $350 million of fictitious profits. GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company, recently announced plans to sell most of the Kidder firm to Paine Webber Inc.

HEADLINE: Iraq Hinders Arms Monitors, U.N. Panel Reports

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Setting the stage for a Security Council debate next month on easing sanctions against Iraq, the head of a commission monitoring the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction said today that Baghdad was falling "far short" in some areas.
Of particular concern are questions about existing biological weapons. These are difficult to answer because Iraq has been reluctant to provide information on past production. 
 Questions also remain about chemical weapons and the purpose of one radar installation that the commission has ordered destroyed. Most of the missing information concerns imports.
In a report to the Council, the commission head, Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, said the monitoring system was at least provisionally functional. But he then listed enough problems to give ammunition to the United States and Britain, which want to hold Iraq accountable not only for technical compliance but also for demonstrations of good intent.
France, Russia, China and to some degree Spain want to begin releasing President Saddam Hussein from some of the sanctions that have crippled the Iraqi economy and held up payment of foreign debts.
Diplomats from several countries say it was Bush Administration's policy to build openings into the web of sanctions to allow President Hussein to be rewarded for steps showing cooperation with the Security Council. The Clinton Administration has been taking a harder line.
Today Russia and France were circulating a draft Security Council statement praising Iraq for its level of compliance while calling for an immediate "full and transparent accounting of its past programs" and of its current industrial programs that could have dual civilian and military use.
During closed-door Council consultations today, the United States and Britain strongly opposed even this step, diplomats said.
When information on imported components of Iraqi weapons is withheld -- and imports were critical to many programs -- the monitors press foreign governments for details about the sales. Gradually, they are building a dossier with which to confront the Iraqis.
"The commission has been provided with very important information from governments and also managed to put that information into a systematic and analytical framework," Mr. Ekeus said. "That has given us quite powerful tools and knowledge about Iraq's past programs, which demonstrate that Iraq has been far from open with regard to these programs."
Mr. Ekeus also hinted that if Iraq was allowed to sell oil under a resolution adopted in April 1991 at the end of the Persian Gulf war, it would take some time to install controls over those sales so that Iraq would be obliged to use at least some earnings in ways defined by the Council.
In another matter, the United States informed the Security Council sanctions committee on Dec. 7 that it had evidence that Iraq was smuggling oil into the Persian Gulf, passing it off as Iranian.
Iran called the new allegations "a funny old story, which has no truth at all."

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid And G.O.P.: Deep Cuts, Selectively

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Republican leaders in Congress are planning a tough new approach that treats foreign aid much like welfare: as a multibillion-dollar handout that needs to be overhauled and cut.
In mapping strategy for the foreign aid budget, which is $13.7 billion this year, the Congressional Republicans want to focus on advancing the United States' national security and economic interests rather than what they say is an entitlement program for poor nations. Many of them talk about using their new majority to cut foreign aid by 15 to 20 percent. 
 The Republican lawmakers who will have the greatest influence on foreign aid suggest that assistance to Africa will be cut sharply, while aid to the Middle East and former Soviet bloc nations -- two areas viewed as vital to national security -- will be maintained at or near current levels.
These lawmakers say they intend to slash the $1 billion in annual aid to Africa because in their view African countries have little strategic importance and have grown dependent on aid without using the money to improve their economies.
"The only way to break the devastating cycle of dependency is to end foreign aid entitlement programs," said Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who will be the new chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, which oversees foreign aid. "If we're going to change welfare here at home, we certainly ought not to be using American tax dollars to foster that kind of dependency abroad."
Africa is not the only target of Republicans; they also aim to cut the $450 million in aid for population stabilization programs overseas as well as the American contribution to the United Nations, World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican whowill be chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, said "American taxpayers are being gouged" by those development banks.
Republican lawmakers have proposed placing tighter strings on assistance and barring aid to countries unless their policies promote free markets, free trade and private property.
Clinton Administration officials have asserted that the Republicans' aid strategy takes a myopic view of the security interests of the United States and undercuts its leadership role and moral authority overseas.
"We cannot exercise influence over the international community in some rosier future if we abdicate responsibility now," said J. Brian Atwood, Administrator of the Agency for International Development, the Government's chief aid arm.
In part, the clash reflects a difference in philosophy, with Republicans viewing foreign aid primarily as a means of cementing strategic alliances, and the Administration focusing on the long-term benefits of combating poverty and environmental problems.
"My view is it ought to be directly targeted toward areas of the world where we have a clear national security interest," Mr. McConnell said.
Under this approach, he and other Republicans say aid -- including military assistance, which represents almost one-third of the aid budget -- should be continued to Israel, Egypt, Ukraine, Georgia and Armenia. To further the use of aid for strategic purposes, Mr. McConnell has proposed cutting off the $700 million in aid to Russia if it intervenes militarily in any other former Soviet republics.
Supporting the $3 billion in annual aid to Israel, Mr. Callahan said: "Aid to Israel is not an entitlement. Israel is our greatest ally in the Middle East, and we ought to do everything we can to continue that relationship."
Mr. Atwood responded that while aid to strategic allies like Israel is vital, it is also valuable to provide money to the poorest countries in Africa and elsewhere to combat hunger, overpopulation and environmental degradation. He asserted that in the post-cold-war era, problems like those in Somalia and Rwanda are increasingly causing conflicts that ensnare the American military. In his view, such aid is not a handout, but preventive medicine.
Accusing many aid critics of being isolationists, he said, "If we don't deal with programs to help stop these countries from failing, we'll spend a lot more money in the aftermath dealing with their crises."
In defending foreign assistance, the Administration notes that after adjusting for inflation, the aid budget has slipped to its lowest level since World War II, and is down 20 percent from 1991. Officials add that the aid budget is less than 1 percent of the $1.6 trillion Federal budget, although in a recent study by the Harvard School of Public Health and the Kaiser Family Foundation, 27 percent of those polled identified foreign aid as the largest Federal expenditure.

HEADLINE: A Study Says U.S. Schools And Families Aren't Failing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
A study by the Rand Corporation takes a much rosier view than usual of American schools and families. Contrary to popular belief, it says, schools have improved over the last 20 years, and better-educated parents and smaller families are helping students learn.
The authors of the study said their research should dispel the notion that schools and parents are failing the nation's children. 
 "If you listen to the national debate, you would believe that families and schools are failing and government programs and policies don't work," said David W. Grissmer, who led the study at Rand, a research institute in Santa Monica, Calif.
The study said standardized test scores for black and Hispanic teen-agers improved significantly between the mid-1970's and 1990, narrowing the gap with white students, who made smaller gains.
The average math and reading scores of students 13 to 17 years of age increased the equivalent of 3 percentile points for white students, 11 points for Hispanic students and 19 points for black students.
The study was based on scores in the National Assessment of Educational Progress tests from 1970 to 1990. The scores were analyzed along with information from government surveys of families.
Education Secretary Richard W. Riley, in announcing the latest National Assessment of Educational Progress results in August, said that although the nation's students were doing somewhat better than 20 years ago, the progress was inadequate.
Mr. Grissmer said today that "we aren't saying that American education is good enough," only that it is not as bad as many believe.
The Rand study said that the gains in test scores suggested that desegregation and increased spending on schools, especially programs designed for minority students, had paid off. Early education and nutrition programs for poor children may also account for some gains, it said.
The researchers said their next goal was to determine which programs work and why, so school spending would be more cost-effective.
"The country should be cautious about dismantling programs until we know which deserve to go and which to continue," Mr. Grissmer said.
While minority students benefited from changes both at school and at home, the small improvement in white students' scores seems to be tied to family life, the study said.
The factor that helped students most, it said, was better-educated parents. In 1970, for example, 38 percent of the mothers had not completed high school, but in 1990, the figure was only 17 percent.
Students in smaller families also seemed to do better, the study found. Average family incomes remained stable while average family size decreased, leaving more resources to care for each child.
The Rand analysis found that two trends that have worried policy makers -- an increase in the number of working mothers and an increase in single mothers -- had no significant effect when considered alone.

HEADLINE: The Fed Forgoes a Seventh Rate Increase

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's top officials met for nearly four hours today but adjourned without announcing any change in interest rates.
Most economists and traders still expect the Fed to raise rates again, possibly at its next meeting on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, or perhaps before then. 
 The Fed is prepared to brake economic growth, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned a Congressional panel on Dec. 7, if necessary to prevent recent increases in raw materials and other manufacturing costs from showing up in consumer prices.
But the central bank's top officials also hinted earlier this month that they would probably pass up the chance today to raise short-term interest rates for the seventh time this year. Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman, emphasized on Dec. 9 that reliable information on the economy's health for the fourth quarter would not become available until January.
Financial markets showed little reaction to the Fed's decision today. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 7.84 percent. [Page D17.] Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.55 points, to 3,767.15. [Page D8.]
The Fed's difficulty lies in judging how much the last six interest rate increases will slow the economy. Interest rate changes take up to two years to affect economic growth because companies plan far ahead in making big investment decisions. Strong growth, in turn, can fuel inflation by creating bottlenecks that allow companies to bid up prices.
Lawrence A. Hunter, the Republican staff director of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said that the Fed faced the same dilemma now as a bather who has just turned the hot water on full in a shower but still finds the water coming out cold. "You have to wait a long time or you'll burn yourself," he said.
Today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee marked only the third time this year that the Fed's top policy-making body had met without announcing an interest rate increase. The statement issued at the end of today's meeting was virtually identical to the statements from the previous meetings on July 6 and Sept. 27.
"The F.O.M.C. meeting ended at 12:45 P.M.," today's statement said. "There will be no further announcements."
At the July 6 and Sept. 27 meetings this year, Fed officials voted to give explicit discretionary power to Mr. Greenspan to raise rates on his own authority before the next meeting.
Although Mr. Greenspan did not use this authority following the meetings on July 6 and Sept. 27, some experts said that he had likely received similar authorization today and might use it next month.
John Lipsky, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said that Mr. Greenspan would be particularly likely to raise interest rates next month if there is a sharp jump in underlying inflation, which excludes changes in volatile food and energy prices.
The Fed was able to leave interest rates untouched today in part because it raised short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point on Nov. 15, the largest increase since 1981. The size of that increase reassured bond investors that they could make long-term investments without worrying that inflation would erode the returns.
Interest rates on long-term bonds have fallen by nearly a quarter of a percentage point since Nov. 15. Within the Fed, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, and others who advocated pushing short-term rates up have argued that tighter money is needed to respond to rising long-term rates. Now that the bond market has responded favorably, this faction may not have pushed hard for a rate increase today.
Starting in February, the Fed pushed up its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks pay each other for overnight loans, to 5.5 percent from 3 percent. The Fed has also raised the less important discount rate, which it charges banks for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent from 3 percent.
The interest rates that Americans pay for mortgages, home-equity loans, car loans and other borrowing have climbed steeply this year, but seem unlikely to change much in response to today's meeting of Fed officials.
White House officials, in line with the Administration's policy of respecting the Fed's independence, declined to comment on today's decision.
Still, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said that recent Labor Department figures on consumer and factory prices showed no signs of accelerating inflation.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bills Gain On Inaction By the Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bills and notes rose yesterday as the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee adjourned its meeting without altering interest-rate policy.
But the price of the 30-year bond slipped 2/32 of a percentage point, to 96 2/32 , for a yield of 7.84 percent, unchanged from Monday. 
 Many investors stayed on the sidelines yesterday ahead of any news that could signal a change in monetary policy. The market's focus now turns to the next meeting of the Fed's policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, which is scheduled to begin on Jan. 31.
Many market participants think the Fed will choose that time for another increase in short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating.
Treasury bills and notes with maturities of five years or less are more vulnerable to interest rate increases by the Fed. The shorter maturities rose after the Fed announced that the final meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee for 1994 had ended at 12:45 P.M. and that there would be "no further announcements."
Ray Worseck, chief economist and manager at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, said there were a number of reasons the Fed took no action on interest rates yesterday. "For one, they bought themselves a little time with the 75-basis-point hike in November," he said, noting that the effects of a rate increase take time to work through the economy.
Also, he said, "the dollar has not been under pressure since the November meeting." And he added that the fiasco involving the investment fund of Orange County, Calif., had given the Fed "another reason not to tighten."
Today the Treasury will auction $17.25 billion of new two-year notes and tomorrow it will auction $11 billion of new five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.57 percent, and the five-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.74 percent.
Elsewhere, municipal bonds were little changed amid growing concern that bond funds will increase selling as investor redemptions resume. Some speculate that those redemptions could increase if Orange County misses a coupon payment or if it is in technical default, according to one trader.
In the corporate bond market, USA Mobile Communications Holdings Inc. moved ahead yesterday with a planned bond offering, taking the company a step closer to thwarting an unwelcome $200 million merger bid from Metrocall Inc.
The company priced a $100 million junk bond offering through Morgan Stanley & Company in anticipation of a USA Mobile shareholder vote on Friday to issue the notes.
Metrocall opposes the junk-bond offering, saying USA Mobile's interest costs are too high. On Monday, Metrocall warned that it would "immediately and irrevocably withdraw" its $14.50-a-share offer for USA Mobile if the bonds are sold.
Metrocall has also has threatened to revoke its offer if USA Mobile proceeds with its planned merger with Premiere Page Inc., a paging company based in Leawood, Kan., that USA Mobile has agreed to buy for about $36 million in cash and stock. That transaction is also scheduled for a vote at the shareholder meeting in Cincinnati on Friday.
The 10-year bonds were priced at par to yield 14 percent, according to MCM Corporate Watch. MCM said the issue was rated B3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and CCC+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Metrocall wants to buy USA Mobile and Premiere Page in separate transactions for about $200 million in cash and stock, creating the nation's second-largest publicly traded paging company. Metrocall, based in Alexandria, Va., has offered to buy Premiere Page for $12 a share in cash and stock.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Lower in Heavy Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed but generally lower in heavy trading yesterday after the Federal Reserve took no action on interest rates, a move that, at least in the short run, should have helped lift stock prices.
But several weeks ago, the market had begun to anticipate the Fed's possible reluctance to raise rates and therefore lifted prices in advance of a deferred action, some analysts said. 
 Meanwhile, the devaluation of the Mexican peso prompted a rush to sell the American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, which represents a large portion of the Mexican stock market's capitalization. The A.D.R.'s dropped 2 1/2, to 46, and was the second-most-active stock at 14.6 million shares, just behind the 15.9 million shares traded in Microsoft. Each A.D.R. represents 20 ordinary shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.55 points, to 3,767.15, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.81 point, to 457.10. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.62 point, to 728.51.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 327 million shares changing hands, about 13 percent above this year's average of 290 million shares.
The confusion of traders on which direction to go was evident in the performance of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. Almost exactly the same number of stocks rose in price as fell: or 1,126 advancing stocks and 1,125 declining stocks. But 101 stocks established new lows and only 29 established new highs.
And some traders cast doubt on whether a "December rally" would materialize. They attributed an almost unbroken advance of seven sessions that lasted until Friday to mainly technical factors, like purchases related to the "triple witching" expiration of options and other instruments last week.
Dudley A. Eppel, managing director of listed trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, "I wouldn't trust anything that happens on the Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of a triple-witching week."
The market is jittery because few traders have made money this year, Mr. Eppel said. Therefore, most traders are not trading on the merits of a stock, but on inflation figures, stock indexes and the bond market, he said. "It wouldn't take much to take this market down 200 points," he said.
Some stocks rose sharply. Class B shares of Nike Inc., rose to a new 52-week high of 71 7/8, before closing at 71 5/8, up 5 5/8. The shoe maker reported a strong second-quarter earnings increase, its first in a year and half. Intel shares rose 37/16 , to 61 1/4, after it agreed to adopt a more generous return policy for its flawed Pentium microprocessor.
Other stocks fell. United Companies Financial established a 52-week low of 22 before closing at 22 1/2, down 4 1/2. United Companies, a provider of mortgage loans, said it expected fourth-quarter net to be below Wall Street expectations. Monsanto, the chemical conglomerate, fell to a 52-week low of 66 1/2 before closing at 68 7/8, down 4 points. It agreed to buy the Kelco specialty chemicals business of Merck & Company for more than $1 billion.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.24 point, to 249.80, and the American Stock Exchange market-value-index fell 0.43 point, to 425.30.

HEADLINE: Germany Shuns Biotechnology

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOECHST, Germany

 BODY:
Hoechst A.G., the pharmaceutical company, has poured $90 million into its biotechnology operations. Its rival BASF has opened an $80 million biotech research operation. And Bayer has just entered a $25 million biotech joint venture.
These investments by the three German pharmaceutical giants were made not in Germany but in the United States and elsewhere. 
 German businesses are reluctant to invest in biotechnology at home not only because of innate caution about risky ventures, but also because of opposition from militant environmentalists and the bad name given genetic engineering by the Nazis in World War II.
"Biotech is almost nonexistent within Germany," said Ulrich Langer, a chemicals analyst at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "Public opinion is still very much against it, so German companies find they have to go abroad, to the U.S. or Japan."
So BASF opened its $80 million biotech research center in Worcester, Mass. Bayer entered its $25 million joint venture with Onyx of Richmond, Calif., following an earlier joint venture with Viagene in San Diego on Factor VIII, a treatment for hemophilia. And Hoechst has spent more than $90 million on its biotech operations in France, Japan and New Jersey.
The problems were illustrated when Hoechst decided a decade ago to open Germany's first production plant for genetically engineered human insulin.
Ten years later, after battles with German laws, red tape and court challenges from local politicians and environmental groups, the plant sits unfinished at the company's home base here. Hoechst officials do not expect to start selling insulin until 1996 and estimate that the years of delay will lose them more than $300 million in revenues.
When Hoechst, BASF and Bayer gave respective annual presentations to financial analysts earlier this month, none of the biotechnology investments they outlined were in Germany.
"North America has not replaced Germany as a location for business, but there are certain innovative activities which are best performed in the U.S.," Manfred Schneider, Bayer's chairman, said.
With Germany struggling to emerge from its worst recession in decades, and with more than three million unemployed, exporting biotech jobs to other countries carries some long-term ramifications.
Most pharmaceutical industry officials predict that the majority of new wonder drugs will emerge from genetic engineering. This has led to doubts that German pharmaceutical companies can compete in the long term with competitors from the United States and Asia.
Lack of domestic support for the biotech industry here has also created a brain drain, with German scientists being hired away by companies abroad.
President Roman Herzog of Germany lamented in a recent interview with the news magazine Focus, "Especially for gene technology, I have the feeling that there is no more chance for Germany here."
Resistance in Germany to producing such wonder drugs as EPO, which stimulates the growth of red blood cells vital to dialysis patients, or TPA, a blood-thinning agent for heart attack patients, has roots in German history as well as in more recent political movements.
The ghastly experiments by Nazi doctors during the war on prison camp inmates plus the Nazi notion of creating a superior race still haunt Germans, giving the concept of gene manipulation sinister overtones.
The politically powerful Green movement in Germany has led public opposition to genetic technology research and production. Scores of Green groups around the country file lawsuits to stop biotechnology work, and elected officials have put up local barriers to biotech companies. The more militant environmentalists have trampled genetically engineered vegetables on experimental plots and burst into laboratories where genetic engineering research is conducted. The most vociferous opposition is aimed at genetically engineered plants and animals.
"The public pretty much thinks genetically engineered medication is O.K." said Manfred Ritz, an official of the Federation of Chemical Industries. "But they're worried about food. That will take more time."
There are no more than 5 experimental plots in Germany where scientists can grow genetically altered vegetables, compared with 30 in Belgium, 30 in France and more than 1,000 in the United States, said Peter Buckel, director of genetic engineering at Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H. outside Munich.
Boehringer Mannheim, a conspicuous exception to the dearth of biotech facilities in Germany, functions partly because the company is based in the conservative state of Bavaria, where the Green Party has relatively little influence.
German suspicions about biotechnology have given rise to European centers of biotechnology emerging beyond Germany's borders. The Alsace region of France, for example, has attracted Swiss and German companies. Hoechst recently built a plant north of Paris to make Hirudin, an anti-coagulant medication found naturally in leeches.
When Germany's legislature passed the Genetic Engineering Act last May to encourage biotechnology at home, Hoechst applied to make Hirudin out of baker's yeast, but ran into a logjam from local politicians.
"The decision was made to shift the plant to near Paris and we received authorization in six weeks from the French Government," said Dieter Brauer, head of Hoechst's biotech research and development. Within months the company had invested more than $10 million in the French plant.
But Germany's problems with biotechnology also have to do with what critics call the penchant among German businessmen for caution, inflexibility and reluctance to make corporate decisions without broad consensus.
In the United States, biotech development has often come from small entrepreneurs backed by venture capital from investors who accept high risk because the payoffs, when they come, can be big. As a result, there are 1,200 biotech companies in the United States and only 17 in Germany.
"We need to do research to find the adventure gene," said Mr. Buckel at Boehringer Mannheim. "American are so much more willing to take risks. We've been sleeping in Germany. We need to wake up."

HEADLINE: For Dancers and Stage Managers With Ballet Theater, a New Voice

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
The American Guild of Musical Artists first took dancers under its wing in 1939. Today, 1,000 of its 5,500 members are dancers and the union represents 24 ballet and modern-dance companies. But the guild lost a major constituent when the 75 dancers and stage managers of American Ballet Theater broke away in June and then voted this month to ratify a contract negotiated by a new union, the Independent Artists of America, which represents only Ballet Theater.
Behind the break, which is the talk of the dance world and performing-arts unions, are problems that threaten the survival of ballet and modern-dance troupes around the country. Those problems demand a new spirit of cooperation with management, the Ballet Theater members say. 
 Government, corporate and private financing for the arts is down. Touring no longer helps to pay for expensive but crucial New York seasons. Ballet and modern-dance companies are now having to produce themselves on the road more frequently, taking greater financial risks, as local producing money has dried up. And so there are fewer tours. To survive, it seems, the largest ballet troupes must increasingly give up the performing that is their raison d'etre because it drives them into debt. Ballet Theater's break with the guild is in part an attempt to address the problems more directly.
In a recent interview at Ballet Theater's Manhattan headquarters, the leaders of Independent Artists spoke of the gains they had made in the new three-year contract, particularly in health benefits and in salary increases, that range from 10 to 13 percent.
They also spoke of working more closely with management to help the company survive in economically desperate times when Ballet Theater and some other major companies are cutting performing weeks and canceling seasons.
The idea of a partnership with management would seem to be antithetical to the philosophy of trade unionism. But the Ballet Theater dancers are not alone in their decision to work more closely with management, said Paul Mishler, an assistant professor of labor studies at the Van Arsdale School of Labor Studies at Empire State College in Manhattan. "Every worker feels that," he said. "Auto workers in Detroit are concerned with that. All of us have been put under the gun because of corporate restructuring. It's not about art. It's about everyone employed by institutions. Don't take survival for granted any more."
Alexander Dube, the dance administrator for the guild, said that this union, too, has encouraged the idea of partnership. It agreed in recent years with Joffrey Ballet dancers' deferring two weeks' pay and with Ballet Theater dancers' giving up contractually guaranteed workweeks.
"What we don't encourage is the idea of unilateral erosion of a collective-bargaining agreement," Mr. Dube said. "A partnership means that the two sides consult on budgets and make decisions about expenditures. Will the dancers be given the right to determine expenditures and cutbacks?"
Ultimately, however, the leaders of the new union said the break had occurred because of a longtime dissatisfaction with the guild, going back to the mid-1970's. "Our dancers now know they're in a union," said Lori Rosecrans, a principal stage manager who is the vice president of Independent Artists.
Representatives of the two unions disagree on a number of bread-and-butter issues in their respective contracts as well as the guild's degree of involvement in representing the Ballet Theater dancers. If there is strength and safety in numbers, however, the guild clearly has the edge. And it has been developing national and local forums for exchanges of information among members throughout the country, a move praised by Independent Artists officers.
The guild also recently elected two dancers -- Gerald Otte, formerly of the Nikolais Dance Theater, and Michael Byars, a soloist with the New York City Ballet -- to its national board. Still, Independent Artists officers say, dancers are a minority in the guild, which failed to take the Ballet Theater contingent seriously enough. Until recently, Ms. Rosecrans and Griff Braun, a corps dancer at Ballet Theater and treasurer of Independent Artists, were members of the guild board.
"We tried to work for change from within," said Michael Owen, a principal dancer and president of Independent Artists. "But all of it fell on deaf ears."
Louise Gilmore, the guild's new national executive secretary, says Ballet Theater's break with mainstream trade unionism may heighten what she calls the "isolation and extreme insularity" common in the profession.
"Dancers are out of touch with what their company's obligations are to them," Ms. Gilmore said. "It is extremely important, for their own protection, for them to hear from other dancers. We know that employers speak with one another and compare notes. It seems a shame to us that dancers don't have the same advantage."
Rather than cut all ties, Independent Artists has suggested that Ballet Theater's dancers and stage managers keep their membership in the American Guild of Musical Artists to make it easier to work as guest performers with guild companies. The leaders of Independent Artists say they view their group as a national union open to anyone in the arts.
Ballet Theater's members say that they are responding to the turmoil the arts find themselves in today and that their jump to Independent Artists is but one attempt to take an active role in helping their company to survive.
Mr. Owen and Ms. Rosecrans said they supported Ballet Theater's recent decision to cancel "Nutcracker" performances at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., where the company recently formed a partnership that would enable it to use the school's studios and theater for extra rehearsing and performing in return for teaching and doing other work with students. If such decisions had been made earlier, Mr. Owen said, Ballet Theater might not have accumulated a $6.7 million deficit, which has been reduced by $3.5 million.
Gary Dunning, the company's executive director, said the dancers' willingness to make concessions seemed to have less to do with the guild than with their desire to "take charge of their own destiny." "Our position about the union is that it was up to the dancers to choose whether they want A.G.M.A. or I.A.A.," he said of the guild and Independent Artists, adding that Independent Artists was not the only union to make concessions.
"The dancers led the way," he said. "But the musicians reduced their workweeks. Other unions took wage freezes, as did the staff. That kind of sacrifice over the last two years was widespread. It needed to be, but it was also important to form a united front in order to save the company and rebuild it. The others didn't form a new union, but they had the same energy and commitment."
Independent Artists leaders say they feel the issue of partnership can be explored more creatively than it was in the past. A provision in the new contract allows for 6 of the guaranteed 36 workweeks to be spent in special activities like teaching, choreographing or other artistic work. "But they can't just send the dancers out to bar mitzvahs," said Leonard Leibowitz, of the Manhattan labor law firm of Leibowitz, Belson, Perlman & Scuflita, who is counsel to Independent Artists and has represented the Ballet Theater dancers, independently of the guild, since 1979.
Ballet Theater dancers have had a long history of dealing directly with management, Ms. Rosecrans said. And the officers of Independent Artists speak of their belief in the leadership of Mr. Dunning and Kevin McKenzie, the former Ballet Theater principal who is now the artistic director of the company. Obviously, Mr. Owen added, a certain distance must be maintained.
Dancers, they say, must speak up. Some are doing just that. Mr. Byars and Ms. Rosecrans are completing degrees in labor studies. And the topics of unionism and survival are much more under discussion today in major ballet companies.
In the end, however, Independent Artists leaders said their major reason for forming their own union was simple. "This doesn't have to be a big feud with A.G.M.A.," Mr. Braun said. "If your plumber isn't doing the job right, you get another one. You don't hate the first plumber." They had already worked with the first plumber, Mr. Owen added, and "the drains are still clogged."

HEADLINE: In Dishes From Soup to Hash, the Sweet Potato Shows Off

BYLINE: By YANICK RICE LAMB 

 BODY:
SOME people are divided into two factions during the holidays: the sweet potato pie camp and the pumpkin pie camp. "I like sweet potatoes better than pumpkins any day," said Norma Jean Darden, an owner of Spoonbread Catering in Manhattan.
"Nobody likes pumpkin pie in my family," said Sadie Bell Herbin of Reidsville, N.C. But then again, pumpkin pies don't stand much of a chance in her state, which is the leading producer of sweet potatoes in this country. 
 While purists bake a basic but tasty sweet potato pie, others get a little more adventurous. Some throw in a little coconut; some add crushed pineapple. Ms. Darden whips up lemon sweet potato tartlets, a favorite of Bill Cosby's, one of her first catering clients, and Mrs. Herbin sometimes makes a sweet potato cobbler. "You haven't lived until you've tasted sweet potato cobbler," said her niece, Olivia Penn of Brooklyn. "Talk about slap-your-face good!"
Mike Cannon, a horticultural specialist at the Louisiana State University Agricultural Center in Baton Rouge and a member of the Sweet Potato Council of the United States, says that in the last five years, restaurants have increased their use of sweet potatoes.
Restaurants have served pies and candied yams for years. But as soon as the temperature begins to dip, many add comfort foods, and often sweet potatoes are the base. Michael Romano, the chef at the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan, created a sweet potato-brussels sprouts hash to accompany a spicy, seared salmon dish.
At nearby Chat 'n' Chew, Kris Yettra-Latham, the general manager and chef, offers a hearty sweet potato soup. There is sweet potato cheesecake at Kwanzaa in SoHo and sweet potato muffins at the Shark Bar on the Upper West Side.
Ms. Darden comes from a long line of sweet potato lovers. Many of her family's recipes are included in "Spoonbread and Strawberry Wine" (Doubleday), a cookbook that she wrote with her sister, Carole Darden Lloyd, who is also her partner in Spoonbread. It was published in 1978 and reissued this year.
But the record for sweet potato recipes probably belongs to Hollie West of Beaumont, Tex. The 94-year-old retired home economist included 700 recipes in "The Exotic Yam," a cookbook that she published with her nephew in 1983.
Although the terms "yam" and "sweet potato" are used interchangeably, they refer to two different foods. Sweet potatoes, which have yellow or orange-colored flesh, are members of the Ipomoea family, while yams are white-fleshed, hairy members of the Dioscorea family, explained Jessica B. Harris, a food historian and author of "The Welcome Table: African-American Heritage Cooking," to be published by Simon & Schuster in February. Yams are not grown in this country but in Africa, the Caribbean and Central America.
What people here eat and often call yams are sweet potatoes. Sweet potatoes are about 2,000 years old, Miss West says, and were discovered during gold expeditions in Central America. She notes that there are 200 varieties.
Besides being versatile, she says, they are also nutritious. The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington-based consumer advocacy group, ranks them first among vegetables on its nutrition scoreboard, said the center's executive director, Michael F. Jacobson, who often eats baked sweet potatoes for lunch.
 
Sadie Bell Herbin's Candied Yams
 
Total time: 60 minutes
 
 5 medium sweet potatoes (about 3 pounds)
 1 cup white sugar
 1 cup brown sugar
 1/2 teaspoon ginger
 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg
 1/2 teaspoon allspice
 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon (optional)
 1/2 stick butter (optional)
 2 cups water.
1. Boil sweet potatoes until soft when pierced with a fork. Peel and slice into 1/2-inch slices along the length or width.
2. Mix together sugars and spices.
3. Line a quart-size casserole dish with a layer of potatoes. Evenly sprinkle some of the sugar mixture and, if desired, dot with butter, and continue to alternate layers.
4. Pour water over potatoes. Bake for 45 minutes at 300 degrees or until a syrup forms. Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving (without optional butter): 365 calories, 0 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 25 milligrams sodium, 2 grams protein, 90 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sweet Potato Pie
Adapted from "Spoonbread and Strawberry Wine"
 
Total time: 1 hour 10 minutes
 
 3 large eggs
 1 1/4 cups sugar
 Dash of salt
 1 teaspoon cinnamon
 1/2 teaspoon allspice
 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg
 Juice of 1 lemon (optional)
 1 teaspoon vanilla (optional)
 1 cup heavy cream
 3 cups cooked, mashed sweet potatoes
 2 unbaked 8- or 9-inch pie shells.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Beat eggs well.
2. Add sugar, salt, spices and, if desired, lemon juice and vanilla. Mix thoroughly.
3. Add cream, and stir.
4. Add mashed sweet potatoes, and mix thoroughly.
5. Turn into pie shells, and bake for 1 hour or until firm.
Yield: 16 to 18 servings (2 pies).
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 285 calories, 15 grams fat, 55 milligrams cholesterol, 160 milligrams sodium, 4 grams protein, 40 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sweet Potato Soup
Adapted from Chat 'n' Chew
 
Total time: 20 minutes
 
4 large sweet potatoes
 8 carrots
 1 large onion, chopped
 1 tablespoon olive oil
 2 teaspoons grated fresh ginger
 1 teaspoon ground nutmeg
 1 tablespoon salt
 2 tablespoons fresh ground pepper
 1 cup heavy cream
 1 cup milk
 1/2 red bell pepper, minced
 3 sprigs parsley, chopped.
1. In a large pot, boil sweet potatoes and carrots until very soft. Drain, peel and cube.
2. Saute onions in oil until soft.
3. Put sweet potatoes, onion, carrots and spices in food processor, and puree until slightly chunky.
4. Add cream and milk until desired consistency is reached.
5. If desired, simmer over low heat for 5 minutes.
6. Garnish with bell pepper and parsley.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 370 calories, 20 grams fat, 60 milligrams cholesterol, 1,150 milligrams sodium, 6 grams protein, 45 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sweet Potato-Brussels Sprouts Hash
Adapted from Union Square Cafe
 
Total time: 30 minutes
 
 5 medium sweet potatoes, peeled and quartered
 1 quart orange juice
 1 1/2 quarts water
 1/4 cup maple syrup
 1 stick cinnamon
 Pinch of nutmeg
 Kosher salt
 Freshly ground black pepper
 1/2 pound brussels sprouts, washed, outer leaves removed and thinly sliced
 2 ounces butter
 2 medium thin-sliced red onions.
1. Place sweet potatoes in large pot; cover with orange juice, water, maple syrup, cinnamon, nutmeg, salt and pepper. Bring to a boil, lower heat and simmer gently until sweet potatoes are easily pierced by a fork. Drain potatoes, reserving liquid.
2. In 1 quart of boiling water, blanch the sliced brussels sprouts for 1 minute. Drain.
3. Heat butter in a 10- to 12-inch nonstick skillet; add sliced onions. Cook over medium heat until wilted, about 10 minutes. Add brussels sprouts and cook 5 more minutes.
4. Add drained sweet potatoes to pan. Use a spatula to break up larger pieces and incorporate them into sprouts and onions. Allow hash to gently brown, turning over pieces with a spatula occasionally. Add a little of the reserved sweet potato cooking liquid if hash becomes too dry. Season with salt and pepper. When hash is thoroughly heated through and evenly browned, serve on a platter or on individual plates.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 250 calories, 5 grams fat, 20 milligrams cholesterol, 100 milligrams sodium, 4 grams protein, 45 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: AT WORK WITH: Kristina Gunnill;
Madison Avenue Meets the Volga

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARATOV, Russia

 BODY:
IN this provincial city, once closed to foreigners because of its military plants, a Peace Corps volunteer named Kristina Gunnill has found both a cause and a second family.
Ms. Gunnill is a Peace Corps volunteer in a country taught to believe that the Peace Corps is a nest of spies. She is a Harvard M.B.A. and former advertising executive in a land where the customer is still regarded as the enemy, where, as the old proverb goes, "You can never sell anything without deceiving someone." 
 And she is a noisy, single, energetic woman in a country where women still think they must be married by 21 and have children immediately if they expect to have any kind of life.
"There's no such thing in America as being too ambitious," Ms. Gunnill says in her brisk, lilting way.
Vera Dmitriyeva -- a teacher who took Ms. Gunnill in, rented her a room and made her part of the family -- laughs in her usual, perpetual astonishment at what comes out of Kristina's mouth. "You can't be ambitious here, not if you're a woman," she says, then pauses. "Kristina brought a lot of optimism into this house."
Ms. Gunnill, 48, has a gift for selling the upside of capitalism and identifying young Russians who can benefit from her experience and enthusiasm. In return, she inspires devotion. And to the deep distress of her Russian disciples, who tend to hover around her as she works in the Saratov Center for Business Development, she has recently learned that she has multiple sclerosis.
She has also turned disease into an opportunity. She founded one of the first chapters of the Multiple Sclerosis Society in Russia.
For the Peace Corps, which tends to work in less developed countries with nurses, doctors and well-diggers, the focus on business is a departure. Russia is among the most difficult assignments for volunteers, with bad food, low salaries, local mistrust and no tropical beach at the end of the day.
In late 1992, after the first chaotic year of the transition to market prices, 99 American Peace Corps volunteers arrived in Russia for training as "shock workers for capitalism." Forty-eight, including Ms. Gunnill, were assigned to Western Russia, along the Volga, and 51 to the far east, centered in Vladivostok. The dropout rate has been high, especially in rough-and-tumble Vladivostok, where only 29 volunteers remain from the first group. Along the Volga, there are 34.
IT has been very difficult in Saratov, Ms. Gunnill freely admits, and some of the offshoots of "savage capitalism" -- crime and corruption, and there's even a local restaurant here named Omerta -- have fed a conservative backlash.
But for Ms. Gunnill, the past is prologue. "What you see are the death throes of the old economy," she says. "Those are always difficult and not very pretty to watch. I'm into birth."
Mrs. Dmitriyeva, who teaches English at Saratov State University, has been pushed by Ms. Gunnill into starting a "business English" course. She keeps lists of her comments and aphorisms. "People in Saratov will learn Kristina English," Mrs. Dmitriyeva says.
For example? "Well," Mrs. Dmitriyeva says, "I like this one: 'Happiness is a worked-out skill.' It's absolutely right."
Ms. Gunnill, listening, blushes a bit, a rare thing for her. "I'd like to phrase it a little better," she says.
"No, it's right," her friend says. "And it sums up a lot in her character."
Mrs. Dmitriyeva also chooses "It's the little things that count," and then explains why this cliche moves her. "For so many years we were told to live for tomorrow, for the bright shining future," she says, and here she rolls her eyes, "for our grandchildren to live in Socialism, or maybe even their grandchildren, and it wasn't supposed to matter how we lived, or how poor or wretched we were. It was all for the future.
"But you know, it's true. It is the little things that count, that count now. We want to be happy today."
Ms. Gunnill, not an easy crier, has wet eyes. She points to Vera Dmitriyeva's 20-year-old daughter, Katya, and says, "I'm sure for Katya's generation, they will have the most wonderful experience!" Katya, who attends college in the United States and is now home for a visit, isn't so sure. Ms. Gunnill waves it all away, saying: "Listen, I'm a trend spotter! This is my job!"
After nearly 20 years in advertising, including 13 years with Young & Rubicam in New York, where she became a vice president, Ms. Gunnill was captivated by the idea of bringing capitalism to Russia. She tried to get her agency to send her. She learned that the Peace Corps would start up here, and she applied.
"I felt I was living too well in New York, that my world was trivial," she says. "I didn't really need three closets full of clothes. There's an element of spiritual development to it all, no question." She had started as a secretary, later attended Harvard University, and then worked her way up.
"I didn't get all these credentials to serve no one but myself," she says. "And advertising is the leading edge of the capitalist economy."
Ms. Gunnill and the Peace Corps helped set up the Saratov Center for Business Development and found financing for it. The center opened in May and is run by a young Russian she discovered in the local bureaucracy. It already has 75 clients.
She has organized courses in business English, which she is helping turn into a profit center for Mrs. Dmitriyeva's university; trained local advertising agencies in market research and focus groups, and started a consulting group with 10 young economics graduates. She has also organized a women's business club; given advertising lectures up and down the Volga for thousands of people, and helped many Russians receive grants for visits and education in America. She is also coming to terms with her disease.
Three months after being sworn in for a two-year term, Ms. Gunnill was in Warsaw and began to lose her sight. "On the train back," she says, "I just got more and more blind."
In Saratov, they brought her to the head of the Ophthalmological Institute, who urged her to return to America. The Peace Corps immediately brought her to Washington, where her disease was diagnosed. The Peace Corps was reluctant to send her back to provincial Russia.
"It's a late onset, so it's a crap shoot," Ms. Gunnill says. "There's no treatment early on. I had to convince people that I could be not treated as well in Russia as in America."
The Peace Corps sent her back. "If there's trouble," she says, defiantly, "I can work with just one eye. I always said that."
When she returned, she found that Mrs. Dmitriyeva had done research on multiple sclerosis. She made sure Ms. Gunnill had a room of her own and tried to minimize the stress. Finally, in January, Ms. Gunnill took a small apartment nearby.
She threw herself into learning all about her disease. She uses the multiple sclerosis chapter to teach Russians about self-help organizations.
But multiple sclerosis is unforgiving. The Merck Manual of Diagnosis and Therapy says it is a chronic, slowly progressive disease of the central nervous system, cause unknown.
Fatigue and overwork, one of Ms. Gunnill's defining traits, should be avoided. Prognosis is not happy, with an average life expectancy of 10 to 15 years after diagnosis. But the course of the disease is variable, with remissions up to 25 years.
MS. GUNNILL knows all this. And she has had reminders. "One eye went out, but came back again," she says. "And my hands went out once. My hands turned into books. I had no sense of touch, and on the computer, the 'e's' would go across the screen. I couldn't turn pages very easily."
She stops, then typically breaks any hint of self-pity with an anecdote: "The Russians brought me to a neurologists' convention once, but they were disappointed in me -- I wasn't sick enough for them!"
Ms. Gunnill would much rather talk about her work with "the wonderful young Russians who will transform this country." In her lectures, she describes how business works in America, how marketing helps product development. To her embarrassment, Ms. Gunnill speaks poor Russian, but somehow she gets her points across.
SHE explains the success of Frank Perdue, who put his stamp on the lowly chicken by guaranteeing freshness and giving consumers what they want. "He even feeds his chickens special marigold petals to improve their color, because consumers said they prefer golden-colored chickens," she tells rapt Russians. "We all eat Frank Perdue chickens, and Frank Perdue is a very rich man."
These kinds of lectures stir debate among Russians, especially along the conservative Volga. "There are people who don't want us here, who don't want Americans here, or small businesses, or the market itself," Ms. Gunnill acknowledges.
Ms. Gunnill was born in Pittsburgh to a mother born in Bulgaria. She went to Northfield School, now the Northfield Mount Hermon School, and then Connecticut College, both on scholarships. "I graduated knowing at least I didn't want to be an executive wife," she says.
The Peace Corps in Russia "lets me be the sort of person I thought I was -- another step to the person I am," she says. She continues: "I could get a debilitating disease like multiple sclerosis, and I knew what Margaret Bourke-White would have done -- go back to Russia.""
Mrs. Dmitriyeva's daughter, Katya, now attends Allegheny College in Meadville, Pa., not far from where Kristina's mother, who's over 80, lives. "There's a daughter swap going on here," Ms. Gunnill says. "My mother wasn't inclined to be too happy about me staying on in Russia. She remembers when I ran away with the balloon man."
With Vera and her clients, Ms. Gunnill has found both a family and a cause. Katya has joked: "She's Kristianizing us." But Kristina Gunnill has also been Russified a little, wrapped in the large, soft arms of provincial affection.
She and five other volunteers in Saratov have already signed up for a third year. "I was supposed to be out of here next February, but I just can't go," she says fervently. "I've got people I'm training; I've got an M.S. society formed here, and I just can't leave all that. Right now I'm playing everything by ear, but this feels like a lifelong commitment."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Owners Offer Players a Deal That Will Exclude a Payroll Tax

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Slowly and surely, the National Hockey League dispute is nearing a possible conclusion. People with knowledge of last week's collective bargaining negotiations confirmed tonight that the team owners have offered the players a deal that doesn't include a payroll tax.
It is the tax, which the players call a salary cap in disguise, that has been the deal breaker thus far in keeping the players locked out and postponing the start of the season for 81 days, as of today. The league also has offered the Players Association a deal that includes a salary tax, but the player representatives from the 26 teams emphatically rejected that approach tonight when they met at a lakefront hotel. 
 "There won't be a deal with a tax in it," said Adam Graves of the Rangers, when he emerged from tonight's three-hour session. "I imagine that talks will continue, but not in a vein with a tax included. The basis of a deal is in place for the most part. We've moved in the middle ground to get something done. This is very, very complex."
Tonight's meeting set the stage for a general membership meeting here on Wednesday that is expected to draw at least 200 players. No one in the union would speak about details of the eventual compromise, but it is expected that the players will give further ground on arbitration procedures, which many owners have said is a primary cause of the salary inflation they are seeking to control.
No formal negotiations are scheduled, although they could resume soon. Full bargaining broke off Dec. 6 when Commissioner Gary Bettman re-introduced the concept of a payroll tax, which he called a "contribution." But last week, during subcommittee meetings attended by two persons from each side, both sides explored solutions that didn't include a tax.
The players already have agreed, tentatively, to major concessions on an entry-level salary cap and reductions in arbitration and free agency for young players. The owners have offered increased free-agency privileges for veterans.
Mark Messier, Graves's Ranger teammate, said "as long as there is a tax on the table, there won't be a season." Bob Goodenow, executive director of the union, said Bettman and the owners should accept the players' stance and bargain accordingly.
"The sooner they understand that, the better off the process will be," he said of the rejection of the tax.
During the lockout, Bettman has insisted that a tax is not a salary cap. One owner who doesn't buy his semantics is Mike Ilitch of the Detroit Red Wings.
"Why not just come right out and say 'cap' now?" Ilitch said. "I mean, it's a cap. That's what we're after here. They're using other fancy terms, but that's what it boils down to."
Ilitch, who owns one of the league's oldest, strongest and highest-valued franchises, made his comments earlier this week on a Detroit radio station after being asked if the owners had miscalculated the resolve of the union when they ordered the lockout on Oct. 1.
"I guess we did miscalculate from the standpoint of how serious the players were," Ilitch said. "And I think they misjudged how serious the owners were."
No formal deadline for cancellation of the season has been announced, although the Board of Governors last week gave Bettman power to cancel the season if it is impossible to play a 50-game schedule and a full slate of playoffs before July 1.
Dave Gagner, the player representative of the Dallas Stars, said the struggle was "in the final stages" and that the players were strong in their resolve because "the sport we play teaches us to be a little more durable than the average person."
Last week, Stephane Richer of the Devils said he thought most players would vote to go back to work if they took a secret ballot. Gagner and several players tonight disputed that and said a vote would be taken by the membership only if the bargaining committee decided to submit a proposal to the membership, through the chain of command that includes the player representatives.
On the management side, all owners haven't been solidly for Bettman's tax plan or for the lockout for several weeks. Ed Snider of Philadelphia has suggested frequently that further cutbacks in arbitration rights might achieve the desired "drag" on salaries. Bill Wirtz of Chicago said late last month that the league needed a deal by Dec. 1. Howard Baldwin of Pittsburgh said the games had to resume before the Christmas holidays. Joseph Cohen of Los Angeles said a tax was "the last thing we should be talking about."
But the hawks seem to dominate the agenda on both sides, going into the crucial crunch weeks. Should the season be canceled, many N.H.L. players would probably seek work in the International Hockey League, a high minor league operating in major cities across the United States.
Earlier this month, after a second N.H.L. player signed with an I.H.L. team, I.H.L. Commissioner Bob Ufer banned further signings. He said at the time that the ban was temporary, so that voting on the I.H.L.'s collective bargaining agreement wouldn't be jeopardized.
That agreement has been ratified by both sides, but the ban continues, on a day-to-day basis, despite dozens of job applicants from the N.H.L. Why?
"I'm not going to, willy-nilly, allow the job security of our players to be jeopardized," Ufer said. "I'm having a conference call with the Board of Governors tomorrow. We'll probably discuss that."
Ufer said the union representing I.H.L. players has told him that it appreciates his concerns for their jobs but that it also recognizes that players from anywhere have the right to compete for jobs in a free market.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
NO one ventures too far into wine lore before hearing someone say: "Of course it's good. It's a first growth." Or, "It's only a fifth growth, but it should be at least a second."
The references are to the Bordeaux Classification of 1855, a list rating what were then considered to be the best wine properties of that renowned viticultural region. "Growth" is an inadequate English translation of the French word "cru," which refers to a vineyard. 
 Serious social and economic movements often base their legitimacy and their purpose on some seminal document like the Bible, Magna Carta or the Declaration of Independence. The same, on a smaller stage, is true of the 1855 Classification.
Drawn up in haste almost 140 years ago, it continues to wield considerable influence over the international wine trade. In Tokyo, New York and London, when wine merchants or their clients talk of Bordeaux, they inevitably refer to the 1855 Classification.
Before there were World's Fairs, there were Universal Exhibitions, the first of which was held in London in 1851. Eager to assert his lofty title, the newly proclaimed Emperor of France, Napoleon III, announced that an even bigger exposition would be held in Paris in 1855.
The commissioners of the Paris show decided to include an exhibition of Bordeaux wines. They asked the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce to pick the best wines of the region. The chamber turned the job over to the courtiers, a group of brokers who, to this day, act as middlemen between the chateau owners and the shippers who buy the wine from the chateaus and sell it around the world.
The courtiers selected some 60 chateaus from Bordeaux's 3,000 or so red-wine producing properties. They divided them into five groups: first, second, third, fourth and fifth growths, with first considered the best. With only minor exceptions, the list has not changed since the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce sent it off to the exposition commissioners in Paris on April 18, 1855.
Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, which had been bought by the Rothschild family in 1855, was known even then as a great vineyard, but the courtiers weren't sure how it would fare in the hands of the new owners. It finally got first-growth status in 1973, by Presidential decree.
There have been a few other changes as well. Chateau Dubignon, a third growth in 1855, went out of business and disappeared from the list. Chateau Desmirail disappeared in 1938 and was re-established in 1981. The single Chateau Leoville in 1855 became three: Leoville-Barton, Leoville-Las Cazes and Leoville-Poyferre.
The original list was based entirely on wines of the Medoc, an area north of the city of Bordeaux, with one exception: Chateau Haut-Brion, which is in Graves, west of the city. The famous areas to the east, St.-Emilion and Pomerol, home to chateaus like Cheval Blanc, Ausone and Petrus, were ignored.
There have been attempts to revise what is obviously an incomplete if not unfair list. In the 1950's, the owners of the classified chateaus established a committee to work on a revision. The committee proposed 19 demotions and the elevation of a dozen hitherto unclassified chateaus to classified rank.
The uproar was such that the project was abandoned. Another semi-official revision was proposed in 1970; it, too, came to naught. Alexis Lichine, the author, chateau owner and wine merchant, championed his own revision for more than 20 years with little effect. Hardly a wine writer or Bordeaux expert has been able to resist the temptation to produce his or her own version. In "Grands Vins," a book on Bordeaux to be published early next year, the English writer and onetime wine merchant Clive Coates offers some insights on the 1855 ranking and, inevitably, produces a version of his own.
It is wrong, Mr. Coates contends, to assume that the St.-Emilion and Pomerol properties were ignored. They simply were not considered to be up to classified growth standards, he believes.
Unfortunately, everyone took the list too seriously, Mr. Coates says. "There was certainly no intention that the 1855 Classification should be permanent," he writes in Wine & Spirits, a trade publication. Its framers, he says, probably had no idea "what a momentous object they had created." And since then, he goes on, "nobody, official or otherwise, has had the legal or political authority nor the will" to replace it.
There is another approach. Perhaps we could just forget the classification. At the top of the list are the five first growths, Haut-Brion, Latour, Margaux, Lafite-Rothschild and Mouton-Rothschild. It is no longer the case, but there have been times when at least three of them -- Haut-Brion, Margaux and Lafite -- produced wines unworthy of first-growth standing.
Ausone, Cheval-Blanc and Petrus, easily the peers of the top five, go their own ways, unlisted but revered by connoisseurs.
Then there are the chateaus lower down the list that consistently rival the first growths: Leoville-Las Cazes, Pichon-Lalande, La Mission-Haut-Brion, Figeac and Lynch-Bages among them. Lynch-Bages is a fifth growth.
Quality promotes demand, and demand increases prices. And none of them have much to do with any classification, be it from 1855 or 1994.
 
TASTINGS
Buena Vista Chardonnay, Carneros, Calif., 1992. About $10.
 
Buena Vista, the largest estate in the Carneros region of Napa and Sonoma counties of California, sells this chardonnay at a reasonable price. This wine has classic Carneros contours, rich and full with good acidity but eminently easy to drink, thanks to the second, or malolactic fermentation for some of the wine. Beginning with the 1992 vintage, Buena Vista put nearly 30 percent of this wine through the second fermentation and then aged the wine with its yeast for five months to achieve the extra concentration. And the wine fermented in the barrel increased from 10 percent in 1991 to 35 percent in this vintage. Oak lovers, who seem to comprise 90 percent of American wine drinkers, should be pleased.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Smaller May Be Better in Talks

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
More than two months ago, the Dodgers' Brett Butler proved to be a sound student of the history of baseball labor negotiations when he made the following observation: When negotiating teams are reduced to the smallest common denominators, deals are made.
It was an important lesson to review on this, the second-to-last day before baseball owners are scheduled to declare an impasse in the four-month-old strike and impose a salary cap. Because, in keeping with labor history, there does seem to be some downsizing of negotiating teams and a recalibration of the bargaining process. 
 Both could prove to be even more important than the substantive issues on the table or the owners' deadline, whose urgency seems to be lost in the eerily quiet atmosphere surrounding talks in the Capital Hilton and nearby offices of management lawyers and union economists.
Change for more than change's sake proved to be important in 1981. That's when Lee MacPhail, then president of the American League, stepped into a war zone, replacing Ray Grebey, the owners' hawkish chief negotiator, whom the players and union rigorously battled during most of the 50-day in-season strike.
MacPhail and Marvin Miller, the head of the union, were then able to sit down and work out a settlement. MacPhail was an integral factor in the agreement, as was the expiration of the owners' Lloyd's of London strike-insurance policy.
In 1985, another strike hit, and owners and even a commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, moved in and out of the negotiations. But in the end it was MacPhail who again wound up going one on one with a union chief, this time Don Fehr. And the two worked out an end to a three-day in-season strike, one of the least painful work stoppages in the history of the sport.
In 1990, another one on one was needed, this time during a spring- training lockout. Again, it produced results. Fehr and the deputy commissioner then, Steve Greenberg, locked themselves in a room to have a go at the logjam over salary arbitration eligibility. About 12 hours later they emerged, with a 17 percent solution involving the disputed class of players with two or more years of eligibility. And, oh, yes, they had with them the bridge to a new basic agreement as well.
Now, in 1994, all of baseball waits to see if history is somehow repeating itself, as one owner, Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies, prepares to take the lead role for management.
Many of the old patterns have already played out. Richard Ravitch started out as the owners' lead negotiator, only to be moved aside and ultimately resign.
Ravitch was replaced by Boston's John Harrington at the beginning of the month. Now, according to Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, the Red Sox's chief operating officer has been left exhausted by the negotiating sessions that have meandered up and down the East Coast corridor since mid-October.
Harrington has yet to come here. McMorris arrived yesterday, and the significance has been lost on few as the belief grows that he is the man now empowered to do a deal. "Jerry's coming in," one union lawyer said. "We'll have to see what happens after that."
"There are solutions to these problems," McMorris said upon arriving at negotiations central at the Capital Hilton. "You have to take each piece in the context of the way it was presented. There will be compromises reached and there will be give and take on given parts. That's how I hope we're going to find a deal."
Now what remains to be seen is if McMorris's wishes can become his reality. Remember, the union doesn't give credence to deadlines, but the owners say they are there nonetheless. So their clock is ticking and adding what they say is urgency to negotiations that have had their share of fits and starts ever since the players struck on Aug. 12.
So, all that was truly certain yesterday was that the first full negotiations could resume with McMorris more involved than ever. What was not certain was just what his presence meant in terms of the owners' approach -- that is, whether it's old, new, altered or indifferent. Or how the union will respond to yet another management change at the point.
While all sides waited to see the effect of McMorris's presence, they busied themselves dissecting the process. And why not, when the talks one assumes both need to succeed could once again be derailed by miscommunications or a system failure.
Seeking the best possible process is worth the effort. That will go doubly if the process produces the right combination of bodies, whether it be 2, 4 or 40.
For what Butler said Sept. 9 still goes. "That's where the real negotiations are going to take place -- in a small room, not in a big room," the player said. "Things happen in small rooms."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Fehr, leader of players' union, arriving for talks in Washington as the club owners' deadline for imposing a salary cap grew nearer. (Reuters)

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 2; Editorial Desk
