HEADLINE: CLINTON & CONGRESS;
How Not to Fix Public Broadcasting

BYLINE: By Leonard Garment; Leonard Garment, who was counsel to President Richard Nixon, is completing a memoir, which is scheduled for publication next year.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich, the next Speaker of the House, intends to change public broadcasting. This is good. There are things about it that need changing. Representative Gingrich has announced that he will do the job by eliminating Federal funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which is getting $285.6 million in tax money in the current fiscal year and distributes 90 percent of it to about 1,000 public television and stations and groups.
I think he will eventually conclude that this is not the way to get the change he wants. 
 Two things about public broadcasting bother many Americans, not just conservatives. First, Government should not be in broadcasting unless it provides necessary services that the market does not deliver. Second, some public programming, especially from National Public Radio and a number of big-city stations, reveals instances of bias -- mostly, but not exclusively, a liberal bias in covering social problems. Usually these are such hot-button issues as crime, religion, race and abortion. Zeroing out the Corporation for Public Broadcasting would solve neither problem.
As for economics, most public broadcasting originates not in big cities but in smaller communities. Most stations are less like New York's or Chicago's than they are like WVMR, a radio station in Dunsmore, W.Va., that offers local programming that no commercial station would consider: lost-dog ads, funeral announcements, school closings, junior high sports broadcasts. Other stations feature high school equivalency and literacy programs and other educational courses, public-health services and computer networking.
The small stations depend more on the Federal stipends they receive than do the larger ones. The overall Federal contribution to stations' budgets ranges from 4 to 40 percent, but generally the smaller the station, the bigger the subsidy. Thus, small stations are the most likely to be killed by the disappearance of Federal financing.
Public broadcasting does what the market does not in another important way. It provides superior cultural and children's programs free. There is lots of talk about how commercial television can do these things, but it is mostly talk. In its feature-length morning and late-afternoon news programs, listeners to public radio get more diverse news, debate and commentary than they can get from the 10-second sound bites of commercial radio.
So far, commercial TV has proved less willing than the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to take the risks entailed in developing ambitious programs, and it does not provide the depth of good children's TV that public broadcasting does.
The nation's well-being depends on a certain level of literacy and common culture in the population -- something Mr. Gingrich understands quite well. Both those "commodities" are in scarce supply. When the Government makes its small contribution to public broadcasting, these are the social benefits it provides; the cost is not irrational or disproportionate.
The second problem with public broadcasting is bias -- programming that does not disseminate a common culture but imposes a partisan attitude. This bias is not frequent and tends to occur in the programming of the bigger public broadcasting stations, which receive perhaps 5 percent of their budgets from the Government. These are the stations best able to survive and continue their activities even if their Federal contributions drop to zero.
Cutting off financing to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting would not address the problem of bias. The opposite is true. Because big stations as well as small ones get public money, all are accountable to public authorities. This accountability makes a difference. In 1992, Congress passed a law requiring national public programming to be balanced and fair. There have been problems carrying out this bland generalization, but there has also been some improvement.
The money we give public broadcasting helps insure its accountability. Remove Federal funds and you remove officials' ability to influence the system. Such withdrawal would be irresponsible, and I do not think it is what Mr. Gingrich wants. There is an argument for transferring more responsibility from the big urban stations to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to make programming more truly national and better able to serve its legitimate unifying purposes.
If Mr. Gingrich spares the corporation, he need not give up on changing public broadcasting. He can keep the budget tight. He can re-examine the way the money is distributed. He can yell bloody murder at what he finds offensive. In short, he can exercise continuous leadership, which in the end is the only thing to which public broadcasting -- or any other enterprise -- responds.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Cubans Welcome Envoys of Capitalism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was happy to read "The U.S. and Cuba: Double Fantasy" (editorial, Dec. 14), but disappointed at how soft it was on United States policy. Yes, there is rhetorical posturing on both sides. But all the rhetoric in the world will not stop a needy people enticed by the possibility of economic growth from embracing capitalism if it is available to them. 
 I got back three days ago from Havana, where as a film director I visited the Latin American Film Festival. I went to Cuba with my father. He and the Association of American Publishers are planning a book show there next March. Bolstered by the State Department's encouragement of cultural trade between the countries, Americans too now have the chance to sell books there on the open market.
In meetings with Cuban publishers, I saw what "socialists" might be like in trade agreements with "imperialist" capitalists. These were people excited about free trade's possibilities. On one side, there were the Cubans with a chance to sell books to their own population, which is 90 percent literate; and on the other, the Americans with a chance to exploit a huge, previously closed market.
From their sales projections, it was clear that if the embargo were lifted and one could exchange dollars for pesos, no rhetoric would stop the dollar from igniting an economic fire for these people, who have exquisite minds and gentle humors, but suffer from having no economy to speak of. With no gasoline, no paper, little food, no soap, only free trade with a dollar market will help them.
If we are so sure of our economic system, why not risk hearing a little "socialist" rhetoric while allowing some "imperialism" to seep in?
Until we do, the saddest thing is that Cuba's malnourished children will continue to starve, its architecture will crumble, and our embargo will fuel Fidel Castro's rhetoric. Then we'll only have ourselves to blame.
 
DAN ALGRANT
New York, Dec. 16, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE SUBWAY FIREBOMB: THE SUSPECT;
From Burns and Tatters, a Bombing Suspect

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
The man in the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn was hurting.
His sneakers and the legs of his blue jeans were singed and shredded, his legs bloody below the knees, Police Officer Michael Ruiz remembered later. There were burns on his arm, some of the skin on his face was peeling away, and through the tatters of his gloves there were burn marks on his knuckles. 
 The two encountered each other about 10 minutes after 2 P.M. yesterday -- about a half-hour after a burst of flame in a crowded No. 4 train injured 41 people as the subway pulled into the Fulton Street station in the Manhattan financial district. Officer Ruiz and his partner in the 84th Precinct, Officer Anthony Roa, were answering a radio call for aid at the subway station in Brooklyn.
"I'm in pain," the man said, staggering near the token booth. They put him in an ambulance, although Officer Ruiz recalled that "it seemed a little odd how he got all the way into Brooklyn."
Then, as they sped toward the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, a description came over their radios of a suspect in the subway firebombing. They looked at the man riding with them: a white man, around 200 pounds, between 40 and 50, burgundy sweater, dark blue three-quarter-length coat, blue jeans torn below the knees, burn marks.
The two officers looked at each other. "Wait a minute," Officer Ruiz said. "That sounds like the guy that we have."
Less than an hour after the explosion, the police said, the man, identified as Edward Leary, 49, an unemployed computer technician from Scotch Plains, N.J., was the target of the investigation not only of yesterday's explosion but also of a similar incident last week. In that first incident, a teen-age girl's backpack suddenly caught fire on a subway train in Harlem, injuring and badly burning a 13-year-old boy, whose clothes had caught fire.
The main link between the two cases, the police said, were similarities in the construction of the incendiary devices that started both subway fires: each consisted of a glass jar about the size of a mayonnaise jar, filled with gasoline or another flammable liquid. Both had two wires leading from the liquid to a battery and a crude timer.
The police's Chief of Department, John Timoney, said the remains of the firebomb were being scrutinized by the police bomb squad and would be examined by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which already has the remains of the first device. After questioning the two teen-agers burned in the Harlem case, the police said they concluded that the two had nothing to do with the device.
Mr. Leary, who was believed to have last worked for Merrill Lynch, lived at 63 Glenside Avenue in Scotch Plains and had co-op apartments at 10 Plaza Street in Brooklyn, a solid-looking brick building with a doorman facing Grand Army Plaza and Prospect Park.
"We did have an Edward Leary who worked for us," said Bobbie Collins, a Merrill Lynch spokeswoman. "We don't know if it was the same person. He worked in our operations department. He was terminated." Ms. Collins said the man last worked there in January 1994.
At the two-story white frame house in Scotch Plains, decorated with strings of blinking white Christmas lights, a neighbor said Mr. Leary had moved there from Brooklyn about a year ago, with his wife, Marge, a nurse-practitioner, and their son, around 12 years old. The neighbor, who would not give her name, said it appeared that Mr. Leary had been unemployed for the last few months.
Detectives who were parked in the driveway had seen gasoline canisters in the garage and a search warrant was being sought last night, said a law-enforcement official who asked for anonymity.
At the co-op building where Mr. Leary had lived in Park Slope, Brooklyn, he had left more distinct impressions. He was once president of the co-op board, a period recalled by one resident as one of "incredibly nasty politics" over running the building.
"Ed was weird," said David Elrich, who served on the board with him and who now lives elsewhere. "He was always involved in computers. He's your classic computer person, great with machines, not so good with people."
At one point, Mr. Elrich recalled, the infighting over the question of spending money to decorate the co-op building grew very emotional. One day, a mysterious fire erupted outside the apartment of the leader of the pro-spending faction, who opposed Mr. Leary's efforts to keep down maintenance costs. Law-enforcement officials said that after hearing tenants recall that incident last night, they were investigating whether Mr. Leary might be connected to it.
After he moved to New Jersey, Mr. Leary still kept the three apartments he owned in the Brooklyn co-op, Mr. Elrich said. One woman who rented one of the co-ops, Jeannette Goldstein, said she was involved in a long-running dispute over repairs she said were needed to the apartment, and produced a sheaf of documents and letters that she had sent to city officials.
"This man is driving me crazy," she said. "I'm on the phone all day long. He would not fix the apartment."
Mr. Leary had advertised one of the apartments in The New York Times on Sunday for $164,000. Last night, no one answered the family's New Jersey's phone number, which was listed in the ad.

HEADLINE: Judge Approves Plan for Logging In Forests Where Rare Owls Live

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
A Federal judge today approved the Clinton Administration's much-disputed plan for logging in the Pacific Northwest forest that is home to the spotted owl and other imperiled species.
The policy, approved by Judge William L. Dwyer of the District Court in Seattle, would let the timber industry cut up to one billion feet of lumber each year in the ancient forests of Washington, Oregon and northern California -- less than one-fifth of the harvest during the 1980's. 
 In deciding one of the most hotly contested environmental issues in recent years, Judge Dwyer, the same judge who had first halted logging in 1991 to protect the endangered spotted owl, turned aside objections to the Administration's plans from both the timber industry and environmentalists.
He ruled three years ago that the Bush Administration was breaking Federal laws by allowing so much logging on public lands that the owl might become extinct and told the Government that it must come up with an environmental plan for the region before he would allow logging to resume.
Although either side might appeal today's ruling, Judge Dwyer's 70-page opinion, which addressed every substantive objection raised so far by environmentalists and the timber industry, left little room for legal challenge, legal experts say.
The Clinton Administration began to carry out its plan in June, starting some restoration work and selling some 60 million board feet of timber, but the influence on the region's economy has been modest so far. In the background, it was clear that the plan was subject to a rejection by the judge who had strictly controlled every step the Government had taken in the owl's habitat.
Judge Dwyer's ruling was seen as a victory for the Administration and its twin policies for handling disputes over natural resources: to seek a balance between development and conservation and to defend its decisions on the basis of scientific judgments about the workings of entire ecosystems, rather than on the state of individual species.
The Forest Service expects to allow the timber industry to cut about 300 million board feet of lumber from public lands within the owl's range next year, said Jim Lyons, the assistant Agriculture Secretary in charge of forestry. He added that it might take three years for logging to reach the level envisioned in the plan because of the time needed to do scientific studies, arrange timber auctions and hire loggers.
Administration officials said the plan also called for new projects like repairing damaged forests and streams, which would provide jobs without increasing logging, as well as other economic aid for the region.
The Administration said its plan would protect not just the old-growth trees and the spotted owl, but hundreds of other species, like salmon, whose endangered status could otherwise be used as easily as the owl's to stop the logging.
The Administration spent more than a year consulting with environmental groups, timber interests, state and local officials, economists and scientists. But the industry objected to the big cuts in its logging quota, and conservationists opposed it because they said it would not protect the last of the region's ancient forests.
Although Judge Dwyer approved the plan today, his ruling made plain that he had lingering doubts about whether it would work.
"The question is not whether the court would write the same plan, but whether the agencies have acted within the bounds of the law," he wrote.
Judge Dwyer said any more logging sales than the plan contemplates would probably violate environmental laws. And he said that the Government must carefully monitor owl populations in the future.
"New information may require that timber sales be ended or curtailed," he cautioned.
Both environmentalists and the timber industry said that they might appeal the decision, but the likelihood of overturning it that way seems remote.
No judge in the country is more familiar with the case than Judge Dwyer, whose past rulings on the issue have withstood appeals, and in the end, as judges often do, he gave the Administration the benefit of the doubt on the disputed scientific merits of the plan.
But that does not mean that the issue of logging in the region has been put to rest, or that the owl and other imperiled species that the Administration's plan tries to protect will survive.
For one thing, the ascendancy of Republicans in Congress strengthens the timber industry's hand in trying to rewrite the basic laws on which his decision rested.
"The only place that a fair balance can be struck is in Congress," said Mark Rey, vice president of the American Forest Products Association.
It remains unclear whether Congress will approve all the spending for restoration projects that the plan calls for, nor is there any accurate way of estimating how much money the timber sales will bring in.
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said the decision vindicated this Administration's efforts to comply with the law and was important new evidence that laws like the the Endangered Species Act could protect both ecosystems and the economy.
The Administration and environmental groups argued that the reductions in logging had not crushed the region's economy, as the timber industry and its Congressional allies had predicted.
"Unemployment for the entire region is at its lowest level in years, millions of dollars have been distributed to more than 100 communities for economic revitalization," said a written statement issued by the White House.
Since it first came to office, the Administration has cited its approach to the forest issue as a model for how it wanted to handle conflicts between development and conservation. President Clinton personally led a public summit meeting of the warring parties in 1991 in an attempt to resolve the differences.
But even though the Administration's plan for managing the forest went a long way toward protecting the owl's habitat, environmental groups have never been wholly satisfied with it.
They complained that the resumption in logging would continue to cut the kind of woods that provides suitable home for the owl into smaller and smaller fragments, and that the regrowth of forests over the next several decades would come too late to help the imperiled species re-establish itself.
They also said that many fish populations are likely to be eliminated as the logging resumes, because of the damage to streams that logging and road-building can cause. They called the plan's measures to protect fish experimental and unproven.
The union representing forest workers today excoriated Judge Dwyers's decision, calling the Administration's plan a "proven failure" because almost no timber was harvested in the 15 months since the plan was first announced. Even though the plan was subject to the judge's approval, the Administration was legally allowed to begin carrying out some provisions during the court's review.
Echoing the industry's view, the union called on Congress to write "a truly balanced, comprehensive forest management plan."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Banks, Time of Reckoning

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
High-rolling hedge fund managers like George Soros were the first to disclose that they lost money in the plunging bond market this year. Then came Piper Jaffray and some others that run mutual funds. More recently, several municipalities, most notably Orange County, Calif., confessed to substantial losses from risky interest rate bets gone bad.
Now it's the banks' turn to come clean. 
 Some big banks like the PNC Bank Corporation, Keycorp, and Banc One have already said that they will be hurt because of problems in their investment portfolios. But banking experts say there are many more that compiled similar losses but have not been as forthcoming. Yet.
Analysts find it difficult to say exactly which banks have been hardest hit. That's because banks provide only limited disclosure about the effects of changes in interest rates on their balance sheets. Indeed, the reason that banking losses are just starting to trickle out now -- rather than in the spring when the problems at mutual funds first emerged -- is not because the losses are newer. Instead, it is because accounting rules make it easier for banks to hide their mistakes.
For buyers of banking shares, the silver lining is that the expectation of this bad news has already depressed prices indiscriminately across the board. Analysts say there is an opportunity to buy undervalued banks that have not been hurt, or may even benefit, from rising interest rates.
Analysts expect many banks to face up to their losses by the end of the year or shortly thereafter. They would do so by selling losing investments to concentrate the pain in one quarterly reduction in earnings. Some likely candidates, analysts said, include the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis and Huntington Bancshares of Columbus, Ohio.
Other banks -- including Shawmut National of Boston, Central Fidelity of Richmond and Integra Financial of Pittsburgh -- will probably not take big one-time write-offs. Instead, they may simply suffer through the next few years with depressed earnings because their bond investments pay interest rates that are below market.
And the problems could get worse before they get better.
"If we see another increase in rates, we will see some more banks start to hemorrhage," said Thomas Hanley, a bank stock analyst with CS First Boston.
The interest rate losses are mainly concentrated among regional and local banks, which turned to investments in bonds when the drop in loan demand in the late 1980's and early 1990's cut deeply into earnings. Many banks borrowed at low short-term rates to pour money into higher- yielding longer-term bonds that appeared to offer safe returns with little effort.
"It's like putting a bowl of candy in front of a child," said Frank DeSantis, a bank stock analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It was there for the taking."
From September to November, bank stocks in the Keefe, Bruyette & Woods index fell 12 percent, mainly on interest rate fears. They are up 1 percent this month.
Among banks that analysts say may be undervalued is First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, which gains ground from interest rate increases because an unusually high percentage of its depositors' money is in checking accounts that do not pay interest. Thus, when market rates rise, its interest costs do not rise as fast as other banks'.
The big New York banks, such as Citibank and Chase Manhattan, also do not face sharp losses from higher interest rates, largely because their investments are more diversified.
Even with the sketchy information that has been disclosed so far, it's clear that many banks with paper profits on their bond investments at the end of last year now have positions that are deeply in the red.
A study by Morgan Stanley, which includes information not disclosed in bank statements, shows that as of Sept. 30, the value of the $217 billion of bonds in the portfolios of 24 big regional banks had declined $5.4 billion. But the banks have not yet reflected those losses in their earnings. Moreover, interest rates have risen considerably since then.
Among those banks, at least 20 also face another $3.5 billion in losses from dealings in derivatives. (The rest of the banks in the study did not report on the value of their derivatives.) Derivatives are contracts that have values linked to some underlying asset, most commonly interest rates. Banks use them both to hedge their risk from rate moves and as a more speculative form of investment.
These problems are coming at what is already expected to be harder times for banks. Profit growth in the last few years had been brisk. But that was largely because the industry was recovering from a bout with bad real estate loans that sharply depressed earnings and came close to toppling some banking titans. Banks face the prospect of lower earnings next year in a business with excess capacity and cutthroat competition.
No one expects any big banks to be pushed close to the brink of collapse. That's because the banking industry has more capital than it had in the past to cushion it from financial blows. Banks have been doing a better job of managing their balance sheets than a decade ago, when First Pennsylvania Bank of Philadelphia and First Bank System in Minneapolis were crippled by enormously wrong-headed bets on interest rates.
Still, the fact that the bank losses have taken so long to show up highlights the gamble individual investors take by investing in banks. At the root of the problem are the notoriously opaque financial statements issued by most banks.
For most of the last decade, investors struggled to determine which banks were vulnerable to losses on loans to oil drillers, third world countries, leveraged buyout artists and real estate tycoons. They got little or no help from the banks themselves. Instead, as these problems first emerged, bank executives said they knew what they were doing and had the situation under control.
Some of them were right. But others were wrong, and often lost their jobs. They certainly lost a lot of money for their shareholders.
Banks show most of their bond investments on their balance sheet at the prices they paid for them, not their current market value. They only report a gain or a loss if they sell the bond before it matures.
In recent years, accountants have tried to help investors by forcing banks to disclose the unrealized losses in footnotes to the financial statements. In some cases, they have been required to deduct the losses from book value. But for the ordinary investor, the limited disclosure has not made the picture much clearer.
Accounting for derivatives is even murkier, largely because the instruments are new and the rules have not caught up with the innovation. Derivative transactions do not show up on the companies' balance sheets at all. Banks have been putting more information on their derivatives holdings in footnotes, but disclosure is inconsistent.


GRAPHIC: Many banks have bond and derivative portfolios that have eroded significantly in value, thanks to rising interest rates. The banks face an unpalatable choice with most of the securities: Sell them at a loss now and take a charge against earnings, or hold on to them and put up with the the drag on earning from their low returns.

HEADLINE: Mexico Will Float Its Battered Currency

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Mexico's economy was thrown into crisis tonight as the Government abandoned its efforts to defend the peso and announced that it would allow the currency to float against the dollar.
At the least, the move was expected to bring a sharp, immediate further devaluation of the peso, plus a burst of new inflation and major losses for Mexican banks. 
 Stockbrokers and financial-market analysts predicted tonight that the currency could quickly fall by 30 percent or more of its value last week against the dollar, and they warned of a possible run on the banks by Mexicans desperate to change their money.
The Government said tonight that it had arranged to draw on $7 billion in emergency credits from the United States and Canada to try to bring the situation under control.
In a statement released late tonight after emergency meetings among Government, business and labor leaders, the Labor Secretariat announced that prices on goods and services would be frozen for 60 days. It also said that for at least that period, wages would rise no more than the 10 percent agreed upon in September.
The move came after a tumultuous day in which investors panicked at an effective devaluation of nearly 15 percent on Tuesday, driving down the values of Mexican stocks nearly 12 percent before a rally in the afternoon.
The central bank also raised interest rates sharply, but pressure on the peso continued, cutting its value to the bottom of the new exchange range, the level at which the Government had said it would intervene.
All these developments amounted to a debacle for President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon just three weeks after his inauguration, and it left new doubts among investors and economists about the viability of the Government's economic strategy.
"This is a major crisis of confidence in the Mexican Government," said Geoffrey E. J. Dennis, head of Latin American equity research at Bear, Stearns in New York.
This morning, Mexican officials had responded to investors' anger by backing more clearly away from both the exchange-rate policy pursued by former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and the promises of greater public spending and lower interest rates with which Mr. Zedillo won election in August.
Like his predecessor, Mr. Zedillo had expressed confidence that the exchange rate could be sustained despite a projected current-account deficit of more than $30 billion next year, the broadest measure of trade. As recently as last week, the new Finance Minister, Jaime Serra Puche, publicly insisted that a devaluation was not in the offing.
In briefings for investors, officials acknowledged more directly that the volatility in Mexico's financial markets this year have been at least partly the result of fundamental weaknesses in the economy. In addition to adjusting what many analysts had seen as an overvalued exchange-rate band, the officials promised to address the problem by cutting public spending, raising interest rates and scaling back loans to private companies for imports.
Appealing for continued "discipline" from Mexican workers who will now face higher inflation with only a 7 percent wage increase they won in September, Mr. Zedillo said the effective devaluation should favor exports and savings, ushering in "a new stage" of economic growth.
It became more evident that the Government's real mistake had not been so much in allowing the peso's value to drop as far as 15.3 percent, but in the way the devaluation was handled.
Mr. Zedillo, a Yale-trained economist who served as Mr. Salinas's Planning and Budget Minister, had been expected to have a comparatively easy time of managing the economy and reassuring the investors abroad who hold tens of billions of dollars in Mexican securities.
Despite somewhat sluggish growth, pressure for a more equitable distribution of wealth, and cries for help from small business, his greater challenges were expected to be domestic and political.
Yet many foreign investors today were seething that Mr. Serra had ignored them in announcing the peso devaluation to the Mexican news media on Tuesday morning. They also complained that Mr. Zedillo and Mr. Serra seemed to have only their domestic audience in mind when they tried to attribute the exchange-rate pressure primarily to rising tensions in the southern state of Chiapas, where rebels have threatened new fighting.
"You can argue that they needed a devaluation," said Luis R. Luis, an economist and expert on Mexico at Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston. "But they also needed a plan to support the devaluation and to convince investors that this was for the good of the economy in the long term. Now these guys are going to have a tough task of rebuilding confidence, and they don't have much time."
In Chiapas today, the embattled Governor, Eduardo Robledo Rincon, said all the roads blocked had now been cleared and his government was in control of all 38 towns the insurgents said they had infiltrated.
After months of losses, stock values on the Bolsa de Valores, the Mexican exchange, had initially rallied 1.9 percent on Tuesday. But this morning, with Wall Street awash in rumors that the Mexican Government might allow the peso to float freely against the dollar, foreign investors led a selloff that sent the market index down 266 points, or 11.7 percent, from yesterday's close of 2,274.17. The index climbed back up in heavy trading to close at 2,203.67, still a loss of 3.1 percent for the day.
Stocks dropped sharply in some other Latin American countries. In Brazil, the Bovespa index was off 6.33 percent, while the Argentine index fell 5.74 percent. Markets in Chile and Peru were off 1.5 percent and 1.35 percent, respectively.
Mexican interest rates took their biggest leap since April. At a weekly auction, yields on benchmark 28-day treasury bills jumped 225 basis points, to 16 percent. Even then, pressure on the peso eased only a bit.
Under the Tuesday devaluation, the band within which the currency is allowed to trade was widened by 15.3 percent; the Government said it would now buy pesos when the exchange rate reached 4.0016 to the dollar. The peso fell roughly 13 percent against the dollar here on Tuesday and about 2 percent further today, to 3.997 to the dollar, despite reports that the Government was already intervening to support it. In late New York trading, the rate was 3.9870 pesos.
Its limited public relations effort left some investors wondering what had become of the Mexican central bank's president, Miguel Mancera, who remained silent about the measure, and left others nostalgic for Pedro Aspe, Mr. Serra's predecessor as Finance Minister. Under President Salinas, Mr. Aspe won a wide reputation for skillfully anticipating the markets in his presentation of major economic policy decisions.

HEADLINE: Judge Voids Disputed Cuts Of Mayor and Council

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
A state judge yesterday tossed out both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget cuts and a competing set of reductions enacted by the City Council, while sidestepping any ruling on the Council's attempt to test its budgetary powers under the City Charter.
Mr. Giuliani promptly said he would now use his power of impoundment to achieve nearly the full $800 million in spending cuts that he originally proposed. And the Council, while claiming a victory, was left with little leverage to block him. 
 In reaching her decision in State Supreme Court, Justice Fern Fisher-Brandveen did not address the main issue raised by the Council: its contention that the City Charter allows it, in some cases, to modify midyear fiscal actions taken by the Mayor. Instead, she based her decision on a more technical question concerning the City Council's internal rules.
The Justice said her action left in effect the city's original $31.6 billion budget, in which a $1.1 billion budget gap has opened because of falling tax revenue and faulty spending assumptions. She expressed "trust that the City Council and the Mayor can work together to find a solution to the city's current budget dilemma, which is both economically acceptable and palatable to both sides."
But the Mayor said he would proceed on his own. "This gives me the flexibility that we need in order to make the cuts in the budget," Mr. Giuliani said. "I said I would do that in order to preserve a balanced budget, which I have the power to do under the Charter."
Sticking to the same negotiating position that drove the Council to court, he added that while he would consider some programs that the Council wants restored, he would not allow such items to exceed $40 million. "The same deal that was available a month ago is available today," Mr. Giuliani said. "No new deal, no additional money. I will not -- just to get a political result -- imperil a balanced budget."
In a move likely to rile the Council leadership further, Abraham M. Lackman, the Mayor's budget director, said the Mayor would even use his impoundment powers to cut the Council's own operating budget.
Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone criticized the Mayor's tack, saying that impoundment was an emergency power and not one to use as a main tool of governing.
"That's irresponsible, obviously, because you can govern by impounding, but that means you can't fund anything," Mr. Vallone said. "So somewhere along the line I assume the Office of Management and Budget is going to recognize that there are certain things that have to be done in this city as well as things that have to be cut in this city."
When told that the Mayor intended to cut $2.5 million from the Council as well, Mr. Vallone said such a move would violate the separation of powers. "It's kind of clear under the Charter that we do have the right to exist," he said.
While both the Mayor and the Council leadership both said they had achieved a victory in the court decision, it was clear that the Council was left in a weakened position, with little to persuade Mr. Giuliani to consider the Council's own spending priorities.
Aides to Mr. Vallone said their one bargaining chip was that Mr. Giuliani's budget plan not only made spending reductions, but had also shifted money between agencies and included new funds for overtime costs. The aides said that only the spending cuts, and none of the transfers of funds needed to run an orderly government, could be carried out through impoundment.
The dispute between the two branches of government began after Mr. Giuliani announced a $1.1 billion budget gap and submitted to the Council his own menu of budget reductions to close the gap. Traditionally, the Council has been held to have the power only to approve or reject such midyear budget changes unless new revenues are involved.
But unhappy with many of the Mayor's cuts in programs like education, youth programs and emergency food pantries, the Council said it had the right to alter some of his budget cuts because his proposal contained some new revenues. The Council then voted overwhelmingly to block $96.6 million of the Mayor's reductions and replaced them with $96.6 million in alternative cuts.
Mr. Giuliani and his aides called the Council's argument illegal and disingenuous, noting that while tax revenues had increased in some cases, the budget plan overall called for a net drop in revenue of $189 million. He vetoed the Council's budget plan and despite an override said he would not carry it out. For the first time since it was created in 1938, the City Council then took the Mayor to court.
But Justice Fisher-Brandveen did not make any ruling on whether the Council had exceeded its powers under the City Charter's definition of new revenues. Instead she based her ruling on a procedural battle that had occurred on the day the Council had first voted to alter the Mayor's budget plan.
Hours before the Council vote, the Mayor's office had tried to stop the vote by sending a letter to the City Council withdrawing the budget proposal and leaving the lawmakers nothing to vote on. But the Council, citing its own parliamentary rules, countered that the Mayor could not withdraw legislation without three days' notice and went ahead anyway.
But the Judge held yesterday that once the Mayor withdrew his plan, the Council should have refrained from voting. She said her conclusion was not based on an interpretation of City Council rules. "Rather, it is rooted in common sense," she said. She said both the Mayor's cuts and the Council's cuts were void.

HEADLINE: A Cease-Fire Called Winter Settles Over Bosnia

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PALE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Nenad Tadic, a Bosnian Serb soldier, looked up today at the snow falling heavily on the mountains surrounding Sarajevo and said, "The weather would achieve a four-month cease-fire, with or without the politicians."
He was right. With snow falling and the weather bitterly cold, the fighting season is largely over in Bosnia. The cease-fire announced by Jimmy Carter is therefore relatively insignificant unless it can be developed into a real disengagement of forces. 
 Such a disengagement, buffered by United Nations forces, took place earlier this year in central Bosnia, where there had been brutal fighting between Muslims and Croats. But in that instance, under strong American pressure, the rival armies and politicians had decided to end, or at least bury, their differences.
That is far from the case in the war between the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces and the Bosnian Serbs, who are based in Pale, outside Sarajevo. Announcing Mr. Carter's agreement, Sarajevo Radio said it was signed by the Government "and the war criminals in Pale." Conciliation is not yet in the air.
At least not among the politicians of Bosnia. Among the populations on either side there is, however, an immense fatigue that would, if it could ever find political expression, open the door to peace at least a crack. But politics in the Balkans does not seem to work this way.
"The war has destroyed us psychologically," said Milja Gluhovic, a Bosnian Serb in Pale who lost both her husband and brother last May to a single Bosnian shell that landed in their trench in the mountains above Sarajevo. "Everyone wants peace, everyone," she said. "But the prospects are dim."
In Sarajevo, an accountant named Amra who declined to give her last name said: "It is very sad when, after two and a half years, you see there is nothing left. I hate this place. I hate these people. If I can ever get away, I will never come back."
Such weariness, disillusionment and disgust with political maneuvering are now rampant throughout Bosnia. But the grim scheming that has already inflicted 32 months of war on Bosnia continues unabated, and the political posturing seems particularly outlandish because Bosnia is still a country to be invented.
Despite all the words on both sides, the fact remains that Bosnia and Herzegovina has no recent history as an independent state and Muslims, Croats and Serbs disagree totally as to what it is and what it should become. This is still the root of the conflict.
To bolster their cases, both sides cling increasingly to myth. Bosnia, for the Muslim-led Government, has become a "millennial state," despite the fact that since its conquest by the Turks in 1462, it has been governed by the Ottoman empire, the Austro-Hungarian empire, a royalist Yugoslav Government, a puppet pro-Nazi Croatian state, and Yugoslav Communists, but never by its own independent authority.
For the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, Bosnia has become part of a land that was always Serbian, despite the fact that Sarajevo has never been a Serbian city and, even at the height of the Serbian empire in the 14th century, only a small part of Bosnia fell under the rule of the Emperor Dusan. There have been Serbs west of the Drina River for centuries; but the Serbian state always lay to the east.
Beside the myths, there is the fact that Serbs and Muslims have lived alongside each other, often uneasily, for centuries on the piece of land now internationally recognized as Bosnia and Herzegovina. They are condemned to continue doing so. The question is how.
The Bosnian Government of President Alija Izetbegovic, outraged by the Serbs' campaign of terror against Muslims across much of Bosnia, wants to "liberate" the country from Dr. Karadzic and the many Serbs who follow him. If that remains the case, President Izetbegovic will try to use an eventual four-month respite from fighting to continue rearming and building an army that has made immense strides over the past two years.
Despite the successful Serbian onslaught on the western Muslim enclave of Bihac, which continued today with mortar and artillery rounds exploding in the suburbs of Bihac, the Bosnian Army continues to put the Serbs under new pressure elsewhere in other parts of the country.
Serbian losses near Trnovo, southeast of Sarajevo, have been heavy in recent weeks. The Bosnian Government has some reason to see a long-term military trend in its favor.
Dr. Karadzic, meanwhile, persists with a vision of an ethnically pure Serbian entity within Bosnia, including a second Sarajevo for the Serbs.
His recent promises on improving human rights and his statement that he has "nothing against Muslims, only a deep objection to Mr. Izetbegovic's fundamentalists" cannot mask the fact that, from Sanski Most in the northwest to Trebinje in the southeast, almost all Muslims in the territory held by the Serbs have been driven out or killed since 1992.
Both these political visions -- Mr. Izetbegovic's of some sort of liberation and Dr. Karadzic's of a big slice of Bosnia for Serbs only -- are probably impossible ones.
A Bosnian military victory over Dr. Karadzic would almost certainly take years; moreover, there would still be many Serbs left in Bosnia who would not want to live under a Muslim-led Government. And the toll of political and economic isolation that goes with Dr. Karadzic's ideas would ultimately prove crippling.
If the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia, -- the countries that make up the so-called Contact Group that has drawn up a peace plan for Bosnia -- can convince the opposing sides of the futility of this essential stalemate, there may be some chance of a real cessation of hostilities that would outlast the effects of the winter.
There may also be some chance of a real political settlement that would allow the two sides to govern themselves in such close proximity that political, economic and emotional links would inevitably emerge over time and wounds begin to heal.
But, as the third winter of the war takes hold, all the signs are that the time is not yet ripe for the political courage that a settlement would demand.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Muslim boy who lives in a camp in Zagreb made a snowball as his mother, braving the Balkan winter without a coat, carried coal to heat the barracks where about 1,000 refugees have lived for two winters. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Ties With Pope on Aid Groups

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 21

 BODY:
At a time of sharpening differences in Congress over the usefulness of United States foreign aid, President Clinton has written to Pope John Paul II proposing closer, formal cooperation between United States Government and Roman Catholic aid agencies to insure that aid reaches the people it is meant for, American and Vatican officials said today.
The idea is to tap into the wide network of Catholic relief and development services around the world -- both private organizations and those directly sponsored by the Vatican -- that often have the most up-to-date and detailed information on the needs of people in disaster areas, United States officials said. 
 The proposal represents a departure from previous practice. But it could also inspire misgivings among some American Catholics because of the Vatican's efforts, most recently in September at a major conference in Cairo on population issues, to stamp its views on abortion and contraception on development policies.
President Clinton's letter was presented to Angelo Cardinal Sodano, the Vatican's Secretary of State, on Dec. 5 by Raymond L. Flynn, the American Ambassador to the Holy See.
Vatican officials said that no formal response had yet been made.
The development coincides with reports that Republican leaders in Congress are planning cuts of 15 to 20 percent in Washington's foreign aid budget, which is set at $13.7 billion this year.
In his letter, which has not been made public, President Clinton praised the Catholic Church as a "cornerstone of efforts to lend assistance in times of need" and suggested "that by working together more closely and better coordinating our responses to humanitarian crises we could alleviate the suffering."
"We would like to share information, including field reports, on a more systematic basis," the letter said, according to American officials who spoke on conditions of anonymity. It also spoke of a new cooperation between the Vatican and the Clinton Administration "in the areas of crisis prevention and mediation" and proposed "the development of a system of information-sharing and a coordinated approach to our humanitarian response efforts."
The idea was under discussion within the Agency for International Development, the principle vehicle for United States foreign aid, before the Republican victory in Congress and was first raised with Vatican officials in May when Brian Atwood, the agency's director, stopped in Rome on the way back from a visit to disaster areas in Africa.
But Ambassador Flynn said in an interview, it had assumed a particular significance since the newest Republican suggestions to cut foreign aid.
"This will save money to the extent that it will insure that the process is effective and professional," he said. "It will insure that the American tax dollar is not being squandered but is going directly to the people in overwhelming need."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Canada Plans Tax on a U.S. Magazine

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Canada's efforts to protect its recording and magazine industries at the expense of powerful American companies are generating fresh tensions with the United States.
On Thursday, the Canadian Government is expected to announce measures to bolster the industries, including a punitive tax on Canadian issues of Sports Illustrated. The tax could provoke direct American retaliation, although such a tax is not specifically prohibited by the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Only two days ago, a Canadian court rejected an appeal by the Country Music Television channel in Nashville to overturn a ruling by Canada's Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission that will ban the American channel in Canada and replace it with a Canadian-owned country music channel.
But despite their conflicts on the cultural front, the United States and Canadian Governments have come together on an agreement, also to be announced on Thursday, to expand air transportation between their countries.
Although the two countries enjoy the world's largest exchanges of goods and services, they lack even direct air links between the two capitals of Ottawa and Washington.
A so-called open skies accord, under which each country's airlines would eventually be able to fly back and forth from any city they want, could be ready for signing by the time President Clinton pays an expected visit to Ottawa this winter, American officials said.
Yet cultural tensions still overhang the relationship. Ottawa has come under increasing pressure from Canadian magazine publishers, who complain that Sports Illustrated attracts Canadian advertising that should go to their publications.
The argument that the economic health of Canadian publishing underpins a national cultural identity has high resonance here but wins little sympathy in the United States.
"We have made our feelings very clear to them at high levels," the United States Ambassador, James J. Blanchard, said in an interview. "There may well have to be retaliation or a separate, special 301. We are looking at all our options."
Section 301 of American trade law empowers President Clinton to strike at imports from countries that take unfair trade action against American exports.
The North American Free Trade Agreement, which includes Mexico, exempts cultural industries from the dismantling of trade barriers. But while Canada would not violate the accord by taking discriminatory action against Time Warner, the publisher of Sports Illustrated, the United States would also not violate the agreement by retaliating.
"We have no problem if they want to subsidize these industries," Ambassador Blanchard said. "Where we object is when they act to penalize our industries, making us pay the cost."
Canada rippled cultural waters earlier this year when the Canadian radio and television commission ordered the Country Music Television from Nashville off the air by Jan. 1 to make way for New Country Music, a Canadian channel jointly owned by Rawlco Communications Inc. of Edmonton, Alberta, and Maclean Hunter Ltd. of Toronto.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh and Gaylord Entertainment Inc. of Oklahoma City, owners of Country Music Television, unsuccessfully asked the federal Court of Appeal in Canada to set aside the ruling on the ground that they had been denied a fair hearing.
Time Warner publishes six Canadian issues a year of Sports Illustrated through a satellite printing operation in Montreal.
Under what is called a split-run, Time-Warner essentially takes the American magazine, adds a few pages of Canadian editorial content and turns it into a Canadian product that competes for advertising.
Through satellite printing, Time-Warner bypassed 20-year-old Canadian restrictions barring Canadian companies from writing off their advertising costs in American magazines for tax purposes. The restrictions originally covered magazines printed in the United States and trucked into Canada.
Canadian publishers have worried that if their Government does not challenge Sports Illustrated's split-run, foreign English-language magazines with significant circulation in Canada could follow suit.
Officials at Time Warner in New York were reluctant to comment today before the Canadian Government announcement. But privately one said, "We're quite upset."

HEADLINE: U.S. Easing Rules on Biotech Patents

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Government will no longer require drug companies to conduct clinical trials on humans before granting patents for biotechnology products, Clinton Administration officials and drug industry executives said today.
The policy, which drug companies said would actually make it easier for them to conduct such clinical trials, is expected to speed development of treatments for cancer, AIDS and other diseases. It is to be announced on Thursday by Bruce A. Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. 
 In the last few years, drug companies say, the Government has often demanded that they do human clinical trials to show the effectiveness of new biotechnology drugs before they can get patent protection for their products. But the companies said they could not raise the money to pay for such testing if they did not have patents because there was no guarantee they would get exclusive rights to the drugs.
In remarks prepared for a news conference on Thursday, Mr. Lehman, who is also an Assistant Secretary of Commerce, says he has ordered a policy change to remedy what he describes as a Catch-22. Companies, he said, complained that they were "required by the Patent and Trademark Office to provide human clinical data" to show that new drugs were useful, but at the same time they were "unable to proceed with clinical trials for a promising new drug because their patent situation was unclear."
While drug makers will still have to show the potential usefulness of new biotechnology products, Mr. Lehman said, they can satisfy the requirement by submitting "any kind of evidence" to demonstrate that their claims are credible.
"Our examiners will no longer impose unrealistic and unattainable evidentiary requirements on patent applicants," he said.
Executives from the biotechnology industry hailed the change, embodied in guidelines for patent examiners, and they praised Mr. Lehman for responding to their concerns.
"This is a big step forward for the biotechnology industry," said Lisa J. Raines, a vice president of the Genzyme Corporation, in Cambridge, Mass. "Biotech companies will be able to get patents earlier in the process of drug development, and that will make it easier for companies to raise the money needed for clinical trials. When you have a patent, you can go to investors. You can't get investors for clinical trials without patents.
"Under the new policy, if you have a drug that could be useful in treating cancer and it stops cancer cells from multiplying in a test tube or in animals, you could get a patent. You wouldn't have to prove that it actually worked in humans."
The patent is needed to raise money for clinical trials, which in turn are essential for the next step in the process. Drugs must be tested in humans to show that they are safe and effective before they can be approved by the Food and Drug Administration for sale to the public.
Robert P. Blackburn, vice president and chief patent counsel at the Chiron Corporation, in Emeryville, Calif., said today: "Consumers will benefit from the new guidelines. More drugs will be put into clinical trials. That increases the chances that new drugs will become available for diseases that now have no treatment."
The policy change has no monetary cost to the Government and may pay some political dividends for the Clinton Administration. Many biotechnology executives praised Mr. Clinton in 1992, when as a Presidential candidate he emphasized the economic importance of high technology industries. But they were dismayed by his effort to control drug prices as part of his ambitious plan to remake the nation's health care system. Drug stock prices fell in 1993, investors were unnerved and many biotechnology companies said they had difficulty raising money to pursue promising drugs.
Patents are valuable property rights, permitting companies to sell products without direct competition, but there is no way to quantify the value of the new policy to drug companies.
Industry executives laid out their concerns at a meeting with Mr. Lehman last spring and at a public hearing he held in San Diego in the summer.
Biotechnology companies complained, for example, that patent examiners often challenged the scientific judgments of experts, including Nobel Prize winners, who certified that new drugs met certain criteria for granting patents.
"We heard many people say that examiners routinely challenge the sound scientific conclusions of recognized experts in the field," Mr. Lehman said. "This practice will cease under the new guidelines."
He said examiners would be trained to make sure they understood the guidelines and correctly applied the relevant laws. Supervisors and "quality assurance experts" will have the authority to overrule the decisions of patent examiners if necessary, he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Lower income taxes stimulate the economy. The sequel.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the Laffer curve? That was the back-of-the napkin illustration by the economist Arthur Laffer of his idea that in some cases lower tax rates actually increase government revenues. It inspired the immense rate reductions of the early Ronald Reagan era -- and later, the I-told-you-so chuckles from mainstream economists who never believed the rosy revenue forecasts.
Well, nobody's laughing these days. The Laffer curve is alive and well, back at the heart of academic and political debates over the "dynamic scoring" proposed by some Republicans in computing how tax changes affect the budget. 
 Although Republican leaders in Congress now say they will pare the budget before they cut taxes, much still hangs on how tax cuts are scored. If the "supply siders" who dominate the House Republicans have their way, Congress will be able to deliver a host of tax breaks without touching the budget perks of the middle class.
Under the self-imposed rules of Congress, any bill that adds to the deficit must be offset by budget cuts or revenue "enhancements," otherwise known as tax increases. The estimates are made by the Congressional Budget Office, using formulas created by the Joint Committee on Taxation. The final arbiter is the White House's Office of Management and Budget. If O.M.B. decides that Congress has, in effect, cooked the books, the President is obliged to hold back a portion of the appropriated funds.
Everything turns on the assumptions used to project revenues. The most conservative stance is that tax rates do not affect the level of taxable transactions.
Assume, for example, that Americans spend $100 billion a year on new cars. A truly "static analysis" would count a special 50 percent tax on cars as a $50 billion gain in revenue.
This approach guarantees error: When you shoot at a flying duck, as the late Senator Russell Long once put it, you aim where the duck is heading, not where the duck is. In the case of the auto tax, people would presumably postpone purchases, buy cheaper vehicles or make payments under the table.
That is why the Joint Tax Committee, contrary to some ill-informed claims by outsiders like Rush Limbaugh, does include some behavioral responses to tax changes. In estimating the revenue impact of cutting the capital gains tax rate, for instance, Congressional tax experts assume that big gains would be "unlocked" in the early years as people chose to sell appreciated assets.
But dynamic scoring is a slippery slope. And the current debate focuses on just how dynamic the scorekeepers can be without sliding into never-never land. Most economists believe it is not legitimate to count the Keynesian "demand side" impact of a tax cut -- for example, the stimulus to taxable income that followed the Kennedy Administration's business-tax cuts in the early 1960's.
Why? Because, when the economy is operating near its full capacity, "the Federal Reserve just isn't going to let it happen," argues Martin Feldstein, the conservative president of the National Bureau of Economic Research. Any such stimulus, he asserts, would be offset by tighter credit policies by the Fed to prevent higher inflation.
What is at stake is how tax changes alter incentives to work, save and invest -- and thus increase total productive capacity and taxable income in the long run. While virtually all experts agree there are effects, the Joint Tax Committee assumes they are too small to matter much in the five-year horizon of budget planning.
But supply-siders are partial to predictions that lower tax rates would stimulate a blizzard of new investment. Gary and Aldona Robbins, senior associates for Taxaction Analysis, a Texas-based research group, estimate that the House Republicans' capital gains cut would generate $167 billion in added revenue over seven years -- compared with the $17 billion cumulative loss estimated by the Joint Tax Committee.
Is there a middle ground here?
Maybe. Mr. Feldstein acknowledges that the short-term growth effects linked to increased investment and risk-taking are probably too modest to count in budget projections. But he argues that tax incentives can change hours worked relatively quickly. And he cites as evidence the doctoral thesis of one of his students at Harvard, Nada Eissa, who found that substantial numbers of upper-middle-income housewives joined the paid labor force after tax rates were cut in 1986.
But even that may be going too far. Stanley Collender, director of Federal budget policy at Price Waterhouse, points out how skewed it would be to score the dynamic side effects of tax policy while ignoring any dynamic effects of government spending. To take just one example, one might assume that subsidies to science add more to productive capacity than an equivalent amount spent on consumer goods. Or a dollar taken from drug rehabilitation might reduce taxable income if it raised the cost of crime.
In Mr. Collender's view, budgeting in the shadow of gigantic deficits ought to put the burden of proof on supply-siders. "You want to be surprised by a deficit that's smaller than expected," he suggests, "not larger."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed, but Auction Helps

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with prices helped by a well-received auction of two-year notes and by a stronger dollar.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 964/32 , for a yield 7.84 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bills were mixed, with a three-month bill rate down four basis points, to 5.40 percent, and a one-year note up two basis points, to 6.59 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The yield spread, or difference in yield, between a two-year and a 30-year maturity is about half of what it was a month ago. Analysts said that a narrowing of the spread was an indication that investors were confident that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates to keep inflation subdued. That confidence is displayed in the willingness of investors to buy longer maturities.
The two-year note was particularly attractive yesterday as yields rose even before the Treasury auction. At the auction, the high yield for a new two-year note was 7.57 percent, up from 7.30 percent last month and its highest since Oct. 30, 1990, when it was 7.84 percent. A year ago at auction the yield was 4.28 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said the Treasury's two-year note auction was impressive, noting the number of noncompetitive bids, which come from many individual investors.
"The noncompetitive number was $2.4 billion, massive as far as noncompetitive bidding goes," he said.
Today the Treasury will auction $11 billion of new five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the new five-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.75 percent, the same return as the current five-year note.
The dollar surged against most leading currencies yesterday, helping dollar-denominated assets like government securities appear more attractive to foreign investors. The dollar was helped in part by a move by some international investors to dump Mexican assets after the devaluation of the peso.
Municipal bonds were mixed as well yesterday, as some investors continued to sell bonds to realize year-end tax losses, traders said. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues remained unchanged yesterday at 7.94 percent for the third consecutive day.
Bonds sold by California issuers continue to trade at significantly lower prices than comparable bonds issued by other states in the wake of the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
California general obligation bonds due in 10 years are yielding 6.25 percent, up a basis point since Nov. 30.

HEADLINE: Investigation Finds 'Complex Network' Of Ticket Scalping

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
A New York State investigation into ticket scalping has found "a massive, complex network" that illegally resells tickets to major entertainment and sporting events for huge profits. But Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell acknowledges he will have been unable to do much about it before he leaves office on Dec. 31.
In a draft report wrapping up an eight-month investigation, Mr. Koppell describes a conspiracy involving the systematic siphoning of large blocs of tickets to illegal brokers through Ticketmaster outlets and by corrupt box-office employees and concert promoters, managers and agents, among others. Although there have been several arrests and small fines levied during the investigation, there have been no major indictments, and the report is sketchy on what major reforms should be made. 
 "I think we're reasonably close, but we don't have enough yet to be nearly at the bottom," Mr. Koppell said in a telephone interview yesterday. He said he had no idea if his Republican successor, Dennis Vacco, would continue the effort. If not, the investigation, which was announced with a flourish last spring, may be ending with little more than a recommendation from Mr. Koppell for tougher sanctions against ticket scalpers and higher allowable markups for licensed ticket brokers.
Mr. Vacco could not be reached yesterday through his transition office in Buffalo.
Although illegal hoarding of tickets for resale at steep markups is hardly new, it has become an increasingly sore point for theatergoers, concertgoers and sports fans. They inevitably find that box-office tickets to major entertainment and sporting events sell out fast, only to emerge from illegal brokers at much higher prices.
Perhaps the most blatant example recently was the Barbra Streisand concerts at Madison Square Garden in June. Tickets at the Garden box office and Ticketmaster, listed at $350, $250 and $100, were gone within minutes. Brokers were later advertising them for as much as $1,700 apiece, and some concertgoers told of paying up to $2,000 a ticket.
"This conspiracy has led not only to the unjust enrichment of certain brokers and persons who control the original source of tickets," the report says, "but to a dual system of distribution -- one for persons with wealth or access; the other for the rest of the population who camp out in front of the box office all night only to find out that the best seats to an event are gone before they get to the window."
Such inequities undermine New York City, Mr. Koppell said in the interview. "Broadway is one of the reasons people come to New York," he said, "and if they can only get to see a show by paying hundreds of dollars, it's going to dissuade them from coming here."
The report is due for release shortly, with the announcement of a pending civil settlement with a large corporation, state officials said. But Mr. Koppell said that a central part of the investigation remains unfinished: an analysis of documents obtained by searches of New Jersey brokers. He also said that despite evidence that box-office people were colluding in the diversion of tickets, for bribes known in the business as "ice," there was not yet enough proof to bring charges.
Mr. Koppell said he had spoken with Mr. Vacco only fleetingly since the election in November and not at all about the scalping investigation.
Thus far, three unlicensed brokers who were arrested have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges and been fined $250, and a Manhattan hotel concierge has pleaded guilty to ticket speculation and paid a $150 fine. Ten civil proceedings have also been brought against other brokers for scalping Steisand tickets, and another broker has been fined for scalping tickets to the Big East Conference basketball tournament in Syracuse. In addition, cases are pending against four Connecticut brokers and a Pennsylvania broker.
In the face of weak legal remedies against scalping, Mr. Koppell is proposing to toughen the penalties to provide for maximum civil fines of $5,000 per violation and criminal fines of up to three times the profit from illegal sales, or $5,000 for three or more offenses.
He also proposed that the legal markup for licensed brokers be increased by an unspecified amount. At present, licensed brokers may charge only $5 or 10 percent of the listed ticket price as their service fee, an amount that many brokers say is far below their business cost. Many licensed brokers now charge over the legal maximum, contending that they come under the exception of acting as an "agent of venue" rather than serving as a broker. But their markups, usually 25 to 38 percent, pale beside those of the unlicensed brokers and other scalpers, which can be as much as 10 times a ticket's face price, the report said.
Mr. Koppell also urged a new disclosure rule requiring producers or theater owners to specify how many seats were being withheld from initial public sale. The opportunity for the New York Legislature to write such changes into state law will come by next June, when the current provisions expire.
The report traces various sources of supply for the scalping underground. In particular, it says, the Streisand concerts -- where nearly half the seats were withheld from public sale by promoters, the house and the star herself -- illustrated "the kind of black market economy that has come to dominate most popular events."
State investigators traced some of the scalped Streisand seats to Ticketmaster outlets, typically counters in record stores and malls where tickets are sold for cash by employees who don't work for Ticketmaster. In the case of one outlet on Long Island, the report said, 40 blocs of seats were sold although only 17 people were on line, according to later Ticketmaster printouts. The outlet was not identified.
"I think that Ticketmaster can't help but know," said Mr. Koppell. "They promised to clean up their act but we have yet to see."
Larry Solters, a Ticketmaster spokesman in Los Angeles, said the company's 2,500 outlets nationwide are bound by an ethics code proscribing diversions to scalpers and that violators are terminated. He said that he had no information about this particular case.
The investigation also traced abuses to "the highest ranks of American commerce," the report said. As laid out in a public hearing held by Mr. Koppell in August, American Express had been offering holders of its platinim card a "concierge" service that put callers in touch with brokers for hard-to-get seats, at more than $100 over the legal resale limit. American Express said at the time that it was suspending the service.
Hotel concierges also commonly tapped unlicensed brokers for access to prime seats at illegally high markups, the report says, citing undercover investigations at eight top hotels: the Four Seasons, Marriott Marquis, Parker Meridien, Park Lane, Peninsula, Plaza, Ritz Carlton and Waldorf-Astoria.
Mr. Koppell said that his office had been negotiating with the New York Hotel Association to end the practice but that the talks collapsed when the group said it could not bind its members.
In an effort to establish whether box-office employees at Broadway theaters were diverting tickets to unlicensed brokers, investigators interviewed industry figures and examined box-office records for hit shows, the report said. "In September," it said, "we obtained search warrants and seized the records of four illegal brokers in New York and New Jersey." The records, it said, "reflect extensive transactions with Broadway box offices."
Also seized were "large numbers of premium tickets to hit Broadway shows which are unavailable at the box office or from licensed brokers."
Licensed brokers also commonly exceeded the legal markup but by less than the illegal brokers and consequently often do not have access to prime seats, the report says. But licensed brokers also trafficked with their unlicensed counterparts, routinely faxing price lists back and forth, it says.
Nor, it says, were licensed brokers immune to the illicit services. "Their records indicate that even they purchase tickets from out-of-state scalpers," the report said.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Middle-Class War

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the White House, the catch-phrase must have seemed like a good idea: Marry F.D.R.'s "Economic Bill of Rights" with Bill Clinton's campaign promise of a "middle-class tax cut" to dress up a necessary placation of the overtaxed as a "Middle-Class Bill of Rights."
But the first thing we don't need is a new assertion of economic "rights," long the basis for budget-busting "entitlements." Mr. Clinton proposes that all taxpayers subsidize a large portion of what some taxpayers will spend on college for their youngsters. 
 Making tax-deductible what some spend on higher education has appeal. But by increasing demand, it pushes up the exorbitant costs of college and does nothing to encourage students to work while studying. The only free-market way to encourage prestige colleges to cut costs and become competitive is to reduce subsidies and tamp down demand.
Let's say the unsayable: Higher education is a privilege, not a right, best to be earned by high-school scholarship merit and willingness to work or borrow. The notion that equal opportunity can be guaranteed by sprinkling degrees on everyone is going out with the welfare state.
The second thing we don't need is the embrace of "class" as a way to categorize American society.
Here's the current state of class warfare. To be a member of the Lower Class is to be a helpless victim of an unfair system, or a lazy bum. To be a member of the Middle Class is to be a wonderful mainstreamer, justly resentful of being put upon by the leeches below and top-hatted bloodsuckers above. To be a member of the Upper Class is to be selfish and sinful.
What kind of a warped outlook is this to apply to a quarter-billion Americans? Why let politicians patronize the poor as pitiable Lowers, lionize those closest to median incomes as long-suffering Middles, and satanize the most successful and productive as greedy Uppers?
That applies political demography to outdated sociology. The divisive Marxist concept of class is social as well as economic, and Americans should never accept its confines. Class is not determined by income alone; richies can be low-class slobs and the genteel down-at-the-heels can be high-class povertarians.
Only because the vast majority of voters are near the non-poor, non-rich median do pols lump these diverse individuals together in a deliciously average economic/social "class," to be flattered and cosseted. But the people with the most voting power are not a class of any kind.
The "middle-class tax cut," which is at the heart of this rhetorical demeaning of our real Bill of Rights, is the newest way of saying "Let's keep on soaking the rich."
Since the poor, who pay little income tax anyway, are not much affected by Mr. Clinton's plan, the meaning of the M.C.T.C. is plain: Exclude those nasty richies from the relief we give the deserving middle. Republicans with their own M.C.T.C. labeling go along with the politics of populist resentment.
But the evokers of class warfare are out of step with the people they purport to speak for. Most of them see the problem with taxes not as "The rich are not paying their fair share," but "We're all paying too much, especially me."
People near the median would like to keep what they earn, make the savings work for them and thereby become "upper class." Such ambition is not to be apologized for; it used to be described as the American Dream.
Central to the Clintonite exclusionary sell is that the richies stole everybody else blind in the 80's. But from 1982 to 1989, as Reaganites cut tax rates, the income of those closest to the middle rose sharply.
Another Big Lie is that the Republicans caused the deficit explosion. Throughout the 80's, the primary pressure to spend came from Tip O'Neill's Democrats. As tax rates fell, tax receipts rose, as supply-siders predicted, but the spending binge -- insufficiently resisted by Ronald Reagan -- came from House Democrats who now pretend the G.O.P. was solely responsible for quadrupling the deficit.
In Clinton's coming Republican half-term, the healthiest and fairest tax relief will be across the board, flattening rates and closing loopholes for everyone -- all-class, no-class economic policy.
