HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Fall as Demand Is Weak for New Notes

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday for the first time this week following weak demand at an auction of five-year notes.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/32 of a percentage point, to 95 31/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.85 percent from 7.84 percent on Wednesday. The new yields on the two-year note, which was auctioned on Wednesday, rose 14 basis points, to 7.71 percent. The spread between the long end and the short end is now just 14 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The narrow spread between the 2-year note and the 30-year bonds suggests increasing expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again to keep inflation from accelerating as some investors accept less compensation for riskier longer-term securities. The spread was 36 basis points two weeks ago and 85 basis points a month ago.'
Traders said the auction of the five-year issue drew a high yield of 7.85 percent, or about three basis points more than had been expected. The higher yield served as a reminder that not everybody was willing buy longer maturities with the Fed seemingly poised to raise rates again in January.
The yield at auction was four basis points higher than last month and the highest since July 1991 when it was 7.89 percent.
Analysts noted that some of the market's weakness could be traced in part to the continuing turmoil in the Mexican market following the devaluation of the peso on Tuesday. There was speculation that the Mexican Government was actively selling some of its United States Treasury securities to raise cash to support the peso. Such a selloff, however, could be offset by foreign investors if enough swap their holdings of Mexican debt in favor of United States notes and bills, a more liquid investment.
James P. Fields, a vice president and portfolio manager at Wright Investors in Bridgeport, Conn., said bond yields had come down steadily since Nov. 7, when they reached a high of 8.16 percent. "More and more, it seems like people are getting more bullish on about bonds," he said.
He said that even if bond yields rose again because there were investors still concerned about inflation, the yields would still fall to about 7 percent by the end of next year. "There are going to be some rough seas during the next couple of months, but in the longer term the rates will come back down."
Asked about the market performance, Mr. Fields replied, "Today, it's not going in the direction we want." He said he thought the problem stemmed from people who still expected a bigger premium for taking a risk on inflation, something he believes has been overblown. And then, he noted, there are always the day-to-day worries over outside events or fundamentals. "But my guess is that the Fed will not move after its meeting next month."
Yesterday's only economic reports included the Government's estimate of third-quarter growth and weekly unemployment report for the week ended December 17. The Government nudged its estimate for the fourth quarter's gross domestic product up to 4 percent from 3.9 percent, in line with market expectations. The Labor Department reported unemployment up by 3,000, to 326,000. Economists had expected the number of claims to drop by 1,000.
In the municipal market, prices were little changed for the third consecutive day amid a drop in demand from mutual funds and selling buy investors to realize year-end tax losses.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues remained unchanged yesterday for a third day at 6.94 percent.
Traders in the corporate bond market said the decline in the Mexican currency made Mexico's Tepic Toll Road Trust an early casualty. The trust shelved a $300 million offering that was to fund construction of a key link in Mexico's highway system.
While the proposed issue of notes and cash flow securities were denominated in dollars, payments on the bonds were to have come from peso-denominated toll revenues. The deal has been shelved until January at least.

HEADLINE: Out of 125th St., Vendors Are Welcome at Queens Market

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Barou Omar has had bundles of his colorful fabrics imported from West Africa seized in periodic police sweeps through 125th Street in Harlem, where he and thousands of other vendors tried to make a living.
The final blow came two months ago, when the city relocated the vendors to a lot on 116th Street. Business there was terribly slow, he said. 
 Now, he has pinned his hopes on Jamaica, Queens, after receiving a most unusual offer: he was invited to set up shop there.
Merchants and developers in Jamaica are gambling that the vendors who are unwelcome in many commercial zones throughout the city will help bolster business. They have even set aside valuable real estate, a section of the Jamaica Market, for the vendors. The sleek two-year-old Victorian-style market building is in the heart of downtown, at 159-15 Jamaica Avenue.
A food court is the building's centerpiece, with restaurateurs who serve food of all types, including ox tails, curried goat, smothered pork chops, chitterlings, collards and pizza.
Brian Williams, promotions manager for the market, which is operated by the Greater Jamaica Corporation, said restaurant owners have long complained that after the lunch rush ends, hardly any customers venture into the mall.
Instead of opening up space to chain stores to bring in more customers, the market solicited vendors from around the city, he said. A new post office branch is expected to bring in more customers.
"The vendors are individual operators, many of whom used to sell their products unlicensed on the street," Mr. Williams said. "By creating Market Square, we are giving them indoor locations so they can develop clientele, permitting them to operate year-round regardless of the weather, and converting their businesses from boards across two boxes into regular commercial operations."
Since November, 30 vendors have been selling merchandise from partitioned shops in a 3,500-square-foot area adjacent to the market's 160th Street entrance, between Jamaica and 90th Avenues. Vendors pay $350 a month for 200 square feet. Until a few months ago, the space was occupied by the farmer's market, which will be moved to the 160th Street sidewalk when it returns in April.
The market, open 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. Monday through Saturday, draws customers from several government-financed projects that have sprung in recent years, including the Federal building. On weekends, the market has drawn crowds with concerts, gospel singing and Kwanzaa festivals.
The new downtown buildings, including the market, have increased the economic viability of this commercial hub in southeastern Queens. Downtown Jamaica had deteriorated in recent years.
"The market is a great community resource that has been slow taking off," Mr. Williams said. "Opening he doors to the vendors is way of letting everyone know we're here."
Clothing, ceramics, vitamins, kinte cloth and other fabrics with streaks of gold, red and blue are laid out on tables in the vendors' area. During a recent lunch hour, a few customers wandered from booth to booth, but not as many as the vendors would have liked. The indoor setting did not have the fast pace of the street.
"I prefer to rent because I'm indoors," Mr. Barou, 30, who lives in Harlem, said as he snipped threads from a quilted coat he had sewed the night before. A native of Mali, he moved to New York City two years ago. "I'm not constantly being chased away by the police and my customers know where to find me. But it's slow. I'm going to see how long I can last here."
Hugh Rivers, 39, of Queens Village, used to make a living selling hats, coats, dresses, scarves and homemade greeting cards door to door at beauty salons, church fairs and street corners.
Now, he has a corner of his own at the market. He said it felt good to settle down and not have to worry about the police confiscating his merchandise.
"This is a good deal as far as being out of the cold weather," he said while seated in front of display case lined with greeting cards with African themes and clothes created by black designers. "I feel it's a good market. Most of the booths are black-owned and we need to do what we can to make it work.
"Did I make a sale today?" he said, checking his watch at 3 P.M. "Not since 11:30 A.M. If I was on the street I would have made a few sales by now."
While many of the merchants applaud the concept, some doubted that it would bring in customers.
"We're losing money," said Richard Lim, manager of Julia's Fish and Chips, who pays $1,250 a month for 343 square feet. "It's hard for us to pay the rent. I don't know if the vendors will bring in more people. We can only hope."
Steven Lowe, manager of Carolina's Kitchen, expressed similar sentiments.
"It's hard making ends meet," Mr. Lowe said during an afternoon lull recently. "We don't have the traffic flow we need. I welcome the vendors. We need something else to attract attention."
Karen Towns, 35, a social worker who works at 89th and 161st Street, said the vendors's market has been a good place to buy gifts.
"They've added real flavor to this food court," Ms. Towns said as she stood in line at Paradise Splash Caribbean Cuisine. "They all have quality merchandise, and you don't have to stand outside in the cold to look at what they have to sell. I look forward to coming here. Last week, the market hosted a Cuban jazz quartet. It was a pleasant surprise."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barou Omar, a fabric vendor, at his booth at the Jamaica Market. He and other vendors, many banned from 125th Street in Harlem, have found a new home in Queens, on the site of a farmer's market. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: County Plans Budget Cuts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 22

 BODY:
Orange County supervisors today ordered $40.2 million in budget cuts over the next six months, giving department heads emergency authority to freeze salaries and lay off workers without usual constraints.
The reductions, which passed on a unanimous vote, represent about 17 percent of the county's discretionary spending through June 1995. 
 "Staff reductions are clearly expected to be significant," said Sheriff Brad Gates, who with the District Attorney, Michael Capizzi, and the health care director, Thomas Uram, had recommended the cuts.
Union leaders expressed dismay that they would not be consulted, saying they wished to work together with management during the county's financial crisis.
"This has all the aspects of a steamroller," said John H. Sawyer, general manager of the Orange County Employees Association, which represents 11,000 employees -- 70 percent of the county's work force.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off vs. Mark and Yen Despite Flight From Peso

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar, which had picked up strength from the financial turmoil in Mexico, ended lower against most leading currencies yesterday.
The dollar has benefited as investors fled Latin American stock and bond markets -- and their currencies -- since the Mexican Government devalued the peso by 15 percent on Tuesday and then decided to let it float. Dealers said investors sought the safety of dollar-denominated securities. 
 But in late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was weighed down by profit taking after reaching a four-month high against the German mark.
"There is the sense that the flight-to-quality sentiment will keep a firmer tone under the dollar," said Hillel Waxman, vice president at the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York.
In New York, the dollar fell from a high of 1.5835 marks to settle at 1.5745 marks, down from 1.5810 marks on Wednesday. It slipped to 100.15 Japanese yen from 100.48 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5475 from $1.5415.
Foreign-exchange markets felt little impact by a decision by the Bundesbank yesterday to leave German interest rates unchanged.
After the Mexican Government decided to let the peso float freely on world currency markets, the dollar strengthened further against the peso, rising to 4.8000 pesos, from 3.9870 pesos on Wednesday. The peso had been previously allowed to trade in a narrow band.
"Mexico, for a lot of us, was seen as the leading country in Latin America and these last couple of days call that into question," said Jay Pelosky, head of Latin America equity research at Morgan Stanley.
Following a meeting with Federal Reserve officials in New York yesterday, Finance Minister Jaime Serra Puche of Mexico said in a statement that "the real exchange rate depreciation should lead to an expansion of exports and stimulate investment growth."
Elsewhere, investor worries over Canada's fiscal and political issues led the Canadian dollar to tumble to an eight-year low.
The weakness came despite heavy intervention from the Bank of Canada, which bought Canadian dollars to defend the currency.
In New York trading, the Canadian dollar fell to 71.44 United States cents from 71.73 cents on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
BASEBALL OWNERS IMPLEMENT A CAP ON PLAYERS' PAY

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Baseball's labor dispute, which prompted a mediation effort by the Clinton Administration in October and induced an offer of help from Jimmy Carter on Thursday, plunged to a new low early this morning when the owners rejected a new proposal from the players and implemented a salary cap, effective at one minute after midnight.
"There was no sense going further tonight and I recessed the negotiations," Bill Usery Jr. said 10 weeks after he began mediating the strike at the request of the Administration. "A deadline was set by owners and it was evident that we weren't going to reach an agreement by that time." 
 The collapse in the 133-day-old strike came hours after the players made a new payroll-tax proposal and former President Carter, who has in recent months held peace talks with North Korea, Haiti and Bosnia, contacted both sides offering his services if they thought he could be useful.
Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said he spoke with the former President briefly and would evaluate his offer, but Mr. Usery, when asked about Mr. Carter's offer, said, "The one thing I didn't think we needed at the moment was another mediator."
Mr. Carter's offer to serve as a mediator was made known Thursday afternoon to Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel who is monitoring the effort to resolve the baseball strike, White House officials said.
The officials expressed some surprise at the offer but said President Clinton did not plan to insert himself or the White House in any kind of intermediary role. It was the Clinton Administration that asked Usery to join the talks as the mediator in October.
In implementing the salary cap that was their first proposal June 14 and modified Nov. 17, the owners made baseball the third sport to have a salary cap. The National Basketball Association initiated it a decade ago, and the National Football League joined in this season.
The players union, however, will not accept this cap lightly. It plans to challenge the owners' declaration of impasse in negotiations before the National Labor Relations Board, charging that the owners did not negotiate in good faith, and very likely will attack baseball's longtime antitrust exemption in United States District Court.
"What we learned today was what we suspected all along," Mr. Fehr said at a news conference Thursday at the Capital Hilton Hotel. "When our proposal was summarily rejected -- this is the third or fourth time players have made sweeping proposals that were summarily rejected -- there was no discussion, no counterproposals. The owners measure every proposal against the salary cap. If it doesn't measure up, they don't want it."
Bargaining, the union chief added, "has consisted of them asking us to agree to a salary cap."
Mr. Usery, a 71-year-old private mediator, said he would report to Secretary of Labor Robert Reich this morning and subsequently to President Clinton himself. He said he was not withdrawing from the dispute but would re-evaluate his position. He said he was prepared to continue but added, "That may change after I report to the Secretary of Labor."
It was largely due to Mr. Usery's efforts that the players made their proposal Thursday. They had been reluctant to give in to the owners' demand for a proposal that would create a secondary tax on payrolls above a designated threshold, but they relented, one union lawyer said, under the mediator's "arm-twisting."
The players had been reluctant to consider an over-the-threshold tax because they thought it would prompt clubs to keep their payrolls at or below the trigger point and thus serve as a salary cap.
Their proposal called for three levels of secondary taxes: 5 percent on the part of payrolls over 20 percent but less than 130 percent of the average club payroll (about $31 million for next year based on this year's projections) 10 percent for the portion of payrolls over 130 percent of the average and 25 percent for the part over 160 percent of average.
Dave Montgomery of the Philadelphia Phillies, the figures filbert of the owners' negotiating committee, belittled the proposal as bringing "us no closer to the objectives we were talking about."
"Any new system must significantly restrain salaries," he said. "The payroll tax we have received simply does not create a significant or meaningful restraint."
After the negotiating committee rejected the proposal, the major league executive council, as it was empowered to do by a 25-3 owners vote Dec. 15, held a conference call and implemented the salary cap.
"Implementation is not forced upon them," Mr. Fehr said. "They do it because they choose to do it."
Announcing the council's action, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox said: "Due to the continued existence of this deadlock and the need to prepare for the 1995 season, the executive council voted today to exercise Major League Baseball's right under Federal labor law to implement the clubs' final salary cap proposal, effective 12:01 A.M. EST Dec. 23, 1994."
The owners twice had postponed implementation. They canceled a Dec. 5 meeting at which they were going to take that action, then voted Dec. 15 in Chicago to delay impasse and implementation for a week.
Mr. Fehr, at the news conference, said he did not know precisely what the onwers were implementing but shortly before midnight he saw the message light on in his room and was told there was an envelope at the front desk for him.
Addressed to "Donald M. Fehr Esquire, Guest" the plain white envelope with no return address contained a five-page letter from Chuck O'Connor, the chief management lawyer, explaining why the owners were implementing the salary cap.
The parties, he wrote, "are plainly at an impasse" on the economic issues. Also included was a longer document with details of the new work rules.
In addition to the salary cap, the new system eliminates salary arbitration, establishes a salary scale for players in their first four years in the majors and creates restricted free agency for players who have four or more years of major league service but fewer than six years.
Unlike players with six or more years, those free agents will be restricted because their clubs can give them qualifying offers and reserve their right of first refusal, meaning they can match offers from other clubs and retain the players.
Mr. Fehr said the union had advised players and agents not to sign new contracts under the new system until the union has had a chance to study it and figure out possible implications.
The salary cap, which next year would force the Yankees, for example, to slash $4.1 million from what their 1994 payroll would have been if the season had been played in full, replaces the so-called free-market system the players prefer. The players long have vehemently rejected a salary cap, which the owners tried to get in 1985 and again in 1990.
Under the new system, the players will receive 50 percent of the industry revenue for salaries and all other player costs. A three-year transition period will precede the time the cap will take full effect. In 1994, 21 clubs were over what the cap would have been and seven were under it.
Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said some members of the players' negotiating subcommittee opposed making a proposal but other players favored it.
After the owners rejected the proposal, all of the players shared the view expressed by David Cone.
"It seems to me," the Kansas City Royals pitcher said, "anything short of total collapse by the players wouldn't have gotten a deal here. I was confused why we were not exchanging ideas. I took the idea that you try to take the higher ground and you try to find a deal. It seems legal posturing was more important to them."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Civilization And Its Price

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Not only Republican voters believe that governments in this country have become too expansive in their functions, too costly and too intrusive. Whoever wins elections, the years ahead are going to be a time of limits on what governments try to do.
But it is a different thing to believe, as some now seem to believe, that government is evil -- an unnecessary evil. To hear Newt Gingrich and his followers, the Federal Government should do little but maintain the national defense and pay out such middle-class entitlements as Social Security and Medicare. Everything else should be left to individual initiative. 
 In a world as complex as ours, and as interconnected, even the strongest individual necessarily relies on all kinds of government actions. There is a real danger that by enfeebling government we shall make the United States a less competitive country, and a less civilized one.
Adam Smith, the great advocate of market economies, nevertheless wrote that they needed government to educate the labor force, assure economic infrastructure and maintain public safety. Noting that view in the current issue of The Atlantic Monthly, Chalmers Johnson observes that our governments perform those functions less well than some of our competitors'.
Consider transportation, a crucial part of any society's infrastructure. Japan has bullet trains. Europe has trans-European expresses from the Mediterranean to the North Sea. We have struggling Amtrak, which is lopping off routes and services in anticipation of cutbacks in Federal funds.
The rationale for starving Amtrak is that subsidies are bad -- that passenger trains must make their competitive way in the market. But that is carrying theory over the edge. There is a national interest in train service. Other countries subsidize it for that reason -- as the United States, starting with President Eisenhower, has spent billions on the national highway network.
Or there is aviation safety. After a series of crashes of commuter planes, we learned that they did not have to meet the same Federal safety standards as larger aircraft. Do we want to let the marketplace determine how safe planes should be? President Clinton has proposed to have a quasi-public corporation take over the F.A.A.'s air traffic control function. Is that a wise gamble?
There is a safety question about medical drugs, too. Some voices on the right are calling for elimination or severe restriction of the Food and Drug Administration, arguing that new drugs would get on the market more quickly if they did not have to go through extensive trials and approval by the F.D.A. first.
That was the situation in Britain -- no effective constraints on new drugs -- when thalidomide went on the market as a tranquilizer in the 1960's. Pregnant women who used it gave birth to terribly deformed children, without arms and legs. Do we want to test drugs in the marketplace?
Safety and physical infrastructure are not the only necessary concerns of government in a market economy. Adam Smith listed education. Today he would surely add to that the encouragement of scientific research. Yet funds for university research are another target of budget-cutters.
There are other elements of a good society that individuals alone cannot provide -- that depend on "the power of a community." Sigmund Freud used that phrase 60 years ago. Trying to define what makes for civilization, he spoke of technological accomplishment, beauty, order and respect for ideas. But the decisive civilizing step, he wrote, was the replacement of individual force by the power of the community.
Some civilizing elements of life are under particular threat in this country today. One example is public libraries, a peculiarly American way to self-improvement, to enlargement of the mind and spirit.
Public television and radio will get no Federal funds if Mr. Gingrich has his way. At one stroke, he would endanger the only meaningful scientific programs and documentaries on American television and by far the most serious news on radio and television. So this large, rich country would have nothing like what modest Britain has in the BBC.
Rugged individualism is part of the American creed. But another part, vital since the beginning, has been the power of the community to improve our lives.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: That's a Strange Way to Finance a Tax Cut

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"President Insists His Tax Cuts Keep Deficit in Check" (front page, Dec. 17) contains reassuring reports from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, about not "cooking the books" and phasing spending cuts with tax relief over time so as not to increase the deficit.
Leaving aside the wisdom of cutting taxes now, what is disturbing is that part of the offset to tax reductions will come from sales to the public of Government-owned properties. Countries all over the world have been privatizing, motivated partly by the desire to increase their budgetary revenue. Such privatization has served useful purposes. 
 But it is a mistake to regard the proceeds of sales of Government enterprises as equivalent to tax revenue or to reductions in expenditures. These proceeds are the same as the proceeds from the sale of Government securities, which are a way of financing budget deficits.
The purchasers of the Government enterprises are either doing so out of funds they would have saved anyway or are substituting their purchases for capital investment they would otherwise have undertaken. Those are the objections to Federal deficits when the economy is operating near its full potential, as is true today. A deficit in those conditions either adds to aggregate demand, increasing the possibility of inflation, or it crowds out private investment if interest rates go up.
It is to be hoped that the Clinton economic team will reconsider this method of financing the proposed tax cuts whether or not they wish to divest Government enterprises.
 
ROBERT SOLOMON
Guest Scholar, Brookings Institution
Washington, Dec. 18, 1994

HEADLINE: That's a Strange Way to Finance a Tax Cut;
Stimulate More Growth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Lean and Very Mean" by A. M. Rosenthal (column, Dec. 16) describes the central reason for today's political sourness thus: "Americans are beginning to understand that the unwritten contract between them and their society is being torn up. The understanding was that in bad times everybody would hurt but that if the boss was doing well so would the workers." 
 But Mr. Rosenthal omits the equally central reason for this broken understanding. It is the failure of fiscal and monetary authorities to stimulate economic growth at a rate that will cause bosses to hire workers into secure jobs at good wages.
From 1946 to 1973 the Government and the Federal Reserve Board used fiscal and monetary policy to stimulate growth while at the same time maintaining a prudent guard against accelerating inflation.
The oil shocks of the 1970's changed that throughout the Western world. The lack of any possible politically acceptable combinations of low unemployment and slow inflation defeated not only Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter but also James Callaghan in Britain, Valery Giscard d'Estaing in France, Helmut Schmidt in Germany and Pierre Elliott Trudeau in Canada.
Ronald Reagan was the beneficiary of the collapse of pricing by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in the early 1980's, but he blew it with his immense increases in the Federal deficit.
Now cumulated deficit and the fear of any inflation at a rate above zero have mesmerized not only the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the Fed, but also most Clinton Administration economists, who should know better.
They contend that even with very slow inflation, the unemployment rate of around 6 percent for 1994 is so low that it will accelerate inflation sometime in the future. Before 1973, 6 percent was a pretty bad recession. Perhaps the economy has changed, but as recently as 1988-90, unemployment was well below 6 percent without accelerating inflation.
Keeping unemployment near or above 6 percent has broken the unwritten contract and engendered the meanness of which Mr. Rosenthal writes. Some form of budgetary stimulus, for example, less grudging tax cuts than President Clinton proposes (and not compensated for by spending cuts), supplemented by decreases in Federal Reserve-controlled interest rates, could stimulate industry to hire, to pay well and to invest in order to increase productive capacity.
The Republicans seem to understand this. It is their clear intention to cut taxes and to compensate with only symbolic cuts in expenditures for welfare recipients and other unpopular people and with a balanced budget amendment that cannot be implemented. Disingenous, but maybe it will work.
 
ROBERT A. LEVINE
Los Angeles, Dec. 18, 1994
 
The writer, an economist, was deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office, 1975-79.

HEADLINE: A Fading Industrial City Totters Toward Revival

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHELSEA, Mass., Dec. 22

 BODY:
At his City Hall office in this put-upon but spirited immigrant town across the Mystic River from Boston, Harry Spence was recently telling a delegation of Russian officials how he came to be the only reigning authorized dictator in America.
He said that Chelsea, trapped in corruption, gutter politics, mismanagement and poverty, was on the brink of bankruptcy three years ago. Things were so dire that the Mayor, John (Butchie) Brennan, begged the state to step in. And so it did, suspending democracy -- which meant that Mr. Brennan was out of a job -- and placing the city in receivership. As receiver, Mr. Spence was given the powers of mayor, aldermen and treasurer, to rule essentially by fiat. 
 As he was relating all this to the Russians, Mr. Spence said, a general in the delegation became excited. "He started pounding his fist on the table, saying: 'We need this! We need this!' " Mr. Spence said. "I kept saying, 'No, no, it's temporary.' He kept saying enthusiastically, 'No, this is what we need!' "
The dictatorship that the general saw as the ideal solution is an emergency measure that is entering its final months. Democracy is returning to Chelsea. How well it will work remains to be seen.
With two of the last four mayors in jail on corruption-related charges, a third -- Mr. Brennan -- under house arrest, and a fourth who took bribes but was given immunity, the citizens who painstakingly drew up the charter did away with the office of mayor as well as the old Board of Aldermen. The first City Council elections under the new charter were held this month.
The 11 new Council members, who include a convenience-store owner, a community organizer, a court officer, a hairdresser and a financial analyst, are now taking classes on how to run a municipal government, and will soon begin searching for someone to become Chelsea's first city manager. They say they want the best and are prepared to pay for it -- $80,000 a year, a hitherto unheard-of municipal salary here.
What is being tried in Chelsea is one of the nation's most ambitious efforts to revive a fading industrial city. (One tiny Texas town, Arcola, is also in receivership.) Chelsea's equally troubled school system, which ceded authority to Boston University in 1989, remains under the university's wing for four more years. But local government starts flying on its own as soon as the city manager starts, probably by June.
Nadine Mironchuk, who remembers being shocked by the epithets and feuding at the first Board of Aldermen's meeting she saw years ago, says she is worried.
"The question now is, Do the people get it?" said Ms. Mironchuk, who, as Chelsea's first public relations director, has what might be considered one of the tougher jobs in town. "Harry's doing the best he can to build up the political culture. That's going to take some time. There's every chance it could go either way."
Indeed, a lot about Chelsea (population 28,000) has not changed. It remains one of the state's poorest cities, its 1.8 square miles teeming with Hispanic and Asian immigrants who cannot find jobs.
The Tobin Bridge, which the state built in 1948 over vehement protests of Chelseans, still cuts an ugly swath through the city, and brings in not a dime of local revenue. "They owe us big time for that bridge," Guy Santagate, the long-suffering town assessor, said as he drove under it the other day. "They raped us."
But Chelsea struggled on, just as it did after two epic fires, in 1908 and 1973.
"People here are resilient," said Mr. Santagate, whose honesty made him a pariah at City Hall for decades. Horatio Alger, after all, was born in what used to be Chelsea but is now Revere.
The tax base remains woefully small. There is little open space. Many of the old wood-frame houses and brick apartment buildings are deteriorating.
"Chelsea has all the problems of a big city, except it's not a big city," said Thomas F. Birmingham, a native Chelsean who, as chairman of the State Senate Ways and Means Committee, fought for the receivership. "Turning around a city like Chelsea is more like turning around an ocean liner than a sports car. It's a slow, gradual process. Nothing is guaranteed."
Mr. Santagate, the son of a Sicilian immigrant, remembers how poisonous the political culture was when he started as an assessor in 1973.
"When I came in as assessor, the only thing missing was the quill pen; they were writing out 6,000 properties by hand," he said as he stopped for a corned beef sandwich at Pressman's Deli. "I brought in an outside computer company to automate the bills. That ruffled the treasurer's feathers. It may have had something to do with overtime. I always hoped something would change, but I never dreamed it would."
Shortly before the state stepped in, Joe Savage, an Assistant United States Attorney, began a corruption investigation with the help of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Internal Revenue Service. "Democracy had ceased to exist 20 years ago," Mr. Savage said. "It had become government by auction."
By September 1991, when the state imposed receivership, the city was facing a $10.5 million deficit on a $40 million budget. The first receiver, James Carlin, and Mr. Spence, who had earlier had been successful in taking over the troubled Boston Housing Authority, were shocked at what they found.
"The chaos was unbelievable," Mr. Spence said. "We weren't sure the city could make it. It took us six months just to figure out what the financial situation was.
"There were, literally, old bills piling up in shoeboxes," he said. "There were department heads who hadn't spoken to each other in years because of long vendettas."
Mr. Carlin and Mr. Spence cut the municipal payroll by one-third, imposed trash fees, froze overtime for the Fire Department -- it was pulling down $1 million in overtime a year -- and brought in desperately needed businesses. Mr. Santagate was one of only three department heads, out of 17, who were kept on.
"Guy was heroic," Mr. Spence said.
Mr. Spence was given plenty of help -- millions of dollars in state aid, for starters, as well as the corruption investigators, who produced 13 indictments and six convictions.
Now, the budget has been balanced for the third straight year. The recent election was, by all accounts, clean. The city's bond rating has gone to triple A from worthless, and there are now three schools under construction -- the first in 80 years -- as well as parking garages and a state computer center.
Gone are the notorious topless bars and gambling joints -- places like Caruso's Celebrity Lounge, Jilly's, Grub 'n' Pub -- that were as much a part of the landscape as the huge gas tanks looming over the waterfront.
With six members of the Police Department convicted of such crimes as illegal gambling, bribery, pension fraud and tax evasion, there is a new police chief, Ed Flynn, from New Jersey, who has drawn national attention for his efforts in community policing.
Of course, remnants of the old political culture of rancor remain. Two former Aldermen have returned as City Council members. While Hispanic residents make up 40 percent of Chelsea's population, only one Hispanic candidate, Juan Vega, was elected.
But life is easier now for store owners like Sergio Jaramillo, who came here 15 years ago from Chile. Mr. Jaramillo, who runs a pawnshop on Broadway, used to have a deli and remembers feeling that he had to pay off health inspectors. "Nothing was written, but it was there," he said. "This was Chelsea."
Now, he said, "I have no troubles," adding, "I think the receivership is one of the better things that has ever happened to Chelsea."
Although the appointment of Mr. Spence, a Groton- and Harvard-educated Bostonian, had for a time stirred inevitable class resentments, he has been widely regarded as a benevolent dictator. Now, as Councilman Vega, said, "There's a lot of anxiety about what happens when Harry's gone."
The new City Council was sworn in Monday night. The first official meeting is scheduled for next month. There is only one item on the agenda: the search for the city manager.
"It's going to be messy," said Mr. Spence, talking the other day in his City Hall office, with his brass ship's clock, made at the still-in-business Chelsea Clock factory, proudly displayed on his desk.
"Chelsea succeeding doesn't mean Chelsea is going to be paradise; it's just going to be like any other place," he said. "It's kind of like that old line about successful therapy: it means you can be normally unhappy.
"Chelsea goes back to real life. It's going to be bumpy and difficult, as real life always is."

HEADLINE: A Nervous City Sees Bombs Everywhere

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Just before rush hour yesterday, a security guard spotted a briefcase sitting atop two cardboard boxes outside a luggage store at Five World Trade Center. Wary, the guard called 911 to report a suspicious leather bag, and the police summoned the bomb squad.
 As the squad raced to the scene, sirens carving a path through commuter traffic, an absent-minded businessman returned to the luggage store and retrieved his briefcase, which, it turned out, contained nothing more perilous than a Bible and a laptop computer. 
 That potential crisis had barely fizzled, however, when the police received another 911 call about a suspicious package, this one lodged between two turnstiles near the tracks of the PATH Station at Sixth Avenue and 32d Street.
 The PATH station was closed for half an hour, and again, nothing was found. Commuters remained calm, if eager to start the holiday weekend.
 But the nervous, impulsive calls spoke volumes about the jitters that have swept the city following Wednesday's firebombing of a subway car at Fulton Street. On Thursday, for instance, the police responded 46 times to calls about suspicious packages and the like, none of which were dangerous. The usual number of such calls is about 10 a day.
 "We're concerned about the increase in work caused by skittish people," said John Timoney, the Police Department's Chief of Department. "But we're also concerned about copycats. I'm afraid of the loser type looking for 15 minutes of fame."
 The police are encouraging people to be alert. But they are also concerned about nervous citizens summoning the 36-member bomb squad away from genuine emergencies.
 The squad has been forced to respond to hundreds of false alarms since a mail bomb killed an advertising executive in North Caldwell, N.J., two weeks ago. And calls have escalated since the fireball erupted on the southbound Manhattan No. 4 train, set off, police suspect, by Edward J. Leary, a disgruntled unemployed man who wanted to hold the city hostage.
 On the average day, amid all the reports of shootings, wife beatings and fender-benders that crackle over the 911 police emergency telephone, a report of a bomb threat or suspicious package comes almost every two hours. But the number increased to a daily average of 17 after the New Jersey explosion. And on the day of the subway firebombing, false alarms rose to 35, with 46 on Thursday and at least 20 more by early yesterday evening.
 Late Thursday, Transit Authority employees working on the G Line in Brooklyn got a scare when an anonymous man called a transit booth on Java Street saying he would blow up the subway if authorities did not release his brother. It turned out to be a crank call.
 "Everybody has been on their toes of late," said Joe Rosco, the security manager at 780 Third Avenue, where a security guard called the police after he found a briefcase outside a gourmet store at 7:50 A.M. yesterday. "We are all very careful."
 Not one of the hundreds of calls has been anything serious. But a few have been disruptive. No one was allowed to enter or leave the Third Avenue building for two hours yesterday until the bomb squad arrived, for example.
 And on Monday, after a suspicious-looking box was found in Port Richmond High School on Staten Island, the school was evacuated. The police found a harmless box wired to look like a bomb.
 In all, there were at least 10 bomb threats or reports of possible explosive devices around the city's subway system yesterday without any major disruptions in service. And in one case yesterday morning, a loud pop under the seat of an uptown subway car near Broadway and 168th Street in Washington Heights frightened passengers until transit repairmen declared it nothing more than a blown fuse.
 "You have to respond to everything," said Michael Amarosa, the Police Department Director of Communications, who oversees 911 service. "That's the only way to treat this."
 Police officials noted that the Christmas season has traditionally been a time when bomb threats proliferate. In 1982, bombs set by the Puerto Rican F.A.L.N. separatist group exploded on New Year's Eve outside four government buildings in New York City, including Police Headquarters.
 But security precautions this holiday season have still not reached the level that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait or the bombing at the World Trade Center, when the police bolstered the bomb squad by temporarily rehiring retired members.
 Anticipating possible copycat bombers or even another strike in the Unabom serial letter bombings, the Police Department last week assembled 300 business and university executives at Police Headquarters for a briefing from experts of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
 Immediately after Wednesday's subway incident, the police stepped up security around scores of religious and government buildings around the city. But once the Police Department was satisfied that Mr. Leary, the 49-year-old Scotch Plains, N.J., man arrested for the subway firebombing, had operated alone, security details were decreased.
 Nevertheless, Police Chief Timoney yesterday expressed concern that all the false alarms would "drain our resources."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
For workers on the front lines of retailing, the holidays are a time of great pressure, when they are forced to juggle many customers at once while exhausted by hours of overtime. The $1,500 sale that provides a huge high is rare, and the housekeeping tasks are endless. For many, the season is make-or-break. [Page 1.] 

Moody's said six California counties had used the aggressive investment practices that drove Orange County, Calif., into bankruptcy. But none of the six -- Monterey, Placer, San Bernardino, San Diego, Solano and Sonoma -- are in danger of falling into bankruptcy, the credit-rating agency said. [41.]
Consumer spending rose briskly in November, increasing six-tenths of 1 percent despite a slight drop in personal income. Orders for durable goods surged 3.4 percent for the month, but the increase was concentrated in airplanes and cars. [41.]
 
International
 
Mexican markets and the peso steadied, after a turbulent slide this week set off by the Government's decision to devalue and then to let the peso trade freely. Investors seem to be reacting cautiously to attempts by Mexican officials to explain how they intended to manage the economy after devaluing the peso. [41.]
Handmade Christmas ornaments are a growing business in Poland and the Czech Republic, bolstered by demand in the United States for traditional tree trimmings. The old European art is back in fashion, pushed by stores and catalogues. [41.]
The flamboyant former chairman of Banesto was jailed on charges of fraud and embezzlement involving more than $53 million. Banesto had been Spain's third-largest bank.[43.]
Credit Lyonnais put up for sale a Brazilian banking unit. The unit, Banco Frances e Brasileiro, is Brazil's second-largest bank. [43.]
Time Warner is asking Japanese investors in its entertainment division -- Itochu and Toshiba -- to put up as much as $300 million apiece to help the company acquire more cable television systems, a Japanese financial newspaper reported. [43.]
Companies William Randolph Hearst 3d will quit as publisher of The San Francisco Examiner, the newspaper his grandfather used as the building block of the Hearst empire. Mr. Hearst will join Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, a leading venture capital firm. [41.]
Ameritech won F.C.C. approval to offer video services in five states. The commission also gave a Sprint subsidiary approval to conduct market trials of the service in North Carolina. But the commission rejected four applications by U S West. [43.]
 
Markets
 
Blue-chip stocks advanced in light, pre-holiday trading. The Dow Jones industrials ended the week with a gain of 26.24 points. [42.]
Treasury prices were flat in a shortened session. [51.]
The dollar strengthened in thin trading. [52.]
Cotton prices climbed on signs of heavy demand. A wheat purchase by China lifted wheat and soybean prices. [52.]
 
Your Money
 
What do investors want? Well, among other things, an end to all taxes on investing would be nice, however unlikely. The approach of the new year is the time to make such wish lists. [39.]
In examining Mexican investments, buyers need to make distinctions. The plunge in the peso has dragged down the American despository receipts of many Mexican companies. But some companies, especially exporters, may stand to gain. [39.]
American Express plans to begin marketing mutual funds directly to its card holders in the coming year. [39.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Up Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
American consumers are on a late-year spending binge that may produce headaches in 1995, according to economic reports released today.
Despite a slight drop in personal income last month, consumer spending climbed briskly again in November, rising six-tenths of 1 percent and embracing a wide variety of goods and services, the Commerce Department reported. 
 Indeed, it is possible, economists say, that overextended households could cause the economy to slow more than policy makers at the Federal Reserve desire and stir fears of recession.
"What we have is strong spending and weak incomes," said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Over time, that can't last."
Personal income fell one-tenth of a percent in November, after a big 1.4 percent advance in October that largely reflected bonus payments in the auto industry and one-time subsidy payments to farmers.
Despite this squeeze, which depressed the personal savings rate last month to 4.1 percent from a 4.8 percent rate in October, consumers actually became more confident with the approach of the gift-buying holidays. The University of Michigan's confidence index was put at 95.1 for December, subscribers to its service said today, up from 91.6 in November.
In still another report on the economy today, orders to the nation's factories for long-lived goods, from camcorders to artillery shells, surged 3.4 percent in November.
Although this was a bigger advance than generally expected, close scrutiny suggested that this sector of the economy might already be softening after buttressing the business expansion for the last two years. The increase was concentrated in airplanes and cars. Orders for durables -- goods intended to last at least three years -- were up only eight-tenths of 1 percent when transportation equipment was excluded. The transportation sector rebounded by a strong 12.5 percent after a 9.5 percent plunge in October.
Orders for primary metals eased 1.2 percent, the first decline since July, and orders for industrial machinery were unchanged. Moreover, said Laurence H. Meyer, a financial consultant in St. Louis, orders for capital goods other than aircraft and military items -- a closely watched indicator of investment in new factories -- fell 1.2 percent last month.
Still, the biggest threat to the business expansion -- the last economic downturn ended in March 1991 -- is the consumer, whose spending at retail counters and for such things as medical care and college tuition accounts for two-thirds of all business activity.
Personal savings, at scarcely 4 percent for 1993 and 1994, is at the lowest rate since records began being compiled in 1929, providing little extra cushion against post-holiday bills.
More confident about their own job prospects and less worried about the future, consumers have been running up big credit card bills to finance personal spending. But some analysts wonder how long Americans can maintain the pace at which they have been borrowing. Consumer installment credit, the Federal Reserve reported early this month, grew at a 15.8 percent annual rate in October as all three categories posted double-digit increases.
"There is a lot of borrowing -- but it will slow," said David Littmann, senior economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit.
By spring, Mr. Littman added, households may be pinched as higher interest rates start to bite. Still, many analysts say the Federal Reserve can succeed in its effort to slow the pace of the economy without producing a stall. The quarter that ends next week is expected to be the second straight in which domestic output will rise at an annual pace of 4 percent or more.
"The consumer can't keep up this rapid pace," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. But he said any pullback would not be too sharp as long as job growth remained solid.
Mr. Dederick largely dismissed today's report of lower personal income because of the special factors that had produced an exceptionally big gain for October. In addition to the subsidy payments to farmers and bonuses to auto workers, there was a sharp increase, reversed in November, in the length of the workweek.
Looking forward, the consumer sentiment index may also be pointing to troubles down the road. The University of Michigan's index, though 3.5 points higher for December as a whole, eased to 95.1 at the end of the month from its midmonth reading of 97.7. Consumers' assessment of current conditions, at 104.9, is more optimistic than the 88.8 for the months ahead.
The Commerce Department's report on orders for durable goods included a 7.7 percent decline for military hardware after a 16.8 percent October drop.
Shipments of durables rebounded 2.8 percent after two straight declines while unfilled orders climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, the third straight monthly increase.

HEADLINE: Suspect in Bombing Says He's Innocent, His Lawyer Asserts

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Handcuffed to his hospital bed, fading in and out of consciousness from the morphine dulling the pain of his burns, the man charged with firebombing a subway train proclaimed his innocence on Thursday, his newly hired lawyer, Stephen J. Murphy, said.
Edward J. Leary, the unemployed computer expert who the police say created and carried the firebomb that injured 48 subway riders in lower Manhattan on Wednesday, said he was just another victim of the explosion, Mr. Murphy said. 
 "He vehemently denies his guilt," said Mr. Murphy, an outspoken lawyer whose clients have included defendants in the Howard Beach and Bensonhurst racial violence cases. "He knows nothing more than anybody else does about it. And he's appalled by all these headlines and politicians and police calling him the mad bomber."
Many of those headlines have been based on evidence the police have said they removed from Mr. Leary's home in Scotch Plains, N.J., including scribbled notes in which investigators say he referred to himself as a "mad bomber." The notes laid out a plan to extort money from the Transit Authority by setting off similar firebombs across the city, the police said.
One investigator said a phrase from the notes that stuck in his mind, apparently intended to be used in an extortion message, was: "We have several more bombs and if you pay a ransom, we will make this bomb safe."
Law enforcement officials have also said they found a trove of bomb-making supplies in Mr. Leary's den, including mayonnaise jars, wires, timers, batteries and containers of gasoline, along with instructions for building a firebomb.
But Mr. Leary told his lawyer that he never made or carried the firebomb and knew nothing about an extortion letter or the other material said to have been removed from his house, Mr. Murphy said. Mr. Murphy charged that some of what appeared to be incriminating evidence had been "made up" by the police.
"He said he was on the train," Mr. Murphy said. "I asked him if he ever had a bomb in his possession. He said absolutely not. I asked him if he ever brought it on the train. He said absolutely not. I said, 'Are your fingerprints going to be on it?' He said no."
Lieut. Robert J. Valentino, a spokesman for the Transit Authority police department, the lead law enforcement agency in the case, said investigators and technicians were still going over the evidence collected from the burned subway car. He said he could not discuss whether any fingerprints have been collected or even whether it is possible to collect them from the fragments of the crude gasoline bomb.
Lieutenant Valentino denied Mr. Murphy's contention that evidence had been concocted, saying it had been removed from Mr. Leary's house and properly tagged by several cooperating law enforcement agencies.
"He can say whatever he likes," Lieutenant Valentino said. "We are just collecting evidence and preparing the case, and disseminating accurate and timely information."
Mr. Murphy said he was only able to speak to his client for about 30 minutes Thursday night at the Cornell Medical Center burn unit before doctors told him to leave. Mr. Leary was so groggy from the morphine running through tubes into his body that he was unable to answer questions in detail, his lawyer said.
Mr. Leary is in critical condition at the hospital with burns over 40 percent of his body. Mr. Murphy said the worst burns appear to be on his client's legs and buttocks, with other significant burns on his nose, lips and chin. Although police officials have said Mr. Leary may be near death, Mr. Murphy said he doubted the situation was that severe.
Because of his condition, however, Mr. Leary was unable to discuss with his lawyer many of the unanswered questions in the case, Mr. Murphy said, including where he was going on the subway that day, why he fled to Brooklyn after the blast, and why his burns appear to be consistent with his having held the firebomb on his lap when it exploded.
Mr. Leary, 49, was arrested in his hospital bed early Thursday after the police said they discovered the notes and equipment in his home. Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, said he would probably be arraigned in the same bed next week, depending on his physical condition. She said the office had prepared a complaint charging him with nine counts of assault in the first degree, because nine of the victims have serious physical injuries. The complaint will also charge him with one count of criminal possession of a weapon, she said. Ms. Thompson said she was not certain when the complaints will be presented to a grand jury.
Law enforcement authorities said yesterday they had widened their investigation to look back at any other suspicious fires and explosions that have occurred in the city in recent years. Except for another subway fire last week that the police believe may have been linked to Mr. Leary, there is no evidence that he caused any other violence, they said.
"We're looking at it all," one investigator said. "Do we consider any of them likely? That's another question."
Police officials said they had received an anonymous tip that Mr. Leary had been a suspect in a fatal explosion in Utah. The officials said they were taking the report seriously and have contacted the Utah authorities asking them to investigate further.
Mr. Murphy said he was hired by Marguerite E. Shaller, Mr. Leary's wife, shortly after the arrest. She told him she had seen him on television and wanted a fighter, he said.
As if to demonstrate his contentiousness, Mr. Murphy immediately began excoriating police officials and politicians for trying to convict Mr. Leary while he lies in his hospital bed. He compared the case to that of O. J. Simpson, saying the authorities were leaking reams of material to make his client look bad even before a trial.
"I find it ridiculous, and completely unfair and unjustified, that the politicians and the police have already crucified a man in critical condition who cannot defend himself," Mr. Murphy said. "They've not only convicted him, they're already talking about whether they should execute him." Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Governor-elect George E. Pataki said the case was an example of why the death penalty should be enacted in New York.
Mr. Murphy said the police even gave relatives a hard time when they came to the Scotch Plains house to pick up Christmas presents for Mr. Leary's nine-year-old son, who is with family members in Binghamton, N.Y.
"It's despicable what they're doing," he said. "Once they decide you're a monster, the truth doesn't matter anymore."
Investigators said they planned to return to the Scotch Plains home last night with Federal Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents to search for additional evidence.

HEADLINE: Risk Is Cited in 6 More California Counties

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The aggressive investment practices that drove Orange County, Calif., into bankruptcy have also been used by at least six other county governments in California, according to a leading Wall Street credit-rating agency.
The agency, Moody's Investors Service Inc., reported late Thursday evening that the six counties -- Monterey, Placer, San Bernardino, San Diego, Solano and Sonoma -- had engaged in "significantly more aggressive" investment strategies than other California counties it surveyed. The strategies included investing with borrowed money, a practice called "using leverage," and investing in the complex interest-sensitive securities known as derivatives. 
 But Moody's emphasized that none of the six counties seemed in any danger of following Orange County into bankruptcy. Their use of these risky strategies was less extreme, and the local governments that invested in the funds were less likely to make sudden withdrawals.
As the Moody's report was made public, the Madera County, Calif., Office of Education warned yesterday that it might default on its public debts if the bankruptcy judge handling the Orange County case did not allow it to withdraw money it deposited in the ill-fated fund. Its request is still pending.
Alarm about Orange County prompted Moody's to survey all the pooled investment funds in California, and to screen a broad sample of about 1,400 such funds across the country. Of the 57 such funds in California, it said that 37 reported no use of leverage or derivatives.
Moody's national survey uncovered problems at only two government units, besides those whose losses had already been disclosed. Those two were Cuyahoga County, Ohio, and Walworth County, Wis.
According to the Moody's survey of California, a total of 14 counties reported using leverage or derivatives to some degree. But the six were singled out for detailed discussion, the agency said, because they "reported a significantly more aggressive use of either leverage or derivatives, or both."
According to the rating agency, "the managers of each of these pools report that they have developed or are beginning to develop strategies to address the risks posed by the nature of their pools." Moody's added, however, that it intended to talk or meet further with each pool manager "to verify information which they have provided to us in order to better assess their strategies."
For example, the Placer County Treasurer, Jenine Windeshausen, said her fund, with a book value of $378 million, had approximately 42 percent of its assets invested in derivatives, with half to three-quarters of them becoming less valuable as interest rates rose. But Ms. Windeshausen, who said her fund had "a high level of liquidity," confirmed that Moody's analysts would be meeting with her early in the year.
Tom Ford, assistant tax collector for Sonoma County, disputed some of Moody's findings. He said the agency had understated the value of the fund, which he put at $735 million, not $565 million. They agree, however, that derivatives represent about $322 million of the fund.
"But we're about equally exposed to upward or downward movements in rates," Mr. Ford said. He confirmed that since November the fund had faced two margin calls totaling $1.6 million, but he insisted that he had ample cash to cover anticipated demands. While Moody's said it would continue to monitor the fund, Mr. Ford said the agency should "either make a decision or move on." "They've just been putting us through hoops," he added.
Monterey County faces paper losses of about $16 million on its $338 million portfolio. It has also borrowed about $237 million, secured by its securities. But Louis Solton, the county treasurer and tax collector, said yesterday that the fund had sufficient cash to meet all its anticipated needs.
Moody's found that Solano County's $427 million fund had borrowed about $182 million through reverse repurchase agreements, making "significant use of derivatives." There was no answer at the county offices at the county seat of Fairfield, Calif., yesterday.
Before the Moody's report, it had been widely known that San Bernardino County and San Diego County had made substantial use of derivatives. Moody's did not raise any new alarms with respect to these funds, but said it would monitor the funds closely.
All six counties face less risk because most of their money comes from "captive" investors, local government units that are required to use the fund and cannot pull their money. Thus, unlike Orange County, they need not sell at a loss. Orange County, with enormous paper losses in its investment portfolio, was unable to raise cash to meet investor demands. It was forced to file for bankruptcy on Dec. 6, sending shock waves through the tax-exempt securities market.

HEADLINE: Peso and Mexican Stocks Calmer

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23

 BODY:
After diving almost 30 percent since the beginning of the week, the Mexican peso settled down today, closing at 4.7 to a dollar from 4.8 pesos the day before.
With the peso floating freely for the first time in seven years, the Mexican stock market also regained lost ground and the bolsa index closed at 2,339.58, a modest but encouraging gain of 1.44 percent. The Government devalued the peso from about 3.6 pesos to the dollar to 4, and then, when the move failed to calm markets, set it free. 
 Compared with the extreme volatility of financial markets earlier in the week, today's activity seemed to indicate a stabilization of the peso, at least temporarily. American depository receipts were basically flat, but serious doubts by American investors about prospects for the Mexican market lingered.
Mexico's hopes for a quick recovery from this week's financial near meltdown took a significant blow when Standard & Poor's lowered by one notch its ratings on long-term Mexican peso debt and warned that another downgrade could follow in the near future.
The rating agency also posted notice that Mexico's foreign currency debt -- the indicator that foreign investors watch most closely -- could lose its double-B rating soon. That dashes yearlong expectations that Standard & Poor's was ready to bump Mexico up one notch to the investment grade rating that would make it possible for many large United States pension funds to invest in Mexico.
"I would say now that an upgrade to investment grade is very unlikely to take place in the near term," said Lacey Gallagher, a Mexico analyst at S.& P. in New York. "The Government's management of the crisis will determine what Mexico's prospects are in the longer term."
The other major rating service, Moody's Investors Service, said it would not change its rating of Mexico, which is two notches below investment grade.
Financial analysts in Mexico and the United States said that investors seemed to be reacting cautiously to attempts by Mexican officials to explain how they intended to manage the economy after devaluing the peso.
"The difference between today and yesterday is that the Government finally came forth in New York with a more credible package of policies that will make the devaluation's success more likely," said Jorge O. Mariscal, manager of the Latin American Equity Group at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "What you saw in the markets today was an incipient but still very fragile stability."
The Mexican stock market endured another erratic session today. Companies with high foreign debt and limited exports were shunned while those companies without any foreign debt showed modest increases.
Barings Securities in Mexico was one of several brokerage houses to revise its stock recommendations because of the devaluation. Its analysts suggested avoiding consumer company stocks like Bimbo baked goods, Valle juices and department stores because they expect real wages, and the buying power of Mexican consumers, to drop.
Bank stocks are considered especially vulnerable, depending on the foreign currency loans and deposits a bank holds. Standard & Poor's today lowered its ratings on the peso-denominated notes of Banco Nacional de Mexico, Mexico's largest bank, and Banpais.
The devaluation is likely to spur travel to Mexico, according to travel agencies and wholesalers in the United States, although package tours will not drop by the same percentage as the devalued peso against the dollar.
Most American tour operators pay dollars to Mexican hotels, airlines and ground operators so those prices are unlikely to fall. But once visitors arrive in Mexico, they should find lower prices for everything from restaurant meals to discos to charter boats.
 "Travel this time of year is already bought and paid for, but next month it's going to go crazy" because of the lower prices, said Joe Tate, whose company, Mexico Wholesalers, in Houston sends 50,000 Americans a year to Mexico.
Mexico's financial crisis reached a culmination Wednesday night when the Government, unable to withstand a speculative run on the peso, was forced to free it from the trading band it had used since 1987 to control inflation and build investor confidence. The Government also turned to a standby swap line of $7 billion from the United States and Canada to help stabilize the financial market.
The new team picked by President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, which took office just three weeks ago, was dressed down by investment bankers in New York yesterday for devaluing the peso after giving an assurance that such a move was unnecessary.
The previous Mexican administration often sent representatives to New York to explain, in advance or on the same day, government actions that would affect the market. This week, American investors learned about the floating peso from news reports.
Financial analysts agree that such moves are likely to hurt Mexican workers and consumers at a time when Mexican society is already experiencing unrest. They rejected the notion that savings rates could be improved if the devaluation virtually doubled interest on credit cards, car loans and mortgages.
Mexicans expect higher rates for car loans and rising prices for tires, stereos and other imported products. Buy some analysts say the devaluation could consequently lead to a drop in imports, thus reducing the trade deficit and the foreign funds needed to finance it. Mexico's trade imbalance is considered one of the reasons the Government was forced to devaluate the peso.
Previous devaluations, especially the one that took place in 1982, caused ordinary Mexicans to panic. But today in Mexico City, most banks and money exchange firms operated normally. If prices for merchandise were raised in violation of the Government's call to freeze them, there was no public protest.
"If I had had money in the bank I would have been poorer and worse off today than I was last night before I went to sleep," said Antonio Hernandez, a 56-year-old taxi driver in Mexico City. "But I've got nothing in the bank because here we live day to day. What I earn today, I use to eat tonight."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mexican Government has called for a freeze on price rises after devaluing the peso by about 30 percent, shaking up financial markets, but one shop owner in Mexico City changed the prices of trousers anyway. (Agence France Presse)

HEADLINE: Stocks Up in Slow Day; Dow Gains 18.51 Points

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed yesterday with strong gains for the third consecutive session.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.51 points, to 3,833.43. It ended the week with a respectable gain of 26.24 points after a 116-point rally last week. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.16 point, to 459.83. The Nasdaq composite index gained 2.85 points, to 742.19, and the American Stock Exchange index gained 1.26 points, to 428.78. 
 Trading on the New York Stock Exchange slowed before the three-day holiday weekend, with 196.5 million shares traded, compared with Thursday's brisk volume of roughly 340 million. Advancing issues outpaced declining ones, 1,223 to 949. The market will be closed on Monday.
After battling rising interest rates and a fickle stock market throughout the year, many money managers were struggling to record gains for 1994.
"Everybody's scrounging for every little percentage they can get," said Brian Finnerty, senior vice president at Unterberg Harris.
The year-end "window dressing" -- with fund managers adding positions in winning stocks and dumping losers -- was the main force driving stocks, analysts said.
"This time of year you usually see people in a little more optimistic mood," Bob Dickey, a technical analyst at Dain Bosworth, said.
Latin American shares rebounded from the beating they suffered after Mexico decided first to devalue the peso and then to let the currency trade freely against the dollar. American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico were unchanged at 40 5/8 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, while A.D.R.'s of Grupo Televisa rose 1/2, to 32 7/8.
Other Latin American stocks also recovered. Telefonica de Argentina A.D.R.'s gained 1 3/8, to 51 1/8, and those of Compania de Telefonos de Chile rose 1 1/2, to 79 1/2.
Automobile stocks attracted bargain hunters for the second consecutive day, while airline stocks were also strong performers.
The General Motors Corporation gained 2 1/8, to 41 1/4, after Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette raised its fourth-quarter earnings estimate for the car maker. The Ford Motor Company advanced 1/4, to 27, and the Chrysler Corporation rose 3/4, to 48 7/8.
Airline stocks benefited from bargain hunting. Delta Air Lines surged 3 7/8, to 49 5/8. Salomon Brothers raised its rating on the stock to a "strong buy" after a Federal judge ruled that the carrier did not breach good faith in negotiating Pan Am's bankruptcy reogranization plan.
The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, rose 2, to 53.
Genentech Inc.'s stock fell sharply on signs that Roche Holdings of Switzerland had apparently passed on its opportunity to buy the rest of the company by the end of the year. Roche already owns 65 percent of Genentech, whose stock fell 4 3/4, to 47 3/4.
Shares of the Immulogic Pharmaceutical Corporation rose sharply in Nasdaq trading amid speculation of a takeover by Marion Merrell Dow. Immulogic gained 1 1/2, to 8 1/2.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.24 point, to 250.95.
In Japan, financial markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Emperor's birthday.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Are Flat in Short Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed yesterday in a shortened trading session.
More signs of economic growth failed to quicken pre-holiday trading, which was thin and ended in New York at 2 P.M. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to 968/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.83 percent, from 7.85 percent on Thursday. Traders were quick to note that yesterday was the ninth consecutive session in which the yield on the long bond traded in a range of 7.84 percent to 7.87 percent.
The yield on the two-year note was unchanged at 7.71 percent -- 12 basis points less than the long bond and the smallest yield spread between the two maturities since June 1990. Traders say such a narrowing of yields is a sign that the market expects the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again soon.
Among shorter and intermediate maturities, rates on bills and yields on notes continued to rise on signs that economic growth was continuing at a brisk pace and that the Fed would indeed act to keep inflation from accelerating.
Among the data released yesterday were durable goods orders for November and personal income and spending data for November.
The Commerce Department reported yesteday that orders for durable goods -- products ranging from washing machines to military aircraft -- increased 3.4 percent in November, the biggest advance since August.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government issues trading strategist for CS First Boston, said the durable goods gain seemed a bit strong, noting that forecasts had ranged from increases of 1.5 percent to 1.9 percent.
But orders for durable goods, he said, are "extremely volatile, if you note the 6.2 percent gain in August contrasted against the 3.9 percent drop the month before." He attributed much of the volatility to the transportation component; orders for aircraft and ships can swing widely from month to month.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said personal income fell one-tenth of 1 percent in November, while spending rose six-tenths of 1 percent.
Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, said Fed policy makers might have come to the realization at the last meeting that despite higher interest rates, financial conditions generally remained conducive to further business expansion. "The lending constraints that tended to slow down the expansion appeared to have given way to more accommodative lending policies by banks," he said.
As result, Mr. Sherman said, the Fed is likely to take more aggressive steps. "Clearly the economy is maintaining momentum," he said. "Friday's reports on new orders for durable goods and personal consumption expenditure in November reinforce that view."
