HEADLINE: Habitats/Greenwich, Conn.;
An Ordinary Suburban Tract House, Transformed

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, CONN.

 BODY:
IT BEGAN life as a box, an ordinary tract house in a subdivision off a winding country road here.
It took a year, but the 2,600-square foot house was ripped apart and put back together again with only two rooms left the same -- and 4,200 square feet added. 
 Besides more than doubling the size of the house, purchased in 1989 by Peter Wright for $845,000 a few weeks before he met his wife, Wendy, through the personals in New York magazine, the owners created an entirely different structure: The box was transformed into a rambling extravaganza inspired by grand turn-of-the-century shingle-style beach cottages.
"He'd just bought the house and he was so proud to have bought a house in Greenwich," said Mrs. Wright, a small, vivacious woman. "When I finally saw it I almost keeled over; he had told me it was a Dutch colonial and you can imagine what I thought when I saw it: I couldn't believe I'd fallen in love with a man who had bought this."
A small color photograph of the house in its original incarnation sits in the new three-story, skylighted front hall of the transformed house. It shows a four-square white box with an enormous mansard roof -- the kind seen so often on pizza parlors and dry cleaners along commercial strips.
"I couldn't understand why he didn't tear it down and start all over again," said Mrs. Wright -- a sentiment shared by the architect in charge of the renovation, Daniel Louis Goldner, who called the 1971 house an "esthetic nightmare."
"I felt that economically it was better to keep as much as we could," explained Mr. Wright, an independent financial consultant with offices here. With all the landscaping and materials, including the new kitchen cabinets, the price of the renovation still approached $1.5 million, Mr. Wright said, sticking to his opinion that he had saved money by renovating.
According to Mrs. Wright, the decision not to tear down also may have had something to do with the wall-to-wall pickled maple bookcase Mr. Wright had just installed in what was then the living room.
"He'd just had that bookcase built in and he wasn't about to tear it out," she said. The living room, done in the beiges and taupes popular several years ago, remains as a den at the front of the house, supplanted by the 20- by 28-foot family room with a 10-foot ceiling and a massive stone fireplace, added to the west side of the house during the renovation.
"Those beiges were popular then," Mrs. Wright said, "but I wanted a lot more color." The wall-to-wall carpet in the new family room, for instance, is a Turkish-inspired print with a deep red background.
THE Wrights had requested a big new house -- by the time they decided on the massive renovation, they had two children and were expecting a third -- but they had no idea what the house should look like. "That's not my field," Mr. Wright explained. "I said how I wanted the house to work -- the practical things -- and I left the design to Dan."
So Mr. Goldner drew up at least a dozen different houses: from LeCorbusier to Edward Durrell Stone to Lutyens. The pencil sketches were drawn on tracing paper, and he went through the pile, slowly lifting the corner of each drawing to show the one below. Gradually, the tracing paper drawings grew more detailed, as the many gables of the final design emerged.
"We settled on a shingle-style house that relies on a composition that is quirky and idiosyncratic," Mr. Goldner said, adding that the house took six months to design. "The process was intensive, the clients were very patient."
"We love the look of the house," Mr. Wright said. "It has a lot of character."
"There's a big boom in Greenwich now," Mrs. Wright continued, "and all of the houses are 10,000-square-foot brick Georgians, very formal. I can't see anybody with a family building them -- all my friends will hate me -- but this seems more like a home and not a palace."
One of the remarkable things about the house -- visible most clearly from the outside -- is the number of different window configurations used by the architect. In the rear, for instance, there are eight different types of windows -- small-paned double hung, bay, Palladian and small squares.
There is a white wooden arbor stretching along the mud room in the rear and a balustrade outside the master bedroom, overlooking the swimming pool. The wood-shingled roof dips and soars, creating what Mr. Wright calls "all the different bumps."
The house was added to symmetrically: the master bedroom atop the large family room on one side and the garage and more bedrooms on the other. On the second floor, only one small room -- Mr. Wright's study -- remains as it was, a small space with simple Formica-covered shelves, overlooking the new brick hexagonal driveway.
The driveway is just one of the most obvious changes to the landscape. Looking to the right of the front of the house from the driveway, the lawn suddenly turns into a tall grassy berm with scattered trees, a hillock that completely hides the four other houses in the subdivision.
BUT the hillock was not created to hide the house. Instead, it is the level of the side lawn that is artificial; the hillside originally sloped down to the house. When the house was extended for the family room side, bulldozers dug out for the side lawn.
In the back, trees were cleared to give a clean view to the three-acre fishing pond bordered by marsh grasses. An enormous field rock was made more prominent, creating a minimountain and built-in play area for Zachary, 3, Zara, 2, and Jake, 8 months old. Beyond the rock, its green netting only partly camouflaged, is the batting cage, with its mechanism that spits out balls to Mr. Wright and his friends. The other day a crew rolled up p the netting and stored it for the winter, an event Mr. Wright noted sadly.
Altogether, the Wrights own seven and a half acres at the end of a cul-de-sac. Stone walls that are several hundred years old stretch along the other side of the street, echoed by the new stone walls -- unmortared like the old ones -- that were built on each side of the Wright driveway. The huge house -- which seems larger than its 6,800 square feet -- nevertheless does not dwarf its surroundings.
"What possessed him to buy it?" Mrs. Wright asked rhetorically. "It was the land that possessed him."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Chain Drugstores;
Drugstore Chains Turn to Manhattan

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
FOR Manhattan drugstores, the lines of demarcation used to be clearly drawn. The local pharmacy, with its white-jacketed pharmacist who dispensed homilies along with high-priced pills, ruled the residential neighborhoods.
Commercial areas were largely the domain of the ubiquitous Duane Reade, home of the off-price health and beauty aids and just-the-facts-ma'am pharmacy: Present the prescription along with the insurance card, pick up the pills later. 
 But what is this? Duane Reade on upper Broadway and on the upper East Side, in the heart of residential-land? Rite-Aid taking over more than a dozen supermarkets from the Red Apple Group? Woolworth with 13 Rx Place Drug Marts either open or planned in Manhattan alone? Even Walgreen, one of the most formidable competitors among the drug store chains, is looking for Manhattan sites.
"The drugstore chains are coming en masse, it's like a fever," said Samuel J. Jemal, who just put CVS into an 8,800-square-foot store in 270 Eighth Avenue, his building on 24th Street.
Brokers have caught the bug, too. "Any broker worth his salt is cultivating drugstores to fill vacant sites," said Michael N. Hirschfeld, head of his own brokerage.
Drugstore chains are snapping up former supermarkets, bank branches, clothing stores, almost any decent-sized spaces. Chains like CVS, Genovese and Rite-Aid that once barely looked at Manhattan are pouring in. Manhattan companies like McKay Drugs, for decades content with one or two stores, now have at least half a dozen, and more on the mental drawing boards.
Manhattan's lure is understandable. According to Chain Drug Review, New York City as a whole represents a $2.7 billion market for drugstores; Manhattan has the densest shopping population in New York.
Duane Reade accounts for 14 percent of the New York sales, leaving lots of room for other chains to grow.
"Competitors will go to the Duane Reades, take a thousand notes, and pick off as much as they can," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company brokerage.
Manhattan is not an ideal place to operate. Shrinkage -- retail parlance for theft -- is high. So is traffic congestion, making deliveries problematic. And the 12,000-square-feet stores that dot suburbia do not fit in cramped Manhattan storefronts.
But with new mall construction at a virtual standstill, chains that want to grow must go to urban areas. When they do, they find the sheer volume of shoppers an ample payback for the problems.
"Our Manhattan store has the same volume as suburban stores twice its size," said Herbert J. Kett, vice chairman of Genovese Drug Stores, which opened its first Manhattan store, on East 68th Street, in November 1993 and will soon open another in an old Bolton's store on 8th Street, between University and Fifth Avenues.
Woolworth's is a new convert, too. The chain has turned eight money-losing five-and-dimes in Manhattan to Rx Place Drug Marts, and five more conversions are planned next year.
"The demand for health and beauty aids has outgrown the demand for general merchandise," said Frances E. Trachter, a Woolworth's spokeswoman.
The soft real-estate market of the last few years has heightened Manhattan's appeal. A lot of space has become available at the $55- to $60-a-foot annual rents that chain drugstores can afford. Duane Reade has taken over a number of former Chemical Bank branches. Rite-Aid is said by John A. Catsimatidis, Red Apple's chairman, to be eager to assume the leases on many of his supermarkets. Rite-Aid itself did not return a reporter's calls.
"Rite-Aid is a public company that needed a major presence in the city where Wall Street is," Mr. Catsimatidis said.
Landlords, loath to carve big spaces into lots of little storefronts, are often quite happy to let the drugstores in. "A lot of co-ops, particularly, don't want to play slice-and-dice with retail space," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty.
And if the space is not perfect, drugstores can make do.
"A DRUGSTORE can make a bowling alley work," said Faith H. Consolo, a managing director of the retail brokerage Garrick-Aug. "They put the pharmacy in back, the beauty stuff up front, fill in with supermarket products, and draw the customers in."
The chains are plunging, not wading, into Manhattan's waters. They are banking that by opening a lot of stores at once they will build name recognition, brand loyalty for house brands, and get a lot more bang for their advertising and distribution bucks. Duane Reade, for example, delivers to its 51 stores daily from a central warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, while Genovese has a warehouse in Bohemia, L.I.
Increased computerization has also made rapid expansion more economic. Several chains affix price stickers and bar codes to items at the warehouse, and the codes are scanned at the cash register. That cuts down on the amount of skilled labor needed at the stores, and enables the chain to keep track of what needs to be restocked.
"New York has always been the home of inefficient, high-priced retailers, but computerized big chains are changing all that," said Allan G. Mottus, a New York health and beauty aids consultant.
The drugstore trade associations are desperately seeking ways to level the playing field for smaller stores. Next month Chain Drug Marketing Associates, in Northbrook, Ill., will begin buying some 360 vitamins, analgesics and other products in bulk, and resell them at cost to small stores that can then sell them at private label prices. It will offer 200 more items April 1.
"This is the only way that small stores can get the economies that the Walgreens of the world have," said James Devine, the association's president.
The changing dynamics of health care threaten small stores more than juggernaut competition. According to the Alexandria, Va.-based National Association of Chain Drug Stores, prescription drugs account for 36 percent of chain drugstore sales, and over-the-counter medications for 14 percent or so. Until recently, the huge profit margins on such items made them the fulcrum on which a drugstore's earnings turned. .
But now, many consumers have insurance plans that cover all but, say, $5 of the cost of a prescription. Then insurance companies pay the participating drugstores a fraction of what they could charge the patients. Nonprescription drug sales are hurting, too, as patients learn that a $5 prescription pain killer is cheaper for them than most branded analgesics. "The margins on pharmacies have gone from about 40 percent to the teens," Mr. Devine said.
Still, since pharmacies do draw shoppers in, drugstores are signing up for as many health plans as they can. And many small stores are getting locked out, because insurance companies do not want to do the paperwork for 50 stores when they can sign one master contract with a 50-store chain.
Some owners of small stores profess not to care. Block Pharmacy, on Third Avenue and 74th Street -- across from a Duane Reade -- does not take insurance plans, stocks high-priced beauty items, and keeps customer data on 3-by-5 cards.
"We were scared when Duane Reade came in, but our business hasn't dropped," said Madeline J. Tartell, Block's owner. "We're keeping customers who want advice from pharmacists and cosmeticians who know them and the products."
Bruce Weitz, Duane Reade's chief executive, concedes that they are. "The independents can't compete on price and assortment," he said. "Their game is service."
Mr. Weitz is finally ready to play that game. Duane Reade has gone to 24-hour operations at its 57th Street and Seventh Avenue store, and plans round-the-clock hours at three other stores soon. It is offering free delivery from some stores in residential areas. And, although he refuses to say what, Mr. Weitz says he is doing something about the difficulties that customers have in getting help from Duane Reade's many non-English-speaking salespeople.
All of the drugstores try to present themselves as vital amenities. But they admit that not all landlords buy the argument.
"WE don't spend thousands on mirrors and steel and glass to sell toothpaste," said Ely Tawil, president of McKay. "So yes, we've been rejected by people who want a more upscale use."
Landlords readily concede that preference. Manhattan House, the huge rental building that stretches from 65th to 66th Streets and from Second to Third Avenue, has 15,000 square feet -- 6,000 feet at street level, about 8,500 feet below ground -- of retail space available on Third Avenue. "Every major supermarket and drugstore has expressed interest," said Bruce A. Spiegel, a senior vice president at Rose Associates who handles the building's retail leasing. He wants to hold out for a high end apparel or furniture store.
"On Second Avenue, we'd rent to a drugstore, because there are a lot of service tenants there already," he said. "But this space is surrounded by high-profile stores."
Mr. Spiegel is rejecting drugstores for a different reason at 25 University Place, the 8th Street residential building that has a supermarket whose lease expires next year. "With Genovese opening around the corner, it's not the best use for the space," he said.
It was a potential supermarket glut that got Genovese its first store. Just about the time that Genovese wanted to come into Manhattan, a Food Emporium opened on Third Avenue and 68th Street. Rudin Management, which owns the retail space at 215 East 68th Street, was happy to replace an existing supermarket whose lease was expiring with a Genovese store.
"When another supermarket is opening down the block, putting a discount drugstore in a residential building is a no-brainer," said Louis Somoza, Rudin's vice president of commercial leasing.
Class A commercial buildings require more gray matter. Often, they insist that the stores agree to copious design rules. But when they do, commercial landlords, too, are happy to have them.
"We have standards for signage, graphics, anything on display," said Kate D. Coburn, vice president for retail leasing at Rockefeller Center, which has two Value Drug stores. "These are good-looking stores, and a great amenity for tenants."
Drugstores are also becoming a great bulwark for recession-battered landlords. Ms. Consolo, who handles leasing at 222 Broadway, at Fulton Street, persuaded the building's owner to combine two small stores into one and rent it to a drugstore. "Discounted health and beauty aids are recession-proof," Ms. Consolo said.
All of the drugstores are marching into each other's geographical and product-mix territory in attempts to increase market share. They are staying open later, offering free delivery, and changing their product mixes -- say, carrying more housewares and baby products in residential areas, more stationery in commercial ones -- to adapt to areas that were once alien to them.
"The drugstores have all covered their own A markets, and must look at other neighborhoods to expand," said Mr. Seligman, the Gordon broker.
The local chains scoff at the newcomers' chances. "The national chains don't understand how to operate without wide aisles and 10 checkouts," said Mr. Tawil, McKay's president. "They don't know what to do when the clock is ticking at $50, $60 or $70 a square foot instead of $12."
Nor does Mr. Tawil seem afraid of Duane Reade. Mr. Fox, the New Spectrum broker, warned Mr. Tawil that Duane Reade was opening in an old Lamston store across the street from the store that McKay wanted to open on 75th Street and Third Avenue. "Ely's reaction was simply, 'Oh, that's O.K.,' " Mr. Fox recalled.
Mr. Tawil insists that his wider range of products will win out. Other chain executives just feel the market can accommodate more players. "Manhattan has a tremendous population that is not being serviced properly," said an executive with CVS.
Although they will not allow themselves to be quoted, several of the rival executives also said that Duane Reade is a less formidable competitor since Bain Capital, a Boston-based investment company, bought the chain from the Cohen family in 1992. Brokers say they hear that comment a lot, too.
"People are not as afraid of an investment company as they are of an entrepreneurial family," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Retail Services.
Retorted Duane Reade's Mr. Weitz, who noted that Bain has opened 15 new stores: "We've had record sales and profits since we took them over."
ACTUALLY, the Cohens are not out of the picture. Ronnie and Leon Cohen, sons of Ely Cohen, one of the three founding brothers, recently opened a Price Depot on Broadway and Fulton Street. The family signed a five year noncompete agreement that prohibits it from running pharmacies and that restricts the percentage of sales that can come from health and beauty aids. So for now, the store is heavy on household goods, books, foods and similar sundries.
When reached, both Ely and Leon Cohen declined to be interviewed. But brokers say they definitely plan to expand.
So does Duane Reade. Mr. Weitz says his chain will "expand substantially through new stores and acquisitions" over the next few years. But he concedes it may not be easy. "Spaces are getting harder to find and rents are going up," he said.
Indeed, it may be real estate scarcities rather than lethal competition, that applies the brakes to drug store growth.
"A mind-boggling amount of space has been gobbled up by Daffy's, by HMV, by the Gap, by other nondrug chains," said Newmark's Mr. Friedman. "You get enough of these tenants, and there won't be any space available for anyone."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
New Life Over the Store

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
THE streets of New York City's neighborhoods are lined with older two- to four-story buildings with a store on the ground floor and an apartment or two above.
Most were built around the turn of the century to house immigrant families pouring in from Europe. Such people were accustomed to living in the same building as their small-business enterprises. And for a while they could not afford to do otherwise. 
 Eventually, all that changed. The idea of living above the store lost favor and the upstairs was rented to transient tenants. The neighborhoods declined. The store itself may even have been boarded up for a while. If a buyer did come along it was frequently an absentee investor who had no emotional ties to the area and little interest in holding on when times got tough.
Thus anyone interested in buying or refinancing one of these small mixed-use buildings had a hard time finding anyone willing to provide a mortgage. "These properties fell through the cracks," said Patrick Niland, managing partner with the First Funding Group of Rochester, mortgage brokers who deal primarily in New York City properties.
Aside from other drawbacks, he said, the buildings were considered too small to make them worth the paperwork involved in initiating a conventional commercial loan, which was how they were classified.
The problem became even more severe in the late 80's and early 90's when commercial lending in general dried up in the wake of the sharp declines in the larger commercial property market.
Now, however, there is new hope for anyone who favors this sort of housing. Lenders are rethinking their posture as immigrants pour into the neighborhoods and revitalize the streets with thriving restaurants, ethnic food stores and other businesses.
These people once again favor the idea of living above their stores. They include Russian Jews in Brighton Beach, Haitians in East Flatbush and Asians in Sunset Park, among others.
Other reasons enticing the mainstream lending community back into these buildings is the need to find new business after the end of the refinancing boom. Also, they discovered that ethnic banks were doing very well in this market niche. Further, they could still get away with charging a slightly higher interest rate than that in the more competitive climate governing the residential mortgage market.
Anyone looking for a mortgage on one of these properties should therefore no longer feel compelled to take the first loan opportunity that falls into his or her lap.
Cross County Savings of Middle Village in Queens, for example, began mixed-use lending three months ago. The Atlantic Bank of New York is making its first commitment this month.
Others already in the market include the Green Point Savings Bank, Astoria Federal Savings, Independent Savings, Maspeth Federal Savings and Cross County Federal Savings.
But these mixed-use mortgages will still be slightly more costly and restrictive than the average home loan. Typically borrowers will have to pay two or three points as an origination fee and about one or two percentage points extra in interest charges.
They will also have to come up with at least 25 percent of the purchase price. Very few lenders can be tempted to finance more than 70 percent because of the continued perception of added risk and the inability to resell these loans on the secondary investor market.
Lenders also expect the borrower to have a sizable personal stake in the premises "because this way they will be less likely to walk," said Thomas Nixon, a vice president at the Independent Savings Bank.
"You also worry more about their ability to keep paying each month if business tails off and the store fails," said Kenneth Rudzwick, executive vice president at Maspeth Federal Savings.
That's one reason why most of these mixed-use loan commitments are being based more heavily on the inherent value of the property than the wherewithal of the borrower -- an approach known as equity lending.
Green Point, for example, is not even bothering with the normal financial verifications connected with the borrower except for a thorough credit check. "We would rather base the loan on property value," said Dale Ng, its vice president and senior underwriter.
A few banks, however, will allow part of the borrower's 30 percent down to come from other sources. For instance, at Green Point, someone else (typically the seller) is allowed to provide up to 10 percent of that 30 percent.
Borrowers should also expect the term of the loan to be capped at 10 or 15 years instead of the residential norm of 25 to 30 years. However, it can now be structured as a self-liquidating loan, meaning that the principal can be paid off by the end of the term.
In the past, a mixed-use borrower -- if he were lucky enough to get the loan at all -- usually had to suffer with a three- or five-year balloon, which required continual refinancing with little principal reduction.
This was the struggle that faced George Louis, longtime owner of a 4,000-square-foot mixed-use building at Lexington Avenue and East 75th Street. It houses his Skyline Greek Restaurant on the first floor and basement level and has a duplex apartment above where he lives with his family.
This month, Mr. Louis became the first property owner to gain a commitment under the Atlantic Bank's new mixed-use policy. He was approved for a $500,000 loan. The building, which he has owned since 1973, carries a current market value of $1.9 million.
Most lenders will also require a personal guarantee and expect the cash flow from the store plus any income from the apartments above to readily cover mortgage payments. And they will look more favorably upon the borrower who has maintained accounts at the bank or intends to become an owner-occupier.
Finally, don't be alarmed if the approval process drags on for two months or more. Despite a generally more hospitable climate, lenders are still treading warily.

HEADLINE: Headed South: Why One Couple Is Leaving the State

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THIS month, David O. Thorp packed his car and a small trailer and drove out of Connecticut, heading south to join his wife, Elizabeth, in Macon, Ga., where they have bought a home. The Thorps have left the state because both lost their jobs and saw little hope of getting others. In doing so, they became two more statistics for Connecticut as a state that is losing population.
A major difference between the departure of David Thorp and the other emigrants of 1994 is that for close to a decade and a half he has helped run the state he is leaving. For seven consecutive two-year terms, he has been a member of the General Assembly, the representative from District 89 that included his home town of Cheshire and also the towns of Prospect and Bethany. The reason he remained in Connecticut until December was to complete his last term. His wife has been in Georgia for several months. 
 Mr. Thorp, who is 62 and easy to recognize as the character who putted around Cheshire once in a while in a 1923 Model T Ford, was an early victim of the state's economic woes. Six years ago, he was laid off from Pratt & Whitney after 16 years teaching computer science. He and several others who were also laid off have filed a suit, charging age discrimination, that is currently wending its way through Federal court.
The loss of a full-time job really hurt him, he said. "I was part of the Puritan work ethic. I thought staying out of work was sinful." Eventually, he found some work in a little company in the town of Plymouth where he had been employed 30 years before, but that only lasted for several months. Since then, he and wife have depended on his legislative pay, less than $20,000 a year, and her salary as an underwriter with Kemper Insurance.
In 1993, however, the Thorps' economic base really unraveled. Mrs. Thorp, who is 57, lost her job on her 19th anniversary with the company when Kemper drastically cut the work force at its Connecticut office in Wallingford. And David Thorp lost a bid to become Cheshire's town clerk. He said he was refused the Republican nomination after he was told he was too old. So he ran as an independent and was badly beaten by the Republican candidate in a three-way race. He and Elizabeth decided it was time to leave Connecticut.
They chose Macon because they knew the area. One of their two grown children, both of whom had left Connecticut earlier for economically greener pastures, had settled there. Before he departed a state where he has lived most of his life and where he was educated -- he graduated from Yale in 1954 -- Mr. Thorp offered many opinions on how Connecticut got into its present woeful economic state. In doing so, he also admitted that he could have been a better member of the General Assembly. "I was hard-nosed and I tried to do the right thing," he said. "But now I might wish I had caught on to how to make deals and swap favors. I might have been more effective."
In any case, he said the great catalyst for the state's downfall was the educational enhancement act of the late 1980's that resulted in Connecticut school teachers becoming the highest salaried in the country.
"It was a dreadful mistake. It was the peak of excesses in Connecticut," he said. Despite the money that continues to be allocated, the act has failed in its mission to better educate students and make them more capable of competing in today's complicated society, he said. "It hasn't done diddly," he concluded, judging from academic tests in comparison to other states.
Mr. Thorp also supplies some evidence to demonstrate that he is not just one more anti-education legislator looking for a scapegoat: His father was superintendent of schools in Cheshire from 1946 to 1967.
What the enhancement act really did, Mr. Thorp said, was not only to raise the salary range dramatically in the entire educational spectrum -- "the superintendents and principals had to get so much percentage more than teachers" -- but also to inspire raising other municipal salaries proportionally.
"Connecticut's gotten into trouble with humungous municipal wages. We've got 169 towns living extremely high off the hog and that's a reflection of the educational salaries," he said. The cost of town government is so high today, he added, that "we should have more regional type of governments. It's kind of quaint and kind of nice to have 169 towns, but I don't think it's affordable."
The precipitous rise in the cost of schools and governments led to the state income tax, Mr. Thorp said. "It's all so perverse."
By the time Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was elected Governor four years ago, Mr. Thorp added, an income tax was necessary. "We couldn't survive without it." But he voted against it on what he calls a technicality. "There was no spending limitation that went with it."
He is also opposed, he said, to millions of dollars in economic aid packages the Weicker Administration has given to keep certain businesses and industries in the state or to attract others from out of state.
"Connecticut is on the list of dumb states that give away the family store," he said. One of the best examples, he added, was the incentive package offered Swiss Bank to leave Manhattan for Fairfield County. "It is stupid to fragment the New York financial marketing industry."
And, Mr. Thorp said, if some old industries in Connecticut are unable to compete in today's world they should simply be allowed to die.
Regardless, he is now through with it all in Connecticut, just as a Republican administration is taking over after two decades. That doesn't bother him. He is off to the South where he does not expect to find a job but which he now feels has a much more dynamic culture than Connecticut and where the living is less expensive. He and his wife sold their two-bedroom house in Cheshire for $165,000 and bought a four-bedroom in Macon for $121,000. He thinks they will be happier there. Life in Connecticut has not been so hot the last few years.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Changing Landmark Windows
 
Q The windows in our condominium building are old and allow easy access for drafts, dirt and noise. We would like to install insulated, energy-efficient windows. However, our building is landmarked. We have heard windows cannot be replaced because doing so would change the exterior appearance. 
 What right does either a condominium board or unit owner have to replace windows? What if the replacement is similar in appearance? Is a variance from the landmark law necessary? Are energy conservation and occupant comfort grounds for a variance? . . . G. Gilbert, Manhattan.
 
A The windows can legally be replaced, with approval from the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, said George Calderaro, a commission spokesman.
"The commission regulates, reviews and approves window replacements on a regular basis," Mr. Calderaro said. "The commission has window guidelines. If they are followed, a permit will be issued on the staff level. If a proposed window does not fit within the existing guidelines, an individual unit owner or a co-op or condominium board can come to the commission with an alternative proposal."
Mr. Calderaro said the writer should check with the condominium board to see whether a master plan for window replacement has already been approved by the commission. "If there is no plan, the commission does encourage boards to develop a replacement window for the entire building. The plan can be implemented over time. We don't recommend changing all the windows if doing so is not necessary."
Having a master plan approved is the recommended method, he said, although plans can also be approved for an individual unit. "With a multi-unit building it is probably easier to come in with a master plan," he said. "It assures the uniform appearance of the building. And it also makes doing the work more economical, because one contractor can do the work for the entire building."
 
When Co-op Board Rejects and Rejects
 
Q I own a unit in a large co-op. Can a co-op board reject potential buyers without reason, even when the couple is financially well off and is paying cash for the unit? Can a rejected party reapply a few months later? The board does not respond to letters I have sent asking about my options in the situation.
Is there no law that requires the board to make the owner aware of certain reasons for rejection to avoid constant payment to the board for each prospective buyer and be rejected over and over again?
If the transfer did not take place can any of the money given to the board for the interview be returned? . . . Lisa Jusko, Manhattan.
 
A There are no laws explicitly governing the procedures a co-op board must follow in passing upon a prospective buyer of an apartment, said Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
"In general, co-ops are free to reject any prospective purchaser for any reason other than those defined as discriminatory under the law," Mr. Weinstein said. "While there is much controversy among co-ops as to whether or not reasons for rejection should be given, I recommend to my cooperatives that the building attorney provide reasons for rejection to achieve four goals."
Those goals, he said, are "to satisfy the co-op's obligations to the selling shareholder, provide guidance for obtaining an acceptable purchaser, refute possible claims that the rejection was based on discrimination, and provide an opportunity to the rejected purchaser to give additional information that may satisfy the co-op."
If a claim of discrimination is raised, the co-op will be forced by the courts or administrative agencies to provide the reasons for rejection, he said. "Providing them at an early stage of the process may curtail expensive litigation or administrative procedures," he said.
Mr. Weinstein said the writer "may offer to the co-op a willingness to provide additional information about a rejected purchaser that could satisfy their reasonable objections." If no help is received from the co-op board, he said, "you may wish to examine whether there are any particular traits of your purchaser that may be protected by one of the antidiscrimination laws."
As to the fees, he said, "most co-ops argue that they cover the cost of processing each application and are earned by the co-op and therefore are not refundable."

LENGTH: 239 words

HEADLINE: On Farmland Preservation

 BODY:
In the recent article about New Jersey's Farmland Preservation Program ("Farmland Preservation Is Lagging"), the number of acres preserved was compared with the number of acres developed since the program began. This is worse than comparing apples with oranges.
The Farmland Preservation Program is not trying to compete with real estate development. To do so would be absurd and a losing proposition. The program's goal is to save key farms in important agricultural areas, thus helping to stabilize farming by showing it has a future there. 
 Each farm saved also helps nearby farm-related businesses, like equipment dealers, and this in turn helps to preserve a micro-economy, which in turn demands little in government services, in perpetuity. The point is, while the number of farms saved may now be small, the impact is multiplied because of preservation's ultimate effect on the larger economy.
Development costs taxpayers untold millions in infrastructure and services, as shown in the study performed at Rutgers University when New Jersey was preparing its state plan. Preserving farmland is a good deal for taxpayers. The challenge is to tell citizens how many tax dollars are being spent every day as governments struggle to serve ever increasing numbers of homes in formerly rural areas.
 
DEBORAH BOWERS
 
Ms. Bowers is editor of Farmland Preservation Report, a national newsletter based in Street, Md.

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
NEWARK, Dec. 25, 2014 -- The executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pledged yesterday that Lincoln Tunnel and George Washington Bridge tolls would hold the line for another year without any major price increases.
"The $150 toll is safe until 2016," Stanley Brezenoff 2d announced. But the director added that in 2016, tolls "will almost certainly rise," to cover an anticipated $400 billion budget shortfall. A source close to the agency, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the charge at the tollbooth was likely to rise to $200. 
 The bistate agency was said to be prepared for widespread revolt on the part of motorists. "Not since 1994, when my father announced a toll hike for 1996 in a time of low inflation, has there been such opposition to a toll increase," Mr. Brezenoff said. His father was authority director at the time.
Mr. Brezenoff said that in the previous century it was laughable that motorists had opposed an increase of only a dollar. He added that future generations would view the proposed 2016 fare increase as "something that was just as trivial as an extra dollar was in 1994."
The director assured the public that the authority would do all it could to help budget-conscious commuters. "Low-cost monthly tickets will now be available," he said at a midmorning press conference in the Newark Trump Tower, "and a frequent-driver mileage plan will be adopted."
Under questioning from reporters about the toll raise, Mr. Brezenoff argued that the proposed bridge and tunnel tolls for 2016 were "quite a bargain in comparison to the new $10 Garden State Parkway tolls."
Last month the parkway raised its tolls and added 100 more tollbooths, increasing the cost of traversing the entire 173-mile parkway to about $1,200. "I think you'll agree that our planned $200 bridge and tunnel toll gives quite good value in comparison to that," Mr. Brezenoff said.
Several questioners, however, pointed out that historically, Port Authority tolls have generally been the equivalent of three times the price of a New York City transit token. Thanks to the recent citywide fare increase, the new $30 subway token is well under that ratio. By that 3-to-1 calculation, authority tolls should be no higher than $100.
Mr. Brezenoff countered, however, that New York City had been unable to raise its transit fares much higher after the Metrocard debacle. He referred to the $2 billion worth of electronic turnstile equipment that had to be scrapped after fewer than 2 percent of New Yorkers bought the Metrocard.
"If the authority's future $200 tunnel and bridge toll is not adopted," Mr. Brezenoff said, "the only way to avert financial disaster would be to set up additional tollbooths at regular intervals within our Lincoln, Holland and Clinton Tunnels, the way the Garden State Parkway has done."
Mr. Brezenoff also announced that there had been little progress in the decades-old lawsuit with New York City that will "get our airports back," he said. The Port Authority has inhabited legal limbo ever since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made good his election pledge and raffled off La Guardia and John F. Kennedy Airports to private enterprise in 1995.
The Port Authority lawsuit, which has dragged on endlessly in the discovery process, has cost the agency $72 billion to date, "and the meter is still running," Mr. Brezenoff said.
Although private companies have managed to operate La Guardia and Kennedy at half the cost while improving service, Mr. Brezenoff said those airports "were denied the benefit of the Port Authority's interior designers and its monorail expertise."
He added: "Our studies have shown that many travelers are comforted by the drab decor of Newark Airport, and it enables them to feel relaxed. Many have felt so much at home there that they have conquered their fear of flying. In fact, our research shows that many fliers are intimidated by the cheerfulness and charming design of the new La Guardia and Kennedy airports."
As for the Newark Airport monorail, the authority announced another delay that will postpone its completion to "early 2017," Mr. Brezenoff said. Begun in 1992, the monorail has experienced a series of construction problems. Motorists have been inconvenienced for most of two decades thanks to the construction closing of parking lots at the airport.
The authority announced that new Newark Airport parking spaces have been made available for motorists miles to the north on Route 3 "because that highway is always a parking lot anyway," Mr. Brezenoff said.
The new parking spaces are "only a few minutes' travel" from the airport, he added. The monorail system itself may be extended to the Route 3 parking lot if construction is delayed long enough.
Mr. Brezenoff termed as "laughable" the report in New Jersey Newsday that the authority was planning to construct personal Hovercraft barriers at the Hudson River. The newspaper said the intention was to prevent the many Garden State owners of these vehicles from crossing to New York illegally, without paying tolls.
"We feel our Port Authority Immigration Police are perfectly capable of interdicting any illegal transport across state lines," he said.
In a more upbeat announcement, Mr. Brezenoff announced that the authority had purchased from the ill-fated Denver airport "its state-of-the-art baggage-shredding equipment," he said.
The equipment will be used at Newark Airport. "Until now, we've been able to give the average flier's bags a real pounding and stomping, but we've never had shredding capability before," he said.
In other news, the authority announced that planning is well under way for the agency's proposed vehicular bridge from the West Side of Manhattan to the Meadowlands. "It's essential that this bridge be completed to help all the New York fans who have to drive to the Meadowlands to see Yankees, Mets, Giants, Jets, Rangers, Knicks, Devils and Nets games," he said.
The bridge was deemed necessary by the State Legislature to avoid any razing of houses in those New Jersey communities located in the highway right-of-way between the Hudson River and the Meadowlands. The bridge has come under attack from environmentalists, who say its high profile may pose a danger to migrating birds.
Last year the authority dropped its lawsuit against New York City for managing to lose all New York sports teams to the Meadowlands sports complex. The authority had argued in court that the city had reduced the value of the Port of New York as a destination location.
In another announcement, Mr. Brezenoff said the authority would "strenuously oppose" the plan of the aging billionaire Donald Trump to build the world's tallest skyscraper hotel and casino in Bayonne. It would, of course, be visible from the authority's own World Trade Center.
"Even if Trump does build a bigger skyscraper, the World Trade Center does not anticipate losing any business," Mr. Brezenoff said. "We've got Windows on the World. All he has is Windows on the Kill van Kull."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Peso's Woes: A Very Familiar Diminuendo

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
IT has turned out to be a not-so-feliz Navidad for thousands of Americans who, wittingly or not, have invested in Mexico.
The value of their holdings plunged 30 percent in five short days last week purely because the Mexican Government could not or would not support the peso any longer. United States mutual funds that specialize in Latin American stocks dropped as much as 15 percent, as did some international bond funds. The Telefonos de Mexico shares that trade on the New York Stock Exchange are now worth about half what some investors paid for them in February. 
 So many people rushed to sell shares of Mexico Fund, an investment pool that trades on the Big Board, that the stock could not open for almost an hour on Thursday morning, and Telmex had the same problem for two days running. Fund investors have been less skittish -- so far. In the week ended Wednesday, Latin American stock and bond funds did have net redemptions, but they were modest, according to AMG Data.
Though you couldn't tell it from the headlines -- or the heavy trading -- this debacle does not come as an incredible shock to anyone with a long memory or a more than passing acquaintance with international investing.
True, the Mexican Government had sworn up, down and sideways that it would support the peso. But as the British discovered in 1992, when George Soros got rich betting against the pound, such promises can be too expensive to keep. And wasn't it just a dozen years ago that Mexican officials said they would defend the peso "like a dog"? The prompt 30 percent devaluation led to a banking crisis here.
Though the Mexican stock market is down more than 40 percent so far this year in dollar terms, such losses barely raise eyebrows among money managers with experience investing overseas. "People don't realize that emerging markets normally correct 40 percent-50 percent," said Mark G. Holowesko, director of equity research for Templeton, Galbraith & Hansberger Ltd.
Indeed, he points out that investors who put their money in Hong Kong 15 years ago have seen it increase tenfold -- but have suffered nine declines of more than 20 percent, including two of more than 50 percent.
Do investors have short memories -- or have they simply forgotten that Mexico is, in fact, an emerging market? Probably a little of both.
Most Americans investing south of the border were not doing so two years ago -- much less back in 1982. In 1992, just two stock mutual funds focused on Latin America, and they held less than $250 million, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Today, there are more than a dozen, and they contain more than $4 billion (or they did before last week).
Meanwhile, Telmex has become ubiquitous in the portfolios of individuals and institutions alike. More than 400 mutual funds own it, according to Morningstar Inc., and many of those funds look, on the outside at least, as American as microwave popcorn. As of Sept. 30, funds with big slugs included CGM Capital Development, 20th Century Growth, Berger 100 and Invesco Industrial Income. Because such funds are diversified, problems with a single holding or two won't kill their performance. But in a rotten year like this one, when these funds are already in the red, it sure doesn't help.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Italy Awaits Fallout of a Political Crisis

BYLINE: By John Tagliabue 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
IT was a week when Italians asked themselves whether they should be watching politics or the economy. This time, the two looked more inextricably linked than they had been in a while.
The ill-starred Government of the tycoon-turned-Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, was pulled down on Thursday by his squabbling coalition partners. And on the same day that Mr. Berlusconi handed President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro his resignation, the Governor of the Bank of Italy, Antonio Fazio, warned Mr. Scalfaro of a worsening financial situation, one marked by signs that inflation was rising again and that interest rates were pressing upward. 
 Yet, as Italians braced for a Christmas of uncertainties, the stock market in Milan posted five consecutive sessions of recovery and six of seven over all, after a slide that had seen equity prices slip more than 25 percent since May. The lira was holding steady, if not gaining, against leading currencies like the German mark and American dollar.
Indeed, signals were strong that foreign capital was flowing back into Italy, attracted by the high yields of Government bonds and the bargains found among Italian equities. The strength of the stock market was being fueled by indications from industry of a nascent but strong business recovery.
From 1992 to 1994, the two Governments before Mr. Berlusconi's had taken giant strides toward bringing public spending under a semblance of control. Scrapping a murderous system of wage indexing that pegged pay increases to the inflation rate, they brought the growth in Italy's cost of living index down to less than 4 percent, only slightly above the European average.
Indeed, Mr. Berlusconi's short-lived administration struggled to maintain the momentum, cutting $30 billion from the budget deficit in a 1995 budget bill.
So even as the Government was tumbling, some major investment brokerage firms were mildly bullish, betting that the departure of Mr. Berlusconi might break a political impasse, perhaps by means of fresh elections after a brief interim Government.
Yet this week, as the Italian Treasury set its bond schedule for the first quarter of 1995, nominal interest rates on bellwether Government bonds were set a percentage point higher than this year's.
Mr. Fazio, of the Italian central bank, reminded his countrymen that, given the size of the public debt, every 2.5 percent increase in interest rates raises by $22 billion to $25 billion the cost of servicing the Italian public debt, now a staggering $1.2 trillion.
Some analysts were concerned that the political crisis would undermine Rome's resolve in fighting inflation and reducing the budget deficit, thus widening the spread between yields on Italian and German Government bonds, the European benchmark.
"We're still skeptical," said Peter Sullivan, an investment strategist at Merrill Lynch in London. "If you had a stable Government with a coherent fiscal policy, say with a four-year plan, you could see bond yields go down 250 to 300 base points."
A base point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Yields on 10-year Italian bonds are now more than 450 base points higher than those on German bonds. This would favor financial service companies, like banks and insurers, and utilities; both of those sectors figure strongly on the Italian stock market.
"We're in an early phase of recovery in Europe and so capital goods are attractive, things like chemicals and oil shares," Mr. Sullivan said. "But financials and utilities are dominant in Italy, and that's not what you want."
Indeed, the week's stock market recovery, however feeble, was led by industrial shares like the auto maker, Fiat S.p.A., and Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., the financial holding company of the Montedison chemicals giant. They are leaders among companies that succeeded in boosting sales and cutting their debt load in 1994.
But there is another link between politics and numbers. Italy's economy was borne aloft in 1994 on the wings of its export industries whose textiles, automobiles and foodstuffs were priced very favorably because of the weak Italian lira, which drove the surplus in the balance of imports and exports in the first 11 months to $16 billion.
Umberto Bertele, a management professor at the Milan Polytechnic Institute, said that industry's ability to cash in on the currency bonus was caused in large part by product development and cost cutting achieved before 1992, when a heavily overpriced lira forced Italian companies to improve their competitiveness.
"My concern is that by maintaining over the long-term exchange rates such as we have at present, you're going to send signals to at least part of industry that this relative facility will continue," he said.
Now, though, a cheap lira means that Italian products virtually sell themselves.
"I fear that without an exchange rate stimulus," Professor Bertele added, "industry will suffer a fallback."

HEADLINE: Business Diary: December 18-23

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
The Mexican Miracle, Apparently, Was Not What It Seemed
Ross Perot, trying to head off the North American Free Trade Agreement, warned that if the accord became reality, Mexico would devalue the peso, letting low-price goods flood northward. He may have been partly right. Mexico, it seems, tried mightily to prop up the peso, but last week that effort failed -- failed big. The peso, already weakening, plummeted when Mexico let it go into free-fall against the dollar. Some costs were quick: banks and other investors lost a bundle. And some will stick around: an abrupt loss of confidence in the new President, Ernesto Zedillo, and a fear of new economic chaos in a nation seemingly getting its footing. So how did the Mexican Miracle take such a nasty spill? Perhaps because that miracle was kept alive more on hope than on basics. The hope now: a new, solid beginning with the peso at a lower, more stable level.
 
Listen to the Children
Think of "hand-held electronic organizers" and you naturally think of sleek, solemn, hyped-up executives. At least American companies think that way; in Japan they had a better idea -- make them for children. And now they're a big hit with preteen-age girls (the boys are still hooked on Sega and the like), who use them for fortune-telling games, or to create computer-animated virtual pets, or perhaps to "whisper" messages across a room. Casio, heeding the lesson, has started selling kid-level organizers in the United States. There's probably a lesson here for Apple Computer and its Newton "personal digital assistant": The children know.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Carter Plays Softball
Talk about the sacred and the mundane! Jimmy Carter, hopping about the globe in a crusade for world peace, last week offered his services in a surprisingly humble dispute -- one in which, though feelings run high, no bloodshed seems likely. Yes, we're talking baseball, and Mr. Carter's gesture didn't seem to help. Players and owners have so far managed to erase a sizable business from the American map, and the owners just declared an impasse and decreed a salary cap -- when, that is, salaries are paid.
 
Of Owls and 'Welfare Cowboys'
On the environmental front, President Clinton just got his way in one battle and retreated from another. He put a lot of effort into resolving a dispute about logging in Northwest forests that house the fabled spotted owl, and the Administration came up with a plan allowing harvests at less than a fifth of 80's levels. And last week a Federal judge approved the plan. At the same time, Interior Secretary Babbitt backed down from a plan to increase grazing fees for public lands, leaving the issue to the Republicans. Environmentalists jumped hard on this one, with one lawyer predicting that Congress would "perpetuate subsidies for welfare cowboys."
 
Open Gift, Insert Foot
The Christmas gift to clients -- it's usually a cliche so tired it's snoring on arrival. A bottle of Scotch, perhaps -- or maybe a bottle of Scotch. But now, into this imaginative void, leaps Raoul Felder. After Mr. Felder, a Manhattan divorce lawyer, dropped a knife on his foot some years ago, he was flooded with slippers of sympathy -- 150 pairs, which he then had to give away. Aha! he said, and a furry idea was born. This year, when gift season descended, he sent out 200 pairs of slippers that have a marked likeness to Mr. Felder -- hardly surprising, since he'd sent off multiple photographs and sketches to a slipper importer, which in turn got a Chinese factory to do the deed. With stuff like this, who needs lawyer jokes?
 
Tax, Spend, Cut, Duck
Robert Byrd hit it on the head last week. Gazing at the jumble of tax cuts and spending cuts sprouting on both sides of the aisle, Senator Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat, called it all "drag racing" that would end in a "demolition derby." No sooner had President Clinton leaped for the tax-cut wagon than the Republicans yanked it from under him, saying spending cuts would have to come first. Sure enough, the next day Mr. Clinton came up with $24 billion in spending cuts, nearly half of it from the Energy Department. Newt Gingrich had no comment; "we have our own plan," his press secretary said. All this commotion, and it isn't even Jan. 1 yet. Tax advice for '95: duck.
 
Prancer for Vice President?
Perhaps it's part of the migration back to traditional values, perhaps it's just a cyclical quirk, but Santa Claus was hot, hot, hot this time around. Hallmark reports that the image of the revered Mr. Claus -- whether on card or gift wrap -- was especially strong, and Coke has splashed a jolly Santa on bottles and cans. And he's managed to put a pudgy, fur-draped foot squarely in the land of the serious (an episode on A&E's "Biography," putting him in a league with F.D.R.) and the popular (a Better Homes and Gardens cover, in a league with Oprah and Di). Clearly, he'll be running for President in '96.
 
COMPANIES
 
A Pentium in Time . . .
It was fun while it lasted -- watching the computer types debate the difference between "perfect" and "99.989 percent perfect" (or was it 99.898?). But the great Pentium drama seems to be over: last week Intel blinked, saying it would gladly replace those flawed chips. Andrew Grove, Intel's president, said he regretted a policy that "seemed arrogant and uncaring," and the company ran large ads apologizing. The impact on Intel: of the five million Pentiums, perhaps a million will be replaced; at $100 a shot, that might cost Intel $100 million. Pretty minor, investors thought, as the stock shot up. The impact on you (if your computer has a Pentium): call (800) 628-8686 now, and you'll get a replacement, though it may take two months. Or wait a decade or two -- the offer's open-ended. But by then, of course, today's computers will seem like amusing antiques. . . . Did the Pentium, by the way, make Intel directors and executives nervous? Perhaps. In the last couple of months, as the crisis was unfolding, eight insiders sold more than 250,000 shares (roughly $15 million worth); in last year's fourth quarter, they sold none.
 
. . . Windows a Bit Late
Just half an hour after Intel threw in the chip, Microsoft said the release of its new operating system would be delayed yet again, possibly till August. It's the successor to Windows 3.1 -- the giant-killer among operating systems -- and when it appears, it could rake in $1 billion in sales in a year. But so far it's been called Windows 95 -- not, as it turns out, the greatest name. At last report, no delay is expected in the onset of the new year, so "we may have to rename it," a Microsoft executive said. But at least it seems determined to get it right before it goes public. Microsoft's shares took a fast dip.
 
A Matter of a Few Zeros
When Prudential Securities agreed last week to pay $550,000 for making illegal political donations, it was the largest civil settlement ever for the Federal Election Commission. But put it in perspective: Prudential has paid more than 1,000 times that -- $700 million -- to settle civil and criminal charges linked to the sale of limited partnerships.
 
'Liberal Books Don't Sell'
Newt Gingrich once accused House Speaker Jim Wright of fuzzy ethics concerning sales of a book Mr. Wright had written (and earned $55,000 from). Soon, farewell Mr. Wright; five years later, enter Mr. Gingrich. And last week came reports that Mr. Gingrich had signed a $4 million-plus book contract with HarperCollins, a Murdoch publishing house. Representative David Bonior labeled the deal a "$4 million Christmas gift" from an empire that includes the Fox network, which faces a regulatory battle. A spokesman for Mr. Gingrich called Mr. Bonior "an attack dog." As for Mr. Gingrich, he said, "Conservative books sell. I can't help it if liberal books don't sell."
 
Quick! Where's the Perfume?
Guess what, guys: the stores are on to you. It's a retailing axiom that merchants make half their annual sales during Macy's Gridlock Month (sometimes known as December, though it starts the second that Thanksgiving's over). But store executives know this bizarre season can be broken into more precise fragments. Last week, for instance, was the week of the panic shopper -- and "men," a Bloomingdale's manager said with assurance, "are panic shoppers." So if you dashed into a store and grabbed the first gifts you saw, you can be sure those gifts were deliberately placed in your line of sight -- and that just over the next rise of perfumes, clerks nodded knowingly.

LENGTH: 2830 words

HEADLINE: Getting to Know George

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
DAY after day, for two summers and three winters now, George Brown has found his way to a heating grate in the center of some of the city's richest, ritziest real estate. The grate, on the corner of 86th Street and Madison Avenue, is an outlet for pipes that heat vast, big-lobbied apartment buildings where cloaked and hatted doormen escort residents to taxis. Mr. Brown practically owns the rectangular metal grid.
Mr. Brown may be among the thousands of chronically homeless people living on the city's streets, exposed and vulnerable and, these days, categorically despised. But he has, at least, had the presence of mind to claim for himself a warm place on an affluent, rather safe and clean street. Having staked out the grate, he is carefully affable, never argumentative, eager to get along in -- or rather, outside of -- the swank surroundings. When the manager of the next-door apartment building asks him to move on, he nods and surrenders his scrounged cardboard -- only to return a few hours later. 
 There he dozes, mouth open, head against the wall of a Gap Kids store. He crouches on his grate, enfolded in cardboard. If he's up to it, he grins and waves and calls out "how-dos."
"That's his game, isn't it?" says a doorman across the street. "He sits and people kind of adopt him. Adopt him and give him a couple bucks here, a couple bucks there."
That is precisely what people on this prosperous block have done. After years of familiarity, local people have come to accept Mr. Brown, some with indifference, others with awkwardness and guilt, but nearly all without complaint. Some neighborhood residents and workers express fondness for him and say they worry about him and admire his friendly ways. They give him blankets and clothes, which he stuffs somewhere. They walk by him and call out, "George!," as they might any securely housed neighbor. A few shake his outstretched hand. Certainly many toss quarters, singles, fives. Mornings, at least one and often several people pass him a sack of coffee, regular, and a muffin. At lunchtime, they buy him hot dogs and sodas from the corner cart.
In a time and a city where people seem to be increasingly sick of the homeless and their intractable presence and their interminable pleas and the guilt, horror, resentment and pity they evoke, Mr. Brown and his neighborhood have quietly negotiated a truce. His armor is a courtly neighborliness, the courtesy of the South, of Orangeburg, S.C.,, where he was raised.
"My mother told me," he says, " 'Say good evening, good night, good morning.' That's the way of the world. People, they good, they good. I speak to them, give them the time of day. Sometimes, 'How you doing?' Sometimes the heart speak. Sometimes I can tell when a person has fear. I can tell when a person walks by with a good heart. People here, they got to know me. They real nice and good to me."
The talk is heartwarming; Mr. Brown sounds like a philosopher of the grate. He has no money, no home, no family, and yet he is cheerful and smiling. The reality is more complicated. In fact, Mr. Brown does have a small income and a family, in the South, who would give him shelter and who worry and wonder where he is. He has chosen this life as deliberately as he has chosen his grate.
On cold days, Mr. Brown sticks his legs straight out, tucking cardboard around them like a blanket. He wears one of several worn sweatshirts and dirt-covered pants and a not-bad gray wool jacket. His head, enswathed in a navy blue wool cap, lolls against the wall. Flopped down on the wide, clean street that sweeps into the leafy expanses of Central Park, he looks like a bony marionette.
His days at his home on the grate have a bit of routine: sift the trash for recyclable bottles to return for cash, walk, limping, the 17 blocks to Metropolitan Hospital for medicine for incontinence caused by the stroke he says made him homeless. Consume the paper cups of coffee and big pretzels people give him. On icy nights, make his way to the projects where acquaintances will take his money for a place on their floors. He has spent a few nights in the Bellevue and Wards Island homeless shelters and refuses to go back. The first, he said, is "a filthy place, freezing." At the second, he slept four nights on a plastic chair. Always, he returns to the grate.
"He's not blocking the sidewalk," said Officer Neil Ariano, whose beat includes the block. "He lives on the grate. I tried to get him to go to a shelter, but he doesn't want to go. He feels safer on the street. He minds his own business. I take it people don't mind because I haven't received one complaint."
Unlike some homeless men on the street, he does not frighten people. He does not thrust a cup in their faces or yell or beg for change or even lock eyes with passers-by.
"He's a sweet man," said Alice Thielen, a nurse at one of the block's many medical offices. "I've brought him breakfast and a few hundred hot dogs. When I saw he had holes in his shoes, I bought him new ones. He's not aggressive, that's what I like."
"We talk basketball," says 13-year-old Andrew Levine, who passes him every Tuesday evening on the way to his aunt's apartment. "He says the Knicks will go all the way, definitely. Then he says God bless me and stuff like that. I usually give him a dollar, partially out of sympathy. It's hard to pass somebody like that that seems so friendly."
Anybody who glances his way, Mr. Brown greets, and if they linger, he talks, his voice a mumble, as if continuing a conversation interrupted midstream. It's not the words but the affable tone that matter. The people who listen and give him money come away with the dual satisfactions of helping a homeless person and getting an inside glimpse of the city's underground.
"I'm always outside talking to him," said Nancy Rosario, who works in a doctor's office next door. "I talk to George about anything and everything. He's a nice person. Very friendly and kind-hearted."
"All the girls here like him," said another worker in the office, who gave her name only as Grace. "I speak to him every day. He gave me this," -- a small wall-hanging of a blue-gabled house -- "a nice gesture, since he has nothing."
Ms. Rosario's warmth does not extend to other homeless people she encounters. She is unmoved by the subway's nagging, nameless panhandlers. Like people all over the city, she and her neighbors have chosen Mr. Brown to be "their own" homeless man.
"Those people who beg for money on the train -- I have no feeling for them," she said. "It's frustrating to see that kind of people. There's nothing you can do if they won't go to shelters."
 
AT FIRST, SKEPTICISM
 For many people, the notion of getting used to Mr. Brown took some getting used to.
"My first reaction was: 'Take a look at this guy, call the police, we don't want him there.' " said Dr. Irwin Leventhal, Ms. Rosario's boss. "My partner gave me a look and said, 'You obviously don't live in New York City.' "
When Mr. Brown first showed up on the grate, Rose Smith, the next-door building manager, tried calling the police. They told her they couldn't make Mr. Brown move. Now, she calls him "my outdoor tenant" and says he helps with the sweeping and shoveling. "I don't have the heart to ask him to move," she said. "The man is trying."
Susan Zaife, who lives in the building next door, concurs.
"He seems like a nice guy," she said. "Very friendly. I give him food on occasion, money on occasion. I gave him a blanket once. There are so many homeless. It's so hard to know who to give to and who not to give to and whether to give at all."
Some people, after pausing to chat and giving money, clothes and food, are torn. Is Mr. Brown a friend? An equal? One wants, after all, to be democratic, to judge people by their hearts and behavior, rather than their housing or the lack of it. But still . . .
Shirley Gaisford, whose daughter, Kelly, lives in the building next door, says they carried him a complete Thanksgiving dinner: turkey, dressing, cranberry sauce, pie.
"He was very gracious," she said. "He said it was the best homemade food he'd ever had. One hesitates: Gee, should I ask him in to eat? He's a very nice man, a very gentle man. We have a nice rapport. When I see him, it's like I'm seeing my very best friend."
Other people, though, regard Mr. Brown with cynicism, preferring another, dirtier homeless man in the neighborhood who talks of being a C.I.A. conspiracy target and calls himself "Old 53-34-4600." This man, they say, is delusional and utterly without resources, and therefore more authentically homeless and in greater need. They suspect that Mr. Brown doesn't have to be a homeless beggar.
"I've never given anything to George," said Betsy Stapleton, who lives in the neighborhood. "I've talked to him, and I can't get my mind, my empathy, wrapped around him. I'm certain he has a place to go. His clothes are so clean. He looks like he's dressed by the Gap. I always acknowledge him, but I've never given him any money. I have a few other favorites I give to. I've been giving to my nameless friend, a truly anonymous man -- the very troubled homeless man -- I've seen for eight years. At first we would just look at each other. I couldn't pass him by without giving him something. He affects me very much. But I've become more callous. Well, callous may be the wrong word. I tune out a lot more than I used to."
 
A FAMILY'S PLEAS, UNHEEDED
 The subject of all this talk lounges each day on the grate, his wide grin splitting a face that is the color and shape of a wizened walnut with a rough beard. Today, Christmas Day, he says, is his birthday; he is 51. The purpose of this, the latter part of his life, has come down to getting enough spare change and hot dogs and blankets and cardboard without giving offense or being driven away.
"When people walk right by, they're not stuck up," he said. "It's not they don't want to talk to you. They got things on their mind. Rent to pay."
But some years ago, Mr. Brown had a life. He, too, had rent to pay and jobs that enabled him to. He used to be a janitor at Fordham University and Baruch College, he says. In South Carolina, he operated a crane and framed pictures. A few years ago, he says, he had a stroke that left him with a pronounced limp and incontinence, making him unemployable. He gets $800 from Social Security disability and $105 in food stamps a month, he says. The money spills from his fingers because he can't turn down the pleas of other homeless people.
Somehow, though, Mr. Brown has been able to remain impervious to the pleas of his family. For Mr. Brown not only has held jobs, he has had a wife and four children, now grown. He left his family for another woman 21 years ago, though he never divorced his wife.
"He loves his fast life," said Margaret Brown, his long-separated wife, who has lived on welfare and disability since she lost her sight. "He likes other women. When I met him I was 18. He was fine, free-going. He likes to laugh, be friendly. "
In those days, Mr. Brown's dress, like his mind, were smart. "He don't like to go around looking tacky," Ms. Brown said. "He's very bright. He could take an old house and design it so you wouldn't know it. Make those walls and ceilings look professional. He did some things I never got over. I'd never want him back. But it's too cold to be out there on the street. He comes back, I'd help him get a place to stay."
Mr. Brown's youngest daughter, Vanessa, who was a baby when he left her mother, is more eager. Her father lived for a while with another woman when she was growing up. Every few months he would come to the house to see his children and contribute money to augment his wife's earnings as a nurse's aide. But that was long ago. Vanessa hasn't seen or heard from him for six years. He even missed his father's funeral.
During those years, Vanessa became an all-America high school athlete and won a basketball scholarship to Voorhees College in Orangeburg. She is now a senior, 23 years old, majoring in sociology. Mr. Brown does not know, has no inkling, of how well she is doing.
"An all-around athlete, great in basketball," Cedric Baker, the Voorhees basketball coach, says of Vanessa. "She has the potential to be great in softball. She's a real sweet person, a very hard worker. She doesn't talk a lot, but actions speak louder than words."
"She loves her daddy," says her mother, sounding rueful. "She really loves her daddy."
"I got upset with him," Vanessa says, "because he took care of someone else's kids before us. But you tell him to come on home. Somebody will take care of him."
Homeless Mr. Brown may be, but he is not apparently psychotic or broke or without family. Why, then, does he live on a grate on the street?
Because of pride, he says. Because he refuses to be a burden on his children. They don't know where he is, he says. They certainly don't know he is homeless. That's how he wants it to remain.
"I'd die before I let them know I'm on the street," he said. "I raised them to be their own people. I don't want to pull them down. They go their own way. That how I want it."
Mr. Brown, too, goes his own way, the way of a homeless albeit very, very friendly New Yorker, shielding himself from rain with scraps of cardboard, eating, like a begging Zen monk, whatever he is given. Unlike many homeless people, Mr. Brown has a far better life within his reach. But living on a metal grate in one of the most prestigious neighborhoods in town has saved his pride, a pride that lets him live off the kindness of strangers but not of those who love him.
 
Helping Those Who Help the Homeless
 Here is a listing of organizations that provide help to the homeless in New York City, and of the services they provide. Most of these groups need and welcome volunteers; donations, doubtless, are also welcome. For a more complete listing, contact the Coalition for the Homeless, which publishes a book of resources for the homeless and serves as a clearinghouse for volunteers. The Coalition suggests that individuals or corporations interested in making donations contact the agency directly.

HEADLINE: An Industry in Need of Regulation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Stop the Subsidies to Europe's Airlines" (Viewpoints, Nov. 27), Lawrence Chimerine and Gregory Stanko recite one of the ancient economic beliefs that was used to justify airline deregulation. The argument was and is that economic regulation, including cash subsidies, perpetuates overcapacity (too many flights); in a free market, competition forces airlines to cut capacity. 
 Since deregulation in 1978, American carriers have lost lots of money, and excess capacity (too many empty seats) has led to ruinous fare wars. Obviously, deregulation has not reduced excess capacity.
The writers would reduce European airline flights to the United States to compel an end to subsidies. The Europeans doubtless would reduce American flights to Europe, an endless tit-for-tat that would become a comic opera. If, as they say, United States carriers do not get a fair share of trans-Atlantic business, only negotiations to regulate flight frequencies can work, along with agreements on quality of services.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, Nov. 27
 
The writer is professor emeritus at the University of Pittsburgh and author of "Rebuilding America: The Case for Economic Regulation" (Praeger) and "Air Transport Policy and National Security" (University of North Carolina).
