HEADLINE: The World;
U.S. Stays Aloof From Russia's War Within

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RUSSIA'S pro-democracy movement was outraged as Moscow's troops tightened their grip around Grozny last week. But the Clinton Administration, which says it shares the goals of the democracy advocates, all but blessed President Boris N. Yeltsin's efforts to bring the breakaway Chechen republic to heel.
 The Russian military campaign there barely rated a mention when Defense Secretary William J. Perry met in Moscow on Dec. 16 with Gen. Mikhail Kolesnikov, the chief of Russian general staff, to talk about Bosnia and NATO issues. And after his trip, Mr. Perry repeated the Administration's line, that Russia's handling of Chechnya was an internal affair, though one Washington hoped would involve a minimal amount of bloodshed. 
 "Provided it is not destabilizing beyond the scope of that activity," Mr. Perry added, "I do not see it as affecting our desire to have a pragmatic partnership with Russia."
 To be sure, there are serious threats to American security and the fate of the Chechen republic is not one of them. But while Chechnya may be a Russian matter in legal terms, there is no such thing as a purely internal matter in an age of satellite broadcasts. Television has carried pictures of Russia's almost random air strikes against civilians in Grozny to Moscow and beyond.

 
 
Letting It Ride
 By the end of the week, the Clinton Administration's detachment was beginning to look like indifference. And it found itself in the odd position of tacitly supporting a military action opposed by a majority of Russians, including pro-democracy supporters, Parliament, Russian human rights supporters -- even many in the military.
 Just as the Bush Administration initially put its bets on one man -- President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union -- the Clinton Administration seemed to be casting its lot with President Yeltsin come what may.
 Defending their hands-off approach, Administration officials say the Chechnya crisis, while a compelling humanitarian story, is only a smaller part of a larger puzzle.
 The United States, they said, is concerned first and foremost with the security of the nuclear stockpile in the former Soviet Union and with encouraging continued political and economic reforms there.
 Both objectives hinge on Russia's ability to avoid civil strife and on Washington's ability to maintain a good working relationship with the Russian Government.
 To that end, the White House has gone out of its way to try to ease Russian suspicions about the West, favoring a go-slow approach on expanding NATO. Meanwhile, the Pentagon has sought to strengthen ties with Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, the Russian Defense Minister and the architect of the military campaign against Chechnya, and other members of the Russian high command.
 For Washington, the Chechnya crisis has been seen as a threat to the relationship the Administration is trying to build with the Yeltsin Government.
 But while the Administration may view Chechnya as a distraction from the main event, it has proven to be too large to be ignored.
 Dimitri Simes, the head of the Nixon Instititute on Peace and Freedom, said the Administration should have handled the Chechnya affair differently.
 It should have told the Russians that while Chechnya was indeed an internal affair, there are political realities in the West as well, Mr. Simes argued. A more conservative Congress -- one less sympathetic to Russia -- is about to take power in Washington. And images of Russia bombers and tanks blasting civilians will be long remembered when the Administration seeks the support of lawmakers for aid to Russia and new joint American-Russian projects. That sort of argument would have allowed the Clinton Administration to respect Russian sovereignty while encouraging military restraint, Mr. Simes said.

 
 
Shift in Tone
 But the Administration's response to the crisis appears instead to be reactive and aimed in part at public opinion at home. Only when the Russian military stepped up its air strikes, and charges of human rights abuses were leveled by Russian officials, did the Clinton Administration begin to shift the tone of its comments, and even then its response was tepid.
 On Friday, the State Department took note of complaints by Sergei Kovalev, head of the Russian President's commission on human rights.
 "We will be following this up with the Russian Government in order to evaluate the facts," said a State Department spokesman, David Johnson. "Respect for fundamental human rights has been and will continue to be a basic precept of U.S. policy toward Russia."

HEADLINE: Never Mind;
Reform Taxes? Give Us a Break!

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT this time 10 years ago, politicians and lobbyists throughout the capital were digging their trenches for the forthcoming battle over rewriting the United States tax code. What followed over the next two years was one of the fiercest legislative fights in this century.
 In the end, against heavy odds because the stakes were so high, a tax system that was universally seen as hideously complicated and inequitable was completely overhauled. The principle behind the new law, one that academic authorities had advocated for years, was to keep rates as low as possible and to allow relatively few deductions, exemptions and other exceptions. 
 Tax rates were cut almost in half. Tax shelters were virtually eliminated. Industries with large disparities in their tax treatment were put on a more equal footing with one another. Many familiar deductions like those for credit-card interest, retirement savings and union dues were abolished.
 But despite the extent of the change, the new system was quickly accepted in the towers of academe and the canyons of Wall Street, in liberal and conservative political circles, in accounting firms and law offices. And once ubiquitous tax lobbyists were mostly forced to find new lines of work.
 Now, it looks as if the Tax Reform Act of 1986 will be unraveled in the next Congress.
 President Clinton and Republicans and Democrats in Congress want to reinstitute a variety of new tax breaks -- not because they think this is good tax policy, but because they think it is good politics.

 
 
The Only Game in Town
 The budget rules are now so rigid and new Government spending is so out of fashion that the politicians had to look for a new way to pass out favors to people whose votes they seek.
 "It is the only thing available," said Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, a veteran of the tax war a decade ago who is now a senior Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee. "You can't spend money. So you have to deal in tax preferences. You have to do it through the back door."
 Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, the philosophical godfather of the 1986 law, said: "People seem to think that if they spend through the tax code, it's not really spending; it's free. That's ludicrous."
 President Clinton wants to give families with incomes below $60,000 a year a $500 tax credit for each child younger than 13. He would allow families with incomes as high as $120,000 a deduction of up to $10,000 to help offset college tuition expenses or the cost of other education or training after high school. And he wants much more generous treatment of tax-favored savings accounts called individual retirement accounts.
 His proposals are modest compared with those of the Republicans who will be controlling Congress. In addition to a $500 tax credit per child (for families with incomes up to $200,000) and more generous I.R.A.'s, the "Contract with America" signed by most House Republicans calls for these tax breaks:
 *A lower tax rate for capital gains -- the profit from the sale of investments -- and an elimination of taxes on any part of profit due solely to inflation.
 *Tax credits for adoption expenses and the cost of caring for elderly dependents.
 *A reduction of the so-called marriage penalty, the additional tax some working couples owe simply because they file joint returns.
 *A repeal of last year's tax increase on middle- and upper-income Social Security beneficiaries.
 *New tax breaks for life insurance and for insurance covering the cost of nursing home care.
 *More favorable tax treatment of business investment in plants and equipment.
 *An increase in the size of estates not subject to Federal tax.
 Other politicians have also put forward what they call middle-class tax cuts. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who will be the House Democratic leader in the new Congress, has proposed a tax credit of $300 to $600 for each child in families with annual incomes up to $75,000. Senator Phil Gramm, a Republican from Texas, wants to double the exemption for dependent children, to $5,000 from $2,500, for families with incomes up to $124,000.
 Tax credits reduce dollar for dollar the amount of taxes owed. So a $300 tax credit saves the taxpayer $300. Exemptions and deductions are subtracted from income before taxes are calculated. This means they are more beneficial to affluent taxpayers in higher tax brackets.
 For instance, an extra $2,500 exemption, as proposed by Senator Gramm, would save someone in the 15 percent tax bracket $375 (15 percent of $2,500) and someone in the 31 percent tax bracket $775.
 This is one reason why some tax experts oppose the Clinton proposal that would provide a deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition costs. "It is an upside down subsidy," said Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research institute sponsored largely by labor unions. "You would be giving $2,800 to a family that makes $100,000 and sends the kid to Harvard, and only $600 to a family making $40,000 whose kid goes to State U."

 
 
Spare Change
 According to calculations by the professional staff at the Treasury Department, which are not seriously disputed by Republicans, the President's proposals over all would cost the Government $60 billion in lost revenue over the next five years. The tax reduction elements of the Republican contract would cost nearly $200 billion over that period.
 But as large as those sums sound, the money would be spread so thin that no one would get a windfall. For example, under the Clinton plan, a couple making $50,000 with two children younger than 13 would get a reduction of less than $20 a week.
 The biggest tax saving under the Clinton plan, according to the Treasury's estimates, would go to taxpayers with annual incomes between $50,000 and $100,000. Taxpayers at every level would fare better under the more generous Republican contract, but the largest saving would go to those with incomes above $100,000.
 All the politicians who support tax cuts insist that they will be offset by spending reductions, but they have not said exactly how they would accomplish that.
 Reducing the Federal deficit, the overriding political issue last year, has now become as passe a topic in the political debate as, say, the question of whether the United States should turn over the Panama Canal to Panama. Republicans want a constitutional amendment to force a balanced budget, and Democrats orate about fiscal responsibility. But all the emphasis is on how to offset tax cuts.
 The Clinton Administration denies that it wants to unravel the tax reform law. "I'm not saying we're not moving away from it," said Leslie B. Samuels, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, "but I don't think it's a sea change."

 
 
'Feel Like Crying'
 But those with the biggest political stake in the 1986 law feel differently. Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who was Finance Committee chairman in 1986 and who will regain the post in the next Congress, said, "I feel like crying."
 Once tax breaks are written into the code, Mr. Packwood said, "getting them out is like prying a rock out of the Rock of Gibraltar."
 Perhaps the most daunting prospect is that with a major tax bill on the docket, the tax lobbyists will come out of hibernation and begin peddling their wares. Before long, the tax system could look like the one that was done away with in the mid-1980's.
 "When you start moving a tax bill," said Lawrence F. O'Donnell, the departing chief of staff of the Finance Committee, "it becomes a lobbyists' beehive. Everyone has a tax provision to sweeten in one way or another."

HEADLINE: A Violent Battle of Wills Besieges Hartford

SERIES: When Trouble Starts Young: The Role of Gangs -- A periodic report:

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
The young men and women of Los Solidos filed into the rented banquet hall cursing and muttering complaints. Even on this solemn occasion, the anniversary of the day brother Pipe was killed by Latin Kings, the police would not let up.
They were watching, as usual. About 10 members of the Hartford Police Department stood outside as Solidos gathered in the squat building for a memorial dinner-dance. And as 350 Solidos marched by in their red and blue colors, officers with camcorders filmed them for future reference. 
 "Ask me if I care," snapped a thin teen-age boy, wearing a red and blue jersey with "L.S.N.," for Los Solidos Nation, printed in white on the chest.
"You will," shot back an officer standing watch.
It was a brief exchange in August, but a telling one. A battle of wills is raging between gangs that have staked a claim to Hartford and the authorities determined to deliver the state's capital from the drug dealing and violence that the gangs have bred.
The struggle for control has heightened as more and more gangs have taken to the streets of Hartford and spread to cities and suburbs throughout Connecticut. Los Solidos, the Latin Kings, 20 Love, Netas -- names unheard of here five years ago -- are household words. The police and prosecutors say the gangs are partly the reason for the city's record murder rate this year, record police overtime costs and a surge in drug dealing.
"The gangs are the Mafia of the 90's," said Christopher Morano, an assistant state's attorney in charge of a statewide gang prosecution unit. "They're highly organized and that's what makes them so dangerous."
Why here and now, Mr. Morano says, is hard to know. Hartford has a history of gangs dating to the 1970's. They dispersed during the 1980's, then began to regroup a few years ago with a fury never seen before.
In one sense, the gang problem here is no different than the gang problem in New York, Chicago or Los Angeles. The gangs sprout in prisons or on the streets. They dig into impoverished neighborhoods, where their ranks grow with youths who have few choices. And they sell drugs.
But Hartford, with fewer than 140,000 people, is smaller than most cities plagued by gangs. Its citizens have no refuge. Downtown, bullets have broken windows in the Old State House and a gang member was shot in front of Superior Court.
This is how bad the gang problem has grown here: Since 1993, the National Guard has set up innovative boot-camp-style education programs in 15 states, aimed at helping high school dropouts earn diplomas. Only Connecticut's program, heavily populated by Hartford teen-agers, has been shut down -- because gang members taking part were involved in fights and drug use.
To Hartford's Police Chief, Joseph F. Croughwell Jr., the way people here talk, it's as if the city is the gang capital of the country. "Whenever anything happens now, people think of gangs first," he said.
For a while, things were quiet. Then in October, after an eight-month undercover investigation by a local, state and Federal task force, 17 Solidos were arrested on Federal racketeering charges. If convicted, some, including the gang's president, could face life in prison.
Los Solidos was broken. But within a week, more Netas and Latin Kings began surfacing on the streets, said Lieut. Daniel Stebbins, commanding officer of a state police crime-control task force. "It seems when one gang is down," he said, "others move in to fill in the void."
 
The Price
Neighborhoods Held Hostage
 The gangs know drug turf is precious. There are only so many corners and alleys. By absorbing, scaring and killing small-time dealers, gangs now control the city's drug trade -- Hartford's biggest crime problem, Chief Croughwell said. Turf wars, crimes of passion, drugs -- and the desperate robberies that they induce -- have given Hartford the distinction, over Bridgeport, of bearing the worst crime rate in the state.
This year, 53 people have been killed in Hartford as of Friday, breaking the city's previous murder record, 46 in 1980. Of this year's cases, the police department considers 17 gang-related. (In others, gang members might have been involved in murders not considered gang-related. In one case, a member of 20 Love shot his cousin to death over a parking spot.)
Just two years ago, Hartford had 13 murders. The Hartford metropolitan area had the lowest murder rate among the 75 largest metropolitan areas in the country, according to statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Then last year, the city's murder rate more than doubled, to 30, with half of the murders classified as gang-related.
Over the last two years, gangs have ravaged two neighborhoods. In the North End, 20 Love has expanded its drug dealing. In the South End, Los Solidos and the Latin Kings have swamped Frog Hollow.
People in the North End are dodging bullets.
[On Friday, a 14-year-old boy was shot and killed in the Stowe Village housing project.]
A fledgling gang, the Young Guns, wants to take on 20 Love to control popular drug spots; 20 Love appears up to the challenge. In November, a man was killed and two others wounded in a hit that police believe 20 Love organized to eliminate other dealers.
Los Solidos and 20 Love are also feuding. In the last 10 days, one member from each gang was killed in two separate shootings
Frog Hollow has long been a tough section. Young men with guns and drugs worked the corners even before the gangs pushed their way in. Yet people here say it was never this bad before the Latin Kings and Los Solidos shot the daylights out of Park Street. In the summer and fall of 1993, they had an all-out war that lasted months. Gang members fired at each other in midafternoon outside of churches and schools. Parents looking for protection from flying bullets put their children to bed in bathtubs.
Hartford's children know gang culture. They'll tell you that "O.F.O.," for Original Family Organization, is the youth chapter of Los Solidos, and that "Death Row" is the female chapter of 20 Love. They'll say Los Solidos prefer being called "The Solids" and warn you that it's dangerous to wear red and blue, Solidos's colors, or black and gold, the Latin Kings's colors, in the wrong neighborhood.
"I'm not afraid of the gangs," said Ismael Mercado, who lives on a block with gang members. "They do what they got to do, and I do what I got to do." This year, the Police Department assigned officers to permanent beats at each of the city's three high schools. The move has helped the schools, but not Hartford's battered image.
Bordering Frog Hollow, Little Italy boasts some of the city's most popular restaurants, but the owners complain that many customers have been scared off. And in a neighborhood where generation after generation once settled down, "For Sale" signs are pitched in front of houses on nearly every block.
As bad as it's been, it could have been worse. Two days before the October raid on Los Solidos, the joint gang task force learned that one Solidos faction planned to eliminate the other, in a fight to the death that was to extend into Connecticut's prisons. The task force pushed up its raid by 12 hours, pre-empting a possible bloodbath.
The police say the gangs are getting better at hitting their intended targets. But at least four innocent bystanders have been killed in the city this year. They included a 7-year-old girl sleeping in a car that a Solido apparently mistook for a Latin King's car.
Another victim simply wore the wrong clothes. In February, Vicente DeJesus Jr., 20, was shot several times at close range, the police say, because a Latin King mistook him for a Solido. The victim, who was in a car returning from a double date, happened to be wearing blue and red. Witnesses said he begged for his life.
Mr. DeJesus' parents, who moved from Hartford to nearby Manchester eight years ago to give their four sons a better education, put their house up for sale two weeks after his death. "It hurts too much to be here," Mrs. DeJesus said. They plan to move, whether or not the house is sold, after the January trial of their son's accused murderer.
"He not only killed one person, he destroyed the whole family," Mrs. DeJesus said. "My sons grew up with the gangs. They went to school with them. What is it with the gangs?"
 
Lost Lives
 When Drugs Run in the Family
 In the 70's, the Black Spades, Seven Brothers and Savage Nomads had chapters in the North and South ends of Hartford. They faded away. In the early 80's, bands of youths, or crews, gathered to sell drugs but the police stopped them and gang activity didn't stir again until the early 90's.
Most of Hartford's gang members come from minority neighborhoods. The gang 20 Love sprang from the Albany Avenue Crew, a loosely knit drug-dealing posse in the mostly black North End. Latin Kings and Los Solidos come from heavily Puerto Rican Frog Hollow.
The neighborhoods where the gangs sprout are the city's worst. At Charter Oak Terrace, a 950-unit housing project in the Southwest end, about 90 percent of the residents are unemployed. Frog Hollow may sound like something out of Mark Twain, but it is an island of despair. Boarded buildings and dying tenements dominate.
The Latin Kings began as a Hispanic fraternal organization in Chicago in the 1940's. The first Connecticut chapters were formed in Bridgeport and New Haven in 1989 by two inmates at the Somers State Prison. The gang branched into Hartford's South End about three years ago. Then, as it gained control of the drug dealing, officials say, dissident Latin Kings began Los Solidos.
Mr. Morano, who prosecuted more than 150 gang-related cases in Hartford from Sept. 1993 to August 1994, said the Latin Kings and Los Solidos seem to offer disaffected youth an escape.
Mr. Morano said: "20 Love is strictly a drug gang. And while Los Solidos are a criminal enterprise, there are members who joined because they didn't know what else to do in Frog Hollow."
Los Solidos, with anywhere from 500 and 2,000 members, according to police estimates, are the biggest Hartford gang. Its founder and "godfather" is Larry Beauvais, known as "L. B.," who is serving time in Federal prison in Florence, Colo.
Members talk about being a family that offers support and love and unity against the threats of a hostile world. "If you live where we come from, you see we offer the best," said Martin (Sharp) Delgado, a 22-year-old Solido with two children, 4 and 2. With the schools failing, the neighborhoods in tatters, "we have a moral code or creed we follow." He added: "We want to start a community. Los Solidos is no longer involved in any kind of violence."
It was a passionate vision offered on a sunny summer day. But both he and Solidos's president, Jorge (Pekino) Rivera, who at the time also talked at length about "the family," were arrested in the October raid by the joint gang task force. Both have been charged with conspiring to commit, and with committing, violent crimes in aid of racketeering -- kidnapping, assault with a dangerous weapon and assault resulting in serious bodily injury.
Authorities say the gang members knew months ago that they were in trouble. They had won the war with the Latin Kings. But the battle with the police was not going as well. By summer's end, Los Solidos were besieged by the law. Members were getting arrested on a daily basis. Their bail fund was rapidly diminishing. And there was too much heat on for them to do business, or make money.
Los Solidos members took their case to the press. They were eager to show the world they were misunderstood, that Los Solidos were a social empowerment organization that was blamed for things they didn't do.
In an interview at the Christ Lutheran Church gym in Frog Hollow, where he was playing basketball, Mr. Rivera, a rangy 23-year-old with dark, hollow cheeks, said Los Solidos flouted society's low expectations of them.
"We don't accept people in our group who go shooting at people," he said. "We're stricter than parents. Our younger members can't smoke. They have a curfew. They have mandatory school or a job."
But the police say that as president of the gang, Mr. Rivera ordered "hits" and "missions" -- killings and assaults that have plagued the city. He had a record of 59 arrests, most for "breach of peace" and license suspensions. He was not involved in drugs, he said.
Both he and Mr. Delgado wore gold crucifixes around their necks. Mr. Delgado, who said his parents sent him to Catholic school to avoid the Hartford public school system, said religion and spirituality played a large role in the gang.
"Not all of us sell drugs, not all of us do drugs," Mr. Delgado said. "We have people who go to school. People who have jobs. If you saw what we're really about, it's love."
It was Mr. Rivera who extended an invitation to a memorial for Felipe (Pipe) Santana, who was killed on Aug. 31, 1993.
"Pipe tried to talk and reason, and the Latin Kings killed him anyway," he said. "That's what started the war."
The memorial service, where all speeches began and ended with the words "Solid Love," offered a glimpse into the gang's society. No members were allowed at the table with reporters unless given permission. One member, Willie (Pepperoni) Mendez, 21, sent by the gang to chat, stayed until he was officially "relieved." The women made and served the dinner -- pork, chicken and rice and beans -- and cleared the red and blue paper plates. Everyone sang along to the rap song dedicated to the slain Solido's memory: "Life's a Bitch and Then You Die."
Officials say that as president of Los Solidos for more than a year, Mr. Rivera had run a tight ship. He organized the gang, expanded membership and consolidated power, inspiring fear and loyalty among the ranks.
"He's a very bright guy, very savvy," said Sgt. Christopher Lyons, who commands the Hartford department's intelligence unit. "It's just a shame he didn't direct his intelligence in a positive way."
Days before his October arrest, Mr. Rivera's power collapsed. He and Mr. Mendez, the vice president, were terminated from Los Solidos for stealing money, according to the police, and were beaten so severely that they spent several days in the hospital. The "beat down" was done by a gang faction that included Mr. Rivera's friend, Mr. Delgado.
"Los Solidos got hurt," said Sergeant Lyons. "Now 20 Love is going nuts. We're going to keep locking them up, but it's going to take a lot more to stop what's going on."

LENGTH: 1604 words

HEADLINE: Colleges Luring Students With Discounts in Tuition

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

 BODY:
It is not quite the "These-deals-are-INSA-A-ANE" world of late-night stereo and sleep-sofa ads, but increasingly discount merchandising is coming to academia.
At Lehigh University here, a new program allows top students to get a fifth year of undergraduate or graduate education free, and the university, for the first time, has offered scholarships not based on financial need as a way to attract top students. 
 Its business school has cut tuition 22 percent for its master's program. M.B.A. graduates get two-thirds off the regular tuition for any course they take after graduation.
The changes at Lehigh are just a glimpse of a revolution beginning to rock America's colleges and universities as more consumers make it clear that they cannot or will not pay the sticker price for college.
"We're not trying to be the discount kings here," said James Schmotter, dean of Lehigh's College of Business and Economics. "But I think we've sat here on campus and thought we're special and we're different from other kinds of marketplaces. Our customers no longer think we are that different; they see us more like other high-priced luxury goods.
"As time goes by, I think we're going to see increasingly more aggressive and creative and sometimes desperate pricing schemes."
The higher-education market has already changed significantly. In four years, the number of students paying full tuition at Lehigh, for example, has dropped to 49 percent from 63 percent, and nationally fewer than half of all college students pay full tuition.
Experts say discount schemes are proliferating. They include more financial aid awards based on need, new merit scholarships intended to attract more sought-after students and innovative pricing plans.
Robert Zemsky, director of the Institute for Research in Higher Education at the University of Pennsylvania, said, "I think the whole price structure of higher education, particularly in the private sector, is collapsing, and there will be a lot of what might be called novel experiments in the years to come. The market is trying to, in a larger sense, clear, and find out the real price the public is willing to pay for higher education."
Experts say at least four factors have put higher education in its current bind. The first is that the cost of a college education has grown far faster than the Consumer Price Index and personal income. Second, the pool of applicants is declining or stagnant. Third, the public is increasingly skeptical and cost conscious as a result of the consumer movement and negative publicity about academic life. Fourth, the competition for top students is increasing.
Those factors have contributed to experiments like these price-cutting plans:
*In October, the University of Rochester announced that it would give a $5,000 grant to all New York State residents who enrolled as freshmen in 1995.
*The University of Detroit Mercy, Michigan's largest private university, took the opposite tack, offering out-of-state students a grant program of up to $1,950 to match what the state gives Michigan students.
*Susquehanna University in Pennsylvania and Clarkson University in upstate New York are among universities that have begun offering four-year degrees for the price of three, allowing students to cut $12,500 to $25,000 from the cost of their bachelor's degree.
*Stevens Institute of Technology in New Jersey and Clark University in Massachusetts offer what amount to 20 percent more education free: a no-tuition fifth-year.
*This month Michigan State University announced what it called a historic policy guaranteeing that tuition would not rise faster than the projected rate of inflation for the next three years.
According to the College Board, average tuition is now $11,709 at four-year private colleges and $2,686 at four-year public colleges, both up 6 percent over the previous year. When room, board, books, supplies and transportation are included, the total price comes to $18,784 for resident students at four-year private colleges and $8,990 at public ones. The average American student pays about half of the total college bill, experts say.
A study by Dr. Zemsky's institute last summer examined five representative colleges from 1987 to 1993 and found that all were increasingly likely over time to offer more financial aid. The study also suggested that the purpose of the aid was not just to assist needy students but to increase enrollment and maintain class sizes.
The emerging discounts are part of the same picture.
Not all campuses feel the pressures equally. But Mr. Zemsky says probably fewer than 35 universities in the country have a reputation or market niche so secure that they are largely immune from the pressure to discount tuition.
Lehigh, once known largely for its rigorous engineering curriculum and wrestling program, is now more broadly based. Of its 6,300 students, only 36 percent are majoring in engineering.
Like many colleges, Lehigh, where 72 percent of entering freshmen came from the top quarter of their high school class, finds it increasingly difficult to find students who will pay full tuition, now $18,700. In 1990, it provided $12 million in financial aid, and 37.4 percent of its freshmen received financial aid. This year, its financial aid budget is $23.1 million, and 50.9 percent of freshmen receive financial aid.
The pressures on colleges are affected by the increasing financial sophistication of prospective students. Chris Holler, an 18-year-old Lehigh freshman from Baltimore, hired a college selection firm to scout out the financial aid prospects at institutions he was considering. They included Lehigh, Bucknell, the University of Maryland, Villanova, Virginia Tech and the University of Delaware.
He said he was leaning toward Delaware, where many of his friends had gone, but chose Lehigh after it came up with the best financial aid offer, including a $15,000-a-year scholarship. He also took out two or three loans, he said.
"In the end, it worked out great, both in terms of the school and the financing," he said.
Mr. Holler's scholarship was based on need, but growing competition is forcing many universities to increase their pool of merit-based as well as need-based financial aid. Until this year, Lehigh was among the fewer than 15 percent of four-year colleges that gave out aid strictly on the basis of need. But the university found that it was increasingly losing more and more students to competitors like Emory, Carnegie-Mellon, Rochester, Richmond, Villanova and Johns Hopkins, all of which have moved aggressively to offer merit scholarships as recruiting tools.
In a survey of applicants who were accepted by Lehigh but chose to go elsewhere, 62 percent said they would have been interested in Lehigh if they had received a merit scholarship.
Partly in response, Lehigh this year announced President's Scholarships, in which students with a cumulative grade point average of 3.5 or higher or who graduate with high honors can attend another year free to get a master's degree or complete a second major. It also announced a small number of $5,000 to $7,000 Dean's Scholarships to superior applicants for the freshman class, and $2,500 music and theater scholarships not based on need.
Some at Lehigh have long advocated merit-based scholarships as a way to reward excellence and lure top scholars, said Lehigh's president, Peter Likins. But until this year, he remained committed to offering financial aid only to worthy students unable to afford a Lehigh education.
"Lehigh has stood with those elite institutions who said, 'I don't care what's happening to the world; I'm going to play by a certain set of principles,' " he said. "Now what's happening is that institutions of considerable historical reputation are moving across the line, and every time one does, it puts additional pressure on the rest of us. Finally, Lehigh succumbed."
At Lehigh and elsewhere, colleges are also using aid to further their academic aims and traditions. For example, Clark University in Massachusetts announced last year a fifth-year-free program like the one Lehigh later adopted. Clark officials say it fits well with the university's niche as a small research university with a strong graduate component.
Alan Jones, dean of graduate studies at Clark, said that along with the 115 merit scholarships it offered, the program allowed the university to provide financial incentives to a broad range of students in addition to those who get aid based on need. "We offer a price break on the front end to certain students and a price break later on to those who perform well here," he said.
Tuition inflation has been slowing for the last four years, according to the College Board. Still, this year's 6 percent increase was twice the rate of inflation.
Although universities have been fighting to control costs for years, their success has been limited by the need to repair or replace aging buildings, by the growing financial needs of students and because they have far less control over their payrolls than most other employers.
Still, as difficult as the task may be, Mr. Likins argues that colleges and universities cannot solve their problems by adjusting prices. The real challenge, he says, is to cut their operating costs.
"Price is becoming more or less a consuming preoccupation, but unless you control costs, you're on an impossible journey," he said. "The economics of higher education are really in jeopardy. If you're just fiddling around with price, you're playing a dangerous game in which no one wins."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Schmotter, dean of Lehigh University's College of Business and Economics, sees the growing competition in higher education this way: "They see us more like other high-priced luxury goods." And colleges, much like automobile dealers, are coming up with "more aggressive and creative and sometimes desperate pricing schemes," because many consumers are refusing to pay the sticker price. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Russia's Army Seen as Failing Chechnya Test

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Demoralized and underpaid, the Russian Army is facing in the rebellious Chechnya region its stiffest test of professionalism and morale since the collapse of the Soviet Union, and it is failing the test, Western diplomats and Russian military analysts say.
Its officers are rebelling in the face of an increasingly vicious war against other Russians. Its soldiers are dispirited and disorganized, badly fed and cold, without any clear idea of why they should be fighting the Chechens. 
 The army's heavy armor has little strategic value in Chechnya, its movements have been sluggish against little resistance, and its jets are almost haphazardly bombing a city defended by only a few thousand poorly equipped troops.
One result is a public relations fiasco so bad that even President Boris N. Yeltsin's supporters in the West, who have regarded Chechnya from the start as an internal affair, have started to complain. The sense of confusion about Moscow's methods is shared by Russians, too.
"It's hard to call this a strategy," said Sergei Yushenkov, the chairman of Parliament's Defense Committee. "It is the barbaric destruction of the city of Grozny and its inhabitants."
Military officials keep saying the army has a plan to use laser-guided bombs and special forces to infiltrate Grozny, the Chechens' capital, and "decapitate" its leadership, including President Dzhokhar M. Dudayev.
There is already a growing and abiding new hatred for Russian power in the North Caucasus, which hoped that the post-Soviet world would be a different one. There is already, in the Russian press, criticism of the military and its leadership that is reminiscent of the American news media toward the end of the Vietnam War. And there is already, in the new Russian military, a sense of shame over Chechnya that will probably further poison attitudes toward Mr. Yeltsin, democratic and economic change, and all politicians generally.
No matter what happens in Chechnya now, whether Grozny is taken tonight or tomorrow or not taken at all, the Russian Army will face a severe period of rebuilding not unlike the United States Army's after the professional humiliation of Vietnam.
Then, American officers said, it was difficult to attract young people of sufficient quality, let alone feel much pride in a military career. The American military responded with much better recruitment and advertising techniques, and most important, with higher pay and better benefits.
But if there is one persistent fact of Russian political life today, it is the scarcity of money for any social need in a tight federal budget, and Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev has already warned of the political consequences of continuing to starve the army of funds for training, housing and modern equipment.
Speaking to Parliament last month, General Grachev said an impatient and impoverished Russian military was losing its ability to defend the Motherland. Young officers are leaving in large numbers, he said. Pilots are not flying because of budget cuts in fuel and maintenance, and ships are stuck in port. Nearly 200,000 officers and their families are without decent housing. Military units engage in trade and troops work as laborers to supplement their pay.
"We must frankly ask ourselves the question -- do we need an army?" General Grachev said. "If so, it is a sin to keep it in poverty and half-starved."
"Not a single other army in the world is in such a catastrophic state," he added. "I ask you to take this as a warning."
The military's performance in Chechnya is a testament to General Grachev's concerns. Despite his efforts to reorganize the army and give it a new mission in a post-cold-war world, there has not been the money to develop the mobile striking units the new military doctrine calls for, and which could have been effective in Chechnya.
But the rot was evident long before Chechnya. "If anyone still had any doubts," said Pavel Y. Felgengauer, the military analyst for the newspaper Sevodnya, "the war in Chechnya has certainly shown the low levels of military readiness and morale of the Russian Army."
Draft evasion remains rampant; there are too many generals running nearly empty units; patriotism is out of fashion; vicious hazing of recruits, especially of those from the Caucasus, frightens young men and their parents; high-ranking generals speak with contempt of President Yeltsin and General Grachev.
The vaunted military-industrial complex that supported the army, even if the quality of the science was overrated, has now largely turned as a matter of state policy toward making civilian products or selling its hardware overseas for dollars.
From the height of Soviet power, with five million men and women under arms (including border troops) and an almost unlimited budget, the Russian Army is now believed to be a hollow force of only 1.4 million or fewer, and without enough money to care for them properly.
It is an enormous fall for an institution that embodied the pride of the empire, first Russian and then Soviet. The officer corps was a pampered elite; the uniform brought respect; the institution had saved the nation from Napoleon and Hitler against all odds.
Then came Afghanistan -- which the Soviets invaded 15 years ago today -- and the first real humiliation; then the revelations of glasnost and a budding free press; then the collapse of the Soviet Union, a professional disaster for the army. And then the inevitable and coruscating pull into politics, despite all the efforts by military leaders to stay out of the maneuvering.
In August 1991 the army refused to carry out the putsch against Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- its first taste of popularly applauded insubordination. In October 1993 it made a pained and slow decision to support Mr. Yeltsin by firing tank shells at the old Russian Parliament. Even General Grachev, Defense Minister by dint of his loyalty to Mr. Yeltsin in 1991, hesitated then, and the country came within a few hours of being run by Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, a former air force general who was then Vice President and led the parliamentary revolt.
The army's support of Mr. Yeltsin suddenly seemed conditional on Mr. Yeltsin's keeping his promises of better support, promises the generals believe that he has not kept. And that conditional support also helps explain Mr. Yeltsin's more robust and nationalist foreign policy.
Then General Grachev became further tarnished. He has always been regarded by the army elite, the General Staff, as a jumped-up paratrooper who earned his position by political loyalty. Suddenly this autumn came a whole new cycle of corruption charges that nearly brought him down.
Sharp and shocking criticism came from inside the army, including criticism from young Turks like the popular Lieut. Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, commander of the 14th Army in Moldova. General Lebed, always outspoken, turned his popularity into a successful public defiance of General Grachev, refusing to be reassigned and appealing directly to Mr. Yeltsin. General Lebed also spoke contemptuously of Gen. Matvei P. Burlakov, who had commanded Russian troops in Germany and was accused of corruption.
Mr. Yeltsin was forced to dismiss General Burlakov last month "to preserve the honor of the army," he said, and General Grachev's position was felt to be hanging by a thread.
But the traditional respect for the army was gone, both in the press and the public, and a pattern of insubordination had taken hold. When Chechnya began to get hot, General Lebed opposed intervention publicly, as he continues to do without reprisal. Even Gen. Boris Gromov, a First Deputy Defense Minister, warned against the military action.
And during the slow, clanking advance toward Grozny itself, and now the round-the-clock bombing, generals and lesser officers have refused orders, expressed dissent and tried to resign. They have said that carrying out warfare against Russian citizens violates the Russian Constitution, and resent carrying out a police action on Russian territory.
The semi-official Itar-Tass news agency first reported that General Grachev had taken personal control of the attack and suspended or relieved six top commanders, including a Deputy Defense Minister, Gen. Georgi Kondratyev, who kept warning Moscow to negotiate and not attack, and Col. Gen. Eduard Vorobyov, the deputy commander of all land forces, the backbone of the army.
The report of the suspensions was then denied, but not the report that General Grachev was now in direct command, implying that the General Staff is belatedly trying to keep its distance from the disaster.
Some Russian critics of the Chechnya action think that attacking Chechnya was forced upon General Grachev as the price of keeping his job, so there would be a ready scapegoat. Some think that the army is using its poor performance now to be able to put pressure on Mr. Yeltsin for more support and more money. Some think that Chechnya means an army even more politicized then before.
"After a long sequence of defeats and humiliations, beginning in Afghanistan," Mr. Felgengauer said, "the Russian Army has reached a point where it might simply refuse to obey orders."
But the biggest problem for the institution was described by General Vorobyov, the most senior of the dissenting officers, confirming that he had tried to resign but that his resignation had been refused.
"I love the army very much," he told Izvestia in an interview. "I gave it 38 years of my life. And I don't want even the smallest stain on its uniform."

HEADLINE: Who Was Jesus? A Search for Clues Grows

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
On this day in particular, Christian churches proclaim the story of Jesus, a Savior conceived by the Holy Spirit and born of a virgin.
But ever since the Enlightenment in the 18th century, some people have hungered for more, a way to reach beyond the creeds to Jesus the man, a historical figure who can be known in human terms much like, say, Washington, Charlemagne or Julius Caesar. 
 The quest for the historical Jesus ebbed and flowed through German Protestant academies for generations, but little about its findings reached people in the pews.
These days, a new quest, mainly led by American scholars, is on, and this time it has found a public whose avidity for it has turned some heavily footnoted academic texts into strong sellers among general audiences.
"I'm just amazed at the appetite there is for this," said Marcus J. Borg, a professor of religion and culture at Oregon State University and a leading figure among the new generation of Jesus scholars. "I think, in common with a lot of commentators on our culture, there's a rebirth of religious interest."
Among academics, research into Jesus is being spurred by the enthusiasm of a new generation of scholars, drawing on information from archeological discoveries in and around Israel, including recent excavations of cities and villages in Galilee, where Jesus preached.
But the interest of the larger public is another matter. For two or three years in the United States, a nation where old denominational loyalties have faded, popular enthusiasm has been surging around ancient spiritual topics, lifting books on angels, prayer and life after death high onto the best-seller lists. In this climate, scholarly works on the historical Jesus have found an audience among those most inclined to probe issues of faith, even if it means tackling hundreds of pages of densely argued text.
Dr. Borg, who lectures frequently about the historical Jesus to adult groups, said he had encountered many people who were seriously wrestling with basic beliefs. "For them, their childhood understanding of Jesus and the Bible at some point stopped working, but their religious interest remains," he said. "Biblical scholarship, and Jesus scholarship in particular, provides a new way of seeing this material."
The portraits of Jesus that scholars like Dr. Borg are offering stand at some distance from the Christ of the creeds; Jesus is variously described as an enlightened person, like the Buddha, who was also a mystic and healer; a peasant who was a social revolutionary, or an apocalyptic prophet who saw himself in the mold of the Old Testament prophet Elijah.
And the scholars offering these divergent images are a far more diverse group than in previous quests: Catholics, Protestants and Jews, many working in secular institutions, and increasingly interested in archeologists' findings.
A few recent discoveries have seemed to come tantalizingly close to Jesus himself. Four years ago in Jerusalem, archeologists uncovered an ossuary, or box for bones, marked with the family name of Caiaphas, the high priest who in the Gospels questioned Jesus before the Roman authorities crucified him. Excavations at the ruins of Sepphoris, a city near Nazareth, and other sites in Galilee have provided insights into the social and economic life of Jewish communities there.
The new findings have indicated that the region around lower Galilee was becoming more urbanized in the first century than previously thought. How much that affected Jesus' activities is debated by scholars. But some have argued that his teachings responded to rising social tensions.
"We have new materials, we have new methods, and we have a new approach in that we want to go public, too," said John Dominic Crossan, a professor of biblical studies at DePaul University in Chicago who wrote "The Historical Jesus" (HarperCollins). Dr. Crossan said he had written the book with a narrow academic audience in mind. But it has sold more than 50,000 copies in hardback since it was published in 1991, he said.
David Lull, the executive director of the Society of Biblical Literature, an international association of biblical scholars, said, "The public is voting with their dollars for biblical scholarship."
Last winter, Dr. Crossan, Dr. Borg and another biblical scholar, Burton L. Mack of Claremont Graduate School in California, met for a "Jesus summit," a wide-ranging discussion, at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. The event's sponsors, HarperCollins and the Trinity Institute, an organization based in New York that runs education programs for members of the clergy, arranged a live broadcast via satellite to 74 colleges, churches and libraries across the country.
The Trinity Institute's director, Frederic Burnham, said that he did not know how many people had tuned in but that he had chanced upon one group of more than 150 people viewing the event on a television in a hotel ballroom. "I think it's just part of the tremendous revival in interest in spiritual matters in this country," he said.
Dr. Crossan said that on his desk he kept a stack of readers' letters. They are not the angry missives from biblical literalists he had expected. Rather, he has been hearing from people struggling with their beliefs. "I wasn't ready for the positive stuff at all," he said. "I wasn't ready for two- and three- and four-page letters, many with questions," theological questions about God and Jesus.
Among those who write to him, he said, are "centrist Christians," the sort of religious moderates who these days can sometimes feel sidelined during shrill religious disputes and uncertain of their place in a nation whose spiritual diversity seems to be in a period of rapid growth.
A significant number of those in search of the historical Jesus are people of the baby-boom generation who feel a "disharmony" between their secular and religious educations, said another scholar, the Rev. John P. Meier, a professor of New Testament at Catholic University in Washington. Many hold advanced degrees, but the knowledge they have of their own religious traditions ended in Sunday school, he said.
They "desire to do for themselves this religious education that they did not get," said Father Meier, the second volume of whose sweeping study of the historical Jesus, "A Marginal Jew" (Doubleday), was published last month. "It's in that struggling with the faith as an adult that the quest for the historical Jesus is so useful to these people."
Younger people, too, are entering on the quest, although the questions they begin with are sometimes more basic.
Speaking of his classes at Oregon State, Dr. Borg said: "For my students, the questions they bring to class are not related to Christian theology. It's: 'What was he like? What was he up to?' "
In a sense, such questions about Jesus echo the ones asked 2,000 years ago. The Gospels tell how, with each miraculous healing Jesus worked, the crowds around him grew. People swarmed after Jesus, but many found him utterly mysterious.
"Whom say the people that I am?" Jesus asked his disciples during a quiet moment (Luke 9:18). They responded that many thought he was John the Baptist, or the prophet Elijah, or another of "the old prophets." Jesus then asked the disciples who the disciples thought he was. "The Christ," answered Peter.
The historical Jesus, Father Meier said, is the "great perennial question" in Western religion, "the great perennial question which every generation thinks it's solved, but which comes back in the next generation."

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS PLAN SWEEPING BARRIERS TO NEW U.S. RULES

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
House Republicans are preparing to push quickly next year for legislation that would radically restrict the Government's ability to regulate everything from auto safety to wilderness protection.
Republicans in the House have pledged to push to a vote within the first 100 days of the new Congressional session legislation that would increase the ability of groups affected by regulations to challenge them before they take effect or are even formally proposed. For the first time, analyses of costs and benefits prepared in the initial phase of drafting regulations would be subject to review by outside experts, and these analyses could be challenged in court. 
 The Republican proposal would also drive down the overall burden on business and state and local governments by creating a regulatory "budget" -- a specific ceiling on the costs of complying with all Federal regulations. That ceiling would be steadily reduced, and Congress would agree not to pass laws whose costs would exceed the ceiling.
If adopted, the Republican proposals would fundamentally alter the workings of agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency and affect matters as diverse as the Transportation Department's pending decision about whether to require anti-lock brakes on passenger cars and the Forest Service's tentative proposal to regulate the use of permanent metal anchor bolts by rock climbers in wilderness areas.
The proposals, included in a draft bill called the Job Creation and Wage Enhancement Act of 1995, are the latest salvo in a decades-long struggle between Republicans and Democrats over the Federal Government's power to make rules. The obscure and often arcane rule-making process has grown into one of the Government's most formidable functions.
The new plan goes well beyond even the anti-regulatory agenda of President Ronald Reagan, involving ideas like the regulatory budget that have never been seriously considered before.
The bill's basic approach is to limit the scope of regulations by imposing detailed strictures on the rule makers themselves. It includes, for example, one paragraph that bars any rule from being published for public comment unless the Director of the Office of Management and Budget certifies that among other grammatical requirements it avoids double negatives and "contains only sentences that are as short as practical."
Public debate on the Republicans' proposal has just begun, as tax cuts, spending cuts and welfare reform have dominated the political agenda since the Republicans won sweeping victories in November. But interest groups on both sides of the issue are enlisting in the struggle by the hundreds, guaranteeing that it will be among the most bitterly contested items considered in the coming year and making the outcome impossible to predict. It is unclear, for example, to what extent Senate Republicans will join in the sweeping measures their colleagues in the House are proposing.
The Clinton Administration, alarmed at what it views as a comprehensive assault on the entire regulatory system, has already begun a campaign to defend current practices as founded on "common sense," a phrase that has appeared in almost every recent public pronouncement by Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator.
The same antagonists are also lining up on a separate but related set of Republican initiatives that would force the Government to reimburse property owners when regulations reduce the value of their holdings.
The proposed House legislation would result in significant changes in the balance of power among the Congressional committees, regulatory agencies and interest groups that battle daily over proposed new rules and the enforcement of those on the books.
The Republican National Committee disputes as a "myth" any assertion that the bill is "inherently anti regulation."
"The objective is not to cause a certain level of regulatory burden, but to make the regulatory burden a matter of conscious choice rather than of accident," the party's newly published tract on its legislative plan, "Contract with America" (Random House/Times Books), states.
The measure's opponents have a starkly different view. "If this bill passes, it will stop the issuance of new rules," said Gary D. Bass, executive director of O.M.B. Watch, a liberal group that monitors the regulatory activities of the Office of Management and Budget and has published an 18-page analysis of the regulatory bill, titled "Eye of the Newt."
"It will gut existing rules, and it will limit the ability of Congress to pass new laws," Mr. Bass said. "It will be impossible to enforce existing laws, and it will seriously harm the ability of the Government to protect individuals."
So far, the debate on the broad and complex proposal has been limited to a relatively small circle of experts and advocates inside and outside the Government. It has been packaged by Republicans as part of their pledge to reduce the capital gains tax.
 Other sections of the bill would erect far more substantial barriers to regulation, including some that have never been seriously contemplated before.
For example, the regulatory budget would attempt to measure the costs to private businesses and to state and local governments of complying with regulations, and would force Congress to shrink those costs much as the fiscal budget tries to shrink the Federal deficit.
It would also set up a detailed process for assessing the costs and benefits of every major regulation, for scientifically reviewing how the rules would affect health and safety risks, and for letting affected parties challenge the highly technical assessments in court.
Its critics say the legislation would tie the regulatory process into knots of scientific review, economic analysis, legal challenge and political gridlock.
But advocates say the bill would guarantee simplicity and common sense where now there is obfuscation and red tape.
"What this is all about is changing the fundamental process from a system where people are serving regulations, to one where the regulations are serving people," said Bruce Gates, a vice president of the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association who is running a coalition called Project Relief that is pressing for the bill's passage.
The measure would create significant new centers of power in the battles over regulation -- battles as important as the more familiar ones over legislation.
The regulatory budget, for example, would undermine the powers of most Congressional committees -- a feature of the bill that could weaken support for it in Congress.
Under the proposal, any committee that attempted to write a law that would impose regulatory costs beyond a specific level could be forced under budget rules either to withdraw those provisions or eliminate other regulations to compensate for the new costs.
The effect, as the law is written, would be to greatly increase the power of the House and Senate Budget Committees over regulatory matters that are now the domain of other committees, like those that control banking, the environment and labor issues.
Congress would be ordering, in effect, those specialized committees to rewrite existing laws to reduce the aggregate costs of regulations by 6.5 percent annually, until the costs borne by the private sector were not more than 5 percent of the economy's total output, and the costs on states and local governments no more than 3 percent of the whole economy.
The regulatory budget would also impose a ceiling on expected regulatory costs while the committees draft new legislation -- even though the costs of regulations are never really known when the laws are passed, since Congress rarely spells out details of how the laws are to be put into effect.
Once a committee reached its limit for imposing costs, it could no longer bring a bill to the floor without permission of three-fifths of the entire House or Senate.
Power would also shift from agencies to the groups they regulate.
In the regulatory agencies, the power would move to panels of technical experts who would provide "peer review" of the risk assessments and cost-benefit analyses required of every major rule. A major rule would be defined as one that affected 100 people or cost any person or corporation $1 million.
Thus, there would be a proliferation of assessments and reviews, along with public hearings in many cases, all subject to court appeals.
As the legislation is written, much of that technical and legal maneuvering would occur even before the proposed rule was published in preliminary form by the regulators.
The Republicans' bill also aims a direct blow at the very foundation of the Clinton Administration's regulatory approach, an executive order signed by Mr. Clinton on September 30, 1993.
The order limited White House interference in regulatory matters and made it harder for interest groups to lobby quietly for regulatory changes at the White House.
In effect, the Republican bill would countermand that executive order, which Mr. Gore called "the foundation of our efforts and our first regulatory reform success."
Instead, it would enact into law President Reagan's defunct Executive Order 12291, which he had used to control the actions of a bureaucracy that he said had run amok.
The biggest difference between the Reagan and Clinton executive orders was that the Reagan order put control of regulations firmly in the White House, instead of in the Federal agencies. In pressing to put the order back into force, the Congressional Republicans appear to be betting that a Republican will be President before long.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
The House Republicans' New Voice On Foreign Policy: Very Soft-Spoken

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
When the Republicans won control of the House of Representatives last month, a few conservative lawmakers began quietly plotting to deny Benjamin A. Gilman the post he had long cherished: the chairmanship of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Their thinking was that Mr. Gilman, a New Yorker whom some conservatives brand "a Rockefeller Republican," was too old, too moderate, too soft-spoken and, truth be told, too nice. In short, not enough of a fire-breather. 
 Alarmed, some of his friends in Congress opened a countercampaign to warn the new Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, that it would be folly to deny the highly visible foreign affairs post to a cautious, worldly-wise lawmaker like Mr. Gilman.
"I called Gingrich's office and said: 'No way. You'll have to crawl over my dead body if Ben Gilman doesn't get the chairmanship,' " said Robert Dornan, a California Republican who is one of the House's staunchest conservatives. "Ben is not as conservative as I am on social and fiscal issues, but on foreign affairs, he's solid."
For the past two years, Mr. Gilman, 72, has been a consistent though quiet critic of President Clinton's foreign policy. He faults the President for not carrying through on his threats to bomb Bosnia's Serbs, for favoring Russia over other former Soviet republics, for moving too slowly to expand NATO and for paying little heed to Congress in sending American troops overseas.
Although Mr. Gilman flew 35 bombing runs over Japan during World War II, no one has ever described him as a street fighter. In stark contrast to his Senate counterpart -- Jesse Helms of North Carolina -- Mr. Gilman remains largely unknown outside his district, notwithstanding his 22 years in the House. He is not the type of Congressman who spends his free time crisscrossing the country to give high-octane ideological speeches.
Instead, almost every Saturday he can be found in a mobile trailer he has turned into an office, roaming a district that runs from close suburbs to farm communities 70 miles from Manhattan, including all of Rockland County and parts of Orange, Sullivan and Westchester counties. He is immensely popular in his district; he took more than 70 percent of the vote in his election victory last November.
Mr. Gilman is so low-key that it has been 16 years since he last vaulted onto front pages. That was when, using the code name "Uncle Ben," he secretly negotiated a prisoner exchange in which an Israeli pilot held in Mozambique and an American jailed in East Germany were swapped for an East German spy imprisoned in the United States.
Now, thanks to the new Republican ascendancy, Mr. Gilman has come out of the cold. He plans to use his new prominence to push his pet issues: human rights, drugs, Middle East peace and the need for the Administration to consult more with Congress. Egged on by Mr. Gingrich and Republican backbenchers, he is also putting more bite into his criticism of Mr. Clinton.
In a news conference after being confirmed as chairman of what has been renamed the House International Relations Committee, he tarred Mr. Clinton for flip-flops and indecisiveness in Somalia, Haiti and Bosnia. "Instead of a strong, steady signal on foreign policy coming from the nation's capital," he said, "regrettably the world has heard a series of wavering notes sounded by an uncertain trumpet, leaving our allies concerned and our adversaries confused."
Friends say that Mr. Gilman is a genial, patient man. But with a face that always seems slightly dour, he comes across as a compulsive worrier, as someone who, if not fretting about human rights in China, is losing sleep over whether Russia is allowing Jews to emigrate freely.
In a recent interview he focused on his biggest current worry: the way President Clinton often commits troops to overseas missions without consulting in depth with Congress beforehand.
He questioned whether 25,000 American troops were needed in Haiti after former President Jimmy Carter won the coup leaders' promise to cede power. He criticized President Clinton for promising to send up to 30,000 troops to Bosnia to help withdraw United Nations peacekeepers. And now he is concerned that the President has offered 3,000 marines to help United Nations peacekeepers pull out of Somalia.
"There are some areas where it's extremely important we take part in peacekeeping, but I think peacekeeping hasn't gone well when the Administration hasn't consulted enough," he said.
He backed President Bush and, later, President Clinton when they sent forces to the Persian Gulf to check Iraqi aggression. As for Somalia, he backed Mr. Bush's decision to send troops to help end the famine there in late 1992, but criticized Mr. Clinton for changing that mission to hunting down Somali warlords.
Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat whom Mr. Gilman will succeed as committee chairman, said: "Ben is very much in the mainstream of American foreign policy. He wants to be supportive of the President whenever he can. But he will insist on the prerogatives of the Congress, as he should."
Mr. Gilman's dissection of a subject is generally more biting than his oratory. Take Bosnia. "President Clinton met with a number of us, and we explored the options," he said. "It seemed there was a consensus that we would engage in selective bombing. Then the President reached out to some allies in Europe, and he didn't find any consensus. So that was put on a back burner.
"Then Congress urged an immediate lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia, and he seemed to go along. Then suddenly he was supporting a six-month delay in lifting the embargo instead. Bosnia, I say, is another instance of vacillation."
While Senator Helms comes across like a fire-breathing dragon, Mr. Gilman seems like a friendly bulldog. Most of the time he seems easy to get along with, but when angered he sinks his teeth in and does not soon let go.
The State Department discovered this a year ago when it sought to eliminate its counterterrorism office and merge it into the department's antinarcotics office. It was not long after the World Trade Center bombing, and Mr. Gilman was convinced that in substance and in message, abolishing the counterterrorism office was a silly idea. So he went to work lining up Republicans and Democrats and blocked the effort.
Despite their differing politics and styles, Mr. Gilman is confident that he will work smoothly with Senator Helms. Administration officials fear Mr. Helms because of his venomous remarks and his ability to embarrass them in oversight hearings. But the Administration fears Mr. Gilman for quite different reasons: His middle-of-the-road views carry a lot of weight on both sides of the aisle and he knows how to build a consensus to enact his agenda.
For President Clinton, Mr. Gilman's message is both reassuring and a warning. "I think we should emphasize that partisanship should stop at the water's edge," Mr. Gilman said. "And I think it's important for the Administration to build a consensus of both parties on any important initiative so that we face the world in a unified manner."
But Mr. Gilman is likely to feel pressure from other Republicans not to be too easy on the Administration. And when he discusses foreign policy, gaps quickly emerge between his positions and those of Republican conservatives. Senator Helms describes the United Nations as a "nemesis"; Mr. Gilman is a firm believer in the organization, although he wants more oversight of its finances. While many Republicans favor a slash-and-burn attitude toward foreign aid, Mr. Gilman appears poised to defend it.
That Mr. Gilman comes across as a moderate is not surprising, considering his roots. As a young lawyer he was inspired to join the Republican Party by some figures whom many modern-day Republicans would condemn as hopelessly liberal, including the late Governor and Vice President, Nelson Rockefeller, and the late New York Senator, Jacob Javits.
"If Ben has any big problems as chairman, I think it will come from his own party," said Peter Peyser, a Democrat who lost to Mr. Gilman in 1982 when redistricting threw them into the same district.
