HEADLINE: Gap Between Rich and Poor in New York City Grows Wider

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
Among the nation's counties, the income gap between rich and poor in Manhattan is surpassed only by a group of 70 households near a former leper colony in Hawaii. Now an analysis of Census results shows that the gap widened in Manhattan in the 1980's, a decade whose extremes of wealth and want inspired Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities."
While the income disparity has historically been large in Manhattan, it widened to a greater degree in the 1980's than in any other county with 50,000 or more people. That increase drove New York City from 11th in 1980 to fifth in 1990 among cities with the biggest income disparities, and New York State from fifth to third among the states. 
 Poor people in the New York metropolitan area are more concentrated in the city itself than in any other major metropolitan area except San Antonio. The disparity has potentially profound political ramifications for the recurring competition between New York and its suburbs -- especially with last month's election of the first governor without New York City roots since 1920.
By the end of the 1980's, the top fifth of Manhattan households made 32 times as much as the bottom fifth, an average of $174,486 compared with $5,435. Put another way, for every $1 made by households in the top fifth, households in the bottom fifth made 3 cents.
In comparison, average income of the top fifth of all the nation's households edged up relatively modestly, from about 11 times the average income of the bottom fifth in 1980 to 14 times in 1990, when it was $94,264 versus $6,810.
Experts disagree about just when a growing divergence in incomes becomes a drag on the economy. But some express concern that vast disparities further disconnect poor people from the economic mainstream and can place additional economic and social pressures on a struggling middle class.
The average family income among the 812 people counted in the city's poorest census tract, around Bradhurst Avenue and West 145th Street in West Harlem, was $6,019. Average family income among the 6,053 Manhattanites recorded in the richest tract, the 10 square blocks in Carnegie Hill east of Fifth Avenue and north of East 86th Street, was $301,209.
The five square blocks straddling Jackie Robinson Park in West Harlem's Bradhurst section are punctuated by the vacant lots and housing hulks that separate sturdy six-story apartment buildings. The prognosis there is improving, though, thanks to a renewal project engineered by the Consortium for Central Harlem Development.
"Most of the people who are here are the ones who couldn't afford to go anywhere else," said Richard Brown, who runs the One and Only Laundry on West 146th Street. "We've got people who live from day to day, people who come in and say, 'Mr. Brown, I don't have no money to do my clothes.' We're the last to get any kind of attention, but it's coming back, slowly but surely."
 
Longest Cab Ride On the Continent
 Bradhurst is only a $5.25 cab ride or six subway stops north of the Upper East Side tract, which abuts the proverbial boundary between haves and have-nots, East 96th Street.
"Three miles makes a lot of difference," Mr. Brown said. "It's enough space to stay away from the poor."
In Bradhurst, 3 of every 4 people live below the poverty level, but fewer than 1 in 100 in Carnegie Hill.
"Today, the disparity is worse because of the decline of the quality of civic life," said Stephen Berger, an investment banker and former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who lives with his wife and two children in Carnegie Hill -- a neighborhood characterized by chic shops, elegant town houses and converted mansions, museums, private schools and apartment buildings manned by white-gloved doormen.
"It's hurt the poor because the first step of the ladder is now 20 feet off the ground instead of two feet," Mr. Berger said. "It's hurt the middle class because they also find the public system has deteriorated, so they are forced to supplement it. And it's hurt the wealthy because they have priced themselves to the point where they need that income disparity in order to live well."
Patrick Gerschel, an art collector and private investor who lives in Carnegie Hill, recalled how the fortunes of neighborhoods shift over time and how, despite the potential for conflict, the city survives. Still, he said, "Obviously, if you live better than your neighbor, that is going to cause all sorts of problems."
 
Poor New Yorkers Are Losing Ground
 An analysis of Census results related to income was conducted for The New York Times by Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, who directs the Program for Applied Research at Queens College of the City University of New York, and by Jeannie D'Amico, a research assistant. These are among the trends it found:
*While average income increased in the 1980's in every borough but the Bronx, poor New York City residents lost ground compared with others. Among the poorest fifth, 13 percent of New York City households and 16 percent of other households in the region were receiving public assistance in 1980. By 1990, 28 percent of the poorest New York City households, but only 14 percent of those elsewhere in the region, were on welfare.
*In all but one county in the 24-county region including New York City, the gap between rich and poor became more extreme. More residents of Suffolk and Putnam counties in New York, Sussex and Hunterdon counties in New Jersey and Middlesex County in Connecticut advanced into the nation's highest one-fifth in income than did residents of any other counties in the nation.
*In Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, and in Essex County, N.J., the proportion of people whose income qualified them for the region's middle fifth -- theoretically those most typical of average or middle income -- declined during the decade. While some of them may have graduated into higher income categories, one consequence of their success was to drive the top and bottom groups further apart.
*When the decade ended, the richest Manhattanites were younger (more than 2 in 3 were under 50), more likely to be American-born, slightly more likely to be in a household headed by a woman or a Hispanic person and less likely to have jobs -- or, presumably, need them -- than when the decade began. Among the poorest, far fewer were employed in 1990 than in 1980 -- about 3 in 10, or slightly more than the proportion who were on welfare. In 1980, 8 in 10 of the poorest were working.
While income disparities are common in virtually every society, demographic analysts said they were struck by the dimensions, both within the city and in comparison with the surrounding region. The gap in Manhattan is greater than that in Guatemala.
"It creates the well-founded impression among low-skilled workers that they don't have a shot at the economic mainstream and a decent standard of living," said Hugh B. Price, the new president of the National Urban League. "If you're living in the inner city, you look at the odds and say, 'Why bother?' "
 
Squeezing Out The Middle Class
 Extremes often exist in close proximity, as the wide disparity in Manhattan suggests.
"When I looked at those numbers, I said, 'Oops, there goes the middle class,' " said Gene Spruck, an analyst for the Port Authority. "Sure, there are some people from the middle who move up. But when you look at the polarization of income, the numbers fit into everything we intuitively know: that the middle class is being squeezed out of Manhattan."
In the New York region, including New York City, Long Island, the lower Hudson Valley, northern New Jersey and southwestern Connecticut, average income for the middle one-fifth increased in every county by at least 20 percent -- ranging from a 22 percent increase in Union County, N.J., to 48 percent in Manhattan. But in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Essex County, N.J., the proportion of people whose income put them in the middle one-fifth of the region declined.
In most of the region's counties, the gap between rich and poor grew modestly, although it widened in every county except Putnam. But it expanded from a ratio of 21-to-1 in 1980 to 32-to-1 in Manhattan, from 14-to-1 to 20-to-1 in the Bronx and from 14-to-1 to 19-to-1 in Brooklyn.
In the Bronx, where income for the wealthiest rose by 34 percent, income among the bottom group declined by 3.4 percent -- the only county where the average income for any of the five groups declined.
The Times analysis divided households into five groups of equal size. For comparison, the gap was defined as the disparity between the average income of the lowest fifth and the average income of the highest fifth.
Dr. Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard, cautions that income in the lower fifth is often understated. But, she said, "the disparity is still going to be great."
Among other counties with 50,000 or more people and where the disparity came closest to Manhattan's, the rich made 29.9 times as much as the poor in Orleans Parish, La. ($83,389 compared with $2,793). In Manhattan, average incomes were higher, but so were living costs.
In Kalawao, Hawaii, where most of the people are either former residents of a leper colony and their descendants or the few wealthier people drawn there by Molokai Island's natural beauty, among other lures, the rich made 41 times as much as the poor.
 
Some Silver Linings In the Income Gap
 The Census results on which the Times analysis is based were released late in 1993; they do not include medical and other noncash benefits or illegal or unreported income. The results captured trends that appear to have continued during the 1990's.
A gap in incomes may reflect some conditions that are not necessarily unfavorable or that may have some beneficial consequences. The lower income groups in Manhattan, for instance, include artists and aspiring theater people working in restaurants and recent immigrants whose willingness to accept low wages may have sustained part of the garment industry in New York.
"Whereas we have lost the middle class, white and black native-born," said Regina B. Armstrong, an economist for the Regional Plan Association, "in a sense New York is the most economically integrated place because we're able to hold onto higher income people at the same time we've accepted poorer people, including immigrants."
William B. Shore, a senior fellow with the Regional Plan Association, agreed that "one reason New York has traditionally been able to redistribute income -- through rent control, low-tuition colleges and the like -- is because we have all these wealthy people who not only pay taxes but contributed to foundations and philanthropies."
But the trickle-down trend may have trickled out in the 1980's, Dr. Beveridge suggested. In the New York region, he said: "There was an incredible increase in people making lots of money and at the low end a minimal increase in income. You could argue that if lots of people got rich that would be fine, but there was not a lot of trickling down."

HEADLINE: Police Say New Evidence Links Suspect to Firebomb

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Authorities examining last week's subway train firebombing in lower Manhattan have located new witnesses who saw the badly burned suspect fleeing in the streets and aboard another train, and have found new evidence at his home in New Jersey, including a videotape on bomb making, investigators said yesterday.
The new witnesses and other evidence appeared to solidify an already strong case against Edward J. Leary, a 49-year-old unemployed computer expert, who is charged with attempted mass murder in a firebombing that injured scores of riders aboard a No. 4 train at the Fulton Street station on Wednesday. 
 Investigators have charged that Mr. Leary, who lost his job at Merrill Lynch last January and had large real estate debts, planned a terrifying campaign of subway bombings to extort money from the city. They said his first bomb burned two teen-agers in Harlem on Dec. 15, while the second exploded in his face as he tried to set a timing device so it would go off in an East River tunnel.
Mr. Leary, who suffered third-degree burns over 40 percent of his body, remained in critical condition yesterday at the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Also in critical condition there were Reufield Edey, 60, who suffered deep burns over 65 percent of his body, and Brenda Dowdell, 40, with burns over 35 percent of her body.
The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that the firebombing case would be presented to a grand jury on Tuesday and that Mr. Leary would be arraigned in the hospital as soon as his condition permitted a bedside proceeding.
Mr. Leary's lawyer, Stephen J. Murphy, visited his client yesterday and said afterward that his condition appeared to be improving. But he said Mr. Leary was heavily tranquilized with morphine for pain, sometimes faded in and out of consciousness and appeared to have impaired hearing.
"He was sleeping when I arrived," Mr. Murphy said. "He awoke to my presence and I talked with him. But it was difficult to ascertain whether he was really hearing and understanding what I was saying. He's drugged, so one minute he can answer and a few minutes later he seems off."
Mr. Murphy said much of Mr. Leary's lower face was burned, especially around the lips, and his legs and buttocks were severely burned. Ointment was spread around the facial burns, but his head was not swathed in bandages, he said. He noted that Mr. Leary's wife, Marguerite E. Shaller, had visited her husband on Friday and was being "very supportive."
Reiterating his client's assertion that he was just a victim of the bombing and had no role in making or setting it off, Mr. Murphy declined to comment on reports of new witnesses and evidence in the case. But he complained that the authorities were "leaking everything in sight" to news organizations in a "grossly unfair" campaign of "vigilante justice."
Investigators insisted, however, that the case against Mr. Leary had been strengthened by the discovery of new witnesses near the scene of the bombing and new evidence found at the suspect's home in Scotch Plains, N.J., where search warrants had been executed and dozens of boxes of materials had been carried away by the authorities.
Law-enforcement officials said that earlier witnesses had placed Mr. Leary in the subway car of the Lexington Avenue train where the firebomb exploded, and that the new ones -- found by returning to the scene at the same time as the explosion occurred and asking for anyone who might have seen the suspect -- clarified what he did afterward.
They said the severely burned suspect, his clothes in tatters, stumbled onto the platform of the station at Fulton Street and Broadway and ran out an exit at Dey Street.
He then walked five blocks up Broadway and entered the Park Place subway station of the Seventh Avenue line, where he boarded a southbound No. 2 express train, investigators said. The train, passing one block west of the scenes of chaos at Fulton Street, rumbled under the East River to the Clark Street station in Brooklyn, where he again ascended to the street.
There, he was found by two transit police officers, who called an ambulance for him. It was while he was en route to New York Hospital that the officers, hearing a description of the firebombing suspect, concluded that the man they were helping might be the bomber.
Investigators said that additional court-authorized searches at Mr. Leary's 10-room home in Scotch Plains had uncovered videotapes, including one with a label that showed it was on the manufacture of bombs, and numerous computer disks. The contents of the tapes and disks remained to be examined, they said.
Earlier searches at the home had found a trove of bomb-making supplies in Mr. Leary's den, including mayonnaise jars, wires, timing devices, batteries and containers of gasoline, according to authorities. They say they also found sketches of bomb devices and notes, apparently in Mr. Leary's hand, that referred to a "mad bomber."
Some of the notes also allegedly laid out plans to extort money from the Transit Authority with a campaign of firebombings across the city. "We have several more bombs and if you pay a ransom, we will make this bomb safe," police said one note said. Another, they said, warned, "I will keep doing this."
Mr. Leary, who had paid $280,000 for his home in Scotch Plains and also owned three apartments at a cooperative building in Brooklyn, apparently was desperate for money, investigators said, and had been unemployed since losing his job at Merrill Lynch. The company said he had been dismissed for poor performance.
A Merrill Lynch official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, confirmed a report in The Daily News yesterday that Mr. Leary, after having been told his performance was imperiling his job, had sabotaged computers at the brokerage.
After the tampering was discovered, this official said, a test was set up to determine who was responsible, and Mr. Leary was identified as the culprit. Mr. Leary, who joined Merrill Lynch in September, 1991, was dismissed on Jan. 28.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Autistic Teen-Ager's Days at Camp Provide Respite for Him and His Mother

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
For 17 years, she has preserved the routines that define her son's cloistered life: putting him on the school bus each morning, walking him home on an unchanging route, fixing his dinner with gentle music in the background. But a stretch of misfortune has left Dorothea Y. wondering if normalcy might soon be out of reach.
Mrs. Y.'s son, Jonathan, suffers from autism, a brain disorder that causes extreme introversion starting in infancy. He cannot maintain eye contact, talk normally or interact with others, and he depends on rigid routines for a sense of security. 
 Jonathan was 5 when his father walked out, leaving Mrs. Y. alone with a child who required unfailing attention. More often than not, she said, others found Jonathan's erratic behavior unacceptable. As an infant, he would cry inconsolably whenever she took him somewhere new. At 17, his moods are equally unpredictable, and he is prone to sudden, fierce rages.
"When Jonathan was younger, so many people made me feel like I was a bad mother and he was a bad child," Mrs. Y. said recently as her tall, shaggy-haired son hunched over their kitchen table with crayons and a coloring book. "There's an attitude that these kids have to adjust to our world, but in this case, that will never happen."
One place where Jonathan has met with acceptance is the Children's Aid Society's Wagon Road Camp, which he has attended since he was 10. The society is among seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, in its 83d year. The camp, in Chappaqua, N.Y., is a respite program for parents like Mrs. Y., allowing them to take a break from the stress of raising disabled children.
Jonathan goes to camp for a month in the summer and for several days during other school vacations. Tomorrow, he will leave for a week at Wagon Road, where he and other disabled children from poor families will celebrate Christmas with parties and field trips.
"The same kids go back every year, so I know my son is going to be with friends," said Mrs. Y., who is 47. "Respite is a godsend for me, but it has also been invaluable for Jonathan."
Helene Zarember, director of the Wagon Road Camp from 1988 through 1993, said the experience has eased Jonathan out of his isolation. "When he first came to camp, he kept to himself," she said. "Now he is more relaxed and sociable, and he has learned how to take care of himself."
As a customer service representative for a large company in New York City, Mrs. Y. earned enough to live comfortably through most of Jonathan's childhood in Park Slope, Brooklyn. But in the summer of 1992, while her son was at camp, she suffered two brain aneurysms and a mild stroke in the course of two weeks. Lying in a hospital bed, she could not stop wondering what Jonathan would do if she died.
"I told the doctors they had to get me through for his sake," she said. "He doesn't have anyone but me."
Mrs. Y.'s recovery has been achingly slow, and coupled with more bad luck. She was on disability for two years, receiving physical therapy and relearning simple things like how to step off a subway car. Shortly after the stroke, her former husband stopped paying child support and Mrs. Y. had to hire a lawyer. Between court fees and medical bills, she spent her entire savings of $13,000.
In October, just after Mrs. Y. returned to work, she was dismissed from her job of 10 years. She received her last paycheck a few weeks ago, and said she cannot look for a new job until she finishes her court battle for child support. She fears her lack of skills will keep her from finding work in a bleak economy.
"I don't have any education to speak of, so I'm scared," she said. "The odds are really stacked against me."
Jonathan's future is equally uncertain. When he turns 18, Mrs. Y. will petition for guardianship, since he will never be able to live independently. He will attend a special school in Brooklyn until he is 21, but Mrs. Y. does not know what he will do as an adult.
"Jonathan is like a small child, and he can never be left alone," she said. "I will always have to watch out for him."
Mrs. Y. is hesitant to apply for public assistance because she does not want to risk losing her small row house, which she has lived in since Jonathan's birth. Relocating could have devastating consequences for Jonathan, she said. She hopes eventually to turn their house into a home for autistic teen-agers or adults.
"If there is one thing I have learned, it's that autistic people don't need institutions," she said. "They need a place that is warm and comforting, where they can live like everyone else."
Mrs. Y. has worked hard to provide that kind of place for Jonathan, and her efforts have been worth it. Their home, decorated with colored Christmas lights and pictures of Jonathan, is his sanctuary. As darkness fell on a recent evening, mother and son sat close together on their couch, one buoyant and talkative, the other stiff and impenetrable. Though few words were exchanged, their closeness was obvious.
"Through all of this, Jonathan has been my one companion," Mrs. Y. said, turning to gaze at her son's impassive countenance. "I need him as much as he needs me."

HEADLINE: Tsongas, Soured on Clinton, Looks to Powell

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas, Bill Clinton's most formidable rival in the Democratic Presidential primaries in 1992, has so soured on the President that he is strongly encouraging the notion of a third-party candidacy in 1996. And he says that Gen. Colin L. Powell might make the best candidate.
After months of refraining from any harsh criticism of Mr. Clinton, Mr. Tsongas has embarked on a personal campaign in which he argues that the President not only lacks moral conviction but is also pursuing irresponsible policies, like promises of tax cuts for the middle class. 
 "The President's biggest problem is a lack of moral authority," Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts, said in a telephone interview this week. "And if he had taken positions that were clearly principled and thusly could occupy the high ground against a Republican challenger, there would be a grudging respect that I think would serve him much better."
The 53-year-old Mr. Tsongas, who says he will not run for President in 1996, said the Democrats' lack of commitment to reducing the Federal deficit and the Republicans' embrace of a right-wing social agenda has left a political vacuum that cries out for a candidate of General Powell's character. He laid out arguments for a third party in a memorandum sent earlier this month to news organizations.
Mr. Tsongas said he had sent the memorandum to General Powell, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but had not spoken to him.
General Powell, who has not stated his party affiliation, is generally assumed to be a Republican because he has worked for Republican Presidents. He has not said whether he is interested in running for President in 1996, but he has not discouraged the speculation that he may run. He is immensely popular and has kept visible through frequent speaking appearances.
In a speech in Cleveland last month, General Powell said he was "developing a political philosophy." Fueling speculation that he would run as a third-party candidate, he said: "I think there is a possibility of a third party in '96. I think it would be wonderful."
Mr. Tsongas, who emphasized deficit reduction in the '92 primary campaign, said he was "horrified" by an assortment of middle-class tax cuts that Mr. Clinton proposed in a speech last week.
"The President's speech last Thursday was pretty much the end of the road for me in terms of not only the middle-class tax cut revisited by the specific reference to Social Security," he said. "I now see Bill Clinton as a direct threat to my children's generation."
Some White House officials dismiss Mr. Tsongas's comments as sanctimonious and say he is bitter over his defeat in 1992. Some Democrats accuse him of being disloyal.
"The notion that he is questioning the President's moral authority is like getting lectures on weight loss from Rush Limbaugh," said Paul Begala, a Presidential political adviser, who asserted that Mr. Tsongas misled voters about the state of his cancer in the primary campaign.
He also criticized the Tsongas campaign's proposals to cut the capital gains tax and entitlement programs like Social Security, saying: "Senator Tsongas has consistently opposed a Democratic Party built around middle class opportunities. It's no wonder the party rejected him."
But among many Democrats, Mr. Tsongas remains a respected political figure, and his comments are certain to add weight to the speculation about General Powell or a third-party challenge.
Opinion polls show voters are increasingly receptive to the idea of a third-party Presidential candidate. but there are enormous obstacles to such a candidate, not the least of which is the difficulty of getting public financing for his campaign.
Mr. Tsongas said he believed that General Powell has the moral authority that the President lacks.
"More than anything else, this country yearns for conviction," Mr. Tsongas said. "I meet people in my travels who have heard Powell speak. To listen to white middle-aged males talk about having been brought to tears by his unabashed, old-fashioned commitment to standards and values was surprising."
Mr. Tsongas said he would be unlikely to support Mr. Clinton in 1996 unless he abandoned his tax-cut proposals. He did not commit himself to General Powell, either, and said he could even end up backing a Republican. "I'd have to take a deep breath first," he said.
Mr. Tsongas had kind words for a fellow Massachusetts resident, Gov. William F. Weld, but said Mr. Weld's moderate stands on social issues would make him unpalatable to some of his fellow Republicans.
Mr. Tsongas also said he felt more comfortable with Republicans since he and former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican, formed the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan group devoted to eliminating the Federal deficit.
While he said he expected Ross Perot to run again in 1996 as an independent for President, Mr. Tsongas said there was "a glass ceiling on his potential for influence" after his poor performance in debating the North American Free Trade Agreement with Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Tsongas said he would have qualms about the social views of another Presidential prospect, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the incoming majority leader. "A Bob Dole has the courage on the economic side," he said, "but I would find it difficult to endorse someone who's not committed to social inclusion."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Braces for a Brave New World of Replacements

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The idea struck the general manager as absolutely ludicrous.
He was talking about replacement players, with whom major league owners are expected to try to stock their strikebound teams next spring, and he was asked how much clubs would have to pay them. 
 "I guess you'd have to offer them at least the minimum salary," said the general manager, who, like some others, spoke about the subject as long as he would not be named. "I really haven't given it much thought."
Well, he was asked, what would happen if three clubs sought the same replacement player? Would they get into a bidding war for him?
He paused for a second, then said, sounding a bit incredulous, "I never thought there'd be a bidding war on a replacement player."
Say hello to the bizarre new world of baseball. It's not the proposed new United League, but good old Major League Baseball, the folks who are mired in the longest strike in sports history and whose lineups of lawyers are becoming better known than their lineups of players.
Companies won't be printing collectible cards any time soon of Chuck O'Connor and Rob Manfred and Gene Orza and Lauren Rich, but they and their colleagues have been and will continue to be on television more often than Frank Thomas, Ken Griffey Jr. and Barry Bonds.
The coming confrontations before the National Labor Relations Board, in United States District Court and in the cloakrooms of Congress will be the focal point of the baseball world in coming weeks and months, but other matters soon will begin demanding attention.
Spring training, for example. And all the ramifications of that usually bucolic time of the calendar year and the sports schedule.
Only 53 days to pitchers' and catchers' reporting!
Somehow that cry clangs with a more dissonant tone than in other winters. Exactly which pitchers and catchers will they be? Will they be strike-breaking pitchers and catchers? Minor league pitchers and catchers? Over-the-hill pitchers and catchers? Park rats and sandlot kings?
They won't be Latin, Australian and Japanese pitchers and catchers because they won't be able to obtain visas to work in this country as long as they would be replacing striking pitchers and catchers.
But not so fast. Before the bizarre new world of baseball reaches that stage of what would then be a six-month-old strike, its leaders must make some decisions.
"Obviously, the clubs have said we want to have spring training," said Bud Selig, the acting commissioner. "There's no question we want to have spring training. Are there any specific plans, any master plan? No, there isn't. What form will it take? There is no master plan at this point. Will there be a season? Same thing."
But surely the owners didn't implement a salary cap simply as a testimonial to milliners. If they don't open camps and prepare to play the season, or at least try to play it, their action last Thursday night would be meaningless.
And if they open camps, they will need players to populate them so what about those replacement players, some of whom could trigger bidding wars?
"That's a subject that hasn't been discussed all along," Selig said. "That's not on the agenda to discuss at this point in time. I'm sure there are differing views, but we've had no formal or informal discussions."
Those deliberations, though, are coming to an operations committee meeting soon.
"We have to look at the format of the next 60-plus days and begin to understand what we have to do, obviously in uncharted waters," Selig said. "What we need is a 60- to 90-day schedule with all the ramifications very well thought out. That's something I'm sure we'll begin to look at next week and clearly after the first of year. We'll have something definitive early to mid-January."
While the owners study the immediate future on the field, representatives of striking players will scrutinize the new economic system -- the salary cap -- and other implemented elements of the new structure to determine if players should even sign contracts.
Union officials have advised players and agents to place a unilateral moratorium on signings until they can study all of the ramifications of the new system. If players do begin signing and the labor board or a court ultimately decides the salary cap was imposed improperly, they could reap a windfall of monetary damages as a remedy to the clubs' action.
Meanwhile, when they open spring camps, just about the time the N.L.R.B. could be issuing a complaint against the clubs based on the unfair labor practice charge the union will file Tuesday, owners will look for massive defections from striking players. But what they will probably need is a massive collection of replacement players. The general managers hope not.
"No general managers like the idea," one general manager said. "Myself included."
All of the general managers who were asked said they had not dwelled on the prospect of needing replacement players.
"We haven't gotten into it at all," said Lee Thomas of Philadelphia. "If I had to, I don't know how I'd do it. I haven't talked to many of the others about it. We haven't discussed it a whole lot. I don't think too many people feel good about it at all."
Herk Robinson of Kansas City said he didn't know if the recruitment of replacements would be feasible. "It's certainly not anybody's first choice, nor was the implementation," he added. "But certainly we'll abide by the direction of Major League Baseball and how they plan to go."
Another general manager speculated that when the time comes to seek replacements, clubs will look at old free-agent lists, the list of six-year minor league free agents and the telephone list of players who retired a year or two ago, voluntarily or otherwise.
"There might be some veteran players who see it as their last chance," he said. "They'd probably say: 'I don't have to worry about guys throwing at me. As soon as there's an agreement, I'll be released.' On other hand, a player might figure, 'If I show enough, I might be able to help the team. I'll gut it through for a year.' "
The prospect is not one managers eagerly await.
"I sympathized with all the N.F.L. coaches who went through the same type of thing," said Don Baylor of Colorado, referring to the 1987 season when National Football League teams used replacement players for three games. "Out of the replacement players, how many players are playing from that group -- a handful maybe. Football seems to have put that behind them as quickly as they could. What I look at is going into spring training with replacement players, and it's going to be a very difficult situation for everybody."
Bob Boone is the Royals' rookie manager, not far removed from playing himself.
"I think it's difficult, to say the least," the former catcher said of the use of replacements. "I don't think any of the things we're facing now as an industry are going to be easy. I don't know what the answers are right now. For me, it's too great to figure out. It's too great an exercise when there are too many intangibles. I don't have any control over any of it. Besides, I'd rather not think about it."
Baylor and Boone both were active in the union and in negotiations when they played. Now they, like other managers as well as coaches and trainers, face a dilemma. Those groups exist in a collective bargaining twilight zone. They are considered management, but they pay union dues so they can receive money from the union's product-licensing program.
Do they have a choice when camps open? One general manager, after all, said he heard that if they go into camp, they'll probably lose the licensing money. It comes to about $80,000 a year, less than a manager earns but slightly more than the average coach's salary and perhaps double a trainer's income.
The general manager noted that the union for some time has considered dropping those groups from the licensing program and this development could give them a ready reason for doing it.
"We are bound to manage," said Baylor, who was as loyal a union member as the union ever has had. "I believe the union understands that, that the manager and coaches don't have a choice in the matter. We have no vote whatsoever. We didn't take a strike vote. We pay our dues, but we're on the management side of it. It's a difficult position to be in when you have no vote."
Boone said there may have to be some soul-searching but added, "There's a lot of time. You don't have to think about it until you know what's really happening. But I don't think the union dues or the licensing is really a factor. The owner pays your salary so what are you going to do?"
Cam Bonifay, the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager, said that while he understood the managers' plight, he didn't see anyone staying home.
"I'm sure there will be some mixed feelings," he said, "but they know they're employees of the clubs and that speaks for itself."
Another general manager didn't want to discuss that situation or, frankly, any other. Capturing the tenor of the times, he said, "I don't want to talk because this is going to be in the courts."

HEADLINE: Dec. 18-24: True Nightmares;
A Firebomb Unnerves A City of Subway Riders

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
It is New York's worst nightmare: a mad bomber roaming the city's subways, where 3.5 million riders squeeze each day in democratic discomfort. Last week it happened. A sheet of flame erupted in a crowded No. 4 train at the Fulton Street station, and more than 40 people were injured in the fire and the frenzied rush to escape. Three were critically burned, including a man accused of being the bomber, Edward J. Leary. The police said the firebomb apparently went off as he was preparing to leave it on the train; escaping with his trouser legs shredded and burns on his legs, hands and face, he tapped a policeman on the shoulder at the Clark Street station in Brooklyn and politely asked for an ambulance.
 The life of this unemployed 49-year-old computer expert, who proclaimed his innocence, was littered with frustration. 
 Reporters interviewing the neighbors of suspects almost invariably are told about "such a quiet person." This time there were descriptions like "weird" and "berserk." In his suburban New Jersey home, law enforcement officials said, were mayonnaise jars, 9-volt batteries, kitchen timers and gasoline -- materials like those in last week's firebomb and a blaze in a subway car the week before that badly burned two teenagers. Rambling, angry, hand-scrawled notes with drawings of firebombs outlined a bizarre extortion scheme, the police said.
 Even with a suspect under arrest, the city remained nervous; calls to the bomb squad rose sharply. JOHN KIFNER

HEADLINE: How to Tell Health Care From Toothpaste

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "While Congress Remains Silent, Health Care Transforms Itself" (front page, Dec. 18) quotes Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a market analyst, who likens health care to products such as "hotel rooms and toothpaste and automobiles." Calling the growth of health maintenance organizations "the corporatization of health care," Mr. Abramowitz asks, "What's wrong with that?" As his own analogy suggests, a lot. 
 This corporatization is widely seen as a way to bring market efficiencies to health care. However, besides health care, there is no realm of the economy in which people buy products by paying an insurance premium. There is a good reason for this: an insurance company's primary interest -- profit -- is best served by minimizing payments to policyholders.
 No one would willingly cede the ability to rent the hotel room he or she wants or to buy the car or toothpaste he or she prefers to an insurance company or any third party. To the extent that health care is a product like any other, the interests of buyers are best served when they can make choices about what they buy and when. But health care is not a product like any other.
 Society expects a uniformly high standard of medical care to be available when it is needed. Doctors and hospitals may be criticized for failing to live up to this standard in every case, but their efforts to do so partly account for the high cost of health care today.
 The potential sacrifices of saving money on most products are not equivalent to those of saving on medical care. One may regret a sleepless night on a lumpy bed in a cheap hotel room, but it hardly compares with the risks of undergoing complicated surgery at the hands of a surgeon with no experience in the procedure.
 We must not accept glib analyses in the health care debate that ignore the highly specific challenges involved in providing first-rate medical care.
 
DOUGLAS G. COLE
Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 20, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Parallel Worlds Collide in Mt. Kisco

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO

 BODY:
ON a recent morning, a well-dressed woman stood at the counter of Starbucks, an upscale coffee bar here, choosing beans from Latin American countries. After some deliberation and a steaming cup of cappuccino, she bought a pound of Guatemala Antigua coffee for $9.25.
Two blocks down the same street, a group of men who also represent various Latin American countries stood against a fence, waiting to be picked up by construction and gardening trucks, which passed by looking for day laborers. On that day, three men -- also from Guatemala -- were chosen to work, at a rate of $6 an hour for an eight-hour day. 
 The parallel but contrasting scenes are representative of this changing northern Westchester town, where national chains like the Gap and Starbucks have opened stores and picked up a sagging commercial strip and where a rising tide of immigrants support a less visible -- and sometimes illegal -- economy. Hispanic immigrants are washing dishes in restaurants, cutting lawns and minding children.
But the two constituencies are colliding, and tensions have risen so much recently that Mayor Richard T. Roth established a task force, the Committee on Community Relations, to address residents' fears.
At the first meeting of the task force, many residents expressed ambivalence about Mount Kisco's newest inhabitants. On one hand, several bemoaned the exploitation of the immigrants by unscrupulous employers and landlords. On the other hand, many of the same residents complained about what they considered a declining quality of life in the village, citing incidents of public drunkenness, vandalism and crime.
Missing for the most part from the discussion were the more recently arrived Hispanic residents themselves, separated in large part by language and fear from the task force designed, in part, to improve their adaptation to the community.
The issue is not new to Mount Kisco nor the county. Mamaroneck, Yonkers, White Plains and Tarrytown have all seen an influx of Hispanic immigrants, along with resultant tensions. About 12 percent of Mount Kisco's population is from Latin America, according to the most recent United States census, up from 5 percent in 1980. What brought the issue to the forefront here was a letter published recently in The Patent Trader, the local newspaper, written by two long-time residents.
The residents, Linda Skiba and Beth Vetare Civitello, wrote: "The influx of illegal aliens is astounding. The problem of loitering in and around the downtown area has generated a feeling of discomfort so strong amongst taxpaying citizens that local businesses are suffering.
"The overwhelming amount of incidents that involve intoxicated persons should be alerting us to a major problem. Check the police records concerning arrests made involving Hispanics (for lack of a better term); undocumented or legal, either driving while intoxicated or throwing beer bottles or tearing street signs out of the ground or knifing one and another."
In closing their letter, Ms. Skiba and Mrs. Civitello, who also said that as women they felt unsafe walking past groups of Hispanic men, wrote, "We want our town back!"
The letter seemed to strike a nerve among residents, and letters flooded the newspaper, some commending the women's courage for putting into writing what had long been whispered about town, while others were appalled at what was described as the letter's ignorance and racism.
Mrs. Civitello acknowledged that she risked being labeled prejudiced but said in an interview that her letter had been misinterpreted. "There are people who agreed with our letter that totally misunderstood our point," she said. "I welcome new people, new cultures and new situations in town. Mount Kisco's diversity is one of the reasons we choose to live here. But I just want to make sure that everyone recognizes that if you choose to live here, like I've chosen to, you need to abide by the laws."
Other residents interpreted the comments differently.
"I was shocked by some of the statements being made by a variety of educated people," said Pedro Laureano, an academic adviser at Marist College in Poughkeepsie. "A lot of it is based on people's fear and internalized feelings, not on evidence.
"No one seems to be frightened by a large number of Latinos congregating in the kitchens of diners, or when five or six Latinos come to their house to mow their lawn or paint their house. But now it's a problem when they become part of your daily life, when they want to have a cappuccino in the mall? As a Latino foremost, hearing some of this was frightening."
Although the purpose of the first meeting of the Mayor's task force was to agree on a mission statement, the 12 panel members and about 30 members of the audience soon became entangled in discussing illegal immigration. Several residents said they wanted to know whether the committee intended to take steps to deport illegal aliens. Some comments echoed the sentiments codified in California's Proposition 187, which requires teachers and clinic doctors to deny help to undocumented aliens and report them to the police.
"People must be legal," said Annie Harper, owner of a real estate company. "I am a taxpayer, and I resent educating and feeding people that have no legal right to be in this country. I resent that they get free medical care while we have to pay. This is a question that has to be solved."
The Mayor and the Police Chief, Robert Martini, said they had in the past contacted the Immigration and Naturalization Service to little avail. They said immigration was a Federal, not a local, problem.
"If the borders aren't controllable in the United States, how am I suppose to control the borders of Mount Kisco?" Mr. Roth said.
What percentage of the population is illegal is not known. Betty Urrutia, president of Organizacion Hispana here, estimated that about half the Hispanic residents were legal. She said that 60 percent of the Hispanic residents are Guatemalan and most of them have work permits, having been granted political asylum. An additional 35 percent are Equadoreans, she said, and the remaining 5 percent are from a variety of Latin American countries.
Ms. Urrutia, a task-force member, spoke of hardships facing immigrants. She said she knew of several situations in which two-bedroom apartments were packed with 10 to 15 people, each charged rent of $200 a month. She also cited employers who hired immigrants without work permits, paid them for a week or two and then promised future wages. When the workers eventually asked for the back pay, Ms. Urrutia said, the employers demanded work permits and refused to make good on the wages.
"These people are very abused and they have to take it because they don't have a choice," Mrs. Urrutia said. "They come to this country because they need to support their families and feed their children. Many Americans feel very frustrated and very threatened, but they need to open their eyes with more compassion. We are just human beings."
The village of Mount Kisco has conducted housing raids in the past when they had reason to suspect overcrowding. One member of the audience asked why the Mayor could not conduct random sweeps of houses, to which Mr. Roth replied: "This is America. You need a search warrant."
Robert Knorr, a contractor and task-force member, described the group as a pre-disaster committee. "If we have seven or eight guys die in a fire, this committee would have a very different slant," he said.
The committee will continue to meet over the winter with subcommittees studying ordinances, housing, crime and economic and other issues.

HEADLINE: A Shelter When Feelings Halt Learning

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
A SECOND GRADER, three weeks into the school year, breaks down when confronted with a reading test. The next day he refuses to go to school. Even with the support of his teachers and the presence of his mother in an adjoining classroom, he breaks down.
A 14-year-old's disruptive behavior occurs so frequently that his teachers are forced to evict him from the classroom. Despite his high I.Q., he is attending school less and less and his learning is halted. 
 With the help of concerned parents and teachers, both youngsters were eventually enrolled in the special education program of the Putnam and Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services at the Learning Center at Walden in Yorktown Heights. Connie and James Keeler, parents of the second grader, said the move turned life around for their son, Kevin.
"After much testing, Kevin was diagnosed with an auditory processing problem, which meant that the traditional methods of teaching rendered him incapable of learning," Mrs. Keeler said. "It was extremely frustrating. When the Walden program was recommended to us, Kevin didn't want to even go on the bus. He had such a negative image of himself at school. However, once he started, he made the adjustment."
The whole environment at Walden, Mrs. Keeler said, "is so supportive and the academic demands on Kevin were reduced so that little by little, he began to react favorably."
The Board of Cooperative Educational Services is a pooling of resources that makes economic sense. It is a link between 18 school districts of northern Westchester and Putnam Counties that offers programs that would be too costly and fragmented for each district to handle alone. Individual districts take part on a cost-sharing basis. They are reimbursed by the state at 35 to 60 percent of what they spend for most services.
The Learning Center at Walden is a school for emotionally disabled children from kindergarten through 12th grade, said T. Mark Costello, the board's director of special education in northern Westchester and Putnam Counties. Currently, Walden's Learning Center has 130 students who get individual attention, counseling and support as they make academic progress.
"Our goal is to return our students at Walden to their home schools as soon as possible," Mr. Costello said. "It is in the regular, unsegregated environment that we believe youngsters learn the social skills that allow them to get along with other people in life."
Mr. Costello, who has been working in special education for 30 years, drew the blueprint for the concept of cooperative boards. In 1973, he wrote the law for special education in New York State.
"The law emphasizes that programs be designed to get kids back into the mainstream in the least restrictive environment as quickly as possible," he said. "And it is to that end that the efforts of the 275 people on the Walden staff are focused."
Classes at Walden are small: 8 to 10 students. "Instruction is given on a one-to-one basis," Mr. Costello said. "Each child has his or her own individual education plan that all the pupils, teachers and counselors and tutors work with. It's student needs that drive the program."
Mr. Keeler said: "The teachers at Walden are extraordinary. They were always available to us after school or on weekends. Whenever we had any sort of problem we could get counseling immediately."
As for Kevin's progress, Mrs. Keeler said: "It was a slow process. After Kevin was diagnosed, new methods were implemented to help him learn. Parallel techniques utilizing different parts of the brain in the thinking process helped him get eventually to the same place."
Kevin is now 10. "His one and a half years at Walden also improved his self-image to the point where now of his own accord he selected three after-school activities to participate in this semester," Mrs. Keeler said. "Spanish, junior naturalist and after-school sports. He was always good in math, but now his reading average is 2.5 on a 4-point scale, and what is so important is that he has a good opinion of himself. I can't praise the staff at Walden enough. We still go to the parent support meetings, and we're active at the school. We like to talk to parents who have had the same experiences as ours."
The capabilities of students at Walden vary, said David J. Zurhellen, supervisor of the program and principal of the Walden School. "Our students are emotionally disturbed, not mentally retarded," he said. "Their I.Q.'s range from low average to very high. But their disabilities make them incapable of benefiting from traditional teaching methods and the environment of the mainstream schools." Walden, he emphasized, is academically based. "Academics are very important here," he said. "The environment is always consistent so students know what to expect. Each has a counselor who works with him on his individual plan." The program, he said, is flexible, and changes are made according to need. When asked about the success rate, Mr. Zurhellen said: "It is high. On the average, only one student a year will fail to return to the home school."
As for cost, the estimate is that it costs $30,000 a student a year at Walden, compared with $12,000 at a mainstream school, said Mr. Zurhellen. He said that it is money well spent "if you look at the alternatives."
"Left alone, these are kids who would most likely drop out of school and become society's dependents for the rest of their lives," he added. "Walden is a turning-around point for them and helps them become productive members of society."
Jonathan Cummings, 17, now a senior at Lakeland High School, is looking forward to college next fall. But a few years back, when he was 14, he was so unhappy in school and his behavior was so disruptive, that he was constantly banned from the classroom.
"Jonathan didn't fit the mold," said his father, Ron Cummings. "He is very intelligent, outspoken and impatient. His behavior showed that there was obviously something wrong." In the ninth grade, Jonathan enrolled in the Walden program.
"I cannot speak highly enough about the school and the teachers," Mr. Cummings said. "They knew better than we did what Jonathan needed. His teacher, Jack Jones, was consistent, a disciplinarian and on duty 24 hours a day. Teachers at Walden don't stop when they leave school after class. Walden made the most tremendous difference in Jonathan's life."
As for Jonathan's reaction, he said: "I was very unhappy at my school. "I hated it. All I wanted to do was outsmart my teachers and act up. I didn't want to go to Walden either, but as it turned out, the experience I had there was the best 18 months of my life. My teacher, Jack Jones, turned me on to school. I look forward to it now and to college next year."

HEADLINE: Profile;
The Beard Is Real. The Joy Is Real. (Shhh: So Is He.)

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
IT's debated in every household. Various films grapple with the issue -- from "The Santa Clause" to "Miracle on 34th Street." It's clearly time to put this raging controversy to rest.
Yes, there is in fact a Santa Claus, though -- don't breathe a word! -- he sometimes goes by the name Brady White. (For simplicity's sake, and to avoid offending non-believers, we'll just call him Mr. White.) 
 Even without his Santa costume, Mr. White often has trouble passing for a civilian. Carolyn H. Cobb recalls seeing a boy spotting Mr. White at a Texas mall and saying, "Look, Mommy -- Santa's on vacation." Even in red shorts and a Hawaiian shirt, he was instantly recognizable.
"I don't think he's an impersonator," said Ms. Cobb, publicity manager for Neiman-Marcus, one of many stores that prize Mr. White's services. "I think he's Santa Claus. I send him my list every year."
He has, in his chosen field, all the right stuff -- the ruddy complexion, the 50-inch waistline, the chest-length ivory beard. On top of that, Mr. White has the sweet-tempered, comic disposition to somehow remain in character virtually every waking hour. Even in street clothes, he can hardly eat at a restaurant or walk through a hotel lobby without being interrupted, typically by an adult with a gift request.
All this has made him one of the nation's most sought-after Santas. Two weeks ago, the famed Beverly Hills Hotel made a last-minute request for a Christmas Eve appearance, but of course he was long since booked up. But he's busy the rest of the year, too: celebrity parties, gift shows in February, shooting catalogues in August, filming commercials any time.
So precious is his image that his beard is insured by Lloyd's of London -- for an amount in the six figures, which is as specific as he would get. "It's enough to take care of the reindeer," he said. Why insure it? Simple: "Going up and down all those chimneys, it could get singed."
Mr. White, once an unemployed actor from Rhode Island, now mixes with all manner of celebrities, from Pope John Paul II to Madonna. He has been photographed in the Swiss Alps and other North Pole-like locations in the company of beautiful models swathed in furs.
"I never, ever dreamed this would be my career," Mr. White said in an interview at the Bowers Museum here in Orange County, which is badly in need of Santa these days. His appearance here was one of the 18 he has made since Thanksgiving at charity events and client parties for his No. 1 client, the jeweler Cartier.
THIS Santa with a flair for promotion and a quick wit has a client list as long as a Christmas stocking.
His blue eyes twinkle in television ads for Cool Whip and the Postal Service. He gave life to "Santa Calls," a Christmas Eve adventure story by William Joyce put on at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York and broadcast to other stores. Clad in diving fins and red swimming trunks, he poised pool side at a Dallas hotel to introduce Neiman-Marcus's famed his-and-her Christmas gift.
But while glitz and glamour frame most of Mr. White's life, he says he is most gratified by bringing good cheer to the elderly, whom he finds to be particularly neglected during the holidays. He has first-hand experience. For three years, he spent a lot of time caring for his 82-year-old mother, who had Alzheimer's disease and died in September. He fits free visits to old-age homes and hospitals into his itinerary throughout the year, he said.
Clearly, Mr. White has found his calling. But "if this didn't happen to me," he said, "I don't know where I'd be."
Mr. White fits a classic entrepreneurial mold, said Jon P. Goodman, director of the University of Southern California's Entrepreneur Program -- the "wannabes who discover they can take a talent and turn it into money."
While there is little chance Santa will fall from popularity, Mr. White does face competitive risks and some unusual business pressures, Ms. Goodman said. But she did note that "he's got to spend a lot of effort maintaining his image and his connections."
With trappings like a red Mercedes with "SANTA" plates and a thick gold Cartier watch, Mr. White does generate some resentment, Ms. Goodman said. "Many of us are ambivalent about an economic system that rewards weirdos."
Like many entrepreneurs, Mr. White cashed in on serendipity. Twelve years ago, Mr. White was an out-of-work Los Angeles actor nine months behind on his rent. In desperation, he donned a red suit and phony beard for a Beverly Hills mall. He was discovered by The Herald Examiner, which polled children to find the best Santa in Los Angeles. The children chose him because, they said, he was unlike any other Santa because he was hip. He knew, for instance, the hot rock group of the day, Duran Duran.
A talent agent who came to the mall to see the top Santa in action suggested to Mr. White that he quit shaving. He did. By the next season, he was on his way to being the ultimate Santa, even starting to fill out his 34-inch waistline.
And taking home bigger paychecks. At the mall he got $4.50 an hour; it went to $5 after The Herald's page-1 story. Soon it took off into the heavens.
For his first big commercial job, for Neiman-Marcus's fur catalogue, he earned $4,000. It was shot in Munich's town square, where Mr. White, who is 6 foot 2, was mobbed by Japanese tourists and had to be rescued by a police car. It was Mr. White's first brush with celebrity, and he quickly got another when he was put up at the Hotel Kempinski and overheard Luciano Pavarotti practicing in a neighboring room.
He's showered with the perks of fame. "They make a deal, like I'm somebody," Mr. White said. "It's not Brady White. It's Santa who has all the free upgrades."
He can command $4,000 for an evening these days, but that once soared as high as $80,000 for six hours' work in a New York studio shooting a television commercial (he will not name the client). What kind of yearly pay does this add up to? He declined to say, except to remark, "It feeds the reindeer and the elves and keeps Santa in Cartier jewelry."
Mr. White is much in demand on the celebrity circuit, where he has earned the nickname "Santa to the Stars." During Pope John Paul's 1987 visit to Los Angeles, Mr. White was granted the security clearance to greet the Pontiff at a helicopter landing pad. "Santee, I like what you do for the children," the Pope told Mr. White. "He didn't sit on my lap." But then he added: "Madonna did. She asked to be a virgin. I told her Santa can't work miracles."
 Santa stays au courant. Mr. White does a holiday rap tune. He sings a "Jingle Bells" parody adored by children: "Jingle bells. Batman smells. Robin laid an egg. Batmobile lost a wheel, and Joker got away." He knows all about Power Rangers, Polly Pocket and American Girl dolls.
Not that he has to do research: he picks up news of the latest toy sensation from his lap. (City girls ask for Cartier diamonds; city boys ask for small-scale Ferraris.)
He has learned a few tricks of the trade. Mr. White, who declined to give his age but appears to be in his mid-40's, regularly gets a B-12 shot and flu vaccinations before Thanksgiving to head off the sneezing lot soon to be gazing up into his whiskered face. Also for health reasons, he wears white gloves on the job.
With children, as with Madonna, he is careful never to raise expectations. At the Bowers Museum, a pig-tailed girl in a red sweater asked him for a pet. Mr. White furrowed his white eyebrows and inclined his head while looking intently into her face. "A puppy might be kind of cold in the sleigh," he said. Crestfallen, her shoulders drooped. He leaned down and gave her a reassuring kiss on the cheek.
HE has 27 Santa suits -- made by Adele's of Hollywood and San Francisco's Bay Area Display -- acquired over the years to fit his clients' varied needs. There is motorcycle Santa, who wears custom-made Harley-Davidson boots. There is patriotic Santa, who looks a lot like Uncle Sam. There is Aloha Santa, in red flip-flops and a grass skirt.
During his visit here, Mr. White wore a traditional red velvet Santa suit embellished with a fancy Nordic twist. Besides rabbit fur trim, a braid of seed pearls and silver beads ran down the sleeves.
Mr. White, who is not married, grew up in Pawtucket, R.I. and briefly attended a seminary, Our Lady of Providence. After enrolling in a local junior college and a New York theater school, he headed West. He began making connections with celebrities while working at the Roxy, a Los Angeles night club. He did celebrity gossip on "AM Los Angeles," a local morning talk show.
Now, he said, about 25 percent of his time is spent pitching new clients or auditioning. Other clients have included gift shows, specialty Christmas boutiques and a mall developer that needed a Santa school for its malls.
It is easy to see why Mr. White is in demand. "If you book him at 9 he's ready to shoot at 9:10," said Guilio Ghiro, art director for the retailer Lord & Taylor, which featured Mr. White in its holiday "Tops" catalogue. "You don't even need makeup. He doesn't have to act. He personifies Santa."
"Other guys look the part but don't know what they are doing," said Elaine Rafferty, senior art director for the department store Macy's, which last year hired Mr. White for a print ad in which he held a camcorder. "He's like a professional model," she said, anticipating the pose and holding equipment so the brand name is revealed.
"There's no one I've ever seen that quite fits the part as he does," said Michael L. Campbell, promotions director for the mall owner New England Development Inc. of Boston. The company hired Mr. White to train St. Nicks for its malls in 1989.
In the classes, Mr. White revealed his own strategies for preserving Santa's image "that put children at ease and create magic for them," he said. For example, Santas never excuse themselves to go the restroom; breaks are needed to feed the reindeer. Santa always appears omniscient by learning a child's name beforehand through an assistant.
Mr. White plays favorites with early clients. His only mall appearance these days is in the Olde Mistick Village in Mystic, Conn., where he annually makes a two-day stop the day after Thanksgiving.
Nearly 300 children line up each day to see him. The wait can be 90 minutes. "He carries on a little conversation with each one," said Christine Robertson, the mall's office manager. "He winks at the moms," she said, and the children stroke his coat and beard.
After the last child has gone, Mr. White relaxes a bit, lighting a cigarette or name-dropping about his latest gig. "It's almost a letdown," Ms. Robertson said, chuckling at her own childlike impulse to believe in the holiday myth. "He's a very good actor."
But of course he isn't acting.
 
SANTA (A.K.A. BRADY WHITE)
 
Favorite on-duty dessert: Chocolate chip cookies without nuts.
 
 Favorite off-duty dessert: Chocolate souffle.
 
 Favorite on-duty drink: Milk.
 
 Favorite off-duty drink: Martinis, two olives and two onions.
 
 Favorite on-duty vehicle: Sleigh or black limousine.
 
 Favorite off-duty vehicle: Red Mercedes, license plate "SANTA."
 
 Favorite color: Red.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Termed Highly Unlikely For Westchester

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
A DAY after well-to-do Orange County in California filed for bankruptcy protection, Stephen V. Reitano, Westchester's Finance Commissioner, fired off a press release. From his offices in the county seat, Mr. Reitano said that what happened a continent away could never happen here.
 "Our investment policy has been and is purposefully conservative," Mr. Reitano said, adding that Westchester law allows only nonspeculative investments. 
By contrast, Orange County, which Mr. Reitano called "the Westchester of California" -- gambled public money on high-risk, rate-sensitive investments known as derivatives, and although it realized a higher rate of return for a time, in the end the county just south of Los Angeles County took a loss.
 The Dec. 6 announcement of bankruptcy marked the largest municipal failure of all time. It involved rated municipal bonds, which are generally considered one of the safest investments in the country.
 In Orange County officials borrowed for the short term at low interest rates in order to invest long term at higher rates. But when rates began rising sharply earlier this year, the county was forced to pay back the short-term debt at higher rates.
 Investments in derivatives -- whose value is based on or derived from an underlying asset, like a bond or a currency -- ultimately cost Orange County, the home of Disneyland and the California Angels, more than $2 billion on its $20 billion portfolio.
 By contrast, analysts in Manhattan say, Westchester's finances and its $336.8 million portfolio as of Nov. 30 come as close to being fail-safe as that of any municipality in the country. About $74.8 million is invested in fully collateralized certificates of deposit; $168.8 million is invested in repurchase agreements with primary dealers that are designated by the Federal Reserve, and $93.2 million is in Treasury bills and notes. Jim Lebenthal, chairman of Lebenthal & Company, a bond underwriter whose clients include Westchester, described the county as pristine.
 Once things began to go wrong in Orange County, some investment banks threatened to cut off its credit, and lenders demanded repayment of $1.2 billion in loans. Just before the county announced that it would file for bankruptcy, Robert L. Citron, the County Treasurer for 24 years, resigned. The bankruptcy has affected 187 school districts, cities and agencies that had millions of dollars invested in the county fund. They were caught short, unable to meet their bills because the county could no longer return principal or interest to the fund's participants. Some expenditures like highway construction may be placed on hold, and public schools and health clinics could run out of money for salaries.
 Orange County also defaulted on Series B pension-obligation bonds, although individual pensioners will not be affected, analysts said.
 It is unlikely that such a scenario could happen in Westchester, though. One reason is that separate municipalities do not contribute to Westchester's investment pool. In Orange County, the municipalities were required by law to do so. Also, the investment policy of Westchester, like other municipalities in the state, is governed by state law, which limits the types of investments that can be made and prohibits derivatives.
 Westchester is top rated AAA by major rating concerns, the only such rating in the state and one of fewer than a dozen nationwide. Nassau and Suffolk Counties, by comparison, are both rated by Moody's as Baa1, meaning they have medium-grade investments, neither highly protected nor poorly secured.
 AAA is "the best, with the smallest degree of investment risk," said Veronica L. Wheeler, manager of the public-rating desk of Moody's Investors Service. "It's gilt edged."
 Orange County was rated AA, but spokesmen for bond raters would not comment on why they failed to see that it was headed for trouble.
 "We were rating the quality of the bonds that the county issued, not its investment portfolio," said Karen Krop, an assistant vice president at Moody's. "We're not commenting on the financial management, and at this point, we're trying to avoid pointing fingers."
 Some officials who were interviewed blamed Mr. Citron, the Orange County Treasurer who advocated investments in derivatives.
 In Suffolk County, John C. Cochrane, the County Treasurer, said, "The bottom line is that we do not invest one penny in derivatives."
 Mr. Reitano said that Westchester's conservative approach notwithstanding, he remains vigilant -- especially in light of Orange County's failures. "You never know in this business," he said. "It is what Will Rogers used to say: 'It's not the return on my money that I worry about. It's the return of my money.' "
 He also said that while Orange County was probably realizing as much as 7 or 8 percent on its investments before short-term interest rates increased, Westchester earns only 4 or 5 percent.
 In a review of Westchester by Fitch Investors Service, the county was described as continuing "to possess the highest-quality credit. Financial performance remains strong, with good balances achieved to meet future needs and unexpected fluctuations in economically sensitive areas."
 Fitch said Westchester's strengths include its diverse and wealthy economic base, its modest debt levels and capital needs and its excellent financial management and planning procedures. Debt per capita is considered above average at $1,703, but the report said that was balanced by other factors -- namely a rapid rate of debt retirement.
 The report also says that despite the levels of poverty found in parts of Westchester, the county remains the second wealthiest per capita in the state --after New York County (Manhattan) -- and one of the richest in the country. At $34,843 in 1992, per capita personal income was 146 percent above the average for the state and 173 percent above the average for the United States.
 The county requires that its funds be placed in New York State-approved investments only, like United States treasury bills, bonds and notes, or in debt obligations of New York State or its municipalities.
 The county has issued $50,967,401.80 in bonds this year, which will pay 4.75 percent on a maturity date of Nov. 15, 1995, and 6.35 percent in 2009 for its general-obligation current-interest bonds. The issue is being used to finance several projects, including modernization of the terminal at the County Airport, equipment for the County Medical Center and reconstruction of parts of the Bronx River Parkway.
 Mr. Reitano said Westchester employs a pooled investment strategy, using various sources of county money to obtain an optimally high interest rate. "My job is making sure the money is in the right place at the right time," he said. "I don't want it sitting around idly."
 William R. Howell, a managing director at Prudential Securities, which markets bonds for the county, described Westchester as being in "the most conservative client" category.
 "Even if they were less conservative, they would still be safe," he said.
