HEADLINE: At Soup Kitchens, Demand Rises, But Supplies and Funds Are Low

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY 

 BODY:
OFFICIALS at nonprofit organizations that care for the poor say they are having a hard time keeping pace with the demand for food this winter. A Federal emergency food program has been drastically cut, and holiday donations of food and money are somewhat down from last year. At the same time, requests for perishable and nonperishable food items are up substantially.
Several organizations say the new demand is coming from pockets of rural as well as urban poverty. Most of the increase, said Pattie Apgar, director of the Northwest Community Action Program in Phillipsburg, consists of "working people who either don't have a job or have one that pays them minimum wage -- people who never imagined they would need a service like ours." 
 Ms. Apgar, whose food bank is the major supplier for the poor in Warren, Hunterdon and Sussex Counties, added, "We have never had so little food available in our warehouse."
Kathleen Di Chiara, director of the Hillside-based Community Food Bank of New Jersey, which supplies 1,200 charitable organizations, said: "There are a lot of people in the state who have not been touched by the economic recovery yet. And there is less cash among groups fighting hunger and homelessness because corporate giving and government grants are down. The thing that we have been hearing from emergency food pantries is that they are afraid of having to turn people away."
In Bergen County, the pinch is being felt by the Inter-Religious Fellowship for the Homeless, which is made up of 240 congregations. "They are all hurting and have had to cut back on their budgets," said Kathleen J. Stanton, director of the fellowship, which, in conjunction with the Community Action Program of Hackensack, provides meals for hundreds of people each day at shelters and a soup kitchen in Hackensack.
An estimated total of 750,000 residents live below the poverty level, and meals are served at some 100 soup kitchens in the state. About 900 food pantries are operating in church and synagogue basements and at other sites, and many individual churches and small charities also regularly feed the poor.
The United States Department of Agriculture's Emergency Food Assistance Program has been a long-standing supplier of protein-rich foodstuffs like cheese, butter, peanut butter and canned meats.
But last September the program's national food-specific financing was reduced by Congress from $80 million to $25 million, and as a result New Jersey is receiving only 20 percent of the high-protein items it received last year, said Ms. Di Chiara of the Food Bank.
"This cutback has put a lot of pressure on private agencies such as ours to make up the difference," said Evelyn Benton, director of the Food Bank's office in Pleasantville, which serves Atlantic City. But donations to the food banks are down 11 percent from last year, she said.
Liz Thomases, director of volunteer services at Food Bank headquarters in Hillside, said that a special public plea for 4,000 turkeys last month fell short by 1,500.
The Community Food Bank of New Jersey is a branch of the Chicago-based Second Harvest, a private, nationwide nonprofit group. Last year, the New Jersey operation received $1 million from the sale of its food at 14 cents per pound. Another $1 million was raised through financial contributions.
A spokesman at the Salvation Army's state headquarters in Union, Spencer Scott, said that food supplies at the organization's 24 centers were adequate to meet the demands of Christmas but would be depleted this week because of increasing demand. "Need knows no season, and Christmas is just when we start to get busy," Mr. Scott said.
Despite the shortages, the work goes on. In Hackensack, for example, 5,000 soup kitchen and shelter volunteers are serving the city's 4,300 homeless. But as in much of the state, the homeless are not the majority of the soup kitchen population. Working poor and single parents with children have become regulars, officials in Hackensack said.
In Vineland, a city surrounded by rich farmlands, four soup kitchens have been opened since 1991 by Spirit and Truth Ministries, a multidenominational urban ministry that serves the poor. The kitchens operate at a different host church from Monday to Thursday, and the guests include migrant farm workers.
Rich McGlynn, the founder and director of the ministries, said contributions to his group had declined this year. As a result, plans for a fifth soup kitchen to better serve the city's large Spanish-speaking population have been held up since last spring.
Diane Carl, Spirit and Truth's soup kitchen administrator, said a 22 percent increase in attendance during the last fiscal year, ending Oct. 1, had put a strain on the ministry, which also experienced a decline of up to 50 percent in some of its larger private contributions.
"Only 37 percent of what it takes to run the four kitchens comes from the Federal Emergency Management Agency," Ms. Carl said. In the last year, she added, "we served 12,850 meals, helped clothe hundreds of destitute people and transported others to shelters and places like drug and alcohol detox centers -- all for a grand total of $27,100."
In Newark, recovering destitute alcoholics from a Salvation Army rehabilitation center are riding at night with canteen truck volunteers to point out the remote hideouts of the homeless. Some 300 to 400 homeless people are being fed each night from the Army's mobile canteen.
"We have noticed that when the weather is cold, few of the homeless are on the streets," said Capt. Raphael Jackson, head of the Army's Newark district. "But when the canteen truck stops at the right place on the west side, or down by Penn Station, it is mobbed by people coming out of abandoned apartment buildings and factories."
Sometimes, Captain Jackson said, "the men on the truck, who are only one step away from homelessness themselves, can encourage their old friends to come out of the cold and get help."
In addition to several thousand dollars from an annual Federal Emergency Management grant and $50,000 from its own budget, the meals in Newark require donations, which Captain Jackson said "are requiring more legwork this year."
Brenda Beavers, director of social services for the Salvation Army's New Jersey operations, said that regular stationary feeding sites operated by the organization were in Elizabeth, Plainfield, Montclair, Passaic, Hackensack and Dover. A special feeding program for the elderly is sponsored by the Salvation Army in Camden, she said.
Many of the poor and homeless in Hackensack are being fed at a soup kitchen operated by the Inter-Religious Fellowship for the Homeless. Dorothy Marcus, the feeding program coordinator, said volunteers from various faiths take turns cooking dinner and breakfast at the individual churches, then deliver the meals to the feeding site at 214 State Street, operated by the local Community Action Program, a nonprofit group that exists on government funds and private donations.
Breakfast and dinner are served at the soup kitchen seven days a week to more than 200 people each day. Meals for an additional 100 homeless and transitional homeless in the Fellowship's shelters are also prepared daily. The fellowship's entire program is run with three paid staff members on a $200,000 annual budget, which does not include about $600,000 worth of food donations and volunteer hours.
 
'People Accepted Me'
IN a Spirit and Truth soup kitchen in Vineland recently, Glenn Mancini, 40, reminisced about his reliance on soup kitchens all over the state, and the changes they have made in his life.
Originally from Passaic County, Mr. Mancini said he had "done time" in county prisons in Passaic and Cumberland Counties for minor theft and fraud offenses stemming from a 15-year addiction to heroin and cocaine.
His life began to turn around a year ago, he said, when he was released from the Cumberland County jail and began frequenting the feeding programs. He also often volunteers to help at the soup kitchen.
"People there accepted me, prayed for me and called me brother," he said. "They helped me find a place to live and took me to doctor appointments and church. What made the difference was God and the love and nurturing I got."
Mr. Mancini said that he had been free of his addiction for about a year and that he has seen others come from jail and other tough circumstances receive the encouragement they needed at the soup kitchens.
He is now employed in the construction business and lives at a private halfway house.

GRAPHIC: Photos: More and more people are using soup kitchens, like that above in Hackensack, but supplies of food are at a low ebb. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times) (pg. 1); Hungry people lining up at the soup kitchen on State Street in Hackensack. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times) (pg. 11)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
 
The many predictions of a strong holiday shopping season were apparently wishful thinking for many retailers, particularly in apparel. Early indications are that the season's sales, while better than last year's, have not been what the retailers hoped for. Many shoppers held off until just before Christmas, forcing merchants to cut prices. The extent of the markdowns implied a desperation not seen since the low points of the recent recession. [Page 1.]
 

Trying to reduce the temptation for employees to take bribes, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has decided to stop issuing work cards in district offices, instead mailing them to immigrants from one or two central offices. Because the cards can be used to obtain driver's licenses, Social Security cards and other documents used to demonstrate citizenship, they can be valuable items on the black market. [12.]
 
International
 
After losing billions of dollars in Mexico last week, investors asked if the peso devaluation would set off a series of damaging devaluations throughout Latin America. The short-term answer appears to be no, even in Brazil and Argentina, which are thought to have overvalued currencies. [55.]
 
The steep decline in the value of the peso has resulted in a potential loss of roughly $8 to $10 billion for American investors in Mexican stocks and bonds, Wall Street experts estimated. American owners of Mexican stocks took the biggest hit, suffering both the devaluation's effect and from falling stock prices. [55.]
 
The collapse of China's bid to join the World Trade Organization suggests that the country's Communist Party leaders might not have given trade negotiators the authority to compromise. Some Western diplomats saw a strong resemblance between China's approach to the talks and its successful strategy last spring to persuade President Clinton to put trade with China ahead of U.S. concerns about the nation's human rights record. [55.]
 
Japan's electronics industry, creeping back from a long slump, has registered an increase in production in 1994 for the first time in three years. But the gain resulted mainly from strong shipments to the United States and Asia of computer parts, not a surge in demand for consumer electronics. Production of consumer-electronics equipment in Japan fell nearly 9.7 percent. [55.]
 
The Media Business
 
This holiday season, "A Christmas Carol," the newest challenger to the Radio City Music Hall's Christmas show, has been drawing big audiences to the Paramount auditorium at Madison Square Garden. But the production is expected to lose money unless it can win acceptance as a New York holiday perennial. [55.]
 
James Warren, The Chicago Tribune's new bureau chief in Washington, has won few fans among journalists working there. Small wonder: His columns rail about "the ethical cesspool of Washington journalism," describing what he believes to be the spoiled-brat nature of some star news professionals. [57.]
 
The hottest cover face this month belongs not to a model, nor a youngster, but to a 70-year-old superstar -- Paul Newman. And the runner-up in popularity seems to be a 74-year-old, Pope John Paul II. Deirdre Carmody: Magazines. [57.]
 
Once upon a time, there was a Salt Lake City advertising man who decided to write a story for his two daughters. On Sunday, "The Christmas Box" will appear in the No. 2 position on The New York Times paperback best-seller list. [57.]
 
Today's Column
 
A computerized food-preparation device looks ahead to futuristic meal-making machines not too far removed from the type that Jane Jetson might use. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [56.]

HEADLINE: Mexican Shock, but Latin Optimism

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 25

 BODY:
In 1982, Mexico failed to honor its foreign debt payments, setting off a traumatic series of Latin American defaults that caused the 1980's to be called the region's "lost decade."
Last week, investors asked if Mexico's peso devaluation, which exceeded 28 percent before the currency rebounded slightly on Friday, would lead to a damaging series of devaluations throughout Latin America, now the world's second-fastest-growing regional economy after Asia. 
 The short-term answer is no.
"This Mexican shock will not take the region with it as it did in 1992," said Miguel Angel Broda, an Argentine economist, on Friday. "This earthquake will be slowly overcome. Sophisticated investors are learning to see the differences between Argentina and Mexico."
The markets appeared to agree. Latin America's major stock exchanges, after faltering badly during the week, rebounded Friday -- led by a 3 percent jump at the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, the region's largest. In New York, traders pushed up the prices of all Latin American debt, except for Mexico's. And of the 40 Latin stocks whose American depository receipts are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, 25 rose in value, 8 fell and 7 were unchanged.
"By now, financial experts have learned that there is significant diversity throughout Latin America," said Sebastian Edwards, the World Bank's chief economist for the region. "People have to avoid the herd instinct that was very damaging in 1982. There is not really a solid reason to sell off in one country because of what happens in another country."
But after losing billions of dollars in Mexico last week, investors are indeed looking with a more skeptical eye at two other Latin giants thought to have overvalued currencies -- Brazil and Argentina. In both countries, exporters are putting pressure on the governments to devalue their currencies to more internationally competitive levels.
The Mexican peso had been severely undermined by a record trade deficit for 1994 approaching $30 million. With imports flooding into the country, Mexico's foreign-currency reserves plummeted this year from $25 billion to $6.5 billion, barely enough to cover two months of imports. Brazil, by contrast, has $43 billion in reserves and a $11.5 billion trade surplus.
"Any parallel with the Brazilian situation would be completely groundless," Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's leading financial newspaper, wrote on Friday in an editorial titled, "The Mexican Lesson."
Argentina, more vulnerable, has $17 billion in reserves and a $6 billion trade deficit. Measured against the gross national product, Argentina's budget deficit is about one-third the size of Mexico's.
Two factors stand against an immediate devaluation of the Argentine peso, which is linked by law to the United States dollar. For President Carlos Saul Menem, who is campaigning for re-election in May, it would be political suicide to tinker with the exchange rate, a cornerstone of his inflation policy. In addition, the exchange rate can only be changed by a vote in Congress, a long and inevitably noisy process that would give foreign investors plenty of time to pull out of the Buenos Aires stock market.
On Thursday, Mr, Menem and his Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, held a televised news conference to underline their determination to stick to their foreign-exchange policy. "We are not Mexico and we will not devalue -- Argentina will not alter its course," vowed Mr. Menem, who had radically slashed Argentina's budget deficit after becoming President in 1989. "There will not a devaluation. Totally to the contrary -- we are going to deepen the adjustment measures."
In Brazil, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who is to be inaugurated as President on Jan. 1, met with his economic team and said, "In Brazil, there is no hypothesis that calls for a currency devaluation."
Both leaders said they planned to use "Mexico's warning" as a club to demand legislative support next year for budget austerity.
For Brazil to reach Mr. Cardoso's 1995 goals of 5 percent growth and 25 percent inflation, down from about 50 percent now, he will need cooperation from Congress to slash state spending and encourage more investment from abroad. With imports surging into Brazil, the trade surplus is expected to drop in half next year, pushing the nation's current-account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, from $1 billion this year to $10 billion in 1995. In November, Brazil recorded its first monthly trade deficit in seven years.
"A yellow light has switched on, warning Brazil that it cannot go from mega-surpluses to mega-deficits in trade," said Carlos Langoni, a former president of the nation's central bank. "The great Mexican lesson is the importance of maintaining reasonably balanced trade over the next few years."
For foreign investors, the Mexican devaluation also offers a reminder of the risks of emerging markets and of the propensity of politicians to betray their promises. "Mexico's officials were perceived as the most credible in Latin America," Lars Schonander, Latin American economist for Baring Securities in New York, said. "Their word was good. Now their word is not good. Where does that leave Brazil, a country with an appalling record of economic plans going up in flames?"
Seeking lessons on Latin America from Mexico, analysts also look at issues of political stability.
In the last year, Mexico has undergone a guerrilla revolt in Chiapas state and the assassinations of the ruling party's president and presidential candidate. But of the region's other leading countries, political instability seems only to threaten Venezuela, a nation with a shrinking economy and jumping inflation.
In the next six months, voters in Peru and Argentina are expected to re-elect Presidents who have put their nation's economies on high-growth, low-inflation tracks. Earlier this year, Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle, a free-market politician, was inaugurated as President in Chile, a country that is turning last year's trade deficit into a surplus this year.
Mr. Cardoso is to take office as Brazil's first President in recent times with a Congressional majority and the support of virtually all major state governors.
Last week, some Latin America fund managers in the United States sold Brazil positions to cover Mexico losses, in order to record year-end profits. But even as Mexico's market slipped, many analysts in Sao Paulo, Brazil's financial center, remained bullish about prospects there.
"Bad for Mexico -- Good for Brazil," was the headline on an article Friday in Gazeta Mercantil. The article listed foreign investment houses -- including Salomon Brothers, Smith Barney and CS First Boston -- that recommended that their clients increase Brazil portfolios and reduce their holdings in Mexico.
With Mr. Cardoso regarded as likely to accelerate the sale of state companies, stocks in Sao Paulo are expected to rebound in January.
"Brazil's fundamentals have not been changed by Mexico, so it's a good time to buy," said Wayne A. Perkins, director of equity investments for Chemical Bank's affiliate in Sao Paulo. "Everyone is closing their year-end books now. The inflow of foreign investment will start early in the first quarter."
